In his 1999 publication, The Disciplined Mind: What All Students Should Understand, Gardner applied his Multiple Intelligences Theory to an educational framework for facilitating understanding. Gardner’s work on cognition and pedagogy has been successfully applied in many disciplines, and the present treatise aims to utilize this framework to create and label a variety of approaches to fundamental tuba pedagogy and inspire others to do the same in this and other contexts. In the pages below, the reader can expect to learn about the tenets and justification of Gardner’s Theory of Multiple Intelligences, his framework of teaching for understanding, and be introduced to different methods of teaching the fundamentals of breathing, sound production, intonation, range, dynamics, and articulation in tuba pedagogy from the lens of Gardner’s framework of teaching for understanding and his Theory of Multiple Intelligences. This research can be expanded into other concepts within tuba pedagogy, and the contents herein may prove useful to teachers seeking to diversify their teaching.

DISS_description.DISS_title: An investigation of music therapists' perceptions and practice for persons with diabetes mellitus

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to assess music therapists’ knowledge of music therapy research for treatment for persons with diabetes mellitus (DM). Participants (N = 236) for this study were music therapists who were members of the Certification Board of Music Therapists. Participants were emailed a link to an online survey and results were sent to the researcher after completion. Results indicated a significant difference between how well music therapists who are working with persons with DM know music therapy research for treatment of DM (M = 1.1, SD = 0.30) compared to music therapists not working with persons with DM (M = 1.47, SD = 0.76), t (167) = 4.14, p < .05, d = 0.64. There was also a significant difference regarding how comfortable music therapists felt working with persons with DM (M = 3.8, SD = 1.13) compared to their wiliness to work with persons with DM (M = 4.4, SD = 0.92), t (364) = -4.75, p < .05, d = 0.49. Results suggest that, while music therapists working with persons with DM know music therapy research better than those not working with persons with DM, they still do not know music therapy research well. Music therapists are, however, comfortable, and very willing to work with persons with DM.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A Simplified Dynamical Framework for the Great Plains Nocturnal Low-Level Jet and Its Impact on Storm-Relative Helicity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: A simplified model of the Great Plains Nocturnal Low-level Jet (NLLJ) is formulated to include the classical inertial oscillation (Blackadar) and baroclinic (Holton) mechanisms. Time and height dependent solutions are analytically obtained with and without baroclinic forcing. Solutions are shown to be consistent with results from previous literature and observations. A novel application of this model is that it is applied to evaluate the temporal evolution of storm-relative helicity (SRH) overnight. That is, the NLLJ evolution is analytically linked to SRH_{0-1 km} to gauge its impact on magnitudes of environmental shear favorable for supercells and tornadoes. It is found that the NLLJ can contribute to sustaining SRH_{0-1 km} > 100 m^2 / s^2 for more than eight hours of the nocturnal period, provided there is sufficient baroclinic forcing to drive stronger amplitude oscillations of the winds.

DISS_description.DISS_title: STRUCTURE, DYNAMICS, RHEOLOGY, AND CHAR YIELD OF PRECERAMIC SYSTEMS: PRECERAMIC POLYMER GRAFTED NANOPARTICLES SUSPENDED IN PRECERAMIC POLYMERS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Preceramic polymers (PCPs) offer advantages in producing ceramics due to their processability and ability to tailor their chemical structure. However, challenges such as volume shrinkage and mass loss during pyrolysis often result in pores and cracks. PCP-grafted ceramic nanoparticles (PCPGNP) have been proposed and studied as a solution to volume shrinkage and mass loss problems. PCPGNPs also help to reduce aggregation and to control the nanoparticle arrangement. The neat state of these PCPGNPs has been characterized with respect to thermal properties and rheology. Dispersing PCPGNPs in commercial preceramic polymer matrices is another attractive, but unexplored, route to control the rheological and char yield properties of the matrices. In this work, a systematic rheological study of well-defined mixtures of a commercial PCP, SMP-877, and PCPGNPs (silica with poly(1,1-dimethylpropylsilane) corona) was executed to develop design rules for the processing of such mixtures. A rheological study demonstrated the effect of increasing particle concentration on network formation with percolation occurring between 50-60 wt%. Samples above the percolation threshold also exhibited higher viscosities and rapid shear thinning thus demonstrating their printability. X-ray photon correlation spectroscopy (XPCS) corroborated the rheology and showed two diffusive modes when the material was above percolation. Mixtures of PCPGNPS and SMP-877 had synergistically higher char yields upon thermal treatment and pyrolysis. XPCS and rheological measurements during thermal treatment identified thermal jamming of the polymer grafts as a key factor in improving the char yield. With the insights gained here we expect these mixed systems to provide advanced inks for additive manufacturing of ceramics for aerospace applications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: WORKING TO GET ‘WOKE’ THREE ESSAYS ON ORGANIZATIONAL EFFORTS TO IMPROVE CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, GENDER EQUITY AND DIVERSITY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Through three independent essays, this manuscript addresses improving civic engagement, gender equity, and diversity within organizations through three unique lenses. The first paper explores the experiences of participants from a national leadership training organization providing the type of training and network building connections that those who are typically removed from the privilege to power pipeline fail to access. Ensuring a diverse workforce is often listed as an organizational goal or achievement, but aside from being understudied, it is also not utilized to its max capacity for organizational performance. Developing human capital among a diverse workforce remains critical for a representative and responsive public service, yet evidence-based recommendations for public training and development programs remain understudied. The second paper is based on a mixed methods gender equity study of a large police department and highlights opportunities for continued growth and improvement to allow masculine organizations to attempt to reach gender parity among their workforce and subsequently, their workforce’s interactions with the residents they serve. The third paper is an exploratory descriptive case study investigating how an advocacy group, a public sector union, can influence voter turnout and voter registration and contribute to an uptick in civic engagement through voting. Implications for future coalition building and the need to expand future literature to study public sector labor unions in the field of public administration beyond focusing on collective bargaining activities.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE EFFECTS OF THE FIRST LANGUAGE ON THE SECOND: A PSYCHOLINGUISTIC INVESTIGATION OF BILINGUAL LEXICAL PROCESSING AND FIRST LANGUAGE ATTRITION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: bilingualism, cross linguistic interference, first language attrition, language contact, psycholinguistics, second language acquisition

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Research on language and cognitive processes in bilinguals over the past few decades has underscored the activation of words in the first language (L1) during comprehension and production of the second language (L2) (e.g., Dijkstra, Van Jaarsveld, & Ten Brinke, 1998; Van Heuven, Dijkstra, & Grainger, 1998; Hermans, Bongaerts, De Bot, & Schreuder, 1998;Lemhöfer, et al., 2008). This activation extends bidirectionally, with words from the L2 also influencing the processing of the L1 (e.g., Van Hell & De Groot, 2008; Linck, Kroll, & Sunderman, 2009; Schmid & Jarvis, 2014; Schmid & Keijzer, 2009), leading to cross-linguistic interference (CLI) in bilinguals’ language processing. However, the nature and extent of this interference may vary depending on the bilingual’s dominant language and immersion context. L1-dominant bilinguals may struggle to control interference from their L1s, while the opposite may hold true for L2-dominant bilinguals, even when their L2 is not their native language. Consequently, the formerly dominant L1 of some bilinguals may exhibit signs of attrition. This dissertation explores the relationship between attrition and L2 acquisition, addressing two key questions: (1) to what extent does context (place of residence) and nature of bilingualism influences the amount and direction of cross-language interference? and (2) to what extent (if any) is the activation of form and meaning modulated by the nature of the lexical relationships and individual differences measures? And, if effects are found, how does sentence context modulate those effects? The contribution of this study stems from the novel examination of two types of semantic extensions: a) new meanings or words that share form but do not share any semantic relationship across languages; and b) extended meanings or words that share form and at least one semantic sense across languages. Additionally, synonyms, unrelated words, cognates, interlingual homographs and translation pairs are also included to explore form-meaning interactions. The comprehension of words with varying degrees of form-meaning relatedness is evaluated in two tasks: (1) a semantic-relatedness decision task (SRDT) within and across languages and (2) a self-paced reading task (SPR). Sentence cues in unilingual language contexts are manipulated in congruent and incongruent conditions to assess interference effects. Participants also complete a flanker task as a measure of cognitive control and a battery of proficiency measures. These tasks are implemented across five participant groups: Page 12 of 308 (1) monolingual speakers of English in the U.S, (2) monolingual Spanish speakers in Argentina, (3) L1 Spanish-L2 English bilinguals in the USA, (4), L1 Spanish-L2 English bilinguals in Argentina and (5) L1 English- L2 Spanish learners in the USA. Results from this study indicate that immersion context influences the direction of language interference, with more L2 to L1 effects observed for immersed bilinguals compared to non-immersed counterparts, and with both groups being vulnerable to CLI effects compared to monolinguals. Despite extended exposure in an L2 dominant context, bilinguals can maintain their L1 proficiency, contradicting L1 attrition views. The activation of form-meaning relationships is directly related to the nature of the lexical relationships, with orthographically and semantically related words (e.g., cognates; extended meanings) showing processing advantages over orthographically related but semantically unrelated words across languages (e.g., false friends, new meanings). Within-language semantic competitors cause more interference during processing compared to unrelated words. Inhibitory control mechanisms or language dominance do not significantly attenuate CLI effects from form-meaning competitors in the non-target language. Results from the SPR revealed that sentence context can modulate interference effects, facilitating the resolution of lexical ambiguities and form-meaning relationships. However, language cues from a sentence alone are not sufficient to constrain CL competition, highlighting the importance of semantic information conveyed by the sentence context for language non-selectivity to occur. Overall, bilingual characteristics, including the type of bilingual, linguistic exposure/experience and levels of L1-L2 proficiency all seem to influence language processing. This dissertation contributes to the field of psycholinguistics of bilingualism, language attrition and second language acquisition. It highlights the importance of understanding language-attrition as a bridge between first- and second-language lexical processing.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Mixed Methods Analysis of "Under What Conditions" Modified Schema Based Instruction "Works"

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Developmental disability, Evidence-based practice, Intellectual disability, Mathematics, Mixed methods, Personal finance

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this dissertation was to extend the literature base for teaching students with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) mathematics and self-determination skills using an evidence-based practice called modified schema-based instruction (MSBI). Chapter one provides the rationale for teaching both mathematics and self-determination skills to students with IDD, highlighting the correlation between both skill sets and positive post-secondary outcomes. This chapter presents the rationale for conducting this dissertation, which extends from prior MSBI research and is grounded in educational theory. To answer the five proposed research questions, this dissertation uses a mixed methods embedded experimental design. This dissertation follows mixed methods publishing recommendations by presenting the findings across multiple manuscripts (i.e., chapters). Chapter two presents the findings from the quantitative single-case design exploring the effects of teacher- and paraprofessional-delivered MSBI targeting personal finance mathematics word problems by students with IDD in a small group setting. Results indicate a functional relation and strong effect sizes between MSBI and learned mathematics skills of students with IDD, further adding to the extant literature base of positive student outcomes produced during MSBI instruction. Chapter three presents the findings from the integrated mixed methods results exploring how, why, and under what conditions MSBI works for teaching mathematics to students with IDD through a rigorous evaluation of fidelity of implementation. Findings provide important contextual information for how differentiated instructional delivery of MSBI can impact student outcomes; additionally, results identified six influences impacting instructional delivery and student outcomes, adding novel information for under what conditions MSBI is effective in teaching mathematics to students with IDD.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Looking Inward: Identifying the Local within the Global in Late Fifteenth-Century Sevillian Artworks

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Iberian city of Seville offers a case study of motif and iconographic transference in the late Middle Ages and Early Modern era. Previous scholars have addressed the idea of transference through a formal lens without consideration for the cultural and historical contexts that surround it, and have previously noted, though rarely explicated, a Sevillian school of painting. The limited foundational studies on late fifteenth- and early sixteenth-century artworks in Seville, most published in the early twentieth century, focus on stylistic categorization and the indiscriminate application of terms such as Hispano-Flemish and mudéjar. My dissertation nuances these terms through an investigation of the artworks’ place and development in a Sevillian context, specifically parsing local and global stylistic and iconographic influences apparent in the works. My work addresses the local outside of the simple framework of mudéjar, the stylistic qualification meant to designate ornamentation, architecture, and motifs showing Islamic stylistic influence but created within a Christian Iberian context.

A close study of how prints and printing in general functioned in Seville and Granada clarifies how iconographies were transferred across media as well as how specific motifs were deployed in efforts to convert Muslims and Jews. While many prints do not survive, my dissertation reconstructs how they were employed by the citizens of Seville. The function and purpose of prints varied significantly: many were kept in the home and used for personal devotion by so-called Old Christians; they were distributed to non-Christians and new converts, and helped to prevent accusations of apostasy; and they served as models for painted and carved panel compositions. Additionally, terminology like “mudéjar” does not work for a Sevillian context where Islamic decorative motifs were strongly connected to the culture and history of the city. Tracking how, when, and why these motifs were copied and transferred sheds light on the global function of Iberian artworks and provides insight into how these methods operated more broadly. My research highlights connectivity and diversity in a way that impacts current studies and modern understandings of how we can define globality in the Middle Ages.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Structural and Biophysical Characterization of La Related Protein

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Collagen, La Related Protein, MLLE, NMR, PAM2

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: La related proteins (LARPs) form a superfamily of 7 distinct, homologous RNA regulatory protein which utilize a tandem La domain and ribonucleotide recognition motif (RRM), termed the La module, to recognize their individual RNA targets. LARP6, in vertebrates, functions to regulate the coordinated synthesis of type 1 collagen peptide mRNA during wound healing processes through the specific recognition of an mRNA secondary structure, the 5’ stem loop (5’SL). This stem loop is located at the junction between the 5’ untranslated region and protein- encoding region of mature type 1 and type 3 collagen mRNA, preoccupying the translation initiation codon. Prolonged injury from chronic disease, lifestyle, or aging results in the hyperactivity of wound healing mechanisms. Overactive myofibroblasts, which excrete extracellular matrix material (ECM) composed primarily of type 1 collagen, fill functional parenchymal tissue space with nonfunctional scaffoldings which rigidifies the tissue or organ. This hyperactivity results in fibrotic scarring which is progressively less reversible and was associated with >17% of mortalities globally prior to 2020. LARP6 acts as a central regulatory element of type 1 collagen mRNA, governing the potential for high-volume collagen excretion and is therefore operative in the development of fibrosis.Recent work, from our lab and others, presented evidence that La related protein 1 (LARP1) lacks an RRM downstream from the La domain. Instead, the intrinsically unstructured region contains a type 2 polyadenylate binding protein association motif (PAM2) sequence which is recognized by the C-terminal MLLE domain of cytosolic polyadenylate binding protein (PABPC1). The PAM2 motif of LARP1 and other protein functions to protect, circularize, regulate, or destabilize 3’ polyadenylated tails of RNA polymerase II transcripts. The PAM2 motif of xi LARP1 deviates from the canonical physiochemical composition and standard length of the consensus sequence from other PAM2 motif-containing protein. In this work novel features of LARP6 substrate recognition and LARP1A PAM2 motif recognition are investigated by NMR spectroscopy and biophysical analysis, as neither system crystalized in our hands. LARP6 can recognize 5’SL RNA without the explicit requirement of the RRM domain, which was previously reported to be mandatory for specific, high-affinity binding. The structure of the LARP6 La domain, residues 79-183, in complex with a 35-nucleotide model of the 5’ SL has been determined by NMR spectroscopy. Specificity conferring arrangements of the La domain and 5’SL explain the ability of the La domain to function as an isolated domain. The alternative MLLE recognition elements within the LARP1 PAM2 motif have also been investigated. This motif deviates in its N-terminal segment from the canonical composition of other PAM2 motifs which have been co-crystallized with the MLLE domain. Chemical shift perturbation of isotopically enriched MLLE domain in the presence of PAM2 peptides, coupled with molecular dynamics simulations, elucidates how the differences between these PAM2 still result in similar binding modes on MLLE. This work is concluded with a review of methyl-detected NMR methods for determining allosteric motions or interactions with the kinetic cooperativity model of human glucokinase as a case study.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Effects of Online Synchronous Versus Online Asynchronous Abacus Professional Development

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: abacus, online, professional development, synchronous and asynchronous, teacher of the visually impaired, transactional distance theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Professional development is viewed as a lifelong learning process for educators to improve student instruction and professional skills (Darling-Hammond et al., 2017). Online professional development for teachers of student who are visually impaired (TVIs) provides opportunities for continuing education, including for earning of recertification hours. With the rapid growth of online professional development, there is a need to assess the efficacy of synchronous and asynchronous options (Rowe, 2019). The purpose of this quantitative study was to compare two types of abacus professional development, online synchronous and online asynchronous, provided to TVIs to determine if a significant difference existed for growth of abacus knowledge, participant engagement, and participant satisfaction. Moore’s transactional distance theory (1973) provided a conceptual framework for the study. The results of the analyses found that participants (N = 93) in both conditions had learning gains. The repeated-measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) suggested the participants in the asynchronous condition had greater gains in abacus knowledge, but the proximity of the p-value (p=.051) to the customary threshold of .05 makes it difficult to use the p-value to draw conclusions regarding the statistical significance of this difference. Participants reported approximately the same levels of engagement or satisfaction in both conditions. This study adds to the very limited literature on differences in educational outcomes for online synchronous and asynchronous professional development for TVIs. The fact that online asynchronous professional development appears to have impacted learning growth more than online synchronous professional development was intriguing. This study suggests that online learning environments can be engaging and satisfying whether delivered synchronously or asynchronously.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UNDERSTANDING THE RELATIONSHIP AMONG SCHOOL CONDITIONS, JOB SATISFACTION, AND TEACHER INTENTION TO STAY IN CHARTER SCHOOLS VERSUS TRADITIONAL PUBLIC SCHOOLS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this research is to understand the relationship among school conditions, teacher job satisfaction, intention to stay, and school type (charter versus traditional public schools) and to determine if school conditions, and thereby job satisfaction, influences teachers’ intention to stay in the field. Understanding this is critical to addressing teacher shortages from a policy and practical perspective. Data was collected from 275 teachers in four Florida counties, with comparable samples of charter and traditional public schools, through an online Qualtrics survey and all survey responses remained anonymous. Data was analyzed using descriptive statistics and independent samples t-test, multiple regression and multiple logistic regression analysis, and ANOVA to determine if significant relationships exist. The findings noted that of eight school conditions, six of those conditions were scored higher by charter school teachers, with one not significant and another higher by traditional public school teachers. None of the school conditions predicted a teacher’s intention to stay in the field and only three (salary, high-stakes testing, and student behavior) significantly related to teacher job satisfaction. Of those three, only high-stakes testing and student behavior showed a statistically significant difference when accounting for the type of school.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Teogonía

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Teogonía is a symphonic poem in five sections based on the mural, Teogonía de los dioses chibchas, by Luis Alberto Acuña. Each section introduces one of the Chibcha Gods and the creation story of the Muisca people. Other references that inspired me are symphonic works by Latin-American composers: Silvestre Revueltas, Alberto Ginastera, José Pablo Moncayo, and Arturo Márquez. This work was written in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music from Florida State University. Based on the mural located at the Hotel Tequendama in Bogotá, Colombia, Teogonía is meant to depict the creation story of the Muisca, or Chibcha people. While there are many more characters in the mural, this orchestral work illustrates the five principal Gods of the creation story: Chiminigagua, Súe, Chía, Chibchacum, and Bochica. The piece opens with Chiminigagua, the all-powerful God and creator of the universe. This character is represented by a three-note motive [D-F-G] which is the basis of the piece and reappears in each of the following sections. The piece begins in a primordial state of the universe until the spark of creation which leads into the second section. Súe is the God of the sun and represents light and energy. This upbeat section is characterized by the use of traditional Colombian dance rhythms, most prominently, the bambuco. These rhythms can be identified by the simultaneous and alternating groupings of two and three. The third section depicts the moon Goddess, Chía. In mythology, Chía and Súe are married and perpetually follow each other in the sky. This section is about their love and culminates in the single moment they can be together, during an eclipse. The fourth section tells the story of Chibchacum, God of thunder and rain. The orchestra, here, depicts the great storm that flooded the world, wiping away the corruption that had spread. The final section introduces Bochica who is commonly seen as the messenger of Chiminigagua. Bochica arrives after the great flood on a rainbow and strikes the ground with his staff creating the Tequendama falls. He teaches the Musica people about moral norms, ways to organize their states, agriculture, metalworking, and crafts. This final section concludes the piece and combines statements of all previous Gods’ themes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PROPRIÉTAIRES IN PLAIN SIGHT: THE LEGAL AND ECONOMIC AUTONOMY OF MARRIED WOMEN IN SOUTHERN FRANCE, 1750-1815

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: France, gender, history, women

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation explores women's property ownership in the south of France from 1750-1815, with a particular emphasis on an overlooked group of women in Bas Languedoc, centered around Montpellier. The study investigates the impact of women's legal and marital status on their economic agency, filling a gap in historical scholarship that has neglected this specific group. In contrast to other regions of France where customary law prevailed, women in the south, subject to written law, enjoyed legal and social empowerment enabling them to independently own and manage property. This assertion applies regardless of social and demographic variables. The argument is substantiated by a blend of qualitative and quantitative evidence. Three in-depth case studies featuring prominent married women- the Marquise de Spinola, the Marquise de Murs, and Catherine Rose Mallié- serve as illustrative examples. These case studies highlight women's formal property ownership and their active engagement in wealth management through activities such as litigation, transactions, leasing, and philanthropy. To complement the case studies, a meticulous examination of notary and tax records reveals the breadth and prevalence of women's property ownership. Geographic comparisons and temporal analyses further illuminate the varied landscape of women's economic autonomy over time. This dissertation argues for the importance of regional perspectives in understanding French history, emphasizing the necessity to provincialize historical narratives for a more nuanced comprehension of women's diverse experiences. Furthermore, it challenges conventional assumptions about the limitations of marriage as an institution, encouraging historians to move beyond passive interpretations of its role in shaping women's economic agency.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Archaeology and Indigenous Migration in the Atchafalaya Basin

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This research delves into the complex history of Chitimacha-speaking communities to form a speculated migrations route during the French Colonial era. The arrival of the French marked a pivotal moment, introducing diseases, displacement, and cultural assimilation for Chitimacha-speakers as well as other Indigenous communities. This research analyzes historical documents, archaeological findings, and georeferenced maps to unravel Chitimacha-speaking communities’ migration through Louisiana to the western Atchafalaya Basin, address the gap of knowledge of the Chitimacha-Speakers’ past, and shed light on challenges that this research and archaeology face.

Due to the unknown accuracy of the historic maps and where the cartographers got their data from, it was determined that historical maps are not a reliable dataset on their own to determine Indigenous migration, but instead should be analyzed alongside historical documents and archaeological findings. Analysis of pottery sherds helped place the current study area into regional context through comparisons to findings from previous investigations. A Coles Creek-Plaquemine component is proposed for 16SMY2 and 16SMY12 because of the pottery sherds recovered from previous archaeological investigations in the region. The other three current archaeological investigation areas do not have enough data to be placed into context.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Dovetailing

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Dovetailing is a collection of nineteen personal essays about my experience with debilitating anxiety and depression. In the collection, I use birds as a mechanism to explore mental illness, with each essay focusing on a specific bird. Throughout the collection, I braid my experience seeing each essay’s titular bird with research about birds, mental illness, literature, or other topics. The entire structure of the book mirrors the experience of being consumed by mental illness and learning to cope with and accept that illness. The opening essays of the collection are shorter, more fragmented, and contain more repetitions, mirroring the way anxiety is cyclical, as well as the way it fragments the way one experiences the world. As the collection progresses, the essays become more linear and less focused on anxiety, mirroring the way the narrator better understands her anxiety and no longer considers it an all-consuming experience. The final essay in the collection, “Passeridae,” is fragmented and follows the narrator through a difficult spell of anxiety. Ending the collection this way allows the collection to counter the notion that anxiety and mental disorders can be “cured.” While the essay collection investigates the way that the narrator finds watching birds a healing and grounding process, it also rejects the common nature writing cliche that nature exists to be healing. Instead, birdwatching has become a part of the narrator, just as she has accepted anxiety and depression as part of her. Accompanying these creative essays is a critical essay that examines the goals and inspirations behind my creative work.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Effects of Music Therapy on Older Adults With Dementia: A Content Analysis

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Alzheimer's, Cognitive Impairment, Dementia, Memory Loss

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Music therapy research (93%) has indicated the impact of music therapy on older adults with dementia, which is enhancing the quality of life, decreasing stress and agitation, improving mood, increasing cognitive and language skills, and improving physical movement. The purpose of this study was to review and analyze publications in the Journal of Music Therapy (JMT) and Music Therapy Perspectives (MTP) on older adults with dementia from the years 1980-1999 and 2000-2024. The researcher sought to find the most effective interventions and mostly used assessments for older adults with dementia. The results of this content analysis suggest that singing activities are the mostly used intervention, observation is the most common assessment used followed by using the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) as a reference for creating music therapy assessments, and that more research is needed due to the small number of articles published. Recommendations were also given to expand research in the field of older adults with dementia.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A Content Analysis of Music Therapy Interventions with Adolescents/Young Adults in Mental Health Facilities

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The use of music therapy with adolescents/young adults (AYA) in mental health facilities has proven to be effective. The purpose of this research was to examine the use of music therapy interventions with AYA at mental health facilities in Journal of Music Therapy, Music Therapy Perspectives, and Voices: A World Forum for Music Therapy from 2019 through 2024. Criteria for inclusion were music therapy applied to the population with music as the primary focus of the intervention, the presence of music therapy interventions in AYA mental health facilities and research from 2019 through 2024. Of the 321 articles, 21 met these criteria, and 5 were identified for further inspection. Overall, the specific interventions used by music therapists with this population is slim. Further research and in-depth annotation of music therapy interventions with AYA in mental health facilities is needed to continue the expansion of accessibility of music therapy within this population. With continued research and robust research contributing to the field, there is hope that a plethora of resources will be utilized by the field of music therapy.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Methods of Shape Analysis:\protect\\ Optimal Transport, Geometric Measure Theory, and Deep Learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this dissertation, we address the development of mathematical frameworks for computationally feasible methods to compare and analyze large datasets of complex-shaped data. We discuss several projects at the intersections of optimal transport, geometric measure theory, elastic shape analysis, and geometric deep learning that contribute novel algorithms for the practical analysis of shape data and develop the theoretical foundations of shape analysis.

We propose a supervised deep geometric learning method to achieve a parameterization-invariant calculation of the square root velocity (SRV) shape distance function. This method learns the invariance of the SRV metric to reparameterizations by implementing a shape-preserving data augmentation method during the training process. Moreover, we propose an unsupervised geometric deep learning method that utilizes methods from geometric measure theory to learn parameterization-invariant feature vector representations of curves and shape graphs. This method provides a robust and efficient approach for the classification of shape data and the identification of point-to-point correspondences between curves and shape graphs.

Additionally, we discuss several methods within a framework of relaxed matching between surfaces with respect to a family of second-order Sobolev metrics. These methods combine Riemannian metrics from elastic shape analysis for shape comparison, along with a relaxed matching loss from the domain of geometric measure theory, to solve the correspondence problem. The adoption of weighted varifold representations of shapes facilitates the matching of shapes with different topological structures, accommodating noise, occlusions, and partial matching problems between shapes. Furthermore, we provide a comprehensive framework to perform statistical analysis of populations in the space of shapes. We also describe the restriction of this model to shapes that undergo deformations within a basis of biologically relevant or physically feasible deformations.

We also discuss a project studying connection between the Square Root Normal Field (SRNF) elastic shape pseudo-metric and the Wasserstein Fisher-Rao (WFR) unbalanced optimal transport metric. By studying this connection, we construct algorithms and deepen the theoretical understanding of the SRNF and WFR metrics. Specifically, we offer a characterization of the closure of the SRNF map and shapes that are indistinguishable with respect to the SRNF metric. Furthermore, we propose a formulation of the WFR as a diffeomorphic optimization problem related to Gallou\"{e}t and Vialard’s recent extension of the Riemannian submersion result of Otto.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Essays at the Intersection of Population Ethics and Animal Ethics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Animal ethics is the branch of ethics concerning non-human animals. Population ethics is the branch of ethics concerning ethical issues related to who will exist or the number of people that will exist. In this dissertation, I argue for some views in animal ethics by appealing to insights from population ethics, and I argue for some views in population ethics by appealing to some insights from animal ethics. There are five chapters. The first chapter introduces the project, while the subsequent chapters each present one of four independent essays. The chapters can be read in any order and each one is self-contained. In the second chapter, I defend a virtue ethics approach to animal ethics. In the third chapter, I discuss an objection to my approach to animal ethics, namely that my approach runs counter to common sense. In the fourth chapter, I defend a theory of well-being that helps us to avoid the so-called “repugnant conclusion,” a conclusion that many population ethicists desire to avoid. In the fifth chapter, I defend a view about the so-called “non-identity problem,” by denying the distinction between doing and allowing harm in what I refer to as “non-identity cases”.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Advanced Control Techniques for Inverter-based Resources and Instant Grid Synchronization

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Grid-tied, Inverter based resources, Renewable energy, Synchronization

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The contemporary power grid landscape is witnessing a transformative shift. As the integration ofrenewable energy resources intensifies and decarbonization objectives gain prominence, there is a discernible migration from traditional synchronous generator (SG)-based systems to inverter-based resources (IBRs). This shift, while promising, heralds the dawn of a modernized electric power grid characterized by unparalleled flexibility and adaptability. Despite the potential advantages, this transition presents complex challenges. At the forefront is the phase-locked loop (PLL), a critical synchronization mechanism for the AC power grid. While its role in inverter controls is essential, it has been linked to issues such as oscillations and subsynchronous harmonics. Additionally, the "black start"process remains a significant concern. For SGs, initiating a black start can be time-consuming, often taking tens of minutes due to factors like the mechanical inertia of generators, extended energizing transients, and system control latency. In the context of IBRs, the black start process is similarly constrained, especially by the bandwidth limitations of the PLL. To address these challenges, this thesis presents a novel PLL-free inverter control approach. Impressively, this new control, even without the PLL, offers a faster transient response to various grid changes while maintaining a low steady-state error. We also introduce advanced startup methods for IBRs. Our hysteresis-based technique allows inverters to connect to the grid within one fundamental cycle without inrush current and is resilient to grid voltage distortions. Further, we propose a switching-cycle-based startup method, enabling inverters to become operational within just two switching cycles, without any inrush current. Together, these innovative methods not only improve the black start process for IBRs but also enhance the overall stability and resilience of power systems.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Three Essays on Reimagining Innovation and Diffusion Studies with A New Multi-dimensional Framework

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Boundary, New framework, Policy innovation and diffusion

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation proposes a novel approach to policy innovation and dissemination studies by developing a comprehensive framework incorporating three key dimensions: space, time, and actors. Policy innovation and diffusion research in the spatial dimension should prioritize the domestic realm and encompass the global sphere. This dissertation demonstrates the influence of national culture on the dissemination of a worldwide policy, using the gender mainstreaming policy as a case study. Using quantitative comparative analysis (QCA) on data from 44 nations, I can identify three distinct pathways when studying the relationship between national culture and the diffusion of global gender mainstreaming policy. This innovative technique is particularly well-suited for symbolic measures. As the adage goes, “Yesterday is history. The future is a mystery. However, today is a gift.” Academics do acknowledge the significance of the present circumstances. Nevertheless, it is imperative to recognize the values of both historical and future-oriented principles. Hence, exploring the integration of path dependency, policy innovation, and diffusion is a valuable subject for researchers. Using GMM models, I have observed that fiscal transparency rankings, as opposed to specific fiscal transparency scores, play a more crucial role in deterring corruption in China. Furthermore, the previous fiscal transparency ranking had a significant influence on corruption in China.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Support-seeking on social media: Navigating acculturation and academic integration among international graduate students

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Academic integration, Acculturation, Informal learning, International graduate students, Professional development, Social media

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Pursuing higher education in a foreign country entails numerous challenges and opportunities for development for international students. Social media allows individuals adapting to a new environment to connect, communicate, collaborate, network, and learn, overcoming geographical, temporal, linguistic, cultural, and social boundaries. In this study, I explored how international graduate students used social media to seek support for acculturation and academic integration, as well as their perceptions of the benefits and challenges of using social media for support-seeking. I employed a naturalistic multiple-case study design to investigate this phenomenon relating to international graduate students’ acculturation and academic integration with social media. I selected participants through snowball and purposeful sampling. The inclusion criteria included that students were in the same university, had finished their first year of study in their academic program, and used social media regularly for support-seeking. The primary inclusion criterion was that students had spent their first year of study in their educational program and used social media regularly for support-seeking. I balanced participant samples based on demographic backgrounds, including country of origin, field of study, and gender, to understand diverse students’ experiences.Participants were eleven international graduate students from seven countries studying in education, social science, humanities, and STEM programs, with an average age of 27. Data were collected through two semi-structured interviews via Zoom and ten participant-generated digital artifacts via Padlet from each participant depicting their use of social media for acculturation and academic integration. Data were transcribed, cleaned, and anonymized before data analysis. I adopted inductive and deductive thematic analysis, guided by Activity Systems Analysis (ASA), as the analytic framework for my data analysis. I used the qualitative data analysis software NVivo to facilitate data analysis. The study findings revealed that international graduate participants’ primary objectives for using social media were to receive emotional and social support, manage daily and academic tasks, and integrate into their local and academic communities. Participants used a mix of home-country and U.S. social media platforms, with some employing a wide range of platforms and web services and others opting for a few selective ones. Participants purposefully tailored social media platforms to suit the groups of people they interacted with, the tasks they addressed, and their personal preferences and topics at hand. The advantages of using social media for support-seeking included affordability, convenience, vast access to information, and extended social and incidental learning opportunities. However, several tensions arose from negative experiences, such as emotional distress related to social media engagement, with some intensified by algorithms designed for mindless scrolling. Commonly reported tensions included digital distractions, compulsive use of social media, and mindless scrolling. Other tensions included varying information quality and limited access to different language information sources. Accordingly, implications for practice and future research were discussed, including implementing social media curricula to support students’ effective use of social media for personal and professional goals while adapting to their new cultural and educational environment.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Procedural Recommendations for the Reconsolidation of Split Collections Under NAGPRA: A Case Study

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: NAGPRA compliance, Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation, Reconciliation of archaeological collections, Repatriation of split collections, Split collection management

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Since the passing of NAGPRA legislation in 1990, the academic community has published extensively on the process of repatriation and its impacts on the field of anthropology and stakeholder communities. While systemic critiques of the legislation are widespread in anthropological advocacy and discourse, there remains a gap in the literature about the actual processes of repatriation and the application of NAGPRA regulations, particularly as they relate to collections that have become/remained split amongst various state entities, universities, museums, and federal holdings. Through a process of literature review, interviews, and case study, this project demonstrates the prevalence of split archaeological collections, investigates attitudes towards reconciliation, and offers procedural recommendations to assist in making the process more universally accessible.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Verb Ventures: Comparative Study on Implicit and Explicit Grammar Interventions for MLs

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Child Language, Developmental Language Disorders, Multilingual Children

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Spanish-English speaking multilinguals (MLs) with Developmental Language Disorders (DLD) have greater difficulty with verb morphology compared to their typically developing peers. Patterns of error are observed in both monolinguals and MLs. However, there are more studies that have explored the effectiveness of grammar intervention targeting verb morphology for monolinguals compared to MLs. Moreover, there are even fewer studies that compare the effectiveness of implicit and explicit approaches used in grammar interventions. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to examine an adapted alternating treatment single case design (AATD) to compare the (1) effectiveness of implicit and explicit approaches used in grammar interventions that target the inflectional past tense –ED and third person singular –s (3S) and (2) efficiency of the implicit and explicit approaches for acquiring the past tense –ED and 3S. The study includes third-fifth grade Spanish-English speaking MLs with and without DLD.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Schenkerian Approaches to the Music of Dmitri Shostakovich

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Russian modal theory, Schenkerian analysis, Shostakovich, Triadic post-tonality

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study explores tonal states in the music of Dmitri Shostakovich (1906–1975) by examining harmony and voice leading from a Schenkerian perspective. Chapter 1 examines Shostakovich’s realignment with socialist aesthetic ideologies in 1936, demonstrating how traditional idioms and forms in works written after the Pravda attacks enable a wider range of access points for tonal analysis. Methodologies derived from Russian theoretical thought such as modal lowering and modal derivation address surface relations; however, they do not make connections between local modal elements and large-scale tonal structure. Analyses by David Fanning and Sarah Marlowe demonstrate that while modal and chromatic behaviors are exhibited at foreground levels, these events represent post-tonal intensifications of customary idioms that unfold within broader tonal designs. Schenkerian processes of mixture and tonicization illustrate how Shostakovich’s modal-chromatic qualities can be contextualized within tonal frameworks. Building on the modal and tonal analytical models from Chapter 1, Chapter 2 investigates how selected passages from Shostakovich’s music articulate tonal structures in a variety of post-1936 works, including the second movement of String Quartet No. 9, the fourth movement of String Quartet No. 3, and Prelude Nos. 4, 13, and 22 from the Twenty-Four Preludes and Fugues, op. 87. Schenkerian theory contextualizes modal and chromatic inflections in String Quartet Nos. 3 and 9 within deeper levels of counterpoint and through the processes of simple, secondary, and double mixture. In Prelude Nos. 4, 13, and 22, Shostakovich’s emulation of Baroque contrapuntal techniques produces foreground and middleground structures that resonate with customary linear models in the Bach-to-Brahms tradition. Although static structures are generated in Prelude Nos. 4 and 22, prolongational techniques express their monotonal designs. Chapter 3 examines the tonal structure of the Passacaglia from Shostakovich’s Violin Concerto No. 1. At the middleground level, this movement produces a static bass line and an incomplete Urlinie (\hat{5}–\hat{4}–\hat{3}). The passacaglia rotations navigate tonal pathways through goal-oriented counterpoint, motivic confirmation of structural thirds, and local bass arpeggiations. The ground bass expands the tonic through surface-level arpeggiations, interior \hat{5}–\hat{1} motions, and the linear idiom 5–6–5 above the tonic pedal, producing a static harmonic state in the first half of the middleground. In the second half, the modulatory function of the cadenza is expressed as it transitions into the last movement, illustrating how chromatic voice leading bridges the F minor key area of the Passacaglia with A minor. Although Schenkerian theory does not accommodate modulations at the structural level, Chapter 3 introduces a model for contextualizing harmony and voice leading in Shostakovich’s attacca transitions. The second case study explores tonal expressions in the second movement of Symphony No. 12. Chapter 4 demonstrates how modal lowering and mixture generate chromatic elements in the second movement’s themes, motives, and secondary key areas. The modally lowered theme establishes a monotonal state through third motions, tonic arpeggiations, and 5–6–5 gestures. A linear framework for the second movement elucidates how its secondary key areas function as chromatic embellishments of standard contrapuntal procedures. A Schenkerian approach illustrates tonal closure within the obligatory register, producing a melodic structure that resonates with customary Urlinien. Lastly, Chapter 5 analyzes selected passages from Shostakovich’s “formalist” works in 1927–1936, including opera Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District, the first movement of Symphony No. 4 in C Minor, and Symphony No. 2. These works present challenges to Schenkerian methodologies in that they provide fewer access points for tonal orientations. Analysis of tonal structure and voice leading in these pieces is complicated by mutable passages that generate subsets of pitches that compete for centricity, counterpoint that lacks directed motion toward a tonal goal (non-functional counterpoint), and melodies with modal orientations that are less responsive to tonal methodology. The studies provide a foundation for tonal applications to Shostakovich’s music. Ultimately, the analyses demonstrate that many components of Shostakovich’s compositional process are addressed by a Schenkerian approach.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE SOURCE AND COMPOSITION OF GLACIER DISSOLVED ORGANIC MATTER

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Carbon Cycle, Cryosphere, Dissolved Organic Matter, FT-ICR MS, Glaciers, Radiocarbon

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Mountain glaciers export ancient, energy-rich, and highly bioavailable dissolved organic matter (DOM) to freshwater and marine ecosystems, influencing downstream carbon cycling and supporting food webs. Despite its importance and the sensitivity of mountain glaciers to climate change, the sources of organic matter (OM) underpinning glacier DOM composition and its high bioavailability remain poorly constrained. To date, our understanding of the glacier carbon cycle has been formed from a handful of glaciers in a small number of regions (typically Greenland, Alaska, and the High Mountains of Asia), where geographically disparate studies have yielded different conclusions as to the dominant source of glacier OM. For example, studies in Greenland have suggested glacier DOM is predominately microbial in origin, whereas studies based in Alaska and Tibet postulate DOM to be primarily atmospheric deposition-derived. Implicitly, these studies indicate there may be regional and global heterogeneity in glacier DOM source and composition, which would have implications for understanding the fate of glacier-derived DOM and the age of carbon respired across glacier-fed ecosystems.

In this dissertation combined analytical approaches (including molecular-level and carbon isotopic techniques) are used to assess glacier DOM composition across regional and global gradients. We highlight the glacier DOM pool as a distinct and dynamic carbon pool in the global carbon cycle, with significant diversity in DOM source and composition at both intra-regional and global scales. By analyzing global variability in composition across 136 glacier outflows covering six continents, we demonstrate glacier DOM is regionally distinct, where its composition is largely determined by the relative contribution of OM from in situ production and atmospheric deposition. We combine molecular-level, and bulk and compound-specific black carbon isotopic analyses, to show that anthropogenic deposition (i.e., fossil fuel combustion byproducts) has impacted glacier carbon cycling at the global scale. Nonetheless, in regions downwind of industrial centers (e.g., Alaska) the glacier OM pool is likely older and more stable in composition compared to remote regions (e.g., Ecuador), where glacier DOM is likely predominately derived from in situ production. In glaciers dominated by in situ production, the DOM exported to downstream and marine ecosystems is likely younger in radiocarbon age and relatively more aliphatic (i.e., energy-rich). Using novel respiratory carbon recovery system experiments for a subset of glacier outflows in southeast Alaska, we conclude this modern, in situ produced OM, may underpin the high bioavailability of the glacier dissolved organic carbon (DOC) pool. Thus, although globally glacier DOC is ancient and bioavailable, a modern pool of OM may underpin its high bioavailability. Together, these findings have wide ranging implications for how we contextualize the glacier carbon cycle and the role of glacier-derived DOC in downstream ecosystems.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring the Relationship between Cultural Intelligence and Burnout in Teachers

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Burnout, Cultural Intelligence, Teacher

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this Dissertation in Practice was to explore the relationship between cultural intelligence and burnout in teachers. This purpose was rooted in a growing trend of teachers reporting a significant degree of burnout and education frequently being noted as one of the most stressful professions in the job market (Johnson et al., 2005; Saloviita & Pakarinen, 2021). In particular, teachers who work with a culturally heterogeneous student body face challenges with linguistic, behavioral, and social differences which can result in work-related stress which, if unmanaged, leads to burnout (Dilg, 2003; Dubbeld et al., 2019; Gutentag et al., 2018). Since cultural intelligence is an indicator as to how successful a person will be navigating culturally diverse environments and has been related to outcomes associated with job performance and job satisfaction (Baluku et al., 2019), it is worth exploring whether a relationship exists between the four factors of cultural intelligence and the three factors of burnout.

This exploratory research study used a quantitative approach with a survey method. Research participants included 153 PK-12th grade teachers working at an international boarding school located in South Florida. Data collected was analyzed through the lens of three research questions:What level of cultural intelligence (CQ) and degree of burnout are reported by teachers working at an international school in the United States? How do the levels of teacher CQ and degree of burnout differ by teachers’ demographic characteristics? What are the relationships between the four factors of cultural intelligence and the three factors of burnout in teachers working at an international school in the United States?

The data was analyzed using descriptive statistics, independent t-tests, and a series of multiple linear regression models. The results of the study are reported in two parts. First the descriptive statistics and results from the t-tests for the mean differences of each factor of CQ and each factor of burnout between demographic groups are reported. Second, multiple linear regression models were fitted, and the results of each model were addressed. All data analyses were conducted using SPSS. The results of the multiple linear regression analyses are especially important as this research found that teachers with high motivational cultural intelligence tend to report lower degrees of emotional exhaustion and depersonalization and higher degrees of personal accomplishment.

This study expands the knowledge on cultural intelligence in educators by finding that Motivational CQ was the only factor statistically significantly related to all three factors of burnout. Moving forward, it is recommended that educational leaders focus on professional development aimed at increasing a teacher’s motivational cultural intelligence as this may lead to a decrease in their burnout. Two limitations of this study are the small sample size and the fact that all teachers work at the same school. Therefore, it is suggested that future research examines the relationship between cultural intelligence and burnout by surveying a larger sample size of teachers who work at multiple schools to allow for greater generalizability of the results.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SOCIAL SKILLS IN MUSIC THERAPY PRACTICE: A CONTENT ANALYSIS ON AMTA JOURNALS FROM 1964-2024

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this content analysis was to ascertain specific practices, demographics, and research formats used to teach or improve social skills in music therapy practice. A history of interdisciplinary research on social skills is presented, followed by an in-depth analysis of 181 journal articles published in the American Music Therapy Association (AMTA) journals. These publications were categorized by their degree of relevance to the practice of teaching social skills. Although a frequently assigned treatment goal and a topic of considerable interest, there remains disagreement among professionals on how to operationally define social skills. The results reflect this discrepancy but provide some useful recommendations on how to successfully treat social skills in music therapy practice with a variety of populations. The most common social skills addressed in music therapy practice were those of initiating verbal communication (49%) and self-regulation (19%). Interventions addressing social skills were implemented by board-certified music therapists typically to children and adolescents with developmental disabilities (31.8%) and mental health disorders (15.4%) using applications with musical instrument play (32%) and group singing (22.9%). Implications for future practice and research are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PROTEIN LIGAND BINDING MOLECULAR DYNAMICS SIMULATIONS AND LARGE-SCALE LEAD IDENTIFICATION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: computer-aided drug design, lead identification, molecular dynamics, protein ligand binding prediction

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In drug discovery, predicting protein-ligand binding structures and affinities is crucial for lead identification. Over the past decades, molecular dynamics simulation-based approaches have gained prominence in this endeavor. Despite some progress, achieving accurate and efficient protein-ligand binding prediction remains challenging. This doctoral dissertation addresses several challenges by focusing on understanding the molecular dynamics sampling bottleneck, developing an accurate isobaric-isothermal ensemble, and creating an automated program to streamline simulation workflow for large-scale lead identification.Enabling sufficient and robust sampling for quantitative protein-ligand binding prediction is challenging in molecular dynamics simulation. Motivated by specific viewpoints on existing sampling challenges, active developments were made largely in four categories: unguided free energy sampling methods, geometry-based free energy sampling methods, alchemical free energy sampling methods, and trajectory stratification approaches. We systematically analyzed these representative methods. In particular, we focus our discussion on essential features of these methods and derive our viewpoint that the orthogonal space sampling problem is the major bottleneck for all of the existing methods. Future areas of improvement that need to be explored was also expanded. The isobaric-isothermal (NPT) ensemble mimics conditions often encountered in chemical and biochemical experiments. Thus, its accuracy is important in obtaining correct biomolecular dynamics and thermodynamic properties in molecular dynamics simulations. We introduced “MTK-Langevin”, a novel NPT ensemble method meticulously optimized the critical components that significantly improve the accuracy and efficiency. Specifically, MTK-Langevin: 1) incorporated correction terms to the equations of motion for the desired NPT partition function, 2) used the Langevin piston algorithm for barostat thermalization to reduce mass-dependent ringing effects, 3) integrated the barostat using BAOAB scheme to ensure minimal error and high stability, and 4) optimized parameters for improved equilibration efficiency. Tests showed MTK-Langevin achieved accurate temperature and pressure control with fast equilibration. Alchemical free energy simulations entail intricate steps, making manual setup labor-intensive and error prone. Practical lead identification campaigns often require numerous calculations, rendering manual setup impractical. To address this, we developed “AutoAlchem” to automate the simulation workflow. AutoAlchem streamlines topology generation, system building, equilibration, GPU-accelerated production runs, and data analysis. Tested in lead optimization, it consistently delivers accurate and efficient setup. Key features of AutoAlchem include integration of enhanced sampling methods and active learning techniques, allowing for large-scale simulations with high recall rates while sampling only a subset of molecules. In summary, these studies highlighted the sampling bottleneck during protein ligand binding process and developed an NPT ensemble method and an automated workflow aimed at enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of protein ligand binding prediction.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN APPROACH TO LEARNING HISTORICAL IMPROVISATION THROUGH THE STUDY OF EIGHTEENTH-CENTURY VARIATION SETS AND CROSS-CULTURAL PIANO MUSIC INFLUENCED BY NORTH INDIAN, BALINESE, AND CHINESE CLASSICAL TRADITIONS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: fusion, improvisation, music, piano, variations

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise is in two chapters, each based on a lecture recital I presented during my doctoral studies at Florida State University. While the topics are not specifically related to each other, both explore performance practices and compositional processes that are not typically considered part of the modern Western classical keyboard tradition. The first half concerns itself with historical keyboard improvisation. Variation sets by W.A. Mozart and C.P.E. Bach are examined for their relationship to improvised eighteenth-century performances and explored as potential learning resources for would-be improvisers. The second half is devoted to three piano pieces by the contemporary composers Gareth Farr, Reena Esmail, and Zhou Long. Each piece combines specific Asian classical traditions with Western composition. The cross-cultural elements present in each composition are analyzed and contextualized to aid performers, scholars, and listeners.

DISS_description.DISS_title: “WE HEAR THE DESERT SINGING”: DIALOGIC SOUNDSCAPES IN EARLY MORMON HYMNODY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: From its inception, Joseph Smith Jr.’s Latter Day Saint Movement, and by consequence, many of the hymns that accompanied this religious tradition, have been preoccupied with place and geography. Looking to Latter Day Saint scripture, as well as Smith’s particular theologies of Millennialism, embodiment, and exaltation, this thesis contextualizes the descriptions of place within early Latter Day Saint hymns as both soundscapes and a dialogue with the movement’s own sacred geography. These hymns served as tools of sonic placemaking, imbuing the landscape with meaning for the Latter Day Saints as the main body of the movement migrated westward, from New York to Ohio, Missouri, Illinois, and finally as refugees to the Salt Lake Valley in the Great Basin area of the American West. As musical negotiations with the North American continent and the larger globe, these Latter Day Saint hymns enabled their writers and performers, European and Euro-American settlers and colonizers, to interact with their surroundings and create a sonic space for themselves in the New World.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DESIGN OF SUSTAINABLE ULTRA HIGH PERFORMANCE CONCRETE (UHPC) USING A MULTI-SCALE FRAMEWORK

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Fiber Bridging Behavior, Multi-Scale Modeling, Recycled Steel Fiber (RSF), Single Fiber Pullout Behavior, Sustainable Material, Ultra High Performance Concrete (UHPC)

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Ultra high performance concrete (UHPC) is an advanced construction material for civil infrastructure development due to its supreme mechanical characteristics and distinct durability properties. There is a notable surge in the application of UHPC, particularly in highway infrastructures in the United States. The current dissertation addresses two critical challenges regarding the implementation of UHPC structures. The first part of the dissertation investigates the impact of fiber orientation and construction processes on the structural performance of UHPC. A comprehensive synthesis of existing literature and the UHPC structural design specifications and recommendations worldwide is conducted to understand how construction processes impact fiber orientation in UHPC elements and how this influence should be addressed in UHPC design. In the second part of the dissertation, sustainable UHPC materials are developed using a multi-scale and probabilistic design approach. A key challenge with UHPC is its high price and high environmental impact from carbon emissions associated with the use of manufactured steel fibers. This study explores the feasibility of using recycled steel fibers (RSF) derived from waste tires in UHPC production. The characteristics of RSF are comprehensively characterized, and their influence on the pullout behavior is determined through experimental and analytical methods. A multi-scale probabilistic framework is then employed to facilitate the design of UHPC composites incorporating RSF. The cost of UHPC production using MSF and RSF are calculated and compared where RSF based UHPC showed significantly lower production cost. The embodied carbon and embodied energy for these UHPCs are also calculated and again RSF based UHPCs showed more sustainability with significantly lower values for these parameters. In conclusion, the dissertation contributes to the sustainable development of UHPC structures by addressing key issues such as fiber orientation and utilizing recycled materials, ultimately enhancing the environmental and economic feasibility of UHPC applications in infrastructure construction.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Essays on The Economic Impact of Micromobility

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Chapter 1 explores how shared micromobility impacts other transportation networks, specifically taxi markets in New York City. I exploit the spatial variation in the rollout of Citi Bike dock stations in a difference-in-differences research design. I find that Citi Bike and taxis are substitutes, with the average taxi market experiencing a 3.2% decline in trips each week. Heterogeneity analysis suggests that this effect is largely driven by rider substituting for relatively short trips. Two potential mechanisms are explored; direct substitution to Citi Bike and substituting from taxis to use Citi Bike and public transportation in tandem. I find evidence that both mechanisms generate the observed substitution pattern.

Chapter 2 explores how transportation stations impact local crime. Most studies on the link between crime and transit stations focus on public transportation, however, there is limited evidence for other transportation alternatives, like micromobility. Using a spatial difference-in-differences research design, we provide evidence that bike share docking stations cause a significant increase in crime within 25 meters by leveraging data on Citi Bike and reported crime in New York City. Our results are robust across various estimators and counterfactuals, and we find heterogeneous effects depending on the type of crime and the time of day a crime was reported to have occurred. These findings provide insights into the external costs of micromobility, offering policymakers further information when considering its adoption as a transportation alternative.

Chapter 3 investigates the impact of shared micromobility access on self-reported drunk driving using data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System survey for Selected Metropolitan/Micropolitan Area Risk Trends. By exploiting the heterogeneous rollout of shared micromobility services in the metropolitan area in a difference-in-differences research design, I estimate a small but negative point estimate for the effect of micromobility access on self-reported drunk driving. Standard errors for the estimates are large, resulting in statistically insignificant results. Therefore, I remain agnostic in the interpretation of my results.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Leveraging Emergence for Enhanced Planning and Decision-Making in the Built Environment: Applications in Resilience and Sustainability Planning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The built environment consists of various, diverse, and independent systems distributed across different organizational levels, such as team, project, regional, state, and national, creating a structured hierarchy. Interactions within and between these hierarchical levels, involving human participants, physical resources, and policies, are crucial for the functionality and efficiency of these systems. However, these interactions—physical, spatial, logical, and cyber in nature—can lead to unexpected 'emergent' properties or behaviors not anticipated in the original design of the systems.Emergence, a concept well-recognized in systems engineering, has not been fully integrated into research and practice related to the built environment. Scientific attempts to study processes in the built environment often adopt a reductionist perspective, treating the outcome of the built environment as the sum of its individual elements, thus simplifying and neglecting the complexity arising from continuous interactions among components. This simplification can overlook emergent behaviors that significantly influence planning and management across various areas, including construction productivity, safety, infrastructure planning, and operations, either positively or negatively. Considering the magnitude and nature of impact of any resultant emergent behavior on the holistic outcome of operations and processes in the built environment, it is crucial to acknowledge and account for emergence during planning and decision-making. This necessity becomes especially vital within the framework of resilience and sustainability planning, where achieving ambitious goals demands a holistic approach that transcends isolated entity planning. To date, research exploring emergence within engineering contexts has been limited. Even among the limited engineering studies that recognize the potential impact of emergent behavior and its significance, formalized analysis approaches are lacking. Moreover, none of these studies have endeavored to regulate the interactions underlying emergent behavior in pursuit of more favorable outcomes. As such, the potential of incorporating the concept of emergence in built environment planning and decision-making, particularly within the realms of sustainability and resilience, remains largely untapped. This research seeks to fill this gap by developing a formalized framework for effective modeling, analysis, and control of emergent behavior. It begins with establishing a taxonomy of emergent behaviors, classifying them into four distinct types based on (a) nature of underlying interactions, (b) level of complexity, and (c) boundaries of information available. This taxonomy is then used as a foundation for a three-step framework – (i) classification, (ii) operationalization, and (iii) implementation – for the systematic modeling and analysis of the different types of emergence within construction and infrastructure engineering and management applications. This study demonstrates the efficacy of the developed framework in augmenting and guiding system- and operational level planning and decision-making within the contexts of infrastructure resilience and construction sustainability planning through two case studies. The first case study examines the disparities in the resilience of municipal solid waste management systems (MSWMSs) during the COVID-19 pandemic stemming from their complex socio-technical interactions. Specifically, empirical investigation of the operation of MSWMSs during the course of the pandemic was conducted in order to investigate the variance in their adopted adaptation pathways as a function of their systems characteristic, particularly in terms of composition, topology, and control. Subsequently, these variances were used to explain the emerged resilience performance of MSWMSs, particularly with regards to (i) the resourcefulness of each system in establishing and implementing response measures and (ii) its rapidity in recovering and adapting to increasingly complex and dynamic conditions. Findings from this case study serve as a foundation for enhancing the resilience of MSWMSs to future pandemics and other disturbances. The second case study investigates the improvements or reductions in the productivity of heavy equipment during demolition debris sorting operations stemming from their spatial interactions. Specifically, lab-based scaled models of demolition operations utilizing small-scale excavators were employed to monitor the variables impacting the underlying spatial interactions, particularly (i) the proximity between excavators and (ii) the orientation of excavators during operations. Statistical models were subsequently established to explain the resulting impact on the collective productivity based on these variables. The insights gained from this case study provide a basis for optimizing excavator allocation and spatial arrangement during material separation operations to maximize the recovery of recyclable demolition waste.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ESSAYS ON THE IMPACTS OF MEDICAID EXPANSION ON STATE GOVERNMENTS, HOSPITALS, AND INDIVIDUALS: FOCUSING ON FINANCIAL ASPECTS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Medicaid expansion

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Following the Affordable Care Act (ACA), state governments have had the option to expand the eligibility of Medicaid programs since 2014. The expansion states increased the eligibility threshold to 138% of the federal poverty line, which allows more individuals to be covered by the program. In the first year, twenty-seven states, including the District of Columbia, decided to expand the program. However, several states hesitated to adopt the expansion, primarily due to concerns regarding the potential increase in fiscal burdens. Therefore, it is imperative to investigate whether Medicaid expansion significantly impacts state budgets thoroughly. Furthermore, Medicaid expansion also affects hospitals and healthcare providers, as it leads to a decrease in the uninsured rate and expands coverage. Consequently, it is crucial to examine how expansion alters managerial conditions and decision-making processes within healthcare organizations. Moreover, given that the primary goal of Medicaid expansion is to improve access to care for low-income individuals, it is imperative to assess the policy outcomes in a more precise and comprehensive manner.
