This necessitates thorough evaluation and analysis to understand the extent to which Medicaid expansion achieves its intended objectives and addresses the healthcare needs of low-income populations effectively. In this regard, this dissertation aims to provide a more clear and comprehensive understanding of the impact of Medicaid expansion by investigating from the perspectives of state governments, hospitals, and low-income individuals. To assess whether the expansion imposes an excessive fiscal burden on the states that adopt the policy, I explore how the number of Medicaid enrollees, expenditures for the program, and overall state fiscal conditions respond to a sudden economic downturn and analyze whether states expanded the programs should bear more fiscal burden compared to states that have not adopted it. Also, I focus on the fact that nonprofit hospitals have been criticized for providing benefits to their communities at an insufficient level despite enjoying enormous amounts of savings due to their tax-exemption status. Employing the principal-agent theory to understand the decision-making mechanisms underlying this behavior, I investigated whether Medicaid expansion mitigates this agency problem. Moreover, to offer a more comprehensive evaluation of Medicaid expansion's impact on access to care, I analyze whether the benefits of the policy are distributed differently among individuals depending on the presence of accessibility barriers. The findings of my study indicate that the Medicaid expansion would not significantly increase the fiscal burden for the states while allowing many people to stay insured during economic recessions. Also, the expansion affects the managerial conditions of nonprofit hospitals by decreasing their costs of uncompensated care. Despite this saving, hospitals are found not to change their behavior and to keep their scrutiny in providing financial assistance to their patients. In addition, my finding shows that Medicaid expansion relieves the financial burden of healthcare for low-income people, but the benefits are not universal to them. When individuals have low accessibility to their healthcare providers, they still have limited access to care even though they have have same health conditions and income levels. That is, there exists a disparity in the benefits from Medicaid expansion among the low-income groups. With these findings, I contribute to the relevant literature by offering a deeper understanding of the impact of Medicaid expansion, both theoretically and empirically. By exploring the nuances of Medicaid expansion's effects on state budgets, healthcare organizations, and access to care, my research provides valuable insights into the multifaceted implications of this policy. Furthermore, I offer practical implications for policymakers to understand the true costs of Medicaid expansion better and identify areas for policy refinement to enhance access to care effectively. By highlighting the potential challenges and opportunities associated with Medicaid expansion, policymakers can make informed decisions to optimize the policy's effectiveness and ensure equitable access to healthcare for all individuals.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A Protocol Evaluation Framework for System-Level Shipboard Power System Controls

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Shipboard power systems (SPS) are increasing their reliance on communication systems. Communication enables system-level controls to coordinate the usage of the SPS and provide significant improvements (e.g., size, weight, cost). Communication is commonly divided into layers (application, presentation, session, transport, network, data link, physical). While the lower layers have not had significant changes, the application layer is constantly in flux. New protocols are often introduced, providing new capabilities to facilitate communication.Real-time simulation (RTS) is a tool that has been effectively utilized to study SPSs. Many models and techniques exist. Similarly, the simulation of computer networks exists. However, leveraging these Real-time simulation tools/facilities for evaluating protocols has received little attention. Currently, a co-simulation environment of the SPS electrical system and its computer network provides a way to evaluate the operation of SPS models and assess their capabilities. Protocols are typically defined in the communication system. Yet not much is known about the potential impact of these protocols. This work proposes a framework to evaluate application layer communication protocols in the communication system of system-level SPS controls using RTS. The framework’s effectiveness was demonstrated by analyzing Modbus TCP and Data Distribution Service (DDS). The network utilization metric was used to compare and contrast the protocols.

DISS_description.DISS_title: OVERPARENTING AND EMERGING ADULTS’ ROMANTIC RELATIONSHIP EFFICACY: THE MODERATING ROLE OF INDIVIDUAL CULTURAL BELIEFS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: cross-cultural studies, emerging adults, parenting, romantic relationships

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Romantic love and intimacy are critical for emerging adults to explore self-identity. Relationship efficacy is a cognitive process related to conflict management that plays an important role in romantic relationship development and quality. Overparenting, characterized by high control and involvement, could undermine the development of emerging adults. Despite the potential negative impact of overparenting, the association between overparenting and relationship efficacy remains unexplored. Furthermore, differences related to norms in romantic relationship development and parenting practices across cultures should be considered, particularly between individualistic societies in the U.S. and collectivist societies in Asia. Using a person-centered approach, this study aimed to investigate the associations between profiles of overparenting and relationship efficacy in the U.S. and Hong Kong. Additionally, the potential moderation by individual-level cultural beliefs was explored to investigate whether these associations vary by horizontal individualism, vertical individualism, horizontal collectivism, or vertical collectivism. Data were collected from 235 American and 303 Hong Kong Chinese emerging adults who were currently in a romantic relationship. Overparenting was assessed across academic, financial, relational, health domains. Results from latent profile analysis (LPA) revealed three profiles in the U.S sample and two profiles in the Hong Kong sample. Regression analyses indicated that an "overall high overparenting" profile was associated with the lowest level of relationship efficacy in both samples. A distinct “overall medium overparenting, but high in financial and low in relational overparenting” profile emerged in the U.S. sample which was related to the most optimal relationship efficacy among American emerging adults. Additionally, moderating effects by individual cultural beliefs suggested that, in the U.S. sample, individuals with higher vertical individualism beliefs were found to be more susceptible to the negative impact of "overall high overparenting" on relationship efficacy compared to those who experienced “overall low overparenting.” Implications, future directions, and limitations were further discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: FPGA-based Accelerator Generation for Artificial Neural Networks

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Artificial Intelligence, Artificial Neural Networks, FPGA, Image Classification, Nios II, SystemVerilog

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Artificial neural networks (ANNs) are a pivotal component of highly successful modern Artificial Intelligence (AI) applications, such as OpenAI's ChatGPT. FPGA’s capabilities of parallelism and efficiency provide an opportunity to provide quicker computation of ANNs than both CPUs or GPUs, whilst consuming much less power in both in data center and edge computing environments. A custom instruction component for the Nios II soft processor and supporting software were developed to allow easy, configurable generation and deployment of high-performance ANN inference on FPGA devices. The custom instruction performs integer matrix-vector multiplications, with each column of the product computed in parallel with pipelined multiply accumulate units. Nios II embedded computer systems were created both with and without the generated custom instruction. FPGA device resource utilization and execution time were evaluated for each system when performing ANN-based image classification on the MNIST handwritten digit database. Speedups of over 300x were achieved when using the custom instruction, at the expense of higher FPGA resource utilization.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Levels Of Parallel Evolution in Sister Species of Drosophila

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Repeated evolution in biology is widespread among morphologic forms but also recognized at essentially all biological levels. Organisms achieving the same functional goal is reported at the level of simple biochemical pathways, complex tissue types, and even social behaviors. Before the advent of the sequencing revolution, studies of repeated evolution centered on morphologic data. With the power of current DNA technologies researchers are increasingly focusing on understanding how repeated forms at the phenotypic level arise at the genetic level. Most of the trait’s biologists’ study are likely continuous and polygenic in nature. Additionally, within diploid sexual organisms, these traits often could exist within populations which consist predominantly of standing genetic variation, opening the door for drift to create genetic variance dictated by history and not fitness. To investigate genetic repeatability from standing genetic variation and retain a possible insight into macroevolutionary outcomes I designed an experiment using two recently diverged species of Drosophila. To create a parallel phenotypic response, we designed a parallel divergent artificial selection experiment in D. melanogaster and D. simulans predominantly selecting on a multi-trait index of proportional length of the three major leg segments. We complimented the phenotypic experiment with population-based whole genome DNA sequencing of individuals from the initial populations and the evolved populations artificially selected for fifteen generations. An experimental design resulting in low estimates of Ne and concurrently strong selection yielded a complicated and idiosyncratic genetic response even within replicates of a species. Evolve and Resequence and convergent evolution experimental designs and null hypotheses often use an expectation that repeated genetics underlies repeated phenotypes. We suggest more skepticism that repeated phenotypes might not be the product of parallel genetic responses for complex quantitative traits..

DISS_description.DISS_title: Social media's role in addressing educational inequity: Focusing on prospective first-generation students' college exploration

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Critical EdTech, Educational inequity, Educational technology, First-generation students, Postdigital perspectives, Social media

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study explores the role of social media in addressing educational inequity, focusing on prospective first-generation students’ college exploration. The study answers two questions: (1) how do prospective first-generation students describe their social media usage related to college? (2) how do prospective first-generation students describe the role of social media in their college choice system? To achieve this goal, I employed interviews and social media diaries. Eleven high school seniors whose parents did not complete a 4-year college/university participated in the study. Social media diaries were adopted to capture participants’ daily social media usage related to college. Interviews were conducted to delve into their lived experiences in detail. I analyzed the collected data using reflexive thematic analysis. For the first research question, I examined specific platforms participants utilize: Instagram, TikTok, YouTube, Facebook, Reddit, Discord, GroupMe, and Twitter. Among them, a subreddit r/A2C (Apply to College), the only niche social media site specifically designed for college information, was used by only one participant, implying the crucial role of a knowledgeable friend. The general pattern of network engagement showed that participants remained within their existing networks rather than forming new connections via social media. Participants explored diverse topics related to college, encompassing majors, options, applications, scholarships, and transitions. For the second research question, the findings revealed that participants were exposed to college information daily. Under the overall influence of social media, however, three contradictory subthemes were identified: vicarious experience vs. not your experience, thought-provoking vs. not leading to actions, and inspiring vs. distressing. The contradictory themes indicate the complex roles of social media in addressing educational inequity. The findings showed that social media plays a beneficial role in prospective first-generation students’ college choice system, albeit with enduring boundaries and constraints. Such complex realities indicate that participants’ digital experiences are not transcending the boundaries existing in their non-digital world but rather are deeply intertwined with them, underscoring the existing structural inequities that marginalized teens are faced with. The study suggests implications for research and practice to provide better support for prospective first-generation students’ postsecondary educational opportunities.

DISS_description.DISS_title: In Defense of Longstanding Anger

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Anger, Blame, Forgiveness, Moral Psychology, Philosophy of Emotion

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This paper introduces the concept of longstanding anger and seeks to address the thought that maintaining anger indefinitely is corruptive to the character of the agent and destructive to relationships. It denies that anger is inherently harmful and argues that it plays a significant role in the moral landscape as a method of ‘valuing the valuable’ that cannot be replicated through forgiveness. The paper argues that forgiveness is not morally superior to anger, and our reasons for condemning anger often have to do with discomfort surrounding the presence of discord, rather than anger being unfitting. Anger is explored within its role as a social emotion as conditions are set out for how and when anger can reasonably be maintained indefinitely, showing how it can fittingly not diminish, even upon the death of the wrongdoer. The paper suggests that longstanding anger arises from circumstances when an unrepentant wrongdoer maintains their commitment to the wrong and can be resolved either by the wrongdoer or through recognition of the wrong by the greater social community.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Underrepresentation of Racially and Ethnically Minoritized Allied Healthcare Faculty: An Exploratory Study of Faculty Experiences and Perceptions in Colleges serving Rural Area in Florida

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Allied Healthcare Faculty, Healthcare Disparities, Minoritized Allied Healthcare Faculty, Underrepresented Racially and Ethnically Faculty

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ABSTRACT

The National Center for Education Statistics (NCES, 2022) reported that White faculty members constituted 74% of the total number of faculty, while racial and ethnically minoritized groups, including Black, Hispanic, Asian/Pacific Islander, and Native Americans, collectively comprised less than one-fourth of faculty members. Comparatively, a decade ago, NCES, (2013) illustrated similar trends, with only 21% of racially minoritized faculty showcasing negligible progress over the past 10 years. This underrepresentation extends beyond specific disciplines, suggesting a systemic issue prevalent across academia, especially in allied healthcare programs. According to Salsberg et al. (2021) study of 10 healthcare professions, there is a notable underrepresentation of Black, Hispanic, and Native Americans compared to their respective proportions in the population. The allied healthcare programs in this study include Cardiovascular Technologist, Emergency Medical Service, Diagnostic Medical Sonography, Radiographer, Occupational Therapist Assistant, and Respiratory Care. This abstract qualitative exploratory study aimed at to examine racial minority faculty experiences and perceptions of difficulties and success within allied healthcare full-time faculty in colleges serving the rural areas of Florida. Understanding the challenges faced by racially and ethnically minoritized faculty members is critical for addressing the persistent underrepresentation in allied healthcare fields (Abdul-Raheem, 2016; Allen & Garg, 2016; Kaplan et al., 2018) by identifying the challenges of underrepresentation, and effective interventions to enhance racially minoritized healthcare faculty recruitment and retention. Addressing this shortage is pivotal for fostering diversity among faculty, improving graduation outcomes for diverse allied healthcare students, enhancing cultural competence within the healthcare workforce, and ameliorating healthcare disparities in underserved rural communities. By shedding light on biases, microaggressions, and skepticism regarding qualifications, the findings from this research underscore the pervasive nature of bias within academic environments. Consequently, academia faces an urgent imperative to confront these disparities and cultivate inclusive climates where all faculty members are valued for their scholarly contributions. Initiatives focusing on mentorship, professional development, and supportive leadership emerge as pivotal pathways to empower minoritized faculty to navigate and surmount prevailing obstacles. Addressing systemic barriers and fostering diversity, equity, and inclusion are crucial for enabling all faculty members, irrespective of background, to thrive and contribute effectively to academia and healthcare (Nair & Adetayo, 2019; Poole & Brownlee, 2020; Ratledge, 2020) The implication of this study for allied healthcare is the key necessity to recruit and retain a minoritized allied healthcare faculty by promoting mentorship and a supportive network for professional development. Overcoming system biases are critical to dismantling barriers faced by a minoritized faculty member, promoting their success, and enriching the cultural variety of healthcare education and profession. Moreover, the implications of this study extend beyond academia to inform broader societal conversations about systemic racism, discrimination, and social justice. The study contributes to ongoing efforts to address disparities in various sectors, including student experiences, institutional leadership dynamics, policy frameworks, and diversity and inclusion endeavors. Effective interventions necessitate decisive leadership action bolstered by robust policy frameworks to improve healthcare disparities in resource allocation and promote equitable support structures for all faculty. Mitigating stereotypes, biases, and resource disparities while fostering supportive leadership and mentorship is crucial for creating an environment where all faculty members feel valued, supported, and empowered to succeed (Luster-Edward & Martin, 2018; Llama et al., 2019; Kelly et al., 2017; Kelly & McCann, 2014). The study's findings supported recommendations needed for further research to advance knowledge about the experiences of minoritized faculty within academia and inform evidence-based interventions to mitigate disparities and promote a sense of belonging, intentional support, and welcome. Acknowledging and addressing the challenges faced by racially and ethnically minoritized allied healthcare faculty is crucial for institutions to fulfill their mandate of providing equitable opportunities for scholarly engagement and professional advancement. Pursuing these research avenues is essential for realizing academia's standard as an inclusive and intellectually vibrant community fostering the holistic development of all academic members in higher education. The exploratory study revealed support recommendations for practice to advocate for racially and ethnically minoritized full-time faculty members. The combination of proactive leadership for an engaging support system, cultural awareness training, and professional training to identify and navigate bias for all employees, and an intentional mentorship program to encourage collaboration and a supportive network is essential for minoritized healthcare faculty members to succeed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BUILD YOUR OWN LIVING SPACE: ARCHITECTURE AND THE POLITICIZED BODY IN THE WORK OF LYGIA CLARK

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ABSTRACT

In modernist and contemporary art history, abstract art has long been associated with issues surrounding autonomy and breaks with figurative art. Scholarship surrounding the development of abstract art in Brazil has tended to focus on those connections in addition to its receptions by local art critics Ferreira Gullar and Mário Pedrosa and trajectories of European movements in abstract art, namely De Stijl, neoplasticism, and concrete art. While these readings have recognized important lineages for abstraction contextualized within the visual arts, the intersection between abstraction in Brazil and architecture remains understudied in comparison. I examine the work of Brazilian postwar and contemporary artist Lygia Clark (1920–1988) to show how her work is just at home in fields of painting and sculpture as it is in disciplines of architecture and design. By forging these connections outside of the visual arts, Brazilian abstract art in the postwar period became a political cultural tool of modern architecture and space, as well as an outlet for civilians to contribute to Brazil’s status as a growing modern nation by constructing modernist spaces. Through formal and social art historical analysis of the work of Lygia Clark, this dissertation revises histories of abstraction in postwar Brazilian art to better account for understudied contexts of architecture, public space, and the built environment. Clark is best known for her interactive geometric Bicho (Critter; 1960–1966) sculptures and association with the neoconcrete group (1959–1961), the Brazilian artistic avant-garde recognized for its participatory artwork. Much like the histories of abstract art to which she belonged, namely concrete and neoconcrete art, her contributions are often tied to painting and sculpture, despite her career-long engagement with architecture. In response to this historiographic problem, this dissertation addresses Clark’s sustained work in and engagement of architecture such as her little-known works, including her ink drawing of a street scene from 1948 and a mural mosaic from 1951, still extant in Rio. Examination of her training and collaboration with landscape designers and architects reveals her synthetic approach to the arts, which facilitates new debates about integrative approaches to the arts that tend to focus on De Stijl and the Bauhaus. Chapter Two, “Staircases, Interiors, and Studies of Space: The Early Works, 1948–1953,” focuses on the earliest and often overlooked stage of Clark’s career—where her architectural engagement began—prior to her affiliation with concretism with the Grupo Frente in the mid-1950s. Chapter Three, “Clark’s Models of Houses and Architectural Interiors: Displays of Modernist Living,” provides the first in-depth study of Clark’s small-scale models of homes from 1955 to 1964, of which she made six. This chapter argues that Clark re-envisioned neoconcrete art—a form of abstract art—as manipulatable architectural models that engaged with local and global trends of architecture and provided opportunities for viewers to construct home layouts. Chapter Four, “’Walking Along:’ Path-Making as Spatial and Subversive Interventions,” analyzes Clark’s sculptural action and abstract sculptures in politicized contexts of Brazil. Fostering interventionist spatial imaginaries, Caminhando (Walking; 1963), and Trepante (Climber; 1965), and Trepante e caixa (Climber and Box; 1964), use “the winding path” as a strategy to subvert authority by questioning spatial and architectural boundaries of the built environment. Chapter Five, “Clark’s Articulation of Architectural and Environmental Imaginaries,” examines the sculptural objects, entitled Caixas de fósforos (Matchboxes, 1964) and Arquitetura fantástica bichos (Fantastic Architecture Critters; 1963), the installation, entitled A casa é o corpo: penetração, ovulação, germinação, expulsão (The House is the Body: Penetration, Ovulation, Germination, Expulsion; 1968), and propositions, entitled Arquitetura Biológica II (Biologic Architecture II; 1969) and Estruturas vivas (Live Structures; 1969) as case studies. As articulations of anti-authoritarian architectural and environmental imaginaries in varying degrees, these sculptural objects, installations, and propositions demonstrate how space and structure provided outlets to challenge authority and question the possibilities of architecture, while also intensifying environments and feelings associated with political repression under Brazil’s military dictatorship. Using formal and social art historical analysis, supported by extensive archival and field research conducted in Brazil, Argentina, England, and the United States, this dissertation addresses existing gaps between visual art and architecture in the field of art history, particularly in histories of abstract art. Rather than situating Clark’s work mainly in relation to histories of neoconcrete art and its broader legacies of painting and sculpture, I have instead mapped out a new trajectory for her practice based on architecture and urbanism as politicized sites of modernism in and out of Brazil in the postwar decades. In doing so, this project also formulates a new term in relation to Clark, the “artist-architect,” a helpful designation for artists who straddle the line between the visual arts and the built environment. This term can encourage global intersections across potentially disparate areas and periods. Analyzing works of “artist-architects” across media can also present experimental grounds for transgressive practices of resistance and self-expression.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Instrumental Choice in Policy Design: Policy Innovation, Implementation, and Citizen Participation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation explores theoretical mechanisms associated with the adoption and implementation of policy instruments. The first paper addresses the impact of past policy choices on the adoption of vaping policy instruments in the United States, specifically investigating how states with strong anti-smoking policies are more likely to adopt vaping control policy instruments. This suggests that compatibility with past policies plays a key role in the adoption of policy tools. On the other hand, the second and third papers focus on the effectiveness of policy instruments in the context of citizen participation. They examine how citizen participation affects government efficiency and responsiveness, and how participation costs influence the level of citizen involvement, respectively. These three studies make an important contribution to theories of policy instruments, particularly in understanding the adoption and implementation of policy tools, and their impact on the policy process and citizen engagement.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE ROLE OF INDIVIDUAL DIFFERENCES AND EFFECT OF TASK REPETITION WITH WRITTEN CORRECTIVE FEEDBACK IN L2 WRITING DEVELOPMENT

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Individual differences, L2 writing anxiety, L2 writing motivation, task repetition, working memory, written corrective feedback

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Research on Task Based Language Teaching (TBLT), and learning has developed significantly in recent years. As a result of the popularity of TBLT, numerous studies in second language acquisition (SLA) have explored the effect of task repetition on L2 performance. However, while previous task repetition studies mainly focused on the effects of repeating the same task on the complexity, accuracy, and fluency (CAF) of oral language production, limited research has examined the influence of different types of task repetition on learners’ written production. Moreover, although written corrective feedback has been extensively investigated in SLA, the synergy effect between task repetition and written corrective feedback in shaping the quality of individual writing task output has not received adequate attention. Notably, no study has yet compared the influence of two types of task repetition (identical repetition and procedural repetition), by providing two distinct types of feedback—direct feedback and metalinguistic feedback, on written production for upper-intermediate adult EFL learners. To address this research gap, the current study investigated the effect of task repetition and two types of feedback on the accuracy of students’ written task performance. Additionally, recognizing the growing importance of individual differences (ID) in SLA, this study investigated the role of individual differences constructs such as working memory capacity, L2 writing anxiety, and L2 writing motivation on L2 learners' written production. Additionally, the level of motivation and anxiety to complete learning tasks was identified as another important factor contributing to individual variation (Kormos & Wilby, 2019). Task motivation is a complex construct influenced by various contingencies associated with multiple actional contexts, making it more intricate than a simple composite of general and state motivation (Dornyei, 2002, 2005). Therefore, beyond general L2 writing motivation and L2 anxiety, the study also examined task-specific anxiety and motivation, which are transitory, to determine whether their levels change over time during task performance. Eighty adult Korean EFL learners participated in four intact classes randomly assigned to four treatment groups: identical repetition + direct feedback, identical repetition + metalinguistic feedback, procedural repetition + direct feedback, and procedural repetition + metalinguistic feedback. A pretest and posttest were employed. The two identical repetition groups repeated the same writing procedure with the same picture description, while two procedural repetition groups repeated the same writing procedure with different picture descriptions. Two types of feedback (direct and metalinguistic) were provided for each task repetition condition. To measure learners’ writing development, overall accuracy and accuracy on three target structures (past tense, articles, and prepositions) were assessed. L2 writing motivation and L2 writing anxiety were measured before the treatment sessions began to explore learners’ general orientation of motivation and anxiety toward L2 writing learning. However, task motivation and task anxiety were measured after they performed writing tasks each week as outcome measurers to observe their patterns. Questionnaires were used for all these four constructs, Lastly, a reading span test (RSPAN) was used for the working memory test. Results from ANCOVA indicated that the procedural task repetition groups significantly outperformed the two identical task repetition groups in overall accuracy and past tense accuracy. Regarding the role of individual differences in working memory, motivation, and anxiety, multiple regressions revealed distinct results based on treatments under each group. For both procedural task repetitions, anxiety was a positive predictor, while working memory was a negative predictor. In contrast to the two procedural task repetitions, anxiety was a negative predictor for both identical task repetition groups. Lastly, two-way repeated measure ANOVA results showed distinct motivational patterns after writing between the two task repetition groups. The two procedural task repetition groups increased their motivation, whereas the two identical task repetition groups decreased task motivation over time. Nevertheless, repeating either content or procedures appeared to alleviate learners’ task-specific anxiety in writing tasks. The findings further our understanding of the language learners’ perceived motivational and emotional factors influenced by task implementation and instructional strategies in the language learning context. These findings provide valuable insights into L2 pedagogy.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Trumpet Mastery in the Digital Realm: Selective DAWs as Tools for Practice

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise offers a diverse approach to practicing with Digital Audio Workstations (DAWs). For many musicians, DAWs are indispensable tools for recording professional projects. Many resources within DAWs allow the musician to discern fluctuations through a detailed analysis, as discussed in this treatise. The pieces chosen to be practiced and examined with the integration of DAWs include three solo pieces for trumpet and piano and three orchestral pieces. Digital Audio Workstations (DAWs) are software applications designed to produce, modify, and capture audio files. They serve different purposes, such as professional music productions and personal projects. The applications offer a diverse approach to assessing a musician’s performance by analyzing their audio using a range of effects integrated into the software. When producing a high-quality recording using DAWs, one can uncover aspects of trumpet playing that would otherwise go unnoticed during a practice session.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INVENTIVE RESPONSE: HOW TEACHERS’ RESPONSES TO STUDENTS’ WRITING PROMPT INVENTION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: composition, first-year composition, formative feedback, invention, response, writing

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This illustrative case study investigates teachers’ formative written responses to students’ writing, and how those responses could be inventive for students’ future composing practices. It engages with the concept of “invention” from a rhetoric/composition standpoint in order to ask: To what extent do different formative written responses on student writing function inventively? What are students’ perceptions of instructors’ written responses on their papers? How can these written responses prompt students to respond inventively in future writing and revisions? There is a general lack of writing assessment or response literature engaging explicitly with invention, even though much of it touches on relevant invention-related concepts, like “topoi” or “heuristic” (Connors, Lunsford 209; Melzer). This research critically considers that literature and makes a case for inventive response, because students’ generativity in their writing could be compatible with the growth-oriented characteristics of formative feedback. The study uses existing scholarship alongside the research questions to inductively analyze three document-based, semi-structured interviews with student writers at Florida State University. Through answering narrative inquiry-based and descriptive questions, the interviewees indicated generativity in response by perceiving teachers’ feedback as conversational, interpretive, and contextually-influenced. Further, the interviews compellingly implied that positive and question-based teacher comments led students to invent new writing ideas, new writing strategies, and new writing confidence. Based on these findings, the study concludes by pointing to connections for future research, and by providing practical suggestions for teachers to implement more inventive response.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ESSAYS ON THE EFFECTS OF THE INSTITUTIONAL LOGICS OF SOCIAL IMPACT ACCELERATORS ON HYBRID VENTURE FIRM PERFORMANCE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Accelerators, Hybrid Firms, Institutional Logics, Social Entrepreneurship

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation discusses hybrid venture firm performance. The predictors include the complementary and competitive institutional logics of social impact accelerators (SIAs) and hybrid ventures, as well as country-level institutional indicators and founder human capital. In Essay 1, I argue that SIA logics shape hybrid ventures’ performance in different ways and that these effects are moderated by both firm logics and founder human capital. In Essay 2, I argue that the effects of the SIA logics not only differ, but also depend on aspects of the institutional environment, specifically the level of managerial discretion and social assistance in countries. Together, the results suggest that the effects of participating in SIAs are contingent upon the institutional-, SIA-, firm-, and entrepreneurial-level characteristics.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Influencing Intermolecular Interactions between Metal-Oxide Bound Molecules Via Post-Fabrication Atomic Layer Deposition

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Intermolecular interactions of metal-oxide bound molecules can have a substantial impact on the electrochemical and photophysical processes of molecules and their subsequent performances as catalysts, sensors, or electron injectors in solar energy conversion. Inherent to the metal oxide-organic molecule interface is the close proximity of molecules, which can facilitate interactions and processes including aggregation, triplet-triplet annihilation, excimer formation, singlet fission, dimerization, and more. These processes can be either advantageous or disadvantageous for a given application, which makes the intentional formation or inhibition of such interactions critical. We have made efforts to understand the role of post-loading atomic layer deposition (ALD) on ZrO2-bound molecules, in which the precursor for an inert metal oxide (Al2O3) reacts with the ZrO2 surface. Both decreased surface loading density of molecules and an increasing number of ALD overlayers resulted in a decrease in excimer formation. However, photoluminescent and femtosecond transient absorption measurements were still dominated by excimer features. These results suggest that ALD may provide a post-surface loading means of influencing such intermolecular interactions. Instead of reacting solely with the ZrO¬¬2 surface, our current research investigates the effects of ALD directly reacting with functionalized, metal-oxide bound molecules.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Symmetry without Skepticism: Compromising with Rosen on Moral Ignorance and Responsibility

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Blame, Moral ignorance, Moral responsibility, Quality of will, Skepticism, Symmetry thesis

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Gideon Rosen famously defends a novel skeptical conclusion about moral responsibility, arguing that we are never warranted in confidently judging that any particular someone X is morally blameworthy for some particular action A. Alternative accounts might seem preferable to Rosen’s, at least on the grounds that they are more consistent with our current blaming practices. However, Rosen’s opponents tend to avoid his conclusion by advocating what Alvarez and Littlejohn call the “asymmetry thesis,” essentially the thesis that non-normative ignorance is excused in a different way than moral ignorance. In doing so, they reject a crucial premise in Rosen’s argument. I argue that one needn’t give up what I will call Rosen’s “symmetry thesis” in order to avoid his ultimate conclusion. I first motivate a reason for wanting to preserve symmetry by detailing an objection to symmetry-denying quality-of-will views. I then attack the final premise in Rosen’s skeptical argument, essentially relying on plausible assumptions about standards of justification and the general commonplace of akratic action.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TOWARDS QUANTUM-SECURE BLOCKCHAIN: ARCHITECTURAL DESIGNS AND EVALUATIONS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Blockchain security, Cryptographic algorithms, Ethereum and Hyperledger Besu, Post-quantum cryptography, Quantum Computing Threats, Quantum-resistant blockchain

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The adoption of quantum computing presents a considerable risk to the security of traditionalcryptographic methods, including those used in current blockchain technologies. Quantum algo- rithms, especially Shor’s and Grover’s, can efficiently solve problems that classical cryptographic algorithms rely on for security, rendering them vulnerable to attacks. This thesis explores the creation of quantum-resistant blockchain platforms to address this critical issue. The research begins with a comprehensive study of the prevailing blockchain infrastructure and the potential vulnerabilities posed by quantum computing, with a particular focus on con- sensus algorithms and cryptographic primitives. Various post-quantum cryptographic approaches, including lattice-based cryptography and quantum-safe digital signatures, are investigated for their suitability in securing blockchain systems against quantum threats. The thesis presents an original contribution in the form of a novel quantum-safe blockchain protocol that utilizes advanced cryptographic techniques to provide robust security in the quantum era. The proposed protocol is rigorously analyzed and evaluated for its effectiveness in various applications, including cryptocurrency, healthcare, tokenization and real world assets. The findings of this research underscore the urgent need for transitioning to quantum-resistant blockchain systems. The thesis offers a practical framework and guidelines for designing and im- plementing secure quantum-resistant blockchain architectures, taking into account the challenges and considerations involved in such a transition. By addressing the imminent threat of quantum computing to blockchain security, this research aims to forge resilient and forward-looking blockchain systems. The outcomes of this thesis have sig- nificant implications for ensuring the continued viability, security, and trustworthiness of blockchain technology against the advancements in quantum computing.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Faculty Motivations for Embedding Librarians in Undergraduate Courses at Sun Sand State College

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: community college, embedded librarian

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Community colleges are institutions that provide access to higher education to anyone with a high school diploma or GED (Kim & Dolan, 2015). The student body is highly diverse and may not be prepared for academic coursework (Cohen et al., 2014). These challenges may be supplemented through embedding services directly into college courses. The focus of this study is specifically on embedding librarians in undergraduate courses that have a research component. For students that have been out of school for a while, or just struggled with research while in high school, an embedded librarian might be a resource that aids in student success. In order to understand what motivates a faculty member to embed, or not embed, a librarian in their courses, I conducted an exploratory qualitative case study at a single institution in the southeastern United States. Interviews were conducted with nine full-time faculty members from this institution. They reflected a variety of campuses, departments, and faculty static levels. I then utilized In Vivo coding for first cycle coding and focused coding for second cycle coding. As a result of the study, I found some common understanding of roles and tasks that embedded librarians can have in college courses; however, I also discovered some underlying emotional reactions to embedding that ranged from excitement to worry. It seems that there is some room for development when explaining what embedded librarians should do, and what embedded librarians should not do. Much of this knowledge comes about through relationships development, and ongoing communication, between the embedded librarian and the faculty member.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN IMMIGRANT PARADOX IN THE BLACK BOX? EVALUATING IN-PRISON MALADAPTIVE BEHAVIORS AMONG FOREIGN- AND NATIVE-BORN PERSONS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: heterogeneity, immigrant paradox, incarceration, mental health, prison, prison misconduct

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The U.S. regularly incarcerates its residents, where time spent behind bars is overwhelmingly negative (Massoglia, 2008a; Rose & Clear, 1998). But not all persons have an equal chance of incarceration. State and federal policies target ethnically heterogenous neighborhoods in ways that lead to residents’ disparate surveillance, arrest, and incarceration, even while research demonstrates that such policies are damaging (Menjívar & Abrego, 2012; Peterson & Krivo, 2010). Contrary to traditional criminological theory, evidence suggests that cultural diversity may work to keep individuals and their communities safer (Wright & Rodriguez, 2014). Indeed, an immigrant paradox has been found, where immigrants are less likely to commit violence, use substances, or offend, though they are more often exposed to criminogenic environments (Salas-Wright et al., 2016).Criminological literature takes this protective effect of diversity for granted, neglecting to unpack the immigrant paradox. It is unknown whether the immigrant paradox extends to prison—where foreign-born persons are less likely to exhibit mental health crises or engage in misconduct—or if incarceration will undo their resilience. Yet effective correctional policy must be sensitive to the diversity of those incarcerated. Guided by theory and research on the immigrant paradox, prison misconduct, and mental health behind bars, the goal of this study is to examine whether incarcerated native- and foreign-born persons vary in the number and kinds of misconducts they engage in and/or mental health crises they experience. Further, this dissertation examines whether relationships vary by sources of heterogeneity within the immigrant group, including sending country, race, and detainer status. To solve these research puzzles, this study asks three primary research questions. First, do incarcerated immigrants differ from non-immigrants in their involvement in prison misconduct? Second, do incarcerated immigrants differ from non-immigrants in their likelihood of experiencing an in-prison mental health crisis? Third, and finally, do incarcerated immigrants who are subject to deportation differ from those who are not in their involvement in prison misconduct or experience of a mental health crisis? Data from administrative records on the full population of incarcerated adults housed in a state prison in the western U.S. between 2010 and 2020 (N=58,289) are used. Over 13% (N=7,697) of individuals come from over 120 different countries, not including the U.S. or its territories. Data trace all administrative details of individuals’ in-prison experiences from intake to release. This rich information, coupled with the growing diversity of this western state, render this system ideal for advancing theory and research on the bounds of the immigrant paradox. Analyses find support for an in-prison immigrant paradox, but they further reveal that the effect of immigrant status varies by race. That is, incarcerated immigrants are expected to engage in fewer counts and types of misconduct than their non-immigrant counterparts and are less likely to experience in-prison mental health crises. But patterns differ for property misconduct and are not uniform across racially diverse individuals. Instead, the immigrant paradox is pronounced among Latinx persons, where these individuals are less likely to engage in most types of prison infractions and have lower odds of mental health crises compared to those of other races. Alternatively, White immigrants more often experience mental health crises behind bars relative to immigrants of color. These differences signify that the protective factors that drive the immigrant paradox may not be readily available to all foreign-born persons, that diverse persons present with diverse in-prison needs, and that prior experience with hardship may be one reason that immigrants are resilient to adversity. Finally, incarcerated immigrants who face deportation only slightly differ from those who do not in their involvement in misconduct or their experience of mental health crises. While immigrants with detainers were less likely to engage in drug misconduct or experience in-prison mental health crises than those without, findings did not significantly differ by detainer status for overall misconduct or any other infraction type. As such, incarcerated immigrants may already anticipate deportation, and certain characteristics about immigrants who receive detainers may matter more than the threat of deportation itself. Yet further investigation of the effect of deportation is needed. Broadly, the substantive effect of the immigrant paradox is diminished in a prison setting and is conditioned by heterogeneous statuses of immigrants, but it is not erased. Treating immigrants harshly for fear that they pose a dangerous criminal threat is unfounded and is only successful in perpetuating legal violence against them. While additional work is needed to further unpack the immigrant paradox in incarcerated settings, we must be mindful of clumsy, overly punitive social policies that harm foreign-born populations.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Role of Semiconducting Electronic Structure on Static and Transient Plasmonic Properties

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: nanocrystals, plasmonics, semiconductors, spectroscopy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The field of plasmonics as a whole is gathering widespread interest due to their wide range of applications and new technology advancements because of their enhancement of light-matter interactions. Although scientists have largely used noble metals plasmonic metals such as gold, silver, or aluminum, the growing field of plasmonic semiconductor nanocrystals (PSNCs) still require extensive research towards how the semiconducting electronic structure impacts relevant properties such as charge carrier mobility, conductivity, and near field enhancement. This work focuses on how the host nanocrystal density of states directly impacts and modifies the plasmonic properties of interest in both the static and ultrafast transient time regimes. Chapter 1 introduces the concept of plasmons starting from the simple harmonic oscillator model leading to the free electron model's critical relationship for plasmon frequency, carrier density, and carrier effective mass. From there, the concept of band theory is introduced, and the interactions of charge carrier quasiparticles with the semiconducting electronic structure are outlined and discussed. Chapter 2 introduces the intermediate band semiconductor, Cu5FeS4, where magnetic circular dichroism is used to analyze the carrier effective mass as a function of applied magnetic field. Chapter 3 introduces one of the highest energy PSNCs in literature to date, WO3-x, where transient absorption relaxation dynamics are deconvoluted for plasmon and optical band gap excited regimes. Chapter 4 turns to CuxFeS4 (x=3,5,7), where the ratio of Cu:Fe is shown to modulate the hole-phonon and phonon-phonon transient absorption relaxation rates correlated with carrier effective mass and plasmon damping frequency respectively. Overall, this thesis showcases that static plasmon properties correlate well with transient plasmonic properties, where experiments such as magnetic circular dichroism and transient absorption are effective tools for developing the correlations needed for predicting desired plasmonic properties when designing novel PSNCs for future applications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NAVIGATING SYSTEMIC BARRIERS AND CULTIVATING SEEDS OF CHANGE: LATINA PRESERVICE TEACHERS' JOURNEYS INTO STEM EDUCATION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Latinidad, Latinx, preservice teachers of color, STEM education, teacher education, teacher learning

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Teachers of Color bring valuable assets into the classroom and play a vital role in empowering marginalized students (Brown, 2014; Dee, 2004), however these teachers remain severely underrepresented, especially in STEM fields (Irwin, 2022, 2023; NCES, 2020). Meanwhile, preservice teachers (PSTs) of Color often confront marginalization including lack of representation, isolation, and pressures to assimilate in teacher education programs situated in historically white institutions (HWIs) (Gist, 2017; Haddix, 2010; Hayes & Fasching-Varner, 2015). More specifically, Latina STEM PSTs encounter gender stereotypes, unwelcoming climates, and assumptions questioning their abilities (McGee, 2020; Ong et al., 2018). Understanding the barriers that these Latinas face, alongside their sources of resilience and resistance, can inform policies and curriculum to better support minoritized teacher candidates (Kohli, 2021). As such, the central question guiding this study asks: What are the experiences of three Latina STEM preservice teachers at a historically white institution (HWI)?Using frameworks of Latinidad, LatCrit theory (Solórzano & Yosso, 2001), and transformational resistance (Solórzano & Bernal, 2001), this study examines Latinas’ intersectional barriers and resilience in white-dominated contexts of STEM and teacher education. Through two semi-structured interviews with each PST, aimed at eliciting their narratives on motivations and experiences in their program, I analyze using qualitative methods how these PSTs navigated systemic inequities and explore their resistance to systemic oppression (Hannegan-Martinez et al., 2022; Solórzano & Yosso, 2001). Findings revealed four key patterns in Latina PSTs’ journeys: (1) gendered and racialized microaggressions which affected their emotional and psychological wellbeing; (2) stark underrepresentation in STEM courses heightening isolation and self-doubt; (3) inspiration and motivation from personal experiences to pursue teaching of marginalized students, and (4) advocacy for engagement with sociopolitical issues affecting communities of Color within teacher preparation programs. Despite barriers imposed by dominant structures, the Latina PSTs displayed transformational resistance as they leveraged wisdom from lived experiences to inform their aspiration to teach (Yosso, 2005). Findings center the participants’ knowledge and lived experiences to inform teacher preparation practices in ways that could better support other Latina PSTs in STEM. This study makes an important contribution by applying LatCrit frameworks to elucidate Latinas’ diverse lived experiences at the intersection of race, gender, and class (Chavez-Moreno, 2023) and by positioning Latin* identities as assets for STEM teaching (Fierros & Delgado Bernal, 2016). Additionally, the study highlights the ongoing resilience and resistance of Latina STEM educators against layered oppression (Hannegan-Martinez et al., 2022). More broadly, the study underscores the urgent need for greater inclusiveness, representation, and cultural responsiveness in teacher education. This includes fostering spaces for minoritized PSTs to share their counterstories, openly discuss oppression, and nurture critical consciousness towards social justice (Kohli, 2021; McGee, 2021; Solórzano & Yosso, 2002).

DISS_description.DISS_title: AEROBIC EXERCISE-MEDIATED PREVENTION AGAINST GLUCOCORTICOID MYOPATHY IN AGED SKELETAL MUSCLE

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Older adults are vulnerable to glucocorticoid-induced muscle atrophy and weakness, with sex potentially influencing susceptibility to those effects. Aerobic exercise can reduce glucocorticoid-induced muscle atrophy in young rodents. However, it is unknown whether aerobic exercise can antagonize glucocorticoid myopathic features in aged muscle. The objectives of this study were to define the extent to which sex influences the development of glucocorticoid myopathy in aged muscle, and to determine the extent to which moderate intensity aerobic exercise training protects against development of myopathy. 24-month-old female (n=30) and male (n=33) mice were randomized to either sedentary or aerobic exercise groups. Within their respective groups, mice were randomized to either daily treatment with injections of dexamethasone (DEX) or saline. Following treatments, the contractile properties of the triceps surae complex were assessed in situ. DEX marginally lowered muscle mass and soluble protein content in both sexes, which was attenuated by aerobic exercise only in females. DEX-treated females expressed greater sub-tetanic contractile properties in a sex-specific manner, which were not influenced by aerobic exercise. DEX increased muscle fatigue in both sexes, but aerobic exercise prevented the fatigue induction only in females. The sex-specific differences to muscle function in response to DEX treatment coincided with sex-specific changes to the contents of protein related to calcium handling, mitochondrial quality control, and glucocorticoid receptor in muscle. These findings define several important sexually dimorphic changes to aged skeletal muscle physiology in response to glucocorticoid treatment and define the capacity of short-term aerobic exercise to protect against those changes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPRESSION REGULATION OF THE PHOSPHOLIPASE A2 GENE FAMILY IN COTTONMOUTH SNAKES (AGKISTRODON PISCIVORUS)

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The genetic mechanisms that regulate transformation of genetic material from genotype tophenotype influence evolutionary response to environmental change and promote species diversity. Identifying molecular regulatory mechanisms that affect gene expression is challenging for researchers because they are complex, highly variable, and affect nearly every phase of gene expression. Venom provides an ideal system for studying adaptive evolution as it is a complex phenotype used for prey capture and defense that is subject to strong selective pressures. Snake venom in particular appears to have arisen through rapid evolution, resulting in a conserved set of toxin gene families that are expressed at highly diverse rates across a wide range of taxa. The venom secretion is the result of a fairly straightforward genotype-to-phenotype map, which allows researchers to study expression at various points along the central dogma. To further investigate the evolution of venom gene expression, in Chapter 1 we characterized the venom profile of the Cottonmouth Snake (Agkistrodon piscivorus). We found that across their geographic range, A. piscivorus venom expression consists primarily of proteins in the Phospholipase A2 (PLA2) gene family. In total, we identified nine complete PLA2s tandemly arrayed in the A. piscivorus genome of a female snake collected from the Apalachicola National Forest (ANF) in north Florida, which is more than in any previously characterized North American pit viper. The array contains four expressed PLA2s, one copy of the basic PLA2-K and three copies of the acidic PLA2-A that appear to be the result of gene duplication. This PLA2 region is consistent with the PLA2 arrays of previously annotated hemorrhagic-type rattlesnakes, which lack the characteristic heterodimeric PLA2s in neurotoxic rattlesnake venoms. We found that expression of the four toxin PLA2s varied among individual A. piscivorus, but in all cases PLA2-K was expressed most highly in the venom gland. In Chapter 2, we aimed to determine whether expression variation of the four toxin PLA2s were differentially expressed among the sampled individuals. We collected snakes from the three recognized subspecies of A. piscivorus : The Florida Cottonmouth (A. p. conanti), the Western Cottonmouth (A. p. leucostoma), and the Eastern Cottonmouth (A. p. piscivorus) and performed RNA-sequencing to quantify venom gland expression. We found that only one copy of the acidic PLA2-A1c was differentially expressed between Florida (A. p. conanti) and Continental (A. p. leucostoma and A. p. piscivorus) individuals. This differential expression seemed largely driven by relatively high expression of PLA2-A1c in half of the sampled Florida individuals. Despite the high conservation of the PLA2s gene array across sampled individuals, we did find that this expression variation may be driven by sequence variation found only in the three more high-expression Florida individuals. We identified one synonymous single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the coding region of Exon 2 of PLA2-A1c that was only present in these individuals. We believe that this SNP could be in linkage with regulatory elements that control PLA2 expression, and thus may explain the increased relative expression. In addition to differential expression among individuals, we all found that PLA2 paralogs are expressed at varying amount within a given individual. In Chapter 3, we aimed to characterize the genomic architecture that may regulate expression of the PLA2 gene family in A. piscivorus. To achieve this, we used ATAC-sequencing of two individuals collected from North Florida (ANF) to characterize accessible chromatin and H3K27ac CUT&RUN sequencing of one individual collected from North Florida (ANF) to identify regions containing active enhancers. We found several regions of interest that may regulate PLA2 expression in A. piscivorus, including open chromatin regions just upstream of each of the four expressed PLA2s that likely contain promoters and large regions of open chromatin downstream of the four expressed PLA2s. We also found three distinct CUT&RUN sequencing peaks associated with active enhancers located between each PLA2-A and their associated unexpressed PLA2-C. These regions are homologous to the third exon of the non-venom expressed PLA2-E, which also shares the associated peak. We used Sequence Capture sequencing reads from 147 individual A. piscivorus to determine whether sequence variation in the identified enhancer and promoter peaks could contribute to PLA2 paralog expression. However, we found that these regions were highly conserved among sampled individuals. Therefore, future works should further investigate the identified peak regions to determine what regulatory elements may be present and contribute to PLA2-expression.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Screening for Balance: The Relationship between Overparenting, Parental Autonomy Control, Low Self-Efficacy, and Social Media Addiction among Emerging Adults

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: emerging adults, overparenting, social media addiction

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Over the recent years, social media use has become increasingly prevalent among American adults. While the impact of the rise of social media platforms is ubiquitous, researchers revealed that emerging adults (individuals between 18 and 29 years of age) are more vulnerable to social media addiction than other populations. Theories and research have suggested overparenting as a potential predictor for emerging adults’ problematic technology use. Specifically, the theory of emerging adulthood and self-determination theory offer explanations for the detrimental effects of overparenting behavior in the lives of emerging adults, as they seek autonomy and independence at this stage. Further, studies have linked overparenting to emerging adults’ internet addiction, as well as game and social media addictive behaviors. Nevertheless, the underlying mechanisms through which overparenting impacts social media addiction remain understudied in the literature. Therefore, the present study examined the association between overparenting and social media addiction among a sample of emerging adults. Parental autonomy control and low self-efficacy were also assessed as potential mediators for this association. College students (N = 545) completed surveys at three time points over 12 weeks. Structural equation modeling suggested that overparenting was positively related to social media addiction via higher levels of parental autonomy control and lower levels of self-efficacy. Future directions and implications of the present study were provided.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Il Divino Musicista: Music and Sound in Dante's "Commedia"

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Affect, Casella, Dante, Music, Music Therapy, Sound Studies

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: As one of the most widely printed and read texts in the world, Dante Alighieri’s Commedia has firmly established its place in the global literary canon. Written between 1308 and 1320, the Commedia quickly became a widely disseminated and studied text. The first lectura dantis, or public readings and accompanying lectures about the poem by the great Giovanni Boccaccio, were held mere years after Dante’s death, and study of the poem has continued for the past 700 years. Its enduring cultural and linguistic value for the Italian people have solidified Dante as a godlike figure in Italian history. The study of diegetic sound and music in the poem, however, has largely been overlooked or ignored, with a few exceptions. This thesis contributes to scholarship on the music and sound in Dante’s Commedia, responds to existing Dante scholars such as Francesco Ciabattoni and sound studies scholars such as R. Murray Schafer and Aimée Boutin, and offers a collection of my thoughts and interpretations on the subject. I argue that Dante crafted an intentional sonic design into the fabric of the poem, and that through analysis of the design we are able to learn more about both the poem and poet. Using the text as an archive of sonic memory that tells the reader significant and culturally relevant information about the city of Florence and its surrounding area in the Middle Ages, I seek to develop a new methodology through which word and music scholars may “listen in” to the past through literature. I also engage with protopsychomusicology and the affective power of music through the ears of Dante. Scenes such as the interaction with the musician Casella in Purgatorio 2 suggest the use of music in an intentionally comforting or healing manner. Although sparse and uncertain, in biographical accounts scholars speculate that Dante may have had epilepsy (or a similar condition), and through the poem I argue that he used music in a therapeutic manner to treat his own condition, similarly to modern medical music therapy. Finally, I look at the sonic remnants of the past in the poem and consider how Dante used audible memory to recall and relate to past literary voices and sought to establish a cultural epic through sonic memory. Dante adopted and adapted elements of epic throughout his work in order to secure his place in literary history, and through this I argue for the relevance of sound in this channel of study. Through this thesis I open avenues for future exploration of the sonic design of the Commedia and establish new ideas with which future Dante and sound studies scholars may approach this and other similar texts.

DISS_description.DISS_title: An Exploration of the Experiences of First-Generation Students at a Private, Business-Focused University

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This qualitative case study explored the experiences of first-generation students with varying levels of support at Bentley University, a private, business-focused university in the Northeast. Data was collected through semi-structured interviews with 11 first-generation students that represented different ethnic/racial backgrounds, gender identities, class standing, and majors. The study found that while first-generation students of color had established supportive communities on campus, they often struggled with feelings of inadequacy in foundational business courses. Participants also had challenges accessing high impact practices, such as internships and studying abroad. Bentley prides itself on providing broad opportunities for students, including international education and career development, so these first-generation student experiences do not align with the university’s efforts to support all students.

DISS_description.DISS_title: IMPROVING LOCAL GOVERNMENT CAPACITIES FOR INTERLOCAL COLLABORATIONS AND CITIZEN-GOVERNMENT INTERACTIONS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation contributes to the intersection of public administration, public policy, and public management by exploring avenues to enhance local government capacities for interlocal collaborations and citizen-government interactions. The first study investigates the joint influence of yardstick competition and managerial stability on bolstering interlocal collaborations for public service delivery, utilizing panel data from municipal governments in Florida for empirical testing. Regarding citizen-government interactions, the second paper focuses on public assessments of local government sustainability strategies and performance. Survey experiment results reveal that citizens exhibit distinct preferences regarding sustainability strategies contingent upon sustainability performance conditions, with these preferences further diverging across different subgroups. Furthermore, the third paper examines how administrative burden reductions by local governments can improve the permitting efficiency of energy infrastructure projects for applicants. The findings suggest that reducing eligibility cost can expedite permitting time for applicants in the short term, especially within low-income and high-minority communities, while reducing collaboration cost can accelerate the application process in the long run, particularly across non low-income and low-minority communities.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Charting New Waters: Navigating Intersectional Identities in STEM — A Focus on Asian International Women

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study illuminates the nuanced experiences of Asian international women students in Computer and Mathematical Sciences, and Engineering doctoral programs in the United States, a domain historically shaped by male dominance, White supremacy, and Western ideologies. While existing literature on gender and racial-ethnic disparities in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math has utilized an intersectionality framework, this investigation reveals the particular ways in which AIS women's identities are constructed and negotiated within these spaces.

Employing narrative inquiries and a counter-storytelling approach, the research uncovers the intersectionality of race, foreign status, and gender identity among these scholars, demonstrating how these dimensions interact uniquely for AIS women. Key findings reveal a pronounced de-emphasis of racial identity in favor of a strong STEM identity, a strategic response to systemic marginalization and racial challenges. This prioritization reflects a culturally embedded respect for meritocracy and academic achievement, reshaped in the U.S. context by their experiences of racialization and othering.The study also highlights the salient gender identity of AIS women, exacerbated by the masculine culture of CME fields. Despite the external assumption of privilege due to their Asian and international status, these women confront significant gender stereotypes and discrimination. Their strong STEM identity, fostered through resilience and the pursuit of academic and professional excellence, emerges as a counter to traditional gender norms and a mechanism for navigating the complex landscape of gender and racial inequality in STEM.

The research proposes a new conceptual framework integrating the intersectionality of AIS women's identities with the Looking-Glass Self theory, offering a comprehensive understanding of their experiences across different cultural and social contexts. This framework challenges the prevailing deficit thinking about AIS women in CME, emphasizing the complexity and resilience of their identity construction in the face of multifaceted inequalities.

Implications of this study are vast, suggesting changes in research, policy, and practice to better support AIS women in STEM. By recognizing the intertwined nature of their gender, foreign, and racial identities, this research calls for a more nuanced approach in academic support, mentorship, and policy formulation to foster an inclusive environment that acknowledges and addresses the unique challenges faced by AIS women in CME fields.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Numerical Methods for Cavity Quantum-Electrodynamics and the Exploration of Hybrid Light-Matter States

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: coupled cluster theory, electronic structure theory, quantum electrodynamics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation explores the integration of quantum electrodynamics (QED) with electronic structure theory to accurately model and understand complex light-matter interactions within optical cavities. Clever designs of optical cavities have enabled experimentalists to achieve strong light-matter coupling, where the interaction between light and matter is so strong that new hybrid light-matter states emerge, known as polaritons. These polariton states can significantly alter molecular properties and chemical reactivity, leading to potential applications in quantum information processing, quantum materials, and light-driven chemical reactions. The dissertation focuses on the development of advanced quantum chemistry methods to capture cavity-induced effects and to provide a comprehensive understanding of the underlying physics. Several key technical advancements in QED are presented, including the development of QED generalizations of coupled-cluster (CC) and equation-of-motion (EOM) CC theories, as well as a framework to automate the derivation of optimized many-body equations for QED. These correlated many-body methods are compared to QED generalizations of mean-field methods like density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TDDFT) for qualitative assessments of cavity-modified molecular properties. In addition, analytic gradients are derived for QED-DFT to elucidate the orientation dependence of cavity-influenced reactions and to caution against the use of unmodified geometries obtained from standard electronic structure calculations in the absence of a cavity. Through the developments of these methods, the dissertation aims to provide novel theoretical insights into cavity-controlled chemistry. Specific topics addressed include the characterization of photon character within electron-attached excited states, the relevance of orbital relaxation within mean-field theories, and the orientation dependence of cavity-influenced reactions. By bridging quantum chemistry and QED, this research paves the way for new fundamental discoveries of light and matter coupling and provides a foundation for understanding and controlling cavity-modified chemistry in experimental settings. The dissertation reflects the substantial progress in modeling complex QED systems, despite challenges regarding their computational efficiency and accuracy.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BORROWING USING HISTORICAL-BIAS POWER PRIOR

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bayesian adaptive design, Historical control, Information borrowing, Non-concurrent borrowing, Power prior

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Adaptively incorporating historical information into analyses of current data can improve the precision of inference without requiring additional new observation. Unfortunately, not all borrowing methods are suitable when limited historical studies are available. When a single historical study is available, the power priors control the amount of information to borrow via specification of a weight parameter that discounts the contribution of the historical data in a likelihood combined with current data. We develop a new type of conditional power prior called the historical-bias power prior using an empirical Bayes approach. It relaxes the assumption of the traditional power priors to allow for historical bias. Moreover, our new weight function controls the amount of borrowing and only borrows when historical data satisfy the borrowing criteria. This is achieved by embedding the Frequentist test-then-pool approach in the weight function. Hence, the historical-bias power prior builds a bridge between the Frequentist test-then-pool and the Bayesian power prior. In the simulation, we examine the impact of historical bias on the operating characteristics for borrowing approaches, which has not been explored in previous literature. The results show that the historical-bias power prior yields accurate estimation and robustly powerful tests for the experimental treatment effect with good type I error control especially when the historical bias exists. Furthermore, we extend the historical-bias power prior to account for differences in subjects' baseline covariates between the historical and current studies by implementing the inverse-probability-weighting adjustment. In the simulation, the adjusted outcomes are examined under two different scenarios based on the imbalanced subjects' baseline. The results show that the operating characteristics may be influenced by the adjustment and is associated with the degree of imbalance between subjects. However, the adjustment is effective because it mitigates the impact of the confounders between studies after borrowing, leading to more reliable inference.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ALLAN WILLCOCKS’ 12 STUDIES FOR GUITAR AN EXAMINATION OF THE ALLAN WILLCOCKS PSEUDONYM AND HIS IMPRESSIONISTIC STUDIES FOR GUITAR

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Allan Willcocks, guitar, impression, pseudonym, studies

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This treatise will briefly explore the reasons a composer would accredit their own works to a different name other than theirs; whether the name is of another living or deceased composer, or a name that is fabricated altogether. This will serve as a prerequisite to the central topic on hand, an examination of a set of guitar studies composed by the German classical guitar pedagogue, performer, as well as composer, Tilman Hoppstock (1961-). In 1992, Hoppstock recorded a piece by an allegedly obscure composer, Franz Werthmüller (1769-1841), and for the next 15 years managed to keep the secret that Werthmüller was merely Hoppstock’s first use of a pseudonym, to present a piece written in the style of an older musical era. In 2010, Hoppstock published a set of 12 studies, for the guitar, under another obscure composer, Allan Willcocks (1869-1956). Undoubtedly, Willcocks was in fact another pseudonym used by Hoppstock, and though this British composer came with an in-depth two-page biography, facsimiles of hand-written manuscripts, and even old photographs documenting various stages of Willcocks’ life, it took only two years for the true identity behind these studies to come out. This treatise will explore the alleged life of Allan Willcocks, Hoppstock’s own reasons for inventing this character, why the Willcocks’ 12 Studies for Guitar has proven to be a valuable addition to classical guitar literature, as well as the style in which they were written in.
