Provided are musical examples, biographical information, original manuscripts, photographs and even concert programs that Hoppstock put together to introduce the world of music to Allan Willcocks.

DISS_description.DISS_title: COMBINATORIAL MIXTURES OF ORGANIC MOLECULES FOR IMPROVED LIQUID/LIQUID EXTRACTION OF IONS AND CATALYTIC REACTIONS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The exploration of combinatorial mixtures in liquid/liquid extraction and phase-transfer catalysis represents a groundbreaking shift in the understanding and application of complex organic systems in chemistry and biology. By investigating the enhanced liquid/liquid extraction capabilities through the introduction of organic solutes, we have demonstrated the superiority of combinatorial mixtures over individual components. At the same time, the study on lipid-based phase transfer catalysis challenges traditional views by revealing the potential of lipids in catalyzing reactions, as evidenced by the successful ester hydrolysis of calcein-AM to fluorescent calcein in phospholipid vesicles. These findings not only illuminate the untapped potential of lipid and organic solute mixtures in catalysis and extraction processes but also suggest broader applications in developing new combinatorial biosensors, materials with unique properties, and innovative catalytic systems. This integrated approach highlights the importance of combinatorial chemistry in advancing our understanding of molecular interactions and the potential for novel applications in synthetic and biological chemistry.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Constructing Women and Nation: Feminized America in British and American Visual Culture 1760-1800

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: America, American Revolution, Art, Gender, Visual Culture

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Early American women’s history and the history of visual culture tend to avoid overlapping in terms of both sources and questions. A gendered lens when applied to the origins of America typically seeks to answer the question of how the Revolution affected women, whereas the history of American visual culture demonstrates changes over time, or the meanings behind symbolism without a fully comprehensive look at gender. This thesis seeks to connect the two fields while raising further questions about white women’s political involvement during the American Revolution through an examination of America as represented by a woman in British-American visual sources from approximately 1760 to 1800. Through both a chronological and thematic approach, this thesis highlights how the changing status of women throughout the Revolution and their experiences are reflected in paintings, cartoons, and state seals, complicating arguments that these female embodiments of America are merely a product of national identity formation. The shift from an Indigenous woman to a Roman goddess can be charted parallel to the rise of Republican Motherhood ideology and anxieties about female autonomy. This thesis will also explore the complex powerful nature of femininity in relation to societal norms and additional iconography, including transgressions of sex and sexuality, liberty, and the mother/daughter dynamic.

DISS_description.DISS_title: FROM STEREOTYPES TO NUANCE: REPRESENTATIONS OF MALE QUEERNESS IN TWO MUSICALS BY JEANINE TESORI

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Fun Home, Jeanine Tesori, Male Queerness, Musical Theater, Shrek the Musical

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: When a character enters the stage in a musical, the audience begins to make assumptions about that character based on what they see—their presented gender, race, etc. Once the character begins to act, speak, and sing, the audience learns who that character truly is. What interests me is how aspects of a character’s identity become manifest on the stage.

This dissertation centers on the portrayal of male queerness in two musicals by Jeanine Tesori, Shrek the Musical (2008) and Fun Home (2015). In exploring how the queerness of three characters from these two shows are represented in both material and performance, I construct a narrative that traces Tesori’s works through a spectrum of representations from those that rely on stereotypes to attempt to portray queerness in a more individualized fashion. I begin by examining the character of Lord Farquaad from Shrek the Musical in Chapter Two. I demonstrate how Farquaad relies entirely on visual and sonic stereotypes to present the character as queer, and I employ Conceptual Integration Networks to highlight how it is the interactions between queer elements, such as his costuming, choreography, vocal performance, and lyrics, that code the character as gay. I then turn to Donkey from Shrek the Musical in Chapter Three, noting the extra complexity that arises with his character’s depiction of both queerness and Blackness. I complicate the ways that Donkey’s character uses stereotypes, questioning the methods employed by the creative team to juggle his marked identities effectively. Finally, I examine the character of Bruce Bechdel from Fun Home in Chapter Four, whose representation is far from stereotypical, instead relying on queer markers established within the musical itself. In examining the differences between how similar identities are portrayed in Chapter Five, I reveal a progressive shift in how queerness is represented on stage, moving from a stereotypical depiction used to garner laughs from the audience to a more true-to-life representation that attempts to capture the realities of being queer.

DISS_description.DISS_title: "Second-Class Citizens:" Exploring the Perception of Racially Marginalized Staff at a PWI

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: classism, CRT, DEI, racism, staff

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Staff members in institutions of higher education who are not faculty, such as those who work in student affairs, information technology, student business services, and other areas, may feel invisible and unappreciated. This sense of obscurity for racially marginalized staff can be intensified by discrimination and oppression that persist within these institutions, despite the implementation of diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives. Unfortunately, higher education literature that examines perceptions and experiences related to racism, oppression, and DEI initiatives tends to focus on students or faculty, neglecting the experiences of professional staff. This qualitative case study delved into the perspectives of racially marginalized professional staff concerning a predominantly White institution's (PWI) endeavors to establish a diverse, equitable, and inclusive environment, employing a critical race theory (CRT) framework. Utilizing a two-phase interview approach, encompassing walking and sitting interviews, nine participants shared their insights and experiences related to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) efforts on campus. The data analysis involved an inductive, iterative coding process of the interview data. Concerning participants' workplace encounters on campus, the findings underscored instances of racial and ethnic bias, discrimination, threats of violence, discrimination based on intersectional identities, being discredited in the workplace, and perceptions of being less valued by administrators compared to faculty, sometimes even facing devaluation by faculty themselves. Regarding participants' perceptions of the institution's DEI effectiveness, a majority expressed unawareness of any DEI initiatives and perceived those they were aware of as lacking permanence. Participants highlighted the challenge of insufficient racial diversity among employees, citing political interference with the institution's DEI efforts. Despite acknowledging these challenges, participants strongly felt that the institution should address DEI concerns. Additionally, the study revealed that DEI programming encountered issues when not appropriately administered, and participants displayed mixed reactions to how their White colleagues received DEI programs and initiatives. This study carries significant implications, affirming that racially marginalized staff encounter notable challenges within Predominantly White Institutions (PWIs), including instances of discrimination, bias, ridicule, violence, and devaluation. Moreover, the findings suggest that institution-sponsored Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs were perceived as more performative than substantive, while grassroots-led initiatives initiated by staff members addressing diversity, equity, or inclusion demonstrated a greater potential for sustainability. Lastly, a poignant observation from one participant underscores the implication that staff being viewed as "second-class citizens" in comparison to faculty significantly contributes to their sense of devaluation within the institution. Drawing from the study’s findings, four key recommendations emerged. First, institutions of higher education should take a stand against racial discrimination, microaggressions, and violence. Second, higher education institutions should take a bow, stop performing, and be intentional with their efforts to positively foster diversity, equity, and inclusion on campus. Third, institutions should take a seat and increase diverse representation among employees. Fourth, institutions should take a leap and prioritize the equal recognition and valuation of staff, mirroring the acknowledgment and opportunities afforded to faculty. In terms of future research, there is a necessity for in-depth analyses of the experiences of all higher education staff, quantitative examinations of staff and faculty salaries from an equity perspective, comparative investigations into staff policies and practices in states with restrictive DEI legislation versus those without, and further research on the effectiveness of grassroots DEI initiatives.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring Administrators’ Perspectives on Cultivating Sense of Belonging Through Black Male Mentorship Programs at Mid-size and Large Predominantly White Institutions (PWIs)

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Black male students enrolled in predominantly White institutions (PWIs) face a myriad of challenges that hinder their academic success and overall well-being. These students often grapple with feelings of disconnection, stress, and isolation. According to studies, Black male students in PWIs are more likely to experience lower retention rates, higher dropout rates, and lower academic performance compared to their peers (Harper et al., 2018). This research explores the critical need to foster a sense of belonging for Black male students at PWIs, acknowledging the multifaceted nature of their experiences and the systemic barriers they encounter. Drawing on the works of Brooms (2020) and McCoy (2014), this study examines administrators' perspectives on Black male mentorship programs and their impact on Black male students' sense of belonging and success within PWIs.

Employing a qualitative methodology (Merriam, 1998), this study focused on gaining insights into administrators' viewpoints on Black male mentorship programs, allowing them to share their experiences and the significance they attributed to these programs (Merriam & Tisdell, 2016). Data collection involved interviews with ten administrators directly overseeing and leading Black male mentorship programs at mid-size and large PWIs. The research questions probed how administrators utilize these programs to cultivate a sense of belonging for Black male undergraduate students and how they addressed challenges encountered in overseeing them.

The findings highlight the positive impact of Black male mentorship programs, indicating that administrators perceive them as advantageous for fostering a sense of community, connection, and positive experiences. Although administrators recognized the advantages of these programs, they also highlighted areas for improvement in different aspects of the programs and within their institutions. This nuanced understanding of mentorship programs for Black male students has played a significant role in fostering a sense of belonging within PWI settings.

In response to research question one, the data identified two primary themes: (1) facilitating personal connection and (2) fostering an engaging and supportive environment. These themes illuminated the ways in which mentorship programs contributed to the sense of belonging for Black male undergraduate students, emphasizing the importance of personal connections and a supportive academic environment.

Addressing research question two, administrators navigated challenges through three key themes: (1) creating and executing strategies for financial resource management, (2) navigating staff and personnel management, and (3) managing the evaluation processes, sharing stories, and aligning with institutional goals. These themes unveiled the varied approaches employed by program administrators to address challenges and enhance the effectiveness of their mentorship programs.

Exploring the implications of the findings, administrators demonstrated adaptability and resilience in integrating mentorship programs into institutional structures. The emergence of engaging activities and understanding program origins as crucial elements underscored administrators' ability to seamlessly align programs with institutional goals. Challenges were effectively addressed through adept financial resource management, strategic personnel navigation, and a commitment to storytelling, thus reinforcing institutional alignment.

Four recommendations emerged from the findings. Recommendation one advocates for prioritizing the hiring of culturally competent staff sensitive to the unique challenges faced by Black male students and emphasizing the need for ongoing training. Recommendation two stresses the importance of establishing clear and measurable program goals, providing a roadmap for success, and enabling outcome assessment. Recommendation three encourages institutions to customize mentoring programs to meet the specific needs of their campus sizes and communities. Recommendation four underscores the need for individualized resource allocation for Black male mentorship programs.

In conclusion, this research contributes valuable insights into the significance of Black male mentorship programs at PWIs, shedding light on their positive impact while addressing challenges. The recommendations offer a roadmap for institutions to enhance these programs, ultimately fostering a sense of belonging and academic success for Black male students in higher education.

DISS_description.DISS_title: FOUR STUART KINGS: ARBITRARY RULE AND THE ORIGINS OF THE LIFE GUARDS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Charles Stuart returned to his native country after fourteen years in exile. His subjects had just endured eleven years of military dictatorship under Oliver Cromwell and wanted a return to the days of monarchy. On 25 May 1660, Charles II landed in Dover and was warmly greeted by his people and the leader of the army, George Monck. They set off for London and arrived on 29 May, Charles II's thirtieth birthday. Escorting Charles into London were his Life Guards, a professional military cavalry force of Royalist supporters who followed their king into exile. Having witnessed his father’s failure to keep his crown because he lacked a loyal bodyguard and seeing first-hand how a devoted household helped his cousin Louis XIV maintain his kingdom, Charles II had every intention of keeping these guards throughout his reign. The challenge was that Charles had promised to disband the military, which had become very unpopular in England and was viewed as a tool of tyranny and absolute rule. This dissertation deals with the challenges Charles II and his brother James II faced in keeping a loyal guard about them in a country that genuinely feared the institution of a standing army. The first four Stuart monarchs stubbornly believed in the Divine Right of Kings and sought to rule by the Royal Prerogative. How they wielded arbitrary powers in an era where Parliament wanted more to say in declaring laws and charting a direction for the country was challenging, and all four dealt with it differently. At the root of these challenges was how money was collected to fund wars and build armies. The Stuart kings could rule without Parliament but not raise taxes to pay for expensive armies to conduct military campaigns. For this, they had to call Parliament, and Parliament was all too aware of their growing power to the point that they used these episodes to demand more say. In this complicated world, Charles II and James II could not rule as absolutists without the Life Guards who formed the nucleus of England’s standing army.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NUMERICAL MODELING OF HURRICANE WAVE AND STORM SURGE OVERTOPPING SAND DUNES AND BARRIER ISLAND

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Coastal Hazard, Hurricane, Overtopping, Storm surge, Wave, XBeach

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation provides a comprehensive analysis of the intricate dynamics of coastal systems under the extreme stress of hurricanes. A multi-faceted study on the interactions between hydrodynamics, morphology dynamics, and various coastal defenses like sand dunes and vegetations during hurricane events is presented, employing advanced numerical modeling to enhance the understanding of coastal resilience and protection. It is constructed upon three pillars of research, each delving into different yet interconnected aspects of coastal defense mechanisms and their responses to hurricane-induced forces.The research begins by examining the protective functions of sand dunes against hurricane forces, utilizing a non-hydrostatic XBeach model (XBNH) to analyze wave dynamics with various storm surge after overtopping sand dunes. The research presents an in-depth analysis of wave behavior as they encounter sand dunes during hurricane-induced storm surges. The research focuses on Hurricane Michael as a case study, dissecting the dynamics of wave propagation, breaking, and overtopping. It offers a quantitative assessment of the dunes’ ability to attenuate waves, pinpointing the conditions that precipitate maximum erosion and wave heights. The findings reveal that sand dunes are pivotal in reducing wave heights, particularly as storm surges intensify, with waves breaking at the dune base, overtopping, and losing their energy as they move inland. Through the model validation, the chapter establishes the superior performance of XBNH over the hydrostatic mode (XBSB), especially in critical metrics such as significant wave height and peak water surface elevation, where XBNH showed a markedly lower average and maximum error rates. This research not only underscores the precision of the XBNH, also provides the foundation for following research. The investigation then extends to the complex processes leading to barrier-island breaching during hurricane conditions. A case study using a two-dimensional XBNH model provides a detailed account of how hurricane-induced waves and storm surges interplay to alter island topography. The study reveals that supercritical flow conditions significantly contribute to the rapid erosion and eventual breaching of barrier islands, offering a predictive analysis of the morphological changes under extreme weather events. In addition, it provides a detailed account of the barrier-island's breaching evolution, through the analysis of bed elevation cross-sections and surge-wave profiles across various storm stages. This comprehensive examination not only reinforces the model's precision but also offers a deeper understanding of barrier island dynamics, contributing valuable knowledge to enhance coastal hazard mitigation strategies. The final aspect of the research integrates the hydrodynamic focus of the preceding chapters to explore the evolution of dune profiles, particular the role of vegetation in coastal protection. It highlights how different conditions of vegetation affect dune morphology under storm conditions. The study explores the use of the XBeach model to simulate these interactions, emphasizing the critical role of vegetation in mitigating erosion. Moreover, the chapter enriches the XBeach model's application by incorporating sensitivity analyses to different wind conditions, thereby broadening its predictive capability. The study's comprehensive approach illuminates the multifaceted relationship between vegetation, coastal morphology, and erosion processes. It highlights the indispensable role of vegetation in bolstering coastal resilience and provides strategic insights for coastal management, reinforcing the vital need for integrated environmental considerations in the design of coastal defense systems. To summarize, this dissertation underscores the importance of integrating hydrodynamics, morphological dynamics, and ecological considerations into coastal management practices. The results contribute valuable insights into the design and conservation of coastal defenses, promoting the development of more resilient communities in the face of increasing hurricane activities. Through the refined application of the XBeach model and the insights gained from its performance, the dissertation makes a significant contribution to the field of coastal engineering and environmental protection.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Pedagogical Content Knowledge in Elementary Mathematics Teachers: A Qualitative Study of Teacher Perspective on Instructional Practice

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Departmentalization, Elementary Mathematics Teachers, Pedagogical Content Knowledge, Teacher Development

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Standardized testing has elementary schools transitioning into departmentalization, where a teacher is assigned to teach a particular subject matter. Elementary education programs tend to provide a holistic approach to education that includes training in all subject matters and learner psychology. The national trend of teacher shortages as resulted in the hiring of teachers who have not attended a formal education preparation program. Departmentalized elementary teachers in mathematics enter the role without prior specialized training due to holistic teacher preparation programs or entering the profession from another role. This study explores the implementation of pedagogical content knowledge of departmentalized elementary mathematics teachers in a large urban district during planning and instruction. Pedagogical content knowledge is the specialized content knowledge needed to effectively instruct a subject matter. Through multiple case study design, this exploration was able to identify specific elements of pedagogical content knowledge evident in the lesson plans, class observations, and interviews with seven elementary mathematics teachers in a large urban district. The findings provide insight on the various levels of planning in the area of questioning, but a consistency of evidence in the areas of multiple representation and problem selection. Despite the inconsistent evidence of planning for productive questioning, the elementary teachers demonstrated evidence of asking productive questions throughout the lesson and responding to student errors. The participants during the interview expressed the desire to increase the level of purposeful reflection on their planning and instruction as a way to improve their craft. Implications of these findings are discussed for school-level professional development programs and district-level structures for continuing education for departmentalized elementary mathematics teachers. This study contributes to the exploration of pedagogical content knowledge and teacher development specifically in the elementary setting and departmentalization that can be supported through collaborative structure and formalized reflections.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Simplicial methods in graph machine learning

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Applied Category Theory, Directed Graphs, Graph Algorithms, Graph Neural Network, Simplicial Set, Weisfeiler-Lehman Algorithm

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Weisfeiler-Leman algorithm is a powerful test of graph isomorphism, and works by iteratively isolating clusters of nodes via a coloring scheme based on binary relationships. This refinement process is akin to message passing on graph neural networks. Graph neural networks are paradigms of computation that yield powerful results for structured data based on binary relationships, and therefore their expressivity shares the limitations of the Weisfeiler-Leman test. One way to circumvent this limitation relies on identifying and working with higher relationships within the data, or by finding a better refinement criterion that can be implemented on a machine. In this thesis, we put forward data structures closely based on the identification of such higher relationships via Kan Extensions of structured data built on binary relations. These data structures are well known in algebraic topology as Simplicial Sets; the theoretical underpinnings based on the combinatorics of simplicial sets and directed graphs are explored in this thesis and, based on of it, algorithms are introduced that can identify higher-order relations. A metric that can serve as a quantification for community detection tools is also introduced, as well as the notion of a pseudoterminal vertex as a proxy for these higher relations. This helps us balance the variance-bias tradeoff necessary for generalizability of the architecture. We introduce functors that show how these higher relationships can be modelled and expanded. Finally, we propose three neural networks that benefit from the topology of these nonbinary relations. These neural networks can be ported into the standard graph neural network library to augment feature classification in a semisupervised manner. All source code is available at \texttt{https://github.com/abdullahnaeemmalik/simplicial-methods-in-graph-machine-learning}.

DISS_address.DISS_addrline: The National High Magnetic Field Laboratory
1800 E. Paul Dirac Drive, The National High Magnetic Field L

DISS_description.DISS_title: STUDY OF THE VALENCE TRANSITION IN EUPD2SI2

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Europium exhibits two stable valence states, Eu2+ and Eu3+, with energies closely matched, wherein the magnetic Eu2+ state is significantly larger than the nonmagnetic Eu3+. EuPd2Si2 (EPS) undergoes a bulk valence state transition from Eu~3+ to Eu~2+ while cooling. The phase diagram of the EPS compound differs from that of other typical rare-earth 1:2:2 compounds with valence instability. Therefore, the valence transition of the EPS compound cannot be explained by theoretical models of other compounds and remains rather mysterious. This study aims to construct a comprehensive phase diagram of the EPS crystal structure during the valence phase transition, while varying chemical substitution, temperature, and magnetic field.Chapter one discusses X-ray crystallography and crystal structures. Chapter 2 delves into the electronic and magnetic states of lanthanides and specifically europium. Curie’s susceptibility of the magnetic divalent europium atoms and the Van Vleck paramagnetism susceptibility of the non-magnetic trivalent europium atoms are discussed. A literature review on the valence instability of 1:2:2 rare-earth compounds, especially the EPS compound, is presented in chapter three. Chapter four covers the efforts on the growth and characterization of the pristine and below 5% chemically substituted EPS compounds. The temperature-dependent X-ray diffraction (XRD) powder measurements by the APS synchrotron and our in-lab XRD machines will be discussed. In the EPS and its low-doped compounds, another smaller unit cell appears beside the high-temperature EPS (HT-EPS) unit cell. The new low-temperature EPS (LT-EPS) unit cell is related to the Eu3+ valence state. A magnetic valence transition was observed in the DC magnetic susceptibility measurements at temperatures where the unit cell transformation starts. In the next chapter, in the 10 to 20 % alloyed samples of EPS, the linear thermal coefficient can suddenly increase or slowly decrease to up to 3.5 times, or stay constant at all temperatures. Finally, the four thermal expansion trends are explained qualitatively by the available space for the europium atoms in the unit cell in chapter 6. The analysis of powder patterns of EPS at high magnetic fields and low temperatures in Cell 5 of MAGLAB has been conducted in chapter 7. Key findings include the magnetic field's enhancement of the HT-EPS phase, driving the valence transition temperature lower. The weight fraction of the EPS phase demonstrates a linear dependence on temperature, particularly around the temperature equating HT-EPS and LT-EPS weight fractions. Moreover, quadratic relationships with magnetic field strength are observed, along with hysteresis effects influencing the symmetry of these relationships. Finally, some of my other side projects that I have done during my study at FSU are presented. Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTSSe) semiconductor materials serve as excellent absorber layers in thin-film photovoltaic devices, yet their low open-circuit voltage hinders mass production. Unlike CZTSSe, Ag2ZnSnSe4 (AZTSe) possesses a favorable bandgap of 1.4 eV, making it a promising candidate to replace toxic or scarce materials in photovoltaics. Powder AZTSe was successfully synthesized. In an attempt to grow single-crystal AZTSe via the chemical vapor transport method, Ag8SnSe6 and SnSe2 phases were obtained. Further exploration focused on Ag8SnSe6's potential as a thermoelectric material, highlighting its superionic conductivity. By constructing a comprehensive electron density map of Ag8SnSe6, the path of silver atoms inside the single crystal was determined. Additionally, efforts to grow AuPbSbS3 and (Au0.5Cu0.5)PbSbS3 for renewable energy applications via chemical vapor transport were explored. Another study investigates the impact of light and temperature on the optical properties and stability of mixed-ion perovskite thin films, demonstrating slight peak shifts under elevated temperature conditions, potentially indicating anisotropic thermal expansion. Additionally, doping with Cs shows improved performance and stability compared to other compositions, as evidenced by XRD measurements. Another study examines the chemical composition of shark teeth artifacts from archaeological sites using XRD analysis, revealing residues that provide insights into ancient tool applications. Despite challenges posed by uneven surfaces, the integration of XRD patterns uncovers phases like hematite, shedding light on ancient material usage and cultural practices.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Decision Theory, Action Guidance, and Moral Uncertainty

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: action guidance, choice-worthiness, decision theory, moral uncertainty, uncertaintism

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Some philosophers have recently argued that a decision-theoretic model of rational choice can guide us to the answer of what it is appropriate to do in situations of moral uncertainty (i.e., uncertainty about what one ought to do). By proposing and defending this view, these philosophers aim to show how decision-theoretic procedures provide us with action guidance even when we have yet to settle all of the issues in normative ethics. In this paper, I argue that decision theory is never action-guiding in cases of moral uncertainty. I thus suggest that because of this limitation on decision theory’s action-guiding capacities, it fails to fulfill the role that these philosophers hope to show that it has. I consider several objections to my argument and reply to each of them.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ENVISIONING A FAT-POSITIVE THEATRE: CRITICAL RECEPTIONS OF FAT BODIES ONSTAGE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: 'night Mother, Critical Reception, Disability Studies, Fat Ham, Fat Studies, Untitled Feminist Show

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis investigates how critics respond to the fat body onstage, aiming to better understand how to develop positive fat representation. Through my research, I advocate for theatre to develop fat-positive practices. I argue that fat positivity in theatre must go beyond simply including fat bodies onstage. A fat-positive theatre would cast fat bodies in all roles, while maintaining the sensitivity that the fat body carries unique cultural assumptions and may require material changes to the theatrical processes. Adopting these fat-positive practices would involve a radical acceptance of fatness onstage.My research examines three notable plays as case studies to understand how the fat body is performed and received onstage in the United States. My first case study, ’night, Mother, takes place in the 1980s as a landmark example of how casting a fat body affected a production’s reception. The other two case studies, Untitled Feminist Show and Fat Ham, focus on the 2010s and 2020s, to examine how recent shifts in fat activism and body-positive movements have impacted cultural understandings of the fat body. My research seeks to understand how these cultural shifts connect to critical receptions of the fat body onstage. Through these case studies, I aim to craft a narrative around the shifting ways we conceptualize the neutral body and how the fat body challenges this unspoken assumption. In this thesis, I use the term “neutral body” to refer to bodies that fit the cultural norms of an ideal performer and “non-neutral bodies” to identify fat bodies that visibly break the traditional mode of what we expect an actor to look like. This framework provides a way of thinking about how fat bodies are routinely excluded from representation and highlights the unspoken assumption that the fat body is not the ideal body.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DOES REFORM LEAD TO SUCCESS FOR ALL? EXAMINING STUDENT OUTCOMES FOLLOWING DEVELOPMENTAL EDUCATION REFORM

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: community college success, developmental education, education policy reform, student success

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Community colleges provide access to higher education for a wide range of prospective students with diverse interests and educational goals. With more than 60 percent of incoming community college students deemed as academically underprepared for college-level work, traditionally, students have been required to enroll in one semester or more of developmental coursework before beginning college-level classes. Several studies demonstrate traditional remedial education models seldom increase students’ skills and contribute towards success in outcomes such as persistence, passage of gateway courses, or credential completion (Bailey & Phillips, 2016; Goudas & Boylan, 2013; Jaggars & Bickerstaff; 2018). Recent developmental education reform efforts include models that have proven to be successful in accelerating the time it takes for students to successfully matriculate through developmental coursework (Edgecombe et al., 2013; Jaggars & Stacey, 2014). These reform models include options for students to enroll directly in college-level courses simultaneously with support courses as with corequisite courses, curricula changes and interventions which consolidate multiple standalone courses into one single semester as with compressed courses, intensive advising policies, and alternatives to traditional placement assessments which result in a higher likelihood of placement accuracy and success in college-level coursework. Overwhelmingly, studies examining the outcomes of students who participate in developmental reform models have found benefits relative to traditional developmental models, however, these studies largely consider the effects of one type of developmental model or the presence or lack thereof of any type of developmental policy (Bahr et al., 2019; Barbitta & Munn 2018; Cho et al., 2012; Jaggars et al., 2013; Ran & Lin, 2019). Additionally, many studies have failed to examine whether certain types of developmental policies are more effective than others and if this differs based on gender and race/ethnicity. With states adopting varying developmental education reform policies to improve student progression into college-level coursework and beyond, this study examined how recent state modifications to placement policies, compressed/corequisite modalities, or changes to advising/academic planning have affected student persistence trends. Using a modified version of Wang’s theoretical model of momentum for community college student success, I conceptualized developmental reform policies based on how they may function to contribute towards the momentum of students, and therefore, outcomes such as first-year retention and graduation rates. Drawing data from the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, this study used a difference-in-differences approach between the years of 2012 to 2020 to observe student success outcomes before and after implementation of developmental education policy reform models, while comparing outcomes among non-adopting states. This study considered how developmental reform policies in a national context contribute to academic momentum and student success outcomes such as persistence and completion. Results in the aggregate provide evidence that the presence of developmental education reform policies in states increase institutional retention and completion rates more so than institutions within states that do not adopt reform policies. Additionally, when disaggregating results by type of developmental education reform policy, there are no differential impacts on student outcomes, with one exception, holistic reforms which may more negatively impact outcomes. Lastly, while developmental education reforms aided in increasing overall student outcomes, gaps in graduation rates among genders and racial/ethnic groups were observed, with disparities between certain groups widening at institutions within states with reforms.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SCHOOL PRINCIPALS’ PERCEPTIONS: FACTORS THAT INFLUENCE SCHOOL-BASED LEADER RETENTION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Leader Persistence, Principal Retention, School Based Leader Persistence, School Principal Retention, School-Based Leader Retention, School-Based Principals

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Problem of PracticeSchool principals have a powerful effect on student achievement, school culture, and teacher turnover. According to the National Association of Secondary School Principals (2020), the average career of a school principal is four years, and one in five school principals leave their schools annually. These numbers are even greater in more challenging schools with high numbers of minority students, English Language Learners, and students living in poverty. These students need the most experienced school principals, yet they often end up with the newest and least experienced. Even more alarming is that results from a recent survey conducted jointly by NASSP and the Learning Policy Institute (LPI) in 2020 indicated that 42% of school principals were considering leaving their position. This exploratory qualitative research study answers the following research question: The purpose of this study is to answer the following research question: What has motivated school principals to remain in school-level leadership? The study focuses on gaining the perspectives of principals on factors influencing school-based leaders to remain in their positions. Motivation and retention of current school leaders is critical to student growth and success, overall school achievement, and retention of school educators at all levels. This study will add to the current body of research focused on development and support of school leaders to positively impact school principal perseverance and retention. Methods Semi-structured interviews and coding methods have been used to organize and analyze outcomes effectively without losing the individuality of the participants’ responses. Ten principals participated in semi-structured interviews. The stratified and purposeful sample included both males and females, principals at all K-12 levels, Title I and non-Title I schools, and urban and suburban schools. Data Analysis First cycle descriptive coding using a priori codes in conjunction with in vivo coding outcomes and second cycle coding outcomes were charted to identify dominant codes: Relevant Preparation, Relevant Experience, Relationships with Staff, the Participants’ Perception of the Role/Feelings About the Role, Passion for Helping Others, Internal Drive, Future Role, Informal Collaboration with Peers, and the Mentor/Mentee Relationship. Code outcomes were clustered based on commonality. Six overarching themes emerged and were named: External Validation, Collaboration, Preparation and Support, Future Plans, Intrinsic Motivation, and Relationships. These themes answered the research question: What has motivated school principals to remain in school-level leadership? Recommendations Based on participant interview outcomes for this study, the following recommendations are offered. The first recommendation is to ensure that the right support is being provided to school leaders to positively impact the leader to be able to succeed within the role. The next recommendation is focused on collaboration. A focus on formal collaboration needs to shift from interaction in meetings to shadowing peers and a sharing of ideas to positively impact schools, leadership practices, and student achievement. Informal collaboration when supported and celebrated by school districts could potentially support school leaders professionally as well as emotionally which would positively impact retention rates. Next, mentor programs should be expanded to include both internal and external relationships. For mentoring programs to be most impactful on the decision-making of school principals, evaluation or fear of retribution should be removed, and this often results from an external match. Additionally, it is critical to establish and encourage a pipeline of leaders within a school district to ensure a continual pool of qualified leaders prepared to support and lead schools. All school districts and current leaders should identify and tap potential leaders and provide effective professional development, encouragement, and mentorship to develop leadership skills. Creating a pipeline of educators at all levels positively impacts students, schools, and school districts as a whole. Finally, salaries should increase to compensate school leaders fairly and adequately. Conclusion Addressing this research question provides answers and informs practice to improve formal and informal learning opportunities for school principals in an effort to address principal turnover rates. Ensuring that the right learning opportunities and supportive measures are in place are of the utmost importance to increase longevity of school leaders in their role to ultimately positively impact student achievement, increase teacher retention, and positively impact the climate and culture of a school community. Based on the perceptions of current school principals in this study, 6 themes have emerged from the data: External Validation, Collaboration, Preparation & Support, Future Plans, Intrinsic Motivation, and Relationships. Each plays an important role in developing and supporting school leaders. The combination of these supports and opportunities increases school principal perseverance and retention in their school-based leader role.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Breaking Barriers, Building Resilience: Unraveling the Link Between Autism Severity, Parent Stress and Access to Care in Families of Children with Autism

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: ASD Severity, Autism, Family Resilience, Healthcare Access, Parent Stress, Social Determinants of Health

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study explored the relationship between autism spectrum disorder (ASD) severity, parental stress, barriers to care, and family resilience among 210 parents of children with ASD. Using path analysis, the study investigated how ASD severity influences parental stress, mediated by barriers to care and family resilience. Results demonstrated positive direct effects between ASD severity and parent stress as well as significant indirect effects when including barriers to care as a mediator in this relationship. The sequential mediation effect of barriers to care and family resilience on the relationship between ASD severity and parent stress also supported partial mediation. While family resilience alone did not have a significant indirect effect on this relationship, resilience plays a significant role in the sequential mediation model alongside barriers to care. These findings emphasize the importance of comprehensive interventions that address both ASD symptoms and familial stressors. They have implications for clinical practice, research, education, public policy, and family support initiatives, suggesting the need for improved access to care and increased awareness and inclusivity.

DISS_description.DISS_title: An exploration of admissions requirements in college-based paramedic programs in Florida

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ABSTRACT

The Sullivan Report (The Sullivan Commission on Diversity in the Healthcare Workforce, 2004) identified the lack of racial diversity among health care practitioners as a major issue. This report points out that, while the U.S. population has continued to become more diverse, the composition of health care workers has not kept pace with these changes. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) workers provide advanced medical care to patients in the prehospital environment. Nationally, 11.6% of the entire workforce is African American, and 16.1% are Hispanic. Within the EMS field, African Americans represent only 6% of workers, and Hispanics represent 10.6% (U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, 2017). One possible impediment to minorities entering the EMS workforce may involve the admissions practices of post-secondary institutions offering EMS programs (Health Resources and Services Administration [HRSA], 2017). This study examined the admissions practices of Florida college-based paramedic programs to determine what they currently are and how decisions about these requirements are made. This study used a document analysis of Florida college-based paramedic program websites to determine what current admissions requirements are in place for these programs, as well as interviews with the program managers of 11 of the 25 Florida college-based paramedic programs, to determine how decisions are made about which instruments are used and how they are used in admissions processes. The study found that these programs used a variety of qualitative and quantitative instruments in their admissions processes as well as several different methods of selecting students based on these instruments. Interviews with program managers revealed that their decision-making processes were influenced by a desire to meet several goals, including selecting students they felt would successfully complete their programs, pass licensing exams, and perform as competent clinicians. They also incorporated influences from accreditors, government regulators, and employers of their graduates in their decision-making processes. Program directors relied mostly on anecdotal evidence to make these decisions, and diversity considerations did not play a meaningful part in their decision-making processes. Accreditors and regulators should provide guidance for these decision makers in this area, and research should be conducted to assess the validity of common instruments and selection processes and their effect on the diversity of these training programs.

DISS_description.DISS_title: To Hinder or to Strengthen: Adult Survivors’ of Child Sexual Abuse Experiences with Parent Disclosure Response

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: child sexual abuse, disclosure, disclosure response, parent disclosure response, parent-child relationship, sexual abuse

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Approximately 25% of women and 15% of men have reported being sexually abused in childhood. Although child sexual abuse (CSA) prevention and treatment methods have been widely supported in the literature, many survivors either never disclose or delay disclosing their abuse until later in life. The absence of disclosure presents major challenges to holistically understanding CSA prevention and treatment methods. Consequently, research attempting to uncover the barriers, influences, recipients, and impacts of CSA disclosure has become increasingly prevalent. A perceived negative response to CSA disclosure has been linked to a variety of long-term survivor consequences including revictimization, mental and physical health struggles, and relational issues. Not only is fear of others’ responses one of the largest barriers to CSA disclosure, but having access to someone you can trust is also the most commonly identified influence to disclosing CSA. Unsurprisingly, survivors who decide to disclose initially do so and are primarily worried about the responses of their parents. Additionally, much of the CSA disclosure literature is oriented especially around children who disclose. It is reported, however, that survivors of CSA often delay reporting until adulthood. In order to increase feelings of safety for survivors to disclose, there is a need to strengthen our awareness of how survivors perceive their parents’ responses to CSA disclosure. The present study aimed to gain an in-depth understanding of survivors’ perceptions surrounding disclosure of CSA to a parent. Grounded theory qualitative methods were employed to develop a central theory surrounding the process of adult CSA disclosure to a parent. Findings highlighted a relational process through which adult survivors perceive and interpret their parent’s response to CSA disclosure. Analyses concluded that parent response to CSA disclosure impacted the parent-child relationship by either hindering or strengthening it. Whether a relationship was ultimately hindered or strengthened by the CSA disclosure experience was dependent on the manner in which parents responded to the disclosure. Harmful and helpful parental responses were divided into five subthemes: statements, questions, behaviors, positionality, and follow-up actions. Other patterns discussed were wished for responses, familial context, and ongoing CSA discussions. Findings from this study provide insights for parents and clinicians, as well as future research directions.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Faunal Analysis of the Rotherwood Site (40SL61), A Pre-contact Mississippian Site in Upper East Tennessee

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Archaeology, Fauna, Mississippian, Rotherwood Site, Tennessee, Zooarchaeology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis offers the first comprehensive exploration of the Rotherwood site (40SL61) in Upper East Tennessee, focusing on faunal remains to understand the subsistence practices of its original occupants. Located along the South Fork Holston River, this site presents a unique opportunity for archaeological investigation, being relatively unexplored and lacking scholarly publication. This study investigates subsistence strategies, social organization, and broader behavioral patterns during the Mississippian period through faunal analysis. Methodologically, the research addresses taphonomic processes, site formation factors, and the challenges of archaeological interpretation. The presence of whole animal remains suggests limited carcass sharing, challenging prevailing notions about Mississippian cultures in Tennessee. Furthermore, the abundance of vertebrate remains suggests that Rotherwood was not a freshwater mussel shell processing station, indicating a more diverse subsistence base. By examining the material evidence from Rotherwood, this study contributes to a deeper understanding of pre-contact societies in Upper East Tennessee and emphasizes the significance of faunal analysis in archaeological research.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Integrative Approaches in Genomic Analysis: Advancing Epigenetic Prediction, TWAS Methodology, and Cell-Type Deconvolution in Spatial Transcriptomics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In the rapidly evolving world of molecular biology, genetics and epigenetics have taken crucial roles in unraveling the complex origins of diseases. Through gene expression, genes govern the synthesis of proteins, the fundamental building blocks of life. Conventional observational studies grapple with major limitations in exploring the relationships between diseases and gene expression, leading to the advent of transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS). Similarly, methylome-wide association studies (MWAS) have been developed to explore the relationships between DNA methylation and disease, as DNA methylation plays a key role in regulating gene expression.

In Chapter 2 of this dissertation, we introduce MIMOSA (MWAS Imputing Methylome Obliging Summary-level mQTLs and Associated LD matrices), a comprehensive set of DNA methylation prediction models for use in MWAS. MIMOSA significantly improves the accuracy of DNA methylation prediction and downstream power of MWAS by training on a large, summary-level methylation quantitative trait loci (mQTL) dataset from the Genetics of DNA Methylation Consortium. We apply MIMOSA to genome-wide summary statistics for 28 complex traits and include a case study in high cholesterol.

In Chapter 3, we present SUMMIT-FA (Summary-level Unified Method for Modeling Integrated Transcriptome with Functional Annotations), which extends the state-of-the-art TWAS method SUMMIT by incorporating functional annotations from the the Multi-dimensional Annotation-Class Integrative Estimation (MACIE). SUMMIT-FA improves gene expression prediction accuracy and TWAS power, which we demonstrate through its application to 24 traits and through simulations.

In Chapter 4, we turn our attention to spatial transcriptomics, which measures gene expression in situ on slices of tissue. We present a novel zero-inflated hierarchical generalized transformation (ZI-HGT) model that functions as a noisy transformation for cell-type deconvolution with conditional autoregressive-based deconvolution (CARD). CARD assumes normality of the highly zero-inflated, count-valued spatial transcriptomic data, and the ZI-HGT transforms the data to better fit this assumption. Joined together, the ZI-HGT and CARD not only achieve enhanced cell-type deconvolution accuracy, but naturally quantify uncertainty in the estimated cell-type proportions through bootstrap Bayesian pointwise credible intervals. This leads to a novel, exploratory ``heterogeneity score'' for quantitative assessment of cell-type heterogeneity at different locations, which is demonstrated to coincide well with pathologist-annotated tissue layer boundaries. We apply the combined method to 12 samples of oral squamous cell carcinomas (OSCC) data to gain a better understanding of the tumor microenvironment.

DISS_description.DISS_title: JOINT VEHICLE DISPATCHING AND REDEPLOYMENT FOR EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES WITH MULTI-CRITIC REINFORCEMENT LEARNING

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: With regard to Emergency Medical Services (EMS), the response time and consistency thatthey can provide care to in need patients is of the upmost importance. The key aspects of achieving this efficiency lies in how the EMS vehicles are dispatched to a patient from the currently available fleet and how they are then redistributed to best cover the area of care. This problem can be formulated as both a Markov-Decision Process and as a Multi-Agent Markov Game in which we can find some optimal policy to best assist those in needs. Previous works have approached this problem in both the combined sense (considering dispatching and redeployment as a single problem) or as two separate systems to optimize. Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) has been growing in popularity over the past half decade, and applications of these advances are still underutilized for this problem. While methods within the DRL family have been applied to this problem, they typically only consider the dispatching or redistribution sides independently, there has been a growing field of interest in applying one DRL policy to multiple tasks. Our approach is centered around improving the redeployment side of the problem but we will also be exploring the benefits of using a single policy to approach two aspects of a conjoined problem to improve the response time and consistency of these vital services.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Conjugating Representations into Lie Subgroups

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Fock-Goncharov, geometry, Lie groups, projective space, projective transformations, topology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Properties of the space of representations of a surface group into a given simple Liegroup is a very active area of research [11, 16, 18, 1, 7, 6, 15] and is particularly relevant to higher Teichmuller theory. For a closed surface, classical Teichmuller space is a connected component of the moduli space of representations into PSL(2, R) and [11] showed that the space of positive representations into PSL(k, R) coincides with the Hitchin component. In this dissertation we study representations of finitely generated groups into PGL(k, C) and determine necessary and sufficient conditions for such a representation to be conjugate into PGL(k, R). In this way, we identify representations in the larger representation variety which are conjugate in PGL(k, C) to a representation in hom (pi_1(S), PGL(k, R)) / PGL(k, R).

DISS_description.DISS_title: Publication Bias in Meta-analysis of Survival Analyses

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: My dissertation explores publication-bias detection methods for meta-analyses of survival analysis studies. I simulated individual-level survival data and created pseudo studies that were combined in meta-analyses. I analyzed the pseudo study data using both Cox and AFT models, then submitted the studies to meta-analysis. I examined 120 conditions describing features of the meta-analyses, each studied with 500 replications. I analyzed the simulated meta-analyses of survival data using eight methods including three tests based on the trim and fill method (using the L0, R0, and Q0 estimators), the Copas-model test, and four Egger’s tests. I calculated the rejection rates of each test based on the 500 simulated meta-analyses and analyzed them via ANCOVA models. In the unbiased meta-analyses of AFT data, all tests showed type I error rates comparable to their alpha levels. In unbiased meta-analyses of Cox data, all tests except the Egger’s test at the alpha level of .05 showed low type I error rates compared to their alpha levels. In the biased meta-analyses of Cox and AFT data, all tests showed low empirical power which indicated that these traditional meta-analysis detection methods cannot detect publication bias effectively.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Why Not Luck?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Distributive, Egalitarianism, Equality, Luck, Pragmatism, Rorty

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This work examines the debate between the luck and relational egalitarians. The former, including authors like Dworkin, Cohen, Arneson, Tan, and Lippert-Rasmussen, are said to view equality as deriving from the nullification of certain types of bad luck, such as by equalizing access to resources, opportunity sets, or experienced well-being. Such accounts are said to be distributive in character, as they are concerned chiefly with the way some good is distributed in a population. The latter, including authors like Anderson, Scheffler, Scanlon, and Schemmel, argue that equality consists not in any sort of distribution, such as an equal distribution of bad luck, but instead in the nature of the social relationships we are enmeshed in. When these are relations of equality, when objectionable status hierarchies are not present and individuals are treated with respect and dignity, equality obtains. I argue, in support of philosophers such as Kok-Chor Tan and Kasper Lippert-Rasmussen, that the two views are not as distinct or incompatible as generally characterized by either side of the debate. Instead, I suggest that a pluralist account which incorporates elements of both is the better choice for our egalitarian purposes. I argue for this conclusion in large part utilizing the work of Richard Rorty, whose pragmatism easily accommodates and encourages the sort of pluralism on offer. Such an account is especially important given recent advances in economics involving our understanding of the structure and behavior of capitalist systems and how they impact the mere distribution of goods. Such distributive concerns as raised by Thomas Piketty are difficult to account for if our philosophies must be entirely non-distributive in their character. Given the importance of incorporating these insights, it stands to reason that merely distributive concerns will be a part of any viable egalitarian philosophy. Broadly speaking, this work sets as its goal the defense of such distributive approaches to egalitarian philosophy.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PARTIALLY HYPERBOLIC SYSTEMS: CLOSED PERIODIC CURVES AND CLOSED ORBITS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Anosov flows, dynamical systems, partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The present work is about partially hyperbolic dynamics on closed 3-manifolds and closed periodiccurves. Partially hyperbolic systems are dynamical systems characterized by a dominated splitting of their tangent bundle into directions of contraction, expansion and intermediate behavior. The prime candidates of study are Anosov flows and partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms. In recent years, these systems have gained a lot of interest, mainly in dimension 3, where there is lot of machinery available. In the realm of Anosov flows, the orbit structure of these systems plays a major role in understanding their properties and even helping in their classification. For skewed R-covered Anosov flows whose weak stable foliation is transversely orientable, it was shown by Fenley [7] that any two distinct freely homotopic periodic orbits are always isotopic. We were interested in knowing whether this result was also true for non R-covered Anosov flows. Our first main result is to extend this result to a class of systems generalizing Anosov flows, called topological Anosov flows. This is theorem 34. In contrast with Anosov flows, partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms may not exhibit a very desirable property called dynamical coherence. This property means that the center direction of the system integrates into a foliation. The first example of a non dynamically coherent partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism in dimension 3 was constructed by Hertz, Hertz, and Ures [37]. The existence of non differentiable points in curves along the center direction, is what makes the system not dynamically coherent. Quite commonly, important invariant sets of regularity no more than C 0 appear in the study of dynamical systems whose regularity is C 1 or better. Seeing as periodic orbits play an important role, we wonder whether a continuous embedded (possibly non differentiable) closed periodic curve, under a partially hyperbolic diffeomorphism could be “tangent” (see remark 11.2.1) to the center direction. We show this is indeed the case in our second main result, theorem 53.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Blockchain and Corporate Disclosure

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: blockchain, corporate disclosure, interfirm communication, supply chain, voluntary disclosure

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Firms struggle to credibly communicate privately with other firms, which leads them to rely on public disclosure to share information. Although public disclosure alleviates the credibility concerns of private interfirm communication, it comes with proprietary costs. Recent advances in blockchain technology provide a potential solution that allows firms to communicate on a shared, immutable, and private ledger which mitigates credibility concerns and avoids the proprietary costs of public disclosure. Thus, blockchain technology may reduce firms’ reliance on public disclosure to corroborate private interfirm communications. Using a difference-in-difference design, I find results consistent with this argument. Specifically, I find that managers, especially those of firms that likely bear greater proprietary costs of public disclosure, decrease their public disclosure following blockchain adoption. I find that this decrease in public disclosure has negative consequences, as it leads to greater analyst forecast errors. Collectively, my results suggest that although blockchain technology can improve private interfirm communication, it may have the unintended consequence of deteriorating the public information environment through reduced public disclosure.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MUSIC THERAPISTS' PERCEPTIONS OF INCLUDING PATIENT’S PRIMARY LANGUAGE IN SESSIONS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to investigate music therapists’ perceptions of including a client's primary language in sessions. It also sought to gather relevant information regarding what tools would be most helpful to assist music therapists in including their clients’ primary language in sessions. A 12-question survey was sent to music therapists in the United States to gather data on their perceptions of including language and culture within music therapy sessions. Results revealed that majority of music therapists included in this study are not actively including different languages in sessions based on patients’ primary language. Results showed having personalized tools for learning and applying different languages is an important resource for music therapists to begin this inclusion. Findings from this survey may reveal a need for more research regarding the effects of language inclusion in music therapy sessions as well as the need for this inclusion based on client preferences. Further results and implications are discussed within this study.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SELF-COMPASSION AS RESISTANCE: EXPLORING THE BENEFITS OF SELF-COMPASSION FOR QUEER COUPLES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Self-compassion can be understood as cultivating a gentle and understanding relationship with the self. The benefits of self-compassion for romantic relationships have been well-established in the literature. Additionally, the benefits of self-compassion for LGBTQ+ individuals has also been examined. However, no studies to date have examined the associations between self-compassion and relationship outcomes for queer couples. Furthermore, given the established connection between internalized stigma and relationship quality, it is important to consider how internalized stigma may affect this association as well. Therefore, a sample of 143 queer couples was recruited to complete an online survey that assessed demographic information, self-compassion, internalized stigma, both positive and negative relationship quality, queer consciousness, and self-esteem. The data was analyzed using an Actor-Partner Interdependence Mediation Model, or APIMeM, to identify the mediating role of internalized stigma on the actor and partner effects of self-compassion and relationship quality. Self-compassion was not found to mediate the relationship between internalized stigma and relationship quality. The decision was made, then, to explore internalized stigma as a mediator between self-compassion and relationship quality, which yielded significant indirect effects, thus supporting the idea that internalized stigma helps to explain the relationship between self-compassion and relationship quality for queer couples. Additionally, self-esteem was added as a covariate, which resulted in self-compassion no longer having any significant direct or indirect associations with any of the study variables. The clinical implications of this study highlight the importance of addressing internalized stigma in queer couples who are hoping to increase relationship quality. One such way of addressing internalized stigma may be self-compassion interventions. Future directions and additional clinical implications are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: HIGH-ACHIEVING TEENAGE STUDENTS’ USE OF SOCIAL MEDIA AND TECHNOLOGY TO COMPLETE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSEWORK

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Academic Dishonesty (AD), Advanced Placement (AP), High-achieving teenage students (HATS), Social Media (SM), Technology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: High-achieving teenage students (HATS) take Advanced Placement (AP) courses to fulfill two goals: boost their grade point average (GPA) and maintain or increase their class rank. To assist in accomplishing these goals, HATS access social media (SM) and technology. Smart devices, laptops, and tablets provide easy access for HATS to build social communities where exchanging knowledge, sharing opinions, and communicating messages are related to AP. Therefore, continual access to social media communities serves as a gateway for HATS to participate in academic dishonesty (AD), which can adversely affect their performance on the AP exam but ultimately challenge the traditional models of teaching and learning. This exploratory qualitative study examines the social, behavioral, and technological worlds of HATS’ participation in AP courses. Twenty-one participants shared their perspectives through focus group interviews to answer why and how social media was used to complete AP coursework. Interview transcripts were coded using Atlas.ti, and these codes, along with prior research, revealed three themes for each research question:
1. Why HATS use SM emerged into the themes of personalized learning structures, time management, and building social media communities.
2. How HATS used SM resulted in developing learning strategies, fact-checking, and AD.
3. HATS's reactions to AD included various emotions, the depths of AD considered through “morally gray” lenses, and the justifications given to rationalize AD acts.
The results reveal a need to redesign our current teaching and learning models rather than trying to catch HATS’ engaging in AD behaviors.

DISS_description.DISS_title: COLLEGIATE CLASS PIANO IN THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE: AN INVESTIGATION OF COLLEGIATE CLASS PIANO COURSES IN NORTH AND SOUTH AMERICA
DISS_description.DISS_supp_title: CURSO UNIVERSITARIO DE PIANO EN EL HEMISFERIO OCCIDENTAL: UNA INVESTIGACIÓN DE LOS CURSOS UNIVERSITARIOS DE PIANO EN AMÉRICA DEL NORTE Y DEL SUR

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Collegiate Class Piano, Globalization, Group Piano, North America, Piano Pedagogy, South America

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Collegiate class piano for music majors has grown substantially since its beginnings in the mid-twentieth century and has been developed by music teachers and organizations. Research on collegiate group piano has increased in the past forty years, and literature on teaching strategies, professional development, technology, and perceptions of students is available. Presently, there have not been any post-pandemic studies which have collected instructor perceptions on collegiate group piano. Additionally, there is limited literature focusing on collegiate class piano outside the United States. The purpose of the study was to investigate the status of group piano instruction as well as instructor perceptions in universities throughout North and South America through a mixed methods investigation. To accomplish this goal, the researcher collected data from class piano instructors in universities across eight different countries within the Western Hemisphere. The questionnaire developed by the researcher served as the survey instrument for this investigation. The researcher used the data collected to analyze the program structure of collegiate group piano classes, investigate the materials, resources, and equipment used by instructors, as well as collect information about instructors’ educational backgrounds and group piano training. The researcher sent emails to a total of 40 universities across North, Central, and South America, and received replies from 20 universities. The number of participants for the present study was 28. Results from the questionnaire indicated that piano performance (36%) was the participating instructors’ most common musical concentration during their training. Other areas were reported as well such as piano pedagogy, theory/composition, collaborative piano, music education, musicology/ethnomusicology, conducting, and jazz. Out of all instructors, a slight majority (54%) had not received training specifically in group piano pedagogy. Data from the questionnaire revealed that the typical number of sequential semesters of class piano offered at universities was 3.55, with music theatre (M = 3.5, SD = 1.91) and theory/composition majors (M = 3.29, SD = 1.07) being required to take the most semesters. Weekly contact hours were reported to be slightly below 2 hours (M = 1.93, SD = 0.73). The textbook most frequently chosen from the questionnaire's list for classroom use was Alfred’s Group Piano for Adults (43%), however several instructors from South America gave titles of the books and materials that they use in their classes which gave deeper insight into the curriculum used in other countries. Names of smart device applications and websites were also shared. Of the digital tools listed in the questionnaire, the most used item across all participating countries (30%) was YouTube. The questionnaire also revealed significant differences in some perceptions between North and South America. When instructors were asked to rank their students’ attitudes toward the university class piano requirement, North American instructors’ rankings (M = 3.4, SD = .83) were lower than South America instructors’ rankings (M = 3.92, SD = .52). Another significant difference found between the two continents was that when asked to rank the importance of 11 skills commonly learned in class piano, South American respondents overwhelmingly rated chord progressions very highly (M = 4.7, SD = .4) whereas North American responses exhibited greater variability and an overall lower ranking (M = 4, SD = 1.13). The reason for this disparity is likely due to the manner in which chord progressions and accompaniment styles are taught in South American countries. Near the end of the questionnaire, instructors also shared their thoughts on the possibility of a national standard for university class piano in their countries. Those who were not in favor of a standardized curriculum mentioned that it is important to keep class content flexible, and respondents who were in favor of a national standard stated that it would be useful for more uniformity across institutions. According to the results from the research questionnaire, the researcher recommends that more rote teaching be implemented into North American class piano instruction to enhance the student learning experience. The researcher also proposes that while a standardized curriculum may not be necessary, more national guidelines can ensure consistency across universities to give students a strong foundation of piano fundamentals on which they can build upon if specialized skills are desired in the future. Finally, the researcher suggests embracing a more global perspective on piano pedagogy, and that instructors worldwide engage in increased international dialogue to foster sharing of repertoire, learning new pedagogical strategies, and nurturing mutual growth.

DISS_supp_abstract.DISS_para: La clase universitaria de piano para estudiantes de música ha crecido sustancialmente desde sus inicios a mediados del siglo XX y ha sido desarrollada por profesores y organizaciones de música. La investigación sobre el piano de grupo universitario ha aumentado en los últimos cuarenta años y se encuentra disponible literatura sobre estrategias de enseñanza, desarrollo profesional, tecnología y percepciones de los estudiantes. Actualmente, no ha habido ningún estudio post-pandémico que haya recopilado las percepciones de los profesores sobre el piano de grupo universitario. Además, existe poca literatura centrada en clases universitarias de piano fuera de los Estados Unidos. El propósito del estudio fue investigar el estado de la enseñanza de piano en grupo, así como las percepciones de los instructores en universidades de América del Norte y del Sur a través de una investigación de métodos variados. Para lograr este objetivo, el investigador recopiló datos de profesores de piano en universidades de ocho países diferentes dentro del hemisferio occidental. El cuestionario elaborado por el investigador sirvió como instrumento de encuesta para esta investigación. El investigador utilizó los datos recopilados para analizar la estructura del programa de las clases universitarias de piano en grupo, investigar los materiales, recursos y equipos utilizados por los instructores, así como recopilar información sobre los antecedentes educativos de los instructores y la formación de piano grupal.??? El investigador envió correos electrónicos a un total de 40 universidades de América del Norte, Central y del Sur, y recibió respuestas de 20 universidades. El número de participantes para este estudio fue 28. Los resultados del cuestionario indicaron que la interpretación del piano (36%) fue la concentración musical más común de los instructores participantes durante su formación. También se informó sobre otras áreas, como la pedagogía del piano, teoría/composición, piano colaborativo, educación musical, musicología/etnomusicología, dirección y jazz. Del total de profesores, una ligera mayoría (54%) no había recibido formación específica en pedagogía de piano en grupo. Los datos del cuestionario revelaron que el número típico de semestres secuenciales de clases de piano ofrecidos en las universidades era 3,55, siendo obligatorios que los de especialidad en teatro musical (M = 3,5, SD = 1,91) y teoría/composición (M = 3,29, SD = 1,07) tomaran la mayor cantidad de semestres. Se informó que las horas de contacto semanales eran ligeramente inferiores a 2 horas (M = 1,93, SD = 0,73). El libro de texto elegido con mayor frecuencia de la lista del cuestionario para uso en el aula fue Alfred's Group Piano for Adults (43%). Sin embargo, varios instructores de América del Sur dieron títulos de los libros y materiales que utilizan en sus clases, lo que brindó una visión más profunda del plan de estudios utilizado en otros países. También se compartieron nombres de sitios web y aplicaciones de dispositivos inteligentes. De las herramientas digitales enumeradas en el cuestionario, el elemento más utilizado en todos los países participantes (30%) fue YouTube. El cuestionario también reveló diferencias significativas en algunas percepciones entre América del Norte y del Sur. Cuando se pidió a los profesores que clasificaran las actitudes de sus alumnos con respecto al requisito de clases de piano en la universidad, las clasificaciones de los profesores de América del Norte (M = 3,4, SD = 0,83) fueron inferiores a las de los profesores de América del Sur (M = 3,92, SD = 0,52).
