Otra diferencia significativa encontrada entre los dos continentes fue que cuando se les pidió que clasificaran la importancia de 11 habilidades comúnmente aprendidas en clase de piano, los encuestados sudamericanos de manera abrumadora dieron una calificación muy alta a las progresiones de acordes (M = 4,7, SD = 0,4), mientras que las respuestas norteamericanas mostraron una mayor variabilidad y una clasificación general más baja (M = 4, SD = 1,13). La razón de esta disparidad probablemente se deba a la forma en que se enseñan las progresiones de acordes y los estilos de acompañamiento en los países de América del Sur. Casi al final del cuestionario, los profesores también compartieron sus opiniones sobre la posibilidad de un estándar nacional para las clases universitarias de piano en sus países. Aquellos que no estaban a favor de un plan de estudios estandarizado mencionaron que es importante mantener flexible el contenido de las clases, y los que estaban a favor de un estándar nacional afirmaron que sería útil para lograr una mayor uniformidad entre las instituciones. Según los resultados del cuestionario de investigación, el investigador recomienda que se implemente más enseñanza de memoria en la instrucción de clases de piano norteamericanas para mejorar la experiencia de aprendizaje de los alumnos. El investigador también propone que, si bien puede ser que no sea necesario un plan de estudios estandarizado, más pautas nacionales pueden garantizar la uniformidad entre las universidades para brindar a los estudiantes una base sólida de fundamentos del piano sobre la cual puedan desarrollar si desean habilidades especializadas en el futuro. Finalmente, el investigador sugiere adoptar una perspectiva más global sobre la pedagogía del piano y que los instructores de todo el mundo participen en un mayor diálogo internacional para fomentar el intercambio de repertorio, aprender nuevas estrategias pedagógicas y fomentar el crecimiento mutuo.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Learning Data-Driven Graphs with Graph Neural Networks for the Classification and Prediction of Alzheimer’s Disease

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: To this day, the origins and prognosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) pose significant challenges. This thesis presents a methodology to understand AD by systematically applying state-of-the-art techniques from graph neural networks (GNNs) to medical images, producing a set of individualized graphs suitable for analysis. We accomplish this task by defining a latent graph variable as an intermediate latent variable inferred in a machine learning task. As one of the first researchers to explore the use of GNNs with medical images, this thesis begins with simple machine learning tasks that gradually increase in complexity. In particular, the thesis is organized into the following four main parts: (1) establishing a baseline with standard attention-based models applied to gray matter and PET probability regions of interest (ROIs), (2) developing a 3D-CNN model for processing voxel images directly to infer a latent graph more interpretable and closely aligned to known forms of connectivity within the brain, (3) learning latent graphs for a challenging network diffusion task with synthetic and real longitudinal datasets, (4) and developing a pipeline based on statistical analysis and metrics for comparing the learned latent graphs to baseline graphs derived from standard methods to assess the performance of the latent graphs.

Our experiments show that the careful application of GNNs to medical images can provide a suitable inductive bias to enhance performance compared to standard baselines such as support vector machines and multilayer perceptrons. The latent graph connectivity structure learned from our new 3D-CNN-GNN model alone is significant enough to achieve state-of-the-art precision when differentiating between patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) who will progress to AD and those who will maintain an MCI diagnosis, providing a set of interpretable features to uncover the mysteries surrounding AD.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Written in the Margins: Forgotten Art Songs of the Romantic Era Transcribed for Horn

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Clara Schumann, Fanny Mendelssohn, French horn, Josephine Lang, Transcription, Women Composers

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Throughout the course of history, women have often been relegated to the margins ofsociety. The cultural and societal expectations kept them on the sidelines and in the footnotes of history books. Historically, women were not allowed to be composers or performers of music, especially of brass instruments until the twentieth-century. This has left a gap in the repertoire of women-composed music before the 1900s. During the nineteenth-century, many women composers produced quality music within the boundaries that society set upon them—music for voice, piano, or sometimes stringed instruments. Unfortunately, compositions for brass instruments such as French horn were seen as a masculine endeavor and most women composers avoided composing for them until the twentieth- and twenty-first- centuries. This document features six compositions by Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel, Clara Schumann, and Josephine Lang transcribed and arranged for French horn. The compositions include Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel’s Schwanenlied from 6 Lieder, op. 1 and Abendbild from 5 Lieder, op. 10; Clara Weick Schumann’s Liebst du um Schönheit from Op. 12 No. 14 and Warum Willst du And’re Frangen; and Josephine Lang’s Wenn zwei Voneinander Scheiden and Wie glänzt so hell.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Economics of Effective Punishment

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Asset Pricing, Corporate Finance, Fraud, Law and Finance, Punishment, Trust

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: First we show that, since 2000 the U.S. federal government has imposed over $600 billion in penalties and spent over $5 billion in preventing fraud. Yet 87% of firms re-offend, which raises the question, is punishment effective? We analyze the effectiveness of federal monetary sanctions using U.S. courts’ five criminal law rationales for punishment: retribution, specific deterrence, general deterrence, incapacitation, and rehabilitation. We show that punishment has the largest effects on retribution and rehabilitation. We measure that a $1,000,000 increase in annual sanctions is associated with 3% decrease in firm value, as measured by Tobin’s Q, and a 57% improvement in Li et.al(2020) strong culture , which we use as a proxy for firm culture. We find substantial evidence that punishment effectiveness is aggravated by firm reputation, governance, and political connectedness. Next, we investigate the impact of government subsidies on corporate financial strategies, focusing on payout policies, debt reduction, and asset management. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset and employing methods to address endogeneity, we provide evidence that firms significantly alter their financial behaviors following the receipt of government subsidies. Specifically, we find evidence that firms increase payouts to shareholders, predominantly through share repurchases, after receiving subsidies. This behavior underscores a preference for returning value to shareholders when external financing conditions are favorable. We further observe a shift towards debt reduction, indicating a concerted effort to optimize capital structure and reduce financial risk. Contrary to initial hypotheses, the anticipated increase in asset investments is not sustained when endogeneity concerns are addressed, suggesting that the immediate response to subsidies does not translate into long-term asset growth. Further, our analysis identifies distinct shifts in firm behavior in theaftermath of significant economic events, during the dot-com bubble burst and the 2007 financial crisis. These periods reflect a change in how firms allocate subsidized resources, highlighting the influence of economic context on corporate financial decisions. This paper notes that while firms react strongly to both negative and positive shocks from the government, the reaction by firms to negative government shocks are broader.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Unsung Heroines: Epic Femininity in Slavic Oral-Traditional Epic of the Balkans

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Balkans, Bosniak, Bulgaria, Epic, Epic femininity, Serbia

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This paper explores modern Bosniak, Serbian, and Bulgarian oral-traditional epic, three closely related Balkan cultures and traditions linked through cross-border exchange and commonality of experience within the Ottoman ecumene. The dominant gender code for men in these borderland societies of the early modern Balkans was epic masculinity, as illustrated in heroic songs (BCS junacke pjesme and Bulgarian junaški pesni.) Through my reading of these heroic songs, I identify a perplexing, submerged theme—feminine roles that scold, censure, and punish failures in epic masculinity. I argue that, ultimately, these expressions of scolding, mocking, vulgarity, and curses serve as a mechanism to maintain and reinforce epic masculinity. Moreover, this study proposes that this function may be an extension of women’s child rearing role. Through examination of these female roles and their expressions in heroic epic and non-heroic epic, this study seeks to recover aspects of epic femininity in oral-traditional narrative song and hypothesize as to women’s gender roles in their heroic Slavic borderland communities of the Balkans.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UNACCOMPANIED HORN REPERTOIRE BY UNDERREPRESENTED COMPOSERS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: French Horn, Horn, Solo, Unaccompanied, Underrepresented

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Works for unaccompanied horn written by straight, white, cisgender male composers are often more accessible than those written by underrepresented composers, information about these works is more readily available than those composed by underrepresented composers. Despite this, there is a plethora of works written by underrepresented composers for unaccompanied horn that are beneficial to learn and program. This treatise provides detailed information about selected repertoire for unaccompanied horn composed by women, black, brown, indigenous, Asian (BBIA), and lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, plus (LGBTQ+) composers. Reference note cards provide information a performer would need to consider when searching for repertoire to program, such as the difficulty of the work, what equipment is needed, the setting of the work, and the background of the composer. Three pieces of varying difficulty from those provided in this treatise are further explored through interviews with the composers and a structural analysis.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Changes in ocean redox over Earth's history: Developing and utilizing paleoredox proxies and constraining oxygen budgets

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: end-Permian mass extinction, large igneous provinces, oceanic anoxic events, Smithian-Spathian boundary, thallium isotopes, trace metal concentrations

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Phanerozoic is typically known as an interval in which complex life has developed and thrived. However, there are multiple instances throughout this era in which climatic shifts and extinctions have made it difficult for the development of life. One of the most notable factors affecting marine biota throughout the Phanerozoic is the presence (or lack thereof) of oxygen; thus, better constraining the redox conditions of the ocean is vital during intervals of rapid change. One means to do this is through the development and improvement of novel and useful redox proxies, such as thallium (Tl) isotopes. Using marine sediments off the coasts of California, Mexico, and Peru, various low oxygen conditions were analyzed for Tl isotopes to expand settings known to record seawater values. This work expanded previous studies that failed to look into more suboxic settings and showed that the most accurate seawater records can be found in anoxic environments with elevated sulfide content in pore waters, with other less reducing conditions showing a range of values between seawater and sources. Applying this proxy to the end-Permian mass event (EPME), there are notable shifts in Tl isotopes. Not only was there a visible change towards more anoxic conditions earlier than other proxies can determine, but there was also a sudden rapid negative excursion that indicated short-term oxygenation at the onset of the extinction interval, contributing to the massive loss of life through rapid redox fluctuations. Continuing this work to the next minor extinction event chronologically, the Smithian-Spathian extinction provides a persistence of the low-oxygen conditions that was present at the very beginning of the Triassic following the EPME as well as transient redox fluctuations at the extinction interval. Lastly, to better constrain these anoxic events, a model of oxygen across Oceanic Anoxic Event 2 and the Toarcian Oceanic Anoxic Event was applied. Using these well-studied events, a model comparing excessive oxygen production from burial of organic carbon and pyrite sulfur to large igneous province erupted reductants was created, the results of which showed a large influx of reductants is capable of balancing much of the excess oxygen that should be produced during anoxic events. All of these projects show the importance of redox to understanding the development of Earth’s systems, which in turn affected the development of life on the planet throughout the Phanerozoic.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A System of Systems Framework for Data Analytics in the Built Environment: A Case Study of Florida Transportation System

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Composite index, Dynamic factor analysis, Emergent behavior, Evolutionary behavior, System of systems, Transportation system

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Infrastructure systems are the backbone of modern civilization, supporting our cities, economies, and way of life. Yet, they do not exist in isolation. They are continually influenced by a multitude of external social, economic, and environmental factors. These impacts may affect the structure of the built environment over time (i.e., through the evolutionary process) or the interplays between and within subsystems, thus causing emergent behaviors. In anticipation of the immense complexity of the built environment and the diversity of the influential factors, the major research challenge is finding an approach that yields engineering solutions to understand how, when, and why the evolutionary and emergent behavior of a system occurs. Answering such questions is the first step toward developing adaptive, preventive, or corrective plans and programs to enhance infrastructure resilience to external dynamics. This research proposes a framework to facilitate understanding the impact mechanisms of the external factors causing infrastructure evolution. Such knowledge is necessary to determine how a behavior evolves throughout a system. Given the diversity of the factors affecting the infrastructure system, an overwhelming amount of information needs to be continuously monitored and analyzed to comprehend the changing nature of the built environment. To address these challenges, the proposed framework uses multivariate analysis methods to identify and detect the most influential external factors driving the behaviors of the built environment system of systems. Dynamic factor models are developed to construct a composite index framework that (1) monitors and analyzes large volumes of information from numerous external factors impacting the system, (2) detects changes in the trends of the influential factors, and identifies how these changes originated within the system, and (3) analyzes how the internal system dynamics are influenced by external impacts.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SHAPING STONES: A 3D GEOMETRIC MORPHOMETRIC EVALUATION OF LATE PLEISTOCENE AND EARLY HOLOCENE ADZES FROM NORTHWEST FLORIDA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Adze, Geometric morphometrics, Lithic anlaysis, Southeastern archaeology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this research project is to provide insight into 3D GM methods in regard to lithic artifact research and provide data that allows a better understanding of the variables that affect a 3D GM study and the importance of the third dimension when investigating adzes. Geometric Morphometrics (GM) quantifies the shape variation of objects while controlling for variables such as scale, size, translation, and rotation then utilizes multivariate statistics to identify trends in the data. GM maintains the shape of an object more than traditional linear measurements so that morphological comparisons can be more comprehensive than traditional linear measurements. Most of the archaeological studies that utilize GM in American archaeology focus on skeletal remains and bifacial lithic points. While 3D GM analyses of skeletal remains are often employed, the lithic analyses have largely been restricted to 2D analyses for reasons that will be covered in this thesis. Because there are not many 3D studies on lithic tools, a portion of this research will be dedicated to refining 3D GM digitization and model construction of thick lithic tools in an effort to help standardize 3D GM analysis so that the comparisons of different research projects are more robust and error introduction is better understood. The results of this analysis provided ways to increase the efficiency of 3D GM studies and indicated that the third dimension accounted for a majority of the variation present in adze morphology, suggesting that a 2D analysis would be insufficient to understand the morphological trends found within this tool type. These methods were also used to analyze a sample of adzes from three different sites as well as an assemblage with unknown provenience. When adze morphology was compared to the site locations, regional trends were able to be identified.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ADHD Behaviors & Response to Reading Instruction

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: ADHD behaviors, hyperactivity-impulsivity, inattention, instruction, reading

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ADHD is a behavioral cognitive correlate of achievement associated with lower reading performance. The externalizing and internalizing symptoms that characterize ADHD behaviors negatively impact the engagement of students experiencing reading difficulties and the ability to regulate attention and behavior during the reading acquisition process. There is also considerable comorbidity between ADHD and reading-related learning disabilities driven by genetic and environmental pathways. This poses challenges for interventions (i.e., an environmental factor) containing reading instruction designed to improve the reading performance of children who may be exhibiting ADHD behaviors. This study examined the associations between ADHD behaviors and response to reading instruction, using a diverse sample of at-risk kindergarten and first-grade children (N = 715) across 67 classrooms who participated in a randomized control trial evaluating the Individualized Student Instruction (ISI) reading intervention. A structural equation modeling approach assessed teacher-rated ADHD behaviors predicting response to instruction across several teacher-implemented instructional reading approaches (ISI vs. BAU). Qualitative differences in the associations based on the operationalization of ADHD behaviors (i.e., inattention, hyperactivity-impulsivity, and combined) were examined. Exploratory analyses were performed to examine whether the association between ADHD behaviors and children's response to reading instruction significantly differed by instructional group. Several subscales of the SWAN Rating scale measured ADHD behaviors. Response to instruction was based on residual gain scores in reading-related skills measured as a composite of decoding and expressive vocabulary skills from subtests of the Woodcock-Johnson III Tests of Achievement. A statistically significant negative relation was found between the ADHD behaviors and response to instruction. Higher teacher-rated ADHD behaviors predicted lower SDs in response to reading instruction. Qualitatively, the combined ADHD behaviors produced the strongest association and explained the most variance than the other ADHD behaviors. Exploratory analyses suggested that there were significant instructional group differences for inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity but not the combined ADHD behaviors. The multiple-group models favored the ISI group. ADHD behaviors and response to instruction were more strongly related to lower responsiveness to instruction in the BAU group compared to ISI. This study highlights the role of distinct ADHD behaviors in early reading-related skills in response to reading instruction. These preliminary analyses have implications for classroom-based reading instructional practices and empirically replicating evidence to understand the influence of ADHD behaviors on efforts to remediate poor reading in children.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORING FOREST CHANGE DYNAMICS: A SYNTHESIS OF MOST COMMONLY IDENTIFIED DRIVERS INFLUENCING TROPICAL FOREST COVER CHANGE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Agriculture, Climate Change, Forest Loss, Land-use land cover change, Tropical Deforestation, Tropical forest degradation.

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The destruction of vast tropical forests poses a threat to both globally significant biodiversity and carbon storage. Tropical deforestation and degradation are complex phenomena driven by a combination of proximate causes, such as agricultural expansion, wood extraction, infrastructure development, and biophysical conditions, as well as broader underlying drivers, including economic, demographic, technological, and cultural factors. Here we present a comprehensive synthesis of case-based studies (n = 199) that identified proximate causes and/or underlying drivers of tropical deforestation or degradation, and quantified forest cover loss. Latin America emerged as the most frequently studied region, accounting for 42.2% of all cases. Agriculture stood out as the most commonly identified proximate cause of deforestation across all regions, constituting 84.9% of cases and was frequently identified in conjunction with other proximate causes. While recent research has emphasized the role of agricultural expansion as a prominent contributor to tropical forest cover change, we show that agricultural expansion rarely occurs in isolation. Biophysical factors, such as droughts, wildfires, and pest outbreaks, also played a significant role in forest cover loss in all regions. Rates of forest cover loss associated with different proximate causes did not appear to differ. We further examined the ability of common satellite vegetation indices of “greenness”, the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and the Enhanced Vegetation Index (EVI), to capture changes in tropical deforestation or degradation after forest cover loss was detected in primary studies. We found that these indices failed to show reduced greenness after forest cover loss was identified. In some cases, these indices showed increased greenness, presumably owing to conversion to intensive commercial agriculture. It appears that only in cases of complete vegetation loss from infrastructure projects such as forest conversion to roads or buildings, did NDVI and EVI decrease after forest cover loss was detected. Our results suggest that strategies for the prevention and mitigation of tropical forest cover loss should not only consider the role of agricultural expansion but also how agriculture interacts with other proximate causes. Furthermore, the vulnerability of these forests to environmental stressors is important to consider given the prominent role of biophysical factors in forest cover loss. Lastly, although NDVI and EVI are widely used in large-scale analysis of vegetation change, they appear to capture only the near-complete loss of vegetation and may be insufficient to detect other ecological impacts of tropical forest cover change.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Photophysical Properties of Fluorescent Triazoles and Their Photochemical Conversion into Indoles

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Copper Catalysis, Fluorescent Triazoles, Photochemistry, Triazole Photodegradation Mechanism, Triazole Photophysics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The photophysical and photochemical properties and the photoconversion scope and mechanism of di- and triaryl-substituted-1,2,3-triazoles are reported in this work. The ease of synthesis of regioisomers of substituted triazoles enables a systematic study on the correlation between regiochemistry and excited state properties, which include the solvent dependence of fluorescence, energy gap between singlet and triplet emitters, and propensity to photon-triggered transformations. Triazoles that carry electron (e)-donor and e-acceptor aryl substituents show high fluorescence quantum yields in weakly polar solvents and exhibit solvent-dependent fluorescence. The luminescence properties of these compounds in glass matrices at 77 K and the thermal and photo-stability of these compounds are determined. The position of the e-donor substituent has a significant impact on the fluorescence emission energy and solvent sensitivity, singlet-triplet energy gap, and photochemical reactivity and stability. Quantum chemical calculations were used to explain the experimental observations on the structural correlation with the photophysical and photochemical properties. The photochemical reactivity in the triazole conversion to indole was leveraged to study the reaction mechanism and intermediates (carbene and azirine). A new method for the synthesis of 5-cyanotriazoles was developed to expand the scope of the photoconversion of triazoles into indoles.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The molecular and genomic regulatory mechanisms underlying the evolution of invertebrate venoms

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Centipede, Epigenomics, Genomics, Molecular Evolution, Scorpion, Venom

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Understanding how a single genome can produce drastically different phenotypes is a central themein evolutionary biology. It requires a keen understanding of the ecological, molecular, and genomic regulatory mechanisms driving phenotypic, often adaptive variation. As complex traits with clear fitness implications and well-defined genotype-phenotype maps, venoms represent practical systems for evaluating the interplay between phenotypic change and genetic regulation. In addition, as approximately 15% of all animals are venomous, studying venomous animals will likely have wide- ranging impacts for the ecosystems in which they inhabit. Furthermore, the tendency for venom proteins to target specific physiological systems and pathways makes them excellent resources for bioprospecting novel therapeutic compounds. However, most research on venom has focused on snakes, which only represent a small proportion of venomous animals. Conversely, invertebrates, which represent a disproportionately large number of venomous animals, have historically received a disproportionately low level of research attention. Although not as charismatic as their reptilian counterparts, research on venomous invertebrates benefits from lower regulatory pressures, often trivial sampling methods, reduced maintenance effort and cost, and significantly diminished safety risks. For this research in this doctoral dissertation, we use scorpions and centipedes to evaluate the molecular and genomic regulatory mechanisms underlying the evolution of invertebrate venoms and make the case for a scorpion as model species. In Chapter 1, we begin our work at the ecological by assessing rates of venom regeneration in one scorpion and one centipede species. As biochemical traits with clear fitness consequences, venoms serve a critical ecological role for the animals that produce them. Understanding how venoms are maintained and regenerated after use will, therefore, provide valuable insight into the ecology of venomous animals. Furthermore, most studies on venomous organisms often require removing animals from the wild and waiting extended periods of time between venom extractions. Uncovering the patterns of venom regeneration across different species will likely lead to the development of more efficient venom extraction protocols, reducing both experimental time and the number of animals required. Using reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography, we identified asynchronous regeneration of venom protein component abundances in the centipede Scolopendra viridis but found no evidence for asynchronous venom regeneration in the scorpion Centruroides hentzi. We also observed high levels of intraspecific venom variation in C. hentzi, emphasizing the importance of testing for intraspecific venom variation in studies evaluating the synchronicity of venom regeneration. Although the regeneration of relative venom protein component abundances is an asynchronous process in S. viridis, we provide evidence that the presence-absence of major venom components is not an asynchronous process and suggest that studies relying on just the presence/absence of individual proteins (e.g. bioprospecting, drug discovery) could use catch-and- release methods of venom extraction to reduce the number of animals removed from the wild. In Chapter 2, we leverage high-throughput sequencing technologies to evaluate the genetic ba- sis for sex-biased gene expression in centipede. Sexually dimorphic traits are widespread across metazoans and are often the result of sex-specific inheritance or sex-based differences in gene ex- pression. Intersexual differences have even been observed in invertebrate venoms, although the identification of these differences has been limited to the more well-studied groups, such as scor- pions and spiders, where sex-based differences in morphology and behavior are apparent. Recent studies on centipede venom have identified evidence of intraspecific variation, but intersexual dif- ferences have not been reported. To investigate the potential for sex-based differences in centipede venom composition, we performed reversed-phase high performance liquid chromatography (RP- HPLC) analyses on five male and 15 female eastern bark centipedes (Hemiscolopendra marginata) from the Apalachicola National Forest in northern Florida. After detecting a significant sex-based difference in H. marginata venom composition, we completed a high-throughput venom-gland tran- scriptomic and venom proteomic analysis of one male and one female to determine the genetic basis for differences in venom composition. We identified 47 proteomically confirmed toxins and 717 nontoxin transcripts in H. marginata venom-glands. Of these proteomically confirmed toxins, the most abundantly expressed in the male venom included ion channel-modulating toxins and toxins so divergent from any characterized homologs that they could not be given a functional classification, whereas the most abundantly expressed in the female venom were γ-glutamyl transferases and CAPs (cysteine-rich secretory proteins, antigen 5, and pathogenesis-related 1 proteins). These differences were then confirmed by performing replicate LC-MS/MS analyses on the venom from an additional three male and three female H. marginata. Our RP-HPLC and high-throughput transcriptomic and proteomic approach resulted in not only an in-depth characterization of H. marginata venom, but represents the first example of sex-based variation in centipede venoms. In Chapter 3, we shift towards improving our understanding of scorpion venom protein diver- sity by characterizing the venom from one species of an underrepresented genus. Scorpion venoms have long been studied for their peptide discovery potential, with modern high-throughput venom- characterization techniques paving the way for the discovery of thousands of novel putative toxins. Research into these toxins has provided insight into the pathology and treatment of human diseases, even resulting in the development of one compound with Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval. Although most of this research has focused on the toxins of scorpion species considered medically significant to humans, the venom of harmless scorpion species possess toxins that are homologous to those from medically significant species, indicating that harmless scorpion venoms may also serve as valuable sources of novel peptide variants. Furthermore, as harmless scorpions represent a vast majority of scorpion species diversity, and therefore venom toxin diversity, venoms from these species likely contain entirely new toxin classes. We sequenced the venom-gland tran- scriptome and venom proteome of two male Big Bend scorpions (Diplocentrus whitei), providing the first high-throughput venom characterization for a member of this genus. We identified a total of 82 toxins in the venom of D. whitei, 25 of which were identified in both the transcriptome and proteome, and 57 of which were only identified in the transcriptome. Furthermore, we identified a unique, enzyme-rich venom dominated by serine proteases and the first arylsulfatase B toxins identified in scorpions. In Chapter 4, we evaluate the molecular signatures of selection underlying the evolution of giant desert hairy scorpion venoms. Venoms are primarily believed to evolve under strong diversifying selection resulting from persistent coevolution between predator and prey. Recent research has challenged this hypothesis, proposing that venoms from younger venomous lineages (e.g., snakes and cone snails) are governed predominantly by diversifying selection, while venoms from older venomous lineages (e.g., centipedes, scorpions, and spiders) are under stronger purifying selection. However, most research in older lineages has tested selection at more diverse phylogenetic scales. Al- though these tests are important for evaluating broad macroevolutionary trends underlying venom evolution, they are less equipped to detect species-level evolutionary trends, which likely have large impacts on venom variation seen at more diverse phylogenetic scales. To test for selection among closely related species from an older venomous lineage, we generated high-throughput venom-gland transcriptomes and venom proteomes for four populations of Giant Desert Hairy Scorpions (Hadru- rus), including three Hadrurus arizonensis populations and one Hadrurus spadix population. We detected significant episodic and pervasive diversifying selection across a highly abundant toxin family that likely has a major role in venom function (αKTxs), providing a contrast to the stronger purifying selection identified from other studies on scorpion venoms. Conversely, we detected weak episodic diversifying and/or stronger purifying selection in four toxin families (non-disulfide bridged peptides, phospholipase A2s, scorpine-like antimicrobial peptides, and serine proteases), most of which were less abundant and likely have ancillary functional roles. Finally, although we detected several major toxin families at disproportionate transcriptomic and/or proteomic abundances, we did not identify significant sex-based variation in Hadrurus venoms. In Chapter 5, we broaden our focus to not only test for sex-biased venom genes in a sexually di- morphic scorpion, but also evaluate the genomic and epigenomic landscape underlying those venom genes. Unfortunately, while our knowledge of how phenotypic variation is influenced by changes in ecology, environment, gene number, and gene sequence is the result of work in a diverse set of systems, our understanding of complex, genomic regulatory networks stems primarily from research on human cells and model systems. Because studies in these systems are not typically paired with ecological experiments, much of the important context underlying the evolution of genomic regula- tory networks is missing. With the emergence of novel genomic methodologies and their continually increasing efficiency and decreasing costs, non-model systems, such as venoms, have become sen- sible, effective systems for studying how the epigenomic landscape influences variation in complex traits. However, as previously discussed, much of what we know about the genomic and epigenomic landscape underlying venom genes is the result of studies in venomous snakes. In most venomous taxa, venom genes are primarily organized into large tandem arrays of duplicated genes on a subset of chromosomes, with few exceptions. Generating a comprehensive understanding of the genomic landscape of venomous systems requires the generation of high quality reference genomes for mem- bers of all venomous lineages. Therefore, to resolve the genomic architecture for scorpion venom genes, we assembled the first chromosome-level genome for the Hentz striped scorpion (Centruroides hentzi). We also tested for sex-based differences in (1) differential expression of venom genes with RNA-seq, (2) differential chromatin accessibility using Cleavage Under Targeted Accessible Chro- matin (CUTAC), (3) differential H3K27ac histone modification using Cleavage Under Targets and Tagmentation (CUT&Tag), and (4) diet using PCR detection of arthropod-specific cytochrome c oxidase I genes. With this multifaceted approach, we not only provide a broad perspective of the ecological and genomic regulatory mechanisms underlying the evolution of scorpion venom genes, but make the case for C. hentzi as a model system.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORING THE RELATIONSHIP OF HOPE, METACOGNITION, AND THE PRACTICES OF L2 TEACHERS DURING COVID-19

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: teacher hope, teacher metacognition, teacher practices

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This work was designed to provide insight into how a disaster of historical proportions, in this case the COVID pandemic, influenced the work foreign language (L2) teachers in an English as a foreign language (EFL) setting. The research was situated within the framework of positive psychology (Seligman, 2011), with the investigation of the interactions of hope, metacognition, and teaching practices. In this work, Hope was understood to be a cognitive construct that refers to setting goals, finding pathways to achieve those goals, and using agency to persevere in those paths or find alternative ones (Snyder, 2002, 2005, 2018). This research hypothesized that the levels of hope experienced by L2 teachers were connected with other events in the classroom. The questions addressed in this research include the following: 1. What is the relationship between hope, metacognition, and foreign language teachers’ practice during a period of intense global difficulty? 2. Is L2 teacher metacognition a mediating variable between hope and teacher practices? 3. What other aspects of L2 teacher hope, L2 teacher metacognition, and L2 teacher practices can be identified through teachers’ reports of their teaching experiences during a period of intense global difficulty? Within an explanatory sequential mixed methods design, and using Likert surveys and interviews, I examined whether the levels of teacher hope, teacher metacognition and teacher practices were associated. The instruments used in in this research were the dispositional hope scale (DHS) (Snyder et al., 1991), the Language Teacher Metacognitive Inventory (LTMI) (Hiver et al., 2021; Jiang et al., 2016), and the Postsecondary Instructional Practices Survey (PIPS) (Walter et al., 2016). Interviews were conducted to provide complementary evidence of teacher hope levels, metacognition, and teacher practices of English as a Foreign Language (EFL) teachers during COVID-19. The High Leverage Teaching practices proposed by Glisan and Donato (2017) complemented the interview in regard to teacher practices as they supplement the 10 macrostrategies introduced by Kumaravadivelu (2006). The research questions were analyzed following a factorial confirmative approach, in which the components of each of the surveys were used to build the constructs they represent, and hypothesis were tested on them. This analysis included an exploratory factor analysis to examine internal reliability and a subsequent confirmatory factor analysis to do the actual testing of the underlying factor structure existence. Afterwards, the mediation analysis was achieved by fitting a SEM model and contrast the pathways among L2 teacher, hope, L2 teacher metacognition, and L2 teacher practices. Teacher interviews complemented the quantitative results, as four the four themes that emerged from the qualitative analysis (i.e., Foreign language teacher goals and pathway thinking, Foreign Language Teachers’ Coping Strategies, Teachers’ Metacognitive Classroom Experience, and Interaction in the Foreign Language Class) provided additional insights from participating teachers. Structural equation modeling suggested that L2 teacher metacognition is a significant mediator of the relationship structure between hope and instructional practices for the population under study. These findings speak to a connection between teacher hope, teacher metacognition, and teacher practices for L2 teachers during a period of social upheaval, something that can pave the way for other researchers working with teachers in different disciplines and during different periods of time. An important conclusion from this study was that understanding these constructs separately, their components and their connection may influence how teachers think about their profession with a view of improving of what they do in the classroom. Finally, tertiary teacher preparation institutions may be encouraged to measure these constructs in order to target interventions to influence how teachers think about their profession with a view of improvement. Keywords: teacher hope, teacher metacognition, teacher practices

DISS_description.DISS_title: State of Charge Estimation of Lithium ion Battery for Electric Vehicle Application

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Battery Management Systems, Electric Vehicle, Kalman Filter, Lithium-ion Battery, NARX, State of Charge

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Battery State of Charge (SOC) is the parameter representing the fraction of a battery’s remaining available energy to its fully charged state. The Battery SOC is one of the most important parameters of an electric vehicle’s (EV) Battery Management System (BMS) as it is used for battery pack balancing, estimating available power, battery safety control, and providing users with available runtime. Electric Vehicle mostly uses lithium-ion battery because of its high energy density which comes with a cost of complex non-linear dynamic system. Lithium-ion batteries are susceptible to over-charging and undercharging because of their inherent properties. Their dynamic properties also tend to change with ambient temperature, operating current, SOC, and operating voltage. Hence requires a complex Battery Management System (BMS) to effectively manage the dynamic parameters. SOC is one of the most important intermediate parameters required for effective EV battery management. In addition, the life cycle of lithium-ion batteries is also a function of its operating SOC. Unfortunately, EV battery SOC cannot be measured directly due to lack of parameter linearly proportional to its available energy. Hence it requires complex estimation algorithms to achieve an accurate SOC estimate. It is often the case that conventional EV SOC management system over-compensates the SOC error estimates at the cost of usable energy. Another common challenge with conventional algorithms is their inability to reconverge quickly from erroneous initialization. Quick convergence and fast SOC estimation algorithm is also required in EV for fast charging. This research proposes a novel ensemble algorithm that uses a weighted estimate of the Central Difference Kalman Filter (CDKF) and Nonlinear Autoregressive with Exogenous Input (NARX) to estimate SOC. The proposed method improves the accuracy of SOC estimates in comparison to convention ensemble SOC estimation methods especially at low temperature. The method introduces an SOC estimation technique which converges quickly from large erroneous initialization state, this is particularly useful in super-fast EV charging technology. Finally, the proposed method provides robust and reliable SOC estimates. The robustness of the proposed method is tested under various drive cycles and temperatures. The estimator provides a reliability indicator in the form of a convergence covariance which indicates how close the estimate is to the true value.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NONLOCAL INTEGRABLE MODELS AND CONSTANT-INTENSITY WAVES IN NON-HERMITIAN MEDIA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: integrable systems, non-Hermitian optics, nonlinear waves, nonlocality

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In the theory of wave propagation, several important nonlinear dispersive systems are known to be integrable – that is, exactly solvable by linear techniques. Such systems are typically characterized by the existence of an infinite number of conserved quantities, a Hamiltonian structure, the admittance of soliton solutions, and many other rich mathematical properties. The primary focus of this thesis is a study of integrable systems that are nonlocal in the sense that they possess a reflected and shifted spatial and/or temporal argument. Chapter 1 serves as an informal overview of the field of integrable partial differential equations and an introduction to this nonlocal variety. Chapter 2 provides a detailed analysis of the solution process, known as the inverse scattering transform (IST) method, for several examples of nonlocal integrable systems. The IST is developed and solutions are constructed for nonlocal variants of the nonlinear Schr ̈odinger (NLS) equation, the modified Korteweg-de Vries (mKdV) equation, and the semi-discrete Ablowitz-Ladik (AL) lattice.

The secondary subject of this thesis is beam propagation in non-Hermitian optical media. In this context, non-Hermiticity refers to the presence of a complex-valued index of refraction, where the imaginary part is interpreted as a distribution of gain and loss of power (which in this case in not conserved). Such systems have been shown (theoretically and experimentally) to possess many counter-intuitive properties, one of which is the existence of constant-intensity (CI) waves that can propagate through the medium without diffracting. In Chapter 3, special types of these CI waves are introduced and their properties and further implications, including their usefulness in the study of dispersive hydrodynamics in non-Hermitian media, are discussed.

These two topics are unified by the fact that they both center around NLS-type models in which certain fundamental properties such as conservation of power and translational invariance are lost. In the latter case, this is due to a complex external potential, while in the former case this is due to a nonlocal self-induced potential.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NO MORE GAMES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The poems in No More Games explore the cyclical and complex relations of religion, loss of faith, newly found love, immigration, the female body, and the Anthropocene in a linguistically hybrid landscape. These poems track the internal and the external world of a speaker who has immigrated from Turkey to America at a young age, as the geographical landscape in which the poems are set vary from Turkey to Kyrgyzstan to America. While influenced by contemporary poets, the manuscript aims at shedding light onto an encounter that is rarely highlighted in contemporary American poetry: the loss of religion, specifically Islam, in a particularly Islamophobic American sphere and the complications that may occur from such an encounter. The speaker of the poems is concerned with similar tensions, including the impending climate crisis, the metamorphoses of cultural identity as a Turkish-American, and the effects of violence upon the female body inflicted by a patriarchal figure. These tensions are navigated by the words of Gloria Anzaldúa in Borderlands/La Frontera, when she writes “I feel perfectly free to rebel and to rail against my culture” (43). She adds to this phrase by stating “Yet in leaving home I did not lose touch with my origins because lo mexicano is in my system. I am a turtle, wherever I go I carry “home” on my back” (43). This idea becomes the compass for No More Games, as the speaker in the poems both rebels and is loyal to the roots which haunt the self, whether those roots are Islam, the patriarchal aspects of Turkish and American culture, or recording the collective cry of an aging world while immersed in love.

DISS_description.DISS_title: WHAT MOTIVATES BUSINESS STUDENTS' INTERNSHIP ENROLLMENT DECISIONS? EXPLORING FACTORS INFLUENTIAL TO DECISION-MAKING

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Business Internships, Career Readiness, Internship Program Design, Satisfaction in Internships, Self-Determination Theory, Student Motivation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation delves into the factors that motivate business students to enroll in internship courses at Florida State University's College of Business, as well as the satisfaction they experience with these internships. Using a quantitative approach rooted in Self-Determination Theory, the study utilizes the Academic Motivation Scale (AMS) (Vallerand et al., 1993) and the Instructional Materials Motivation Scale (IMMS) (Reference) to determine students' intrinsic and extrinsic motivations and their satisfaction with internship experiences. The research provides an understanding of how internships align with students' educational and professional goals, highlighting the role of academic curricula and external influences in shaping their decisions. Findings indicate the dominance of extrinsic motivations, particularly identified regulation, over intrinsic factors. While participants expressed moderate intrinsic motivation, emphasizing the "To Experience Stimulation" regulatory style, satisfaction levels, measured by the IMMS, revealed a moderate trend. Higher satisfaction correlated with the successful completion of course modules and engagement in a well-designed course. Robust correlations between intrinsic motivations and satisfaction underscored the significance of autonomy. Notably, identified regulation within extrinsic motivations significantly correlated with satisfaction, particularly concerning career decision-making. The findings have implications for developing internship programs, emphasizing the importance of aligning these programs with students' career aspirations and ensuring that they offer meaningful, practical learning experiences.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Skeletal Devotion: Reading Death in Polychrome Wood Sculpture of the Colonial Andes

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Death and Dying, Devotional Sculpture, Manuel Chili "Caspicara", Polychrome Wood Sculpture, Quito School, Skeletal Imagery

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Fates of Man, a series of four polychrome wooden sculptures attributed to Indigenous artist Manuel “Caspicara” Chili, made in Quito, Ecuador in c. 1775, stands as one of the primary examples of the artwork produced by the Quito school. Characterized by their emotionality, the four figures represent the iconographical program of The Last Things, a Catholic visual convention demonstrating the four endings that await the soul once the material body has passed on, including Death, Soul in Heaven, Soul in Hell, and Soul in Purgatory. By considering this group within the complex and ever-changing historical landscape of the colonial Andes, the figure of the skeleton takes on a broad multivalent meaning. Through the examination of the skeleton within the European and Andean iconographic canons, the figure of Death in Caspicara’s devotional program becomes a means of thinking about the complex worldviews of the eighteenth-century Andes that informed the various viewer perceptions of Catholic imagery in the region.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EVALUATING THE IMPACT OF A RESEARCH ADMINISTRATION WORKPLACE TRAINING PROGRAM ON THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY OF A RESEARCH-INTENSIVE UNIVERSITY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Evaluation, Kirkpatrick's, Research Administration, Training, University, Workplace

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: As governments and other organizations worldwide increase their investment in research, the demand for skilled research administrators grows. Researchers need knowledgeable administrators to provide guidance and ensure their projects are administratively managed according to required policies and guidelines. Institutions must ensure their audit risk is managed appropriately without creating unnecessary burdens and hardships for their researchers. With a lack of academic programs in research administration, most research administration professionals enter the field with limited to no understanding of research administration. The need for research administration training programs is high. To address Florida State University’s (FSU) needs in this area, the Office of the Vice President for Research (OVPR) staff developed and implemented a research administration certification program. All FSU research administrators must complete the eSPEAR Research Administration Certification Program within six months of starting their position.Florida State University (FSU) has invested staff time and other resources into developing and delivering this program. FSU wishes to evaluate the value provided to FSU’s research community by eSPEAR and identify where changes or expansion would bring value. While FSU’s OVPR requests feedback from participants following the training, this provides only a snapshot of the learner’s experience immediately following the completion of the program. No industry-accepted method for evaluating research administration training programs exists. Kirkpatrick’s Four Levels of Evaluation, which looks at learner satisfaction, learning, behavior, and return on expectations, provides a model that could potentially fill this void. This study uses Kirkpatrick’s Four Levels of Evaluation to evaluate FSU’s eSPEAR Program. Information was gathered from learners who completed the training, their supervisors, the researchers they support, those involved in developing eSPEAR, and members of FSU’s Council of Associate Deans for Research (CADR). Overall, favorable feedback was received from learners and their supervisors. The response rate from researchers, CADR members, and those involved in developing eSPEAR was lower. Their responses were broad, with some highly favorable and others unfavorable. Many respondents answered with neutral answers, mainly due to their lack of direct knowledge. The study results provided insights into what works well with the program and where additional content, or further training development is needed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A Partnership Case Study: The American Repertory Theater and Harvard University

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This qualitative case study describes how American Repertory Theater (ART) and Harvard University (Harvard) decision-makers perceive the exchange that occurs through their partnership. Since the majority of nonprofit theaters in the United States struggle with sustainability (Fonner et al., 2020), and affiliations support sustainable operations for nonprofits (Álvarez-González, 2017; Mandel & Brudney, 2018; Shumate, 2018; Sowa, 2008), this study ultimately profiles this one specific affiliation to promote awareness of a theater and higher education affiliation model. The study uses social exchange theory (Burgess et al., 1979; Homans, 1958) as a theoretical framework. Pragmatism (Dewey, 1948; James, 1928) as a philosophical worldview informed the study. This case study explores three research questions: (1) What do Harvard and ART decision-makers perceive that each entity gives through the exchange? (2) What do Harvard and ART decision-makers perceive each entity gets from the exchange? and (3) What is each entity’s level of relationship commitment and propensity to leave the affiliation? Jeong and Oh’s (2017) business-to-business social exchange model served as a framework for answering research question three. This case study used content analysis (Schreier et al., 2019) and interviews (McGrath et al., 2019) to collect data and coding (Strauss & Corbin, 1990) to analyze the data. To enhance the study’s trustworthiness, member checking (Birt et al., 2016) served as a form of structural corroboration (Eisner, 1991). Through the findings I identified three ways that decision-makers perceive what each entity gives and gets through the partnership, (1) resource-driven exchange, which includes a give from one organization’s resources and a clear get for the other organization; (2) byproduct benefits, which are benefits received by one entity as a result of the partnership but not definitively tied to the resources of their partner, and (3) synergy, which occurs when the partners work together with their resources on a single artistic output. The results show that through resource-driven exchange ART gives, and Harvard gets: educational support for Harvard’s Theater, Dance & Media concentration; internship and mentorship for students; facility operations; and Harvard events produced by ART, and that Harvard gives and ART gets: use of performance, rehearsal, office, and set construction space; financial support; and support for information technology, legal, and human resources. As a result of the partnership, ART receives the byproduct benefits of: reputational benefits by association with Harvard; increased audience development opportunities due to the geographic area they operate in; enhanced access to donors who otherwise may not support a nonprofit theater. Likewise, as a byproduct of the partnership, Harvard gets: reputational benefits relative to the arts, locally, nationally, and internationally; engagement opportunities for local community members to access Harvard; the arts more infused in the cognitive life of Harvard; opportunities for interdepartmental connections through the arts in an otherwise decentralized institution. Through a synergetic collaboration, the partners develop new works of theater. ART staff and Harvard researchers each provide their expertise to develop well-informed and impactful pieces of art. Through the co-creations ART gets access to in-depth expert research, and Harvard researcher get an artistic platform to share their research with a broad community. Examples of this include the new musical We Live in Cairo, and Ocean Filibuster. The partners exhibited a high level of relationship commitment and a low level of propensity to leave the partnership based on Jeong and Oh’s (2017) model. Decision-makers used the partners’ collaboration of a new $100,000,000 arts center that will house ART as evidence of relationship commitment. Participants described high levels of trust between those at ART and Harvard. The decision-makers shared that Harvard’s policies and bureaucracy created the only challenges. This dissertation includes several conclusions, and recommendations for practitioners and future research relative to nonprofit arts organization and HEI partnerships based on the study. In the ART and Harvard partnership, ART receives more impactful resource-driven benefits than byproduct benefits, and Harvard receives more impactful byproduct benefits than resource-driven benefits. Recommendations for practitioners include: seek to understand what their organization could give and get through a partnership; identify possible the motivations a partnered, or potentially partnered organization; and, for decision-makers in nonprofit arts organizations, consider how integrated their organization should be with an HEI – the more integrated they are, the greater the potential resources but the more they must work with the often-bureaucratic structures of an HEI.

DISS_description.DISS_title: POPULISM, PATRIOTISM, AND PROPAGANDA: THE TWENTIETH CENTURY AMERICAN BRASS FANFARE AND ITS CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Brass, Chamber Music, Fanfare, Patriotism, Populism, Propaganda

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this treatise is to survey eight of the Ten Fanfares by Ten Composers for Brass and Percussion commissioned by Maestro Eugene Goossens and the Cincinnati Symphony for performance use throughout the 1942-43 season. Eighteen composers responded with fanfares for different combinations of instruments. Ten feature brass and percussion exclusively. Composers included in this commission consist of prominent figures such as Aaron Copland, Howard Hanson, Virgil Thompson, Paul Creston, among others. This treatise revitalizes the importance of these chamber works as an addition to the brass ensemble repertoire, the larger diaspora of twentieth century American music, and how the underlying connection(s) between musical performance and politics have cultural implications that shape and manifest various outlooks on citizens within a nation.In addition to exploring the historical and cultural context and legacy of these works, this document serves to invite greater discussion within arts organizations about the importance of programming lesser-known works for the sake of greater representation. These fanfares are less than a century old and many of these works have not seen a proper performance since their original premieres in the 1940s. The research and explanations in this treatise intend to bring greater exposure surrounding their purpose and effect in hopes of these fanfares utilized for performance into the twenty-first century.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXTRA-LINGUISTIC FACTORS IN LANGAUGE COMPREHENSION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Anxiety, Big Five Personality Traits, Language Comprehension, Neuroticism, Personality, Pupillometry

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Personality has been found to have significant connections to language. Ranging from impacting narrative style, to informing expectations about others based on linguistic factors such as accent, personality affects both language comprehension and production (Oberlander & Gill, 2004; Van den Brink et al., 2012). However, research in this area primarily focuses on offline measures. Online measures, such as EEG or pupillometry, have not been included until recently. Pupillometry, which involves measuring the size of the pupil, is considered a reliable indicator of cognitive effort during language comprehension. Hubert-Lyall and Järvikivi are unique in their research studying the possible relationship between personality and online language comprehension due to their use of pupillometry (Hubert & Järvikivi, 2019; Hubert-Lyall & Järvikivi, 2021). They showed that several of the Big Five personality traits are related to the processing of errors during language comprehension. Unfortunately, theoretical explanations of the language-personality link are undeveloped. One theory, presented by Hubert and Järvikivi (2019) and Jiménes-Ortega et. al. (2022) posits that perhaps for Neuroticism, anxiety may be the connecting factor between personality traits and language comprehension.

The current studies had two goals. First, we aimed to replicate the findings of Hubert-Lyall and Järvikivi (2021) using the same methodology but in a new population and culture. Second, we aimed to address a more specific hypothesis – does Anxiety, through its connection to Neuroticism, predict cognitive load in response to errors in sentences? Overall, we found mixed results. While we did not replicate the findings from Hubert-Lyall and Järvikivi (2021), nor did our results replicate from our own Experiment 1 to Experiment 2, we did find possible support for the connection between anxiety and language processing. However, it does not seem as though anxiety alone can account for the Neuroticism x language comprehension connection.

DISS_address.DISS_addrline: 954 Indigo Creek Way, Tallahassee, FL, USA

DISS_description.DISS_title: DEVELOPMENT OF SULFIDE- AND HALIDE-BASED FAST-ION CONDUCTORS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) represent a promising advancement in electrochemical energy storage, with solid electrolytes (SEs) playing a crucial role. Sulfide and halide SEs have garnered substantial interest due to their distinct characteristics; sulfide SEs offer high ionic conductivity and stability with Li metal anodes, while halide SEs have better compatibility with high-voltage cathodes. This dissertation explores the structure-property relationship of mixed-anion frameworks in both sulfide- and halide-based SEs, aiming to fine-tune material structures and properties for enhanced battery performance.Firstly, we delve into the transformation of Li3PS4 via the introduction of LiBr. 31P NMR unveils the emergence of a glassy PS43− network interspersed with Br−. Solid-state NMR corroborates fast Li+ migration between PS43− and Br−, with increased Li+ mobility. A more than four-fold enhancement in ionic conductivity is observed upon LiBr incorporation (1.06 mS cm-1) into Li3PS4 (0.23 mS cm-1) resulting from the reduction of the energy barrier and transitioning Li+ transport dimensionality from 2D to 3D. The compatibility of Li3PS4 with Li metal is improved alongside an increase in critical current density (CCD) from 0.34 mA cm-2 to 0.50 mA cm-2 while preserving the electrochemical stability window. ASSB cells with 3Li3PS4:LiBr as the SE and TiS2 as the cathode active material (CAM) show robust high-rate and long-term cycling performance. Secondly, we incorporated LiBr and LiI simultaneously in Li3PS4 as a mixed-halide strategy. We achieve a two-fold increase in conductivity using a one-step ball milling technique. Subsequent low-temperature sintering further enhances conductivity to 4.43 mS/cm with a low activation energy of 0.29 eV. Furthermore, we engineered a cell configuration with stable milled SE layers toward Li metal and a high-conductive sintered SE separator in the symmetric cell with which CCD further increases compared to individual separators. In addition to sulfide-based SEs, Li-deficient lithium yttrium bromide, Li3-xYBr6-x, was prepared using the co-melting method. High-resolution X-ray diffraction and Rietveld refinement confirm the formation of the monoclinic structure with the C2/m space group with increased cation site disorder and polyhedral volume. Bond valence site energy calculations show the Li+ migration energy barrier from Li-deficiency. Ab-initio molecular dynamics simulations show the emergence of 3D-Li+ conduction. Solid-state NMR spectroscopy confirms the elimination of LiBr impurities and reveals increased Li-ion dynamics. An ionic conductivity of 4.49 mS cm-1 and activation energy of 0.28 eV were achieved. Furthermore, we synthesized a series of Li2.73Ho1.09Cl6-xBrx compounds using a solid-state co-melting approach. Crystal structure analysis revealed the presence of Li-ions in 2d octahedral sites of the C2/m space group for x ≥ 2. Analysis shows highly disordered cation sites with mixed occupancy of Li/Ho. 6Li solid-state NMR revealed a highly disordered local Li environment, which increases with Br/Cl substitution. The significant improvement in room-temperature ionic conductivity from 0.45 mS cm-1 for Li2.73Ho1.09Cl6 to 3.79 mS cm-1 for Li2.73Ho1.09Cl3.27Br2.73 is achieved with a significant decrease in activation energy from 0.38 eV to 0.32 eV, respectively. Further mixing anions and cations within a SE significantly enhances ionic conductivity by introducing controlled disorder at both cation and anion sites. This increases the system's configurational entropy and allows for the overlap of energy bands. Incorporating Mg2+ and Hf4+ into a Li3ClBrI mixed-rock-salt structure results in a substantial increase in ionic conductivity, reaching 0.88 mS cm⁻¹ for Li1.54Mg0.23Hf0.17Cl0.68BrI. The enhanced conductivity is attributed to a nanoscale solid solution between the disordered rock-salt and spinel structure. Moreover, introducing a mixed anion sublattice into cost-effective LiAlCl4 through a simple one-step mechanochemical milling process led to a 22-fold increase in ionic conductivity – from 0.0083 mS cm⁻1 to 0.18 mS cm⁻1 for Li2AlCl3S. This improvement can be attributed to the formation of new Li sites, enabling efficient 3D Li+ transport. The strategy leverages the inherent disorder to modify the Li-sublattice locally, leading to broader lithium-ion site occupancies and enhanced ion dynamics through polyhedral edge sharing. Mechanochemical milling of thiophosphate-based SEs combined with TiS2 CAM produces a composite material that leverages both cationic (Ti3+/4+) and anionic (S2-/n-, where n<2) redox processes – resulting in ~2× enhancement in specific capacity. Catholytes containing mixed-anion SEs, especially with 3Li3PS4:LiBr, demonstrate better cycling performance compared to their mono-anion counterparts due to the improved ionic conductivity and thermodynamical stability. In summary, this dissertation explores innovative compositional design, optimal synthesis environment, and characterization of mixed-anion SEs, in addition to the utilization of these SEs in ASSBs. Overall, this research provides valuable insights into the development and application of high-performance ASSBs, addressing challenges associated with SEs in energy storage.

DISS_description.DISS_title: CULTURAL RESPONSIVENESS IN INSTRUCTIONAL DESIGN: A STUDY OF INSTRUCTIONAL DESIGNERS’ USE OF STRATEGIES IN THE NON-ACADEMIC, ADULT LEARNING CONTEXT

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: adult learning, culturally responsive design, culturally responsive pedagogy, DEI, instructional design, professional development

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Training and development are used extensively in the United States to impact employee learning and performance. The considerable investment and expenditures across public and private sectors and the vast number of employees who receive support from training and development professionals warrants exploration into how instructional designers are supporting a culturally diverse labor force. This qualitative research study explores how and why instructional designers developing training in a non-academic, adult learning settings incorporate cultural responsiveness in their instructional design (ID) practices. Incorporating evidence from semi-structured interviews with thirteen instructional designers across various levels of experience and organizational types, findings demonstrate that instructional designers are incorporating culturally responsive strategies in support of diverse learner populations. Results suggest that focus can be placed on cultural responsiveness during all phases of the systematic ID process and that there are considerable instructional, institutional, and personal dimensions working together at various degrees. Designers rely on their existing ID knowledge and institutional supports to execute their strategies and are driven by personal experiences and an organizational culture that respects diversity, equity, and inclusion.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NONTRADITIONAL-AGE STUDENT ENROLLMENT IN A PUBLIC REGIONAL UNIVERSITY: THE ROLE OF INDIVIDUAL, ACADEMIC, AND FINANCIAL FACTORS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Adult Student, Nontradtional

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The number of Nontraditional-age students has been on the rise in higher education over time, and although this population has been increasing nationwide, there has been a continued decline in nontraditional-age students at Florida Gulf Coast University (FGCU). This quantitative study focused on the background characteristics, academic characteristics, and financial characteristics of accepted nontraditional-age undergraduate students in an effort to alter admission strategy and improve enrollment of nontraditional-age students at the institution. The results of a three-step logistic regression model found there were significant predictors of enrollment related to the background characteristics, academic characteristics and financial characteristics utilized in the regression models of the study. The results of the study will be utilized in FGCU Admissions to refine recruitment strategy in an effort to enroll more nontraditional-age undergraduate students.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Evaluating Values: Understanding the Epistemic Worth of Values in Science

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Epistemic, Non-epistemic, Science, Social, Values

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: I argue that the dividing of values into epistemic and non-epistemic is not a productive way to understand and judge the influence of values in science. A better approach is to consider what is motivating a value and what justifies using it in a particular context. By reframing our assessment of values this way, we can better recognize epistemic contributions from diverse values. I further argue that when a value improves the empirical adequacy of a hypothesis or theory, the use of that value is epistemically justified in that context. To illustrate this point, I offer an example where the value of egalitarianism, which is widely considered to be a “non-epistemic value,” improved the empirical adequacy of a neuroscientific hypothesis, rendering the value epistemically justified in that context. Ultimately, I hope to make plausible the epistemic advantage of using that which has traditionally been relegated to the category of the non-epistemic—morally sound values.

DISS_description.DISS_title: INTERNET BASED ADAPTIVE TELEOPERATION OF LEAD VEHICLE IN PLATOON : USING WAVE VARIABLE AND PREDICTOR TECHNIQUES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Adaptive, Consensus, Multi-agent, Predictor, Stability, Teleoperation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study addresses the challenge of achieving a stable teleoperation over the Internet, improving the convergence rate in the presence of high communication time delays, and maintaining consensus in the platoon while the lead agent is being teleoperated over Internet. The first part of this thesis dealt with stable teleoperation where we employ a passivity-based formalism to establish stability using wave variables and wave scattering techniques, and we enhance the convergence rate by combining it with predictor-based approaches. The elevated time delay within the teleoperated communication layer - The second part is known to induce collision between the agents as well as descensus behaviour in the platoon, which reduces the convergence rate and increases the settling time in the convergence of power variables. This issue is addressed in this paper by utilizing a Smith predictor on the operator end and Minimum Jerk (MJ) predictors on the remote end. We present experimental and simulation results to demonstrate the improvements, ensuring stable teleoperation under high communication time delays.Contributions of this thesis work include: • Setup a teleoperation platform over Wi-Fi and the Internet. • Identify the instability in the system, and implement the wave variable method to introduce stability which leads to witnessing the convergence issue. • Implementing Smith Predictor and MJ predictor to compensate convergence issue. • Design a platoon multi-agent system where the first agent is teleoperated over internet. • Study the performance of the approached model in Simulink and Hardware.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring Striated Muscle: Cryo Electron Microscopy Insights into Thick Filaments in Drosophila and Vertebrates

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The introduction of cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) has greatly improved our understanding of structural biology, especially regarding muscle tissue. This technique has been key in revealing the complex structure and functional dynamics of myosin filaments, essential for muscle contraction. Cryo-EM's ability to provide high-resolution images gives us an unmatched look into the intricate interactions of muscle proteins, effectively closing the gap between biochemical theory and the actual observation of molecular structures. Unlike traditional crystallography, which needs protein crystallization and might introduce artifacts, cryo-EM allows for the observation of proteins in a state close to their natural environment, avoiding these issues.This study centers on the cryo-EM investigation of myosin filaments, focusing on sample preparation, data processing, and the protein composition and structure across different species, including both vertebrates and invertebrates. Chapter 1 introduces the basic principles of structural biology and explaining the groundbreaking role of cryo-EM in this field. It covers the essentials of protein structure, tracing the path from genetic code to the three-dimensional shapes vital for biological function. It also points out the key protein structures related to striated muscle, setting the stage for an in-depth look at myosin filaments in the following chapters. Chapter 2 explores the discovery of two distinct forms of myosin thick filaments in the flight muscles of Drosophila melanogaster, achieved through advanced cryo-EM techniques. This chapter not only points out the structural differences between ordered and disordered filament types but also introduces variations in flightin, a non-myosin protein, in these filament types. By obtaining high-resolution structures, this analysis provides a deeper understanding of the protein composition and conformational differences that contribute to these variations. In Chapter 3, the focus moves to building atomic models for both filament types, enabled by near-atomic resolution structures. This comparative study of myosin filament backbones in Drosophila flight muscles highlights the structural differences between ordered-head and disordered-head filaments. These models clarify the molecular interactions between myosin coiled coils and non-myosin proteins. Additionally, this chapter looks at mutations in myosin-related genes linked to human cardiac diseases, examining the corresponding residues in the atomic models and the significant interactions they are involved in. Chapter 4 turns the focus to vertebrate models, addressing the challenges and methodologies involved in preparing myosin filaments for cryo-EM study. It emphasizes the critical importance of preserving structural integrity during sample preparation, highlighting some techniques that help preserve the structure of the vertebrate’s filament during this process and paving the way for future experiments on vertebrates’ myosin filament. Looking forward, future research plans to use cryo-EM to study myosin filaments across different Drosophila mutants, comparing them with the wild type in terms of protein structure. This effort aims to figure out how changes between ordered and disordered configurations happen, hoping to gain deeper insights into the molecular mechanisms that control myosin filament organization and the functional effects of these structural changes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Betaine Improves Chronic Physiological Stress in Firefighters and Acute Thermoregulatory Outcomes During a Live Burn

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Environmental Physiology, Health, Recovery, Safety, Thermoregulation
