DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Dollhouse Dreams and Other Broken Things is a collection of personal essays exploring issues of the body, the historically silenced voice and shifting notions of femininity. The collection also investigates how myths that shape the body are continually carried down and reinforced by families, institutions, and culture. This essay collection is both a deconstruction of these myths and a reconstruction of what the body/home can look like—or rather what it means to (re)build after the deconstruction of patriarchal values. These essays illuminate both the holding of breath and the relinquishing of voice, but also the stirring movements towards agency. One sub-focus of this essay collection includes an interrogation of the fairy tale childhood—one that not only encourages a belief in happy endings anchored by a prince charming but also encourages this magical thinking in other avenues. Instead of doing away with these classic tales, I merge them with autobiographical essays in order to bring the woman back into these stories written by men, rebuilding and reshaping patriarchal representations of womanhood in the process.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring Well-being for Black Women Student Affairs Administrators

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Balance, Black Women, Student Affairs, Well-being, Wellness

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study will explore the mental and emotional well-being of Black women Student Affairs administrators by examining their experiences while working at historically White institutions. Their experiences will be examined using critical narrative inquiry and Black Feminist Thought to understand the layers of race and gender on their well-being in an academic institution. The participants' stories will add context to the conversation about the well-being of Student Affairs administrators and how their specific identities influence their experiences in these spaces.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Discovery, Exploration, and Evolution of Treefrog Biofluorescence

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Visual communication plays an important role in the evolution of organisms, as selection processes often rely on the organism’s physical appearance. For example, mate choice—often by females selecting the most attractive males—can lead to the evolution of brighter or more exaggerated patterns. However, there are instances where organisms have evolved physical attributes beneficial for sexual selection but costly in terms of energy expenditure or increased predation risk. A particularly valuable communication channel, then, would be one invisible to predators but helpful for identifying potential mates. Signals produced via the mechanism of fluorescence have been proposed to be such a channel. Although biologists have described biofluorescence in a diversity of taxa, there have been few systematic efforts to document the extent of biofluorescence within a taxonomic group or to investigate its general significance. These signals were recently discovered in amphibians. The goal of my dissertation was to: (1) assess the diversity of frog biofluorescence, (2) examine the function of fluorescence in predation on frogs, and to (3) reconstruct a highly supported phylogeny for a treefrog genus upon which we can (4) test for accelerated speciation of biofluorescence lineages within one treefrog clade.

First, through a field survey across South America, I discovered and documented patterns of biofluorescence in tropical amphibians. Through these efforts, I more than tripled the number of species that have been tested for this trait and added representatives from previously untested anuran families. Fluorescence was ubiquitous; I recorded at least a low-level fluorescent signal from every individual I tested. I found evidence for ecological tuning (i.e., the specific adaptation of a signal to the environment in which it is received) of the novel anuran biofluorescent signals. For the majority (56.58%) of Anura species tested, the fluorescence excitation peak matches the wavelengths most abundant at twilight, the light environment in which most frog species are active. Additionally, biofluorescence emission spans both wavelengths of low availability in twilight and the peak sensitivity of green-sensitive rods in the anuran eye, likely increasing contrast of this signal for a conspecific receiver. With evidence of tuning to the ecology and sensory systems of frogs, my results suggest frog biofluorescence is likely functioning in anuran communication.

After demonstrating the significance of frog biofluorescence as a potential signal, the next critical line of inquiry was to examine who is receiving the signal: potential predators, mates, or both. I began to test this through a case study experimentally testing the function of frog fluorescence in predation of a local treefrog species. Over half of the studies documenting biofluorescence in the last century suggest this fluorescent signal may affect predation; however, to date, only one other experimental study has tested this hypothesis. To address this question, I first quantified the spectral characteristics of a novel biofluorescence pattern in the Cope’s Gray Treefrog, Hyla chrysoscelis. In both sexes of this species, the fluorescent signal is concentrated in an area that contains a proposed aposematic pattern that may warn predators of the frog’s toxic secretions. I hypothesized that the biofluorescent trait may increase the conspicuousness of this pattern and enable the frogs to deter predators more effectively. I then tested this prediction by conducting a clay model field experiment to assess differences in predation attempts on fluorescent versus non-fluorescent H. chrysoscelis models by various predator types. I found no effect of biofluorescence on the overall presence, type, or location of predation, suggesting that biofluorescence alone does not act as an antipredator signal of H. chrysoscelis. This study represents one of the first attempts to experimentally test the effect of biofluorescence on predation in any organism and the first to do so in amphibians. Further work is needed to explore the role of this trait in predation in other systems and to investigate alternative functions for the biofluorescent signal in H. chrysoscelis.

The final goal of my dissertation was to examine the evolution of biofluorescence across an amphibian clade. To do so, I first reconstructed, and time-calibrated, a highly supported phylogeny for one treefrog genus upon which we can test for trait-dependent accelerated speciation rates. With 108 recognized species, Dendropsophus is one of the most diverse genera of tropical treefrogs in the Western Hemisphere. Despite the broad distribution of the clade across Central and South America, little is known about the biogeographic origins and expansion of the group or how key life history traits have evolved in this taxon. I reconstructed a phylogeny of Dendropsophus based on 432 nuclear loci for 78 taxa (72% of species) obtained using anchored hybrid enrichment. I estimated divergence times within the clade to reconstruct the biogeographic history of the genus to test alternative models of dispersal. I also assessed the evolution of egg deposition mode and examined correlations with speciation rate and the extent of biogeographic expansions. I recovered a well-resolved phylogeny with very strong support at 92% of the nodes. I found evidence that the genus likely originated approximately 57 mya, occupying the Eastern Highlands and Amazonian-Orinocan Lowland, and underwent multiple expansions into the surrounding Central and South American biomes. The origin of the genus predates the beginning of the Andean uplift in western South America. The best supported biogeographic hypothesis for the Dendropsophus clade is one of unconstrained dispersal between the Eastern Highlands and Amazonian Basin. My results suggest that the majority of Dendropsophus groups originated via range expansion speciation events that occurred during the Andean uplift. Overall, my phylogenomic data provide clear resolution of the evolutionary relationships among species of Dendropsophus. My study provides insight into the biogeographic origin and expansion of the clade and demonstrates that the dispersal of this group was not as heavily constrained by a changing ecological history as previously hypothesized. The evolution from an aquatic to terrestrial egg deposition mode was not correlated with speciation rate or the extent of biogeographic expansions. Given Dendropsophus is one of the most broadly ranging genera in South and Central America, my highly supported tree will be an invaluable tool for future clade-specific and comparative studies investigating the evolution of life history traits, mating behaviors, and ecological associations throughout these regions.

Finally, I mapped the evolution of biofluorescence across the Dendropsophus treefrog genus. I utilized ancestral state reconstruction to examine the evolutionary history of biofluorescent traits (intensity, area, and color) within the genus. Dendropsophus is a widespread, diverse South American genus, and studies have examined clade-specific drivers of diversification, but only within the context of ecological constraints and not color pattern divergence. The biofluorescent patterns I discovered in Dendropsophus range from widespread, full body coverage to location-specific patches. Hence, my goals of this study were to (1) map these traits across the recently published, highly supported, time calibrated Dendropsophus phylogeny based on anchored hybrid enrichment data, and (2) use state-dependent diversification models to determine if biofluorescence parameters affect speciation rate to ascertain whether visual (fluorescence) signals have contributed to an accelerated rate of speciation within the genus. My study provides the first insight into the evolutionary history of biofluorescence in Dendropsophus frogs. My results suggest a biofluorescent ancestor for the clade with an intense, widespread, green emission phenotype. I found evidence of a strong phylogenetic signal between the traits of fluorescence and the Dendropsophus phylogeny. Finally, fluorescent intensity, but not emission color, influenced speciation rate in the genus; and the influence of fluorescent area is still unresolved. Dendropsophus lineages with greater than 10% biofluorescent intensity had a speciation rate over 7.2 times faster than the speciation rate for lineages with less than 10% fluorescent intensity.

The combination of my findings suggests there is an adaptive function of frog fluorescence for intraspecific communication. I found (1) evidence for sensory drive of the frog fluorescent signal, (2) this signal meets criteria of ecological significance for intraspecific communication, (3) no effect of fluorescence on predation of frogs, and (4) a correlation between treefrog fluorescent intensity and an increased speciation rate. Together, these results highlight the potential importance of this recently discovered trait and the need for further exploration of this novel signal to determine its function in anuran communication.

DISS_description.DISS_title: STRING MUSICIANS’ PERCEPTIONS OF BATON USE AS COMPARED TO CHORAL AND BAND MUSICIANS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: baton use, conducting, perception

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to determine how choral, band, and orchestral string musicians perceive the clarity and expressivity of choral, band, and orchestral conductors based upon the use or non-use of the baton. This study aimed to address the following research questions: (1) Are there differences in collegiate choral, band, and orchestral string musicians’ ratings of conductor clarity or expressivity dependent upon the presence or absence of the baton? (2) Are there differences in collegiate choral, band, and orchestral string musicians’ ratings of conductor clarity or expressivity dependent upon the specialty of the conductor? (3) What aspects of conductor baton use or non-use influence collegiate choral, band, and orchestral string musicians’ ratings of conductor clarity and expressivity? (4) Do collegiate orchestral string musicians’ ratings of conductor clarity and expressivity align more closely to those of choral musicians, band musicians, or neither?I selected three highly expressive professional recordings of Morton Lauridsen’s O Magnum Mysterium, one each of the original chorus composition, the band transcription, and the string orchestra transcription. I then invited a graduate orchestral conductor, graduate band conductor, and graduate choral conductor to conduct the recording that fit their specialty both with and without a baton. I then recorded each conductor as they conducted along to their recording with and without a baton and replaced the camera audio with the professional audio. Two 30 second to 45 second excerpts from each conducting recording were selected and anonymized. These excerpts where then placed into a survey asking participants to view each video, rate each video for conducting clarity and expressivity, and optionally provide feedback about how they arrived at their ratings. This survey was then distributed to several universities around the United States. Participants (N = 238) consisted of collegiate choral (n = 93), band (n = 74), and orchestral string (n = 71) musicians. Statistical analysis revealed significant main effects for baton use in ratings of expressivity as well as significant interactions between conductor specialty and baton use for ratings of clarity and expressivity and significant interactions between participant musician type and conductor specialty for ratings of clarity. No significant interaction between participant musician type and baton use was found. Participants overall found the bare hands to be more expressive than the baton, with no significant difference in clarity. Both the choral conductor and band conductor were found to be clearer with the baton, significantly more so than the orchestral conductor. Chorus musicians considered the choral conductor to be clearer than either the band or orchestral conductor, while band and orchestral musicians both agreed that the orchestral conductor was less clear than either the choral or band conductor. Band and orchestral string musicians tended to align on most metrics. Qualitative analysis of comments (N = 599) left by participants suggests that most participants were influenced by aspects of the conductors unrelated to the baton or right hand. Of those comments that did center on the baton or right hand, most were concerned with issues of technique, congruency of musical gestures with musical response, and overall quality. Only a small subset of comments specifically attributed their ratings to the presence or absence of the baton. Taken together, these findings have implications for both conducting research and applied conducting. In conducting research, the practice of generalizing findings of studies done with wind and percussion players to all instrumentalists, inclusive of string players, would appear to be valid. The converse may also be true: the findings of future conducting research done with orchestral string players may also be generalizable to wind and percussion players. For applied conducting, while the need to be comfortable both with a baton and without a baton has not been negated, it seems that as far as musicians in general are concerned, conductors may be able to take advantage of the increased expressivity of conducting without the baton without a significant loss of clarity given appropriate technique and training. However, further research on the use of the baton in a variety of styles and tempi is necessary.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Flutist's Guide to Opera Fantasies

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Flute, Flute Music, Opera Arrangement, Opera Fantasy, Opera Transcription

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Many flutists are familiar with Francois Borne’s Carmen Fantasie, Franz and Karl Doppler’s Rigoletto Fantasie, and Paul Taffanel’s Mignon and Der Freischütz Fantasies. While these virtuosic showpieces have been favorites of the flute repertoire for decades, they only represent a small portion of a much larger body of repertoire. There are over 300 extant opera fantasies that feature the flute which have been arranged by over 120 composers and feature motives and themes from over 130 operas.

In addition to discussing the context in which the opera fantasy became so popular in the nineteenth century, this document intends to serve as a reference work for flutists by suggesting a proposed process for analyzing and performing opera fantasies and cataloging known and lost opera fantasies written for the flute. It also proposes why opera fantasies fell out of favor in the twentieth century, and presents justification for their continued relevance, pedagogical implications, and newfound popularity in the flute repertoire today.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Moscow is a State of Mind

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Moscow is a State of Mind explores the psychological landscape of a Dark Night of the Soul the narrator worked through between 2011-2023. Excising the roots of personal trauma by means of poems that describe personal events too intense and traumatic to place into narrative format—“event,” in this case, meaning a rupture in the narrative fabric of reality itself—Moscow is a book that reads “across” itself, as if a strong wind were spreading memory, desire, and lawn ornaments across the field of a troubled life. The poems speak to one another like an entangled quantum system. A dog appears in one poem as a porcelain accessory in an MTV music video, only to reappear later being led into the water to be drowned by its owner. By following the different guises of the dog and other similar patterns of imagery and exploring how they relate to one another, we begin to see a story superimposed on top of its own self, the mind as a feedback loop feeding itself back into itself, struggling to make sense of emotional realities too intense for narrative to capture. As William Blake wrote in his “Proverbs of Hell,” “The cistern contains; the fountain overflows.” The emotional trauma of a difficult childhood explains itself through meditations on time, human consciousness, global catastrophes present and past, Biblical allegory, and other similar intensities. Throughout, however, a curious form of joy and play provides a levity that counterbalances the darkness. In this surreal fusion of hell and joy, the narrator of Moscow is a State of Mind dances a war within himself, resolving what cannot be said through witness to what must not be forgotten. The end goal is annihilation of self, not through self-destruction but through self-transcendence: To wake up from history, even for a moment, into the vast presence of every possible dawn.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UTILIZING UNIVERSAL SCREENING TO ASSESS EFFECTIVENESS OF TARGETED SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL LEARNING CURRICULUMS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: ABSTRACTThe purpose of this study was to explore whether a targeted Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) program, Classroom Champions, would close gaps in SEL skill areas identified by a student universal screener. This study specifically examined the skill areas of persistence, engagement, and optimism. The first research question examined the levels of student persistence, engagement, and optimism in comparison and intervention groups before and after program implementation. The second research question examined the relationship between student participation in Classroom Champions and student growth in the areas of persistence, engagement, and optimism. The third research question examined how growth in the areas of persistence, engagement, and optimism among intervention group participants differed by gender. Participants in both the intervention (n = 215) and comparison group (n = 545) were in grades 6-12. Participants were given a universal screener prior to SEL curriculum to obtain baseline scores for persistence, engagement, and optimism. The screener was administered again after completion of instructional delivery to obtain post-test scores. Data analysis was completed with the use of paired sample t-tests, independent sample t-tests, simple linear regression, and multiple regression. Findings showed that both the intervention and comparison group saw statistically significant differences in pre- and post-test scores in the area of engagement. There was a statistically significant change score in the area of persistence for the intervention group; however, analysis of pre-test means showed that the intervention group started out significantly lower than the comparison group in this area. There were no statistically significant findings related to gender. In conclusion, although there were some statistically significant findings, there were no conclusive results that the targeted SEL curriculum was able to close the identified SEL skill gaps.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Building Reading Skills for Students with Extensive Support Needs

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: decoding, extensive support needs, letter sound correspondence, literacy, sound blending

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this dissertation was to extend the knowledge in the field on effective and efficient ways to teach reading to students with extensive support needs (ESN) in small groups. Chapter one provides the rationale for research on reading for students with ESN and an overview of the questions addressed in the dissertation. Chapter two is a systematic literature review of the research on reading interventions for students with moderate and severe intellectual disabilities (ID). This chapter describes the reading components targeted, identifies the evidence based instructional practices used in current research, describes the treatment intensity of intervention implemented in current research for students with moderate and severe ID and discusses the percentage of goal obtained for single case studies as a measure of effect size. Chapter three is a single-case, repeated acquisition design study that examines the effects of the Accessible Literacy Learning (ALL; Light & McNaughton, 2009) program on the development of letter sound correspondence, sound blending and decoding skills for students with ESN in small groups. Result of this study indicate that with explicit, systematic instruction and supports students ESN can make gains in foundational reading skills. Results, social validity, implications and future research are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: “Talent is evenly distributed, opportunity is not”: Exploring the role of the High School Partners Program on the college choice process among Black students at Florida State University

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: At-risk students, Black students, College access, College choice, College enrollment

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: While Black students have experienced significant growth in college enrollment since the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and Higher Education Act of 1965, they are still less likely than their white counterparts to attend and graduate from a post-secondary institution (Ryan & Bauman, 2016). There have been previous studies on college access programs that aim to combat the challenges contributing to the college access gap for Black students, such as percentage plans, admissions lotteries, and admissions preferences for low socioeconomic students. Although the aim was to promote equality, race-neutral and objective admissions policies perpetuate patterns of power, privilege, and racial inequity by assuming that all educational resources are equal (Bonilla-Silva, 2010). In an effort to address educational disparities, the Florida State University Office of Admissions, Center for Academic Retention and Enhancement (CARE), and Office of Financial Aid joined forces in 2015 to launch the High School Partners Program, a new college access initiative. Students from eight (8) public high schools located in three counties along the eastern and western corridor of Interstate 10 in Florida receive support with college applications and enrollment through the High School Partners Program (Florida State University, 2021). Increasing the percentage of students from underfunded public high schools who applied and were accepted to Florida State University was the objective of the High School Partners Program. All students at participating high schools are eligible for the High School Partners Program, regardless of their financial situation or status as first-generation students, although most of them come from historically underserved backgrounds. The purpose of this study was to explore the role of the High School Partners Program in the college choice process among Black students who enrolled at Florida State University through the general admissions process. This study is supported by research on factors associated with Black students' postsecondary enrollment patterns and chances to improve the pipeline and yield of students from high schools with inadequate resources. Hossler and Gallagher (1987) created a college choice model that outlined three stages (predisposition, search, and choice) that students go through while selecting a college, and this model had an influence on the research framework. The study explored a range of factors that influence students' decision-making through semi-structured interviews. The sample consisted of seven Black students who were enrolled in Fall 2023 and were alumni of a school that was affiliated with the High School Partners Program. According to the study's findings, Black students' enrollment in the predisposition or search stages of the Hossler and Gallagher College Choice Model (1987) was not significantly impacted by the High School Partners Program. Comparable to previous studies, family, college reputation, geographic location, cost, and availability of financial aid shaped Black students’ pre-college experiences (Bers & Smith, 1989; Clayton et al., 2023; Comeaux et al., 2020; Sevier, 1992; Weiler, 1994). However, the study indicated that the High School Partners Program played an influential role in the choice stage. Students gave a variety of reasons for choosing to enroll, including scholarship funding, interactions with Black FSU personnel, a different academic and cultural setting from their high schools, household structure, and family member accessibility. The findings also revealed that the High School Partners Program is positively correlated with postsecondary enrollment at FSU for Black student populations that were previously overlooked in the admissions process. These populations include first-generation students who are not eligible for Pell grants and second-generation students who are eligible for Pell grants, who each represent only 9.7% of the university's total FTIC Black student body in Fall 2023 (FSU Office of Institutional Research, 2024). Participants suggested that in order to improve the FSU High School Partners Program, the admissions staff should consider three primary modifications: 1) increase awareness of the High School Partners Program; 2) provide more opportunities to build relationships with FSU representatives; 3) assist in integrating students from partner schools into the FSU community. Further research is imperative to determine the High School Partners Program's viability as an approach to Black student recruitment and to obtain a better understanding of the student populations that stand to benefit the most from involvement.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EMOTION DYSREGULATION, PARENT-CHILD RELATIONSHIP QUALITY, PARENTING STRESS, AND ANXIETY OF EMERGING ADULTS AND THEIR PARENTS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Emerging Adult Anxiety, Emerging Adulthood, Emotion Dysregulation, Maladaptive Self-processes, Psychological Distress

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Emerging adulthood is a time of great vulnerability for psychological well-being, as during this time, individuals are facing numerous challenges stemming from societal demands in this transitional period. Most notably, emerging adults are some of the most highly anxious cohorts, with over half reporting symptoms of anxiety (Arnett & Colleauges, 2014). Furthermore, anxiety is rising more rapidly for emerging adults than any other age bracket (Goodwin et al., 2020). This research aimed to look internally and examine how emerging adult’s emotion dysregulation may potentially influence their levels of anxiety. Further, this study aimed to examine whether parent-child relationship quality moderated the relation between emerging adult emotion dysregulation and emerging adult anxiety. This research conducted a second study that examined the influence of emerging adult emotion dysregulation on their parent’s anxiety levels. This study also aimed to test whether parenting stress mediated the relation between emerging adult emotion dysregulation and their parents’ anxiety.

Study one participants consisted of 449 college students (M age = 20.45 years, SD = 2.85). Furthermore, study two participants were 142 parent-child dyads. This study analyzed secondary data, as both samples used in this study were sourced from a previous project. Findings from study one suggested that emerging adult emotion dysregulation was significantly associated with emerging adult anxiety. The hypothesis that parent-child relationship quality would moderate the relationship between emerging adult emotion dysregulation and emerging adult anxiety was not supported. For study two, results suggested that emerging adult emotion dysregulation was not significantly related to parents’ anxiety levels. Additionally, the mediation hypothesis of parenting stress between emerging adult emotion dysregulation and parent anxiety was not supported either. Implications of study findings, recommendations, limitations, and future research directions are discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: BAYESIAN SMOOTHER TUNING: DATA ASSIMILATION IN THE GEOSCIENCES WITH SUPER-PARAMETER OPTIMIZATION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Assimilation, Bayes, Bayesian, Filter, Smoother

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The process of Data Assimilation in the Geosciences, in which real world data is used to improve the mathematical simulation of some event of interest, is a large field in applied mathematics. When that system is driven by dynamics, and the real world data is incomplete and noisy, we use the interactions of Bayes Rule with the probability distributions to apply either a filter or smoother to the data. A filter considers an estimate of the current state of the system using up-to-date data, while a smoother considers an estimate of previous state(s) using up-to-date data. In this thesis, we focus on lag-$l$ Linear Ensemble Transfrom Smoothers (LETS), that use current data to estimate the state of the system $l$ cycles in the past using Monte-Carlo strategies confined to a lower dimensional subspace than the system's dimension. These methods assimilate each new observation as it arrives, behaving as a `smoother in filter's clothing.' Smoothers can have an advantage in forecasting future states over filters in some scenarios; characterizing these scenarios in a way that is practical is one of the goals of this work.

Each system in the geosciences will have a unique structure; the relevance of each observation to a feature of a system (such as a observation of wind above Liverpool and an estimate of the temperature in London), or the distance between two features in the system (such as the rainfall in New York and the rainfall in Seattle). By assimilating this structure, we can further improve the assimilated results produced by a smoother; this is called localization. Further, we can assimilate the reliability or unreliability of the system; this is called inflation. Finally, we can assimilate the `normality' (Gaussian) of the distributions produced to apply the correct method at the correct time; this is called hybridization. Each of the above can be accomplished by `tuning' scalar superparameters, and turning over the task of tuning to a Machine Learning (ML) method. In this work, we consider tuning all of the above when applied to the standard Lorenz test problems, using Global Bayesian Optimization (GBO) as the ML tool. Showing the extensive flexibility of tuning for smoothers, and how they can provide more meaningful comparisons than are standard in the literature, is the main goal of this work.

Along the way, we consider a novel cost/loss functions defined on a lag-$l$ smoother, and various novel LETS methods that are created by the constructive composition of multiple methods together. We consider different localization strategies under a `more fair' framework than what is standard in the literature, by tuning each competitor to near optimum performance given the system.

DISS_description.DISS_title: 13D Filings: Corporate Activism and Firm Skewness

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation explores two chapters of 13D filings. Chapter one examines the impact of activism by non-financial corporations. I find that the market reacts more favorably to corporate activism relative to non-corporate activism. This is irrespective of apparent economic links between a corporate activist and their target firm. Further, corporate activists do not facilitate takeovers in the ways traditional activist investors do. Despite this, I find that corporate activist target firms experience similar ex-post changes in cash, investment, leverage, payout policy, and profitability to non-corporate activist targets. Overall, corporate activists are beneficial to target firms, so it is important to consider them in future activist studies. Chapter two proposes that target firms of activist 13D filings are associated with a decline in the likelihood of experiencing an extreme positive return outcome; i.e., a decline in the target firm’s right-tail return skewness subsequent to the 13D event. The underlying logic is that activists often take actions that increase the target firm’s stock price at the expense of the small possibility of extremely favorable long-term return outcomes. Consistent with a correction of skew-induced overpricing, I report that stock price reactions to 13D filings are lower for target firms associated with higher idiosyncratic skewness. Additional evidence indicates that subsequent changes in firm investment are lower for 13D targets relative to non-13D targets. Further, ex-post extreme right-tail returns are less likely in the years after the 13D filing for targeted firms as opposed to non-targeted firms. Overall, the evidence suggests that investors downwardly revise their expectations of an extreme right-tail outcome following the involvement of activists.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TOCCATAS: SELECTED TOCCATAS BY BACH, DEBUSSY, PROKOFIEV, AND DIEMER; FRESH TAIWANESE FOLK SONGS: YI-CHIH LU AND HIS PIANO ARRANGEMENTS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Folk music, Piano arrangement, Piano music, Toccata

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This document comprises two main parts which will respectively focus on how composers, Johann Sebastian Bach, Claude Debussy, Sergei Prokofiev, and Emma Lou Diemer, composed original piano works under the generic title of “Toccata.” The second part will explore Taiwanese pianist Yi-Chih Lu and his four piano arrangements, which draw on various traditional Taiwanese folk songs.The first part explores the history of the toccata and its development in various periods, illustrating certain intrinsic toccata features that permeate these works. It examines the role these toccatas play in the composers' respective periods of composition and the individual approaches of composers in creating highly original works, despite all sharing the same title. The second part focuses on Yi-Chih Lu and his piano arrangements. Lu, a Taiwanese musician, was born and grew up in Taiwan. After completing high school, he went to Europe to continue his music study. Lu was majoring in piano performance when he was studying classical music in Europe, and this experience influenced a lot in his following arrangements about Taiwanese folk songs. Lu has composed numerous arrangements to date, the selected four works in this document serve as fitting examples to demonstrate Lu’s compositional journey. Both Lu and his piano arrangements are gaining more recognition and are being wildly performed. Beyond representing Taiwanese folk songs, Lu seeks to merge both types of culture in his musical compositions. It is meaningful to discover how Lu employs concepts and ideas that he learned from his Western Classical music training and applies to his treatment of his homeland’s folk tunes. According to Florida State University’s requirement, this research document is based on two public lecture recitals presented on April 27, 2022, and November 21, 2022.

DISS_address.DISS_addrline: Tianfu New District, Wanan Town, Luxehills Avenue Section 2

DISS_description.DISS_title: Navigating the Pandemic: Comparative Analyses and Theoretical Insights in Policy-making and Implementation during COVID-19

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Chinese characteristics, Comparative studies, COVID-19, Multiple streams framework, Network governance, Policy Implementation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Combining the network governance model with knowledge of emergency management, this manuscript analyzes the performance of Hubei and Sichuan provincial governments in response to COVID-19 in early 2020. This study reveals that network governance, as seen in the Chinese response to COVID-19, does not closely resemble any of the three well-known forms of network governance in the literature. Instead, although the prevailing governance structure mimics some elements of the Network Administrative Organization form, it exhibits some uniquely Chinese characteristics. This manuscript also argues that core leaders’ characteristics, mass media roles, and path-dependent adherence to systems created earlier significantly affect the resulting network governance. This manuscript also provides suggestions for improving the effectiveness of network governance of emergency management in China’s centralized system.

Incorporating insights from implementation theory and emergency management, this manuscript examines the performance of the Henan and Shanghai provincial/municipal governments during their early response to COVID-19 in 2020. The study reveals that the Chinese approach to COVID-19 policy implementation diverges from traditional models found in the existing literature. While it mirrors some of these conventional models, it also showcases distinctive Chinese attributes. Furthermore, the paper posits that during the COVID-19 response, Henan's strategies were predominantly steered by provincial governments, with grassroots organizations playing a pivotal role. In contrast, Shanghai's approach was chiefly guided by government departments, bolstered significantly by professional bureaucrats.

Utilizing the Multiple Streams Framework (MSF), this research delves into the determinants guiding COVID-related decisions across U.S. states from August 2020 to January 2022. It critically evaluates eight salient variables linked to the problem, policy, and political streams of MSF, focusing on the adoption patterns of mask mandate policies. The analysis reveals that factors such as monthly COVID case rates, political affiliation, vaccination rates, and interstate travel restrictions significantly influenced the strictness of mask mandates during different periods.

DISS_description.DISS_title: STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION STUDIES OF METHYLATION AND PSEUDOURIDYLATION ON RIBOSOME BIOGENESIS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Eukaryotic cells employ a sophisticated process to generate properly assembledribosomes. This intricate process commences in the nucleolus through the transcription of a singular 35S ribosomal RNA precursor (pre-rRNA), encompassing three distinct rRNAs (5.8S, 18S, and 25S), along with the 5’ and 3’ externally or internally transcribed spacer regions (5’-ETS, 3’-ETS, ITS1, and ITS2). Approximately 2% of rRNA nucleotides undergo 12 of the 140 recognized types of RNA modifications (Sharma and Lafontaine, 2015; Sloan et al., 2017).Among the most prevalent modifications of rRNA are 2’-O-methylation and pseudouridylation, both facilitated by small nucleolar ribonucleoparticles (snoRNPs). The box C/D snoRNPs play a pivotal role in the site-specific addition of 2’-O-methyl groups at 80-100 sites in rRNA, while the box H/ACA snoRNPs are responsible for the isomerization of a similar number of uridines. Each snoRNP comprises a catalytic subunit, with fibrillarin serving as the methyltransferase and Cbf5 as the pseudouridine synthase in yeast, respectively1 . There are still many unanswered questions to be explored for the function of 2’-Omethylation and pseudouridylation. The impact of rRNA modification is mainly concentrated on the assembly of ribosome precursors (such as 90S pre-ribosome) and the protein synthesis process of mature ribosomes. Therefore, by studying the structural and functional changes of pre-ribosome and mature ribosome caused by loss of modification, we can understand the regulatory roles of the RNA backbone modification. This dissertation uses structural and functional studies to shed light on the intricate mechanisms of the regulatory roles of the RNA backbone modification. In Chapter 1, we showed that removal of chaperones for box C/D snoRNP can potentially alter the dynamics of 90S pre-ribosome of which the U3 box C/D snoRNP forms the core and thus allow us the capture of transiently associated factors. Our structure model provides the first near atomic model of the yeast Bfr2-Lcp5 complex. And I proved the model with the protein-protein interaction results and the secondary structures of recombinant Bfr2 and Bfr2-Lcp5 complex obtained by Circular Dichroism. Chapters 2 of this dissertation details unpresented views of ribosomes as they function and assemble in absence of 2’-O-methylation. For the first time, I - 8 - extensively surveyed the growth sensitivity of cells that lack 2’-O-methylation to translation inhibitors, revealing a dependence of inhibition on temperature. In Chapter 3, I further compared melting temperatures of the healthy and the hypomodified ribosomes by Circular Dichroism and showed a significant decrease in thermal stability in absence of chemical modifications, underscoring their pivotal roles in determining ribosome stability and possibly its sensitivity to translation inhibitors. I pioneered the study of the effects of translation inhibitors on ribosome stability using Circular Dichroism. Finally, our lab obtained the structure of a hypopseudouridylated ribosome bound with a aminoglycoside (hygromycin B), which revealed a possibility mechanism for its hypersensivity.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Changing Annual Cycle of Sea Surface Temperature

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In recent decades, many research efforts focused on global climate change, multidecadal, decadal, interannual variability, and the increasing extreme events of sea surface temperature. In contrast, the continuous evolution of the reference frame, the annual cycle of SST used to quantify the aforementioned variability and changes, has long been overlooked, resulting in difficulties in under- standing the underlying physical mechanisms responsible for these variability and changes. This study strives to bridge this gap on the changes in SST annual cycle.By devising a running correlation-based method, the seasons such as summer and winter are characterized as a period of varying SST rather than an exact timing and the phase and amplitude of non-sinusoidal annually evolving SST annual cycle is quantified. It is revealed that the varying phases of summer or winter are more closely linked to multidecadal SST variability than to long- term climate change, with the former reaching 3.0 day/decade. Moreover, the changes in amplitude are well-explained by the distinct variation of summer and winter SST. Both the systematic shift of the phase and alterations in the annual cycle shape contribute to the phase changes which explain up to 1.2 K of monthly SST anomaly with respect to climatological annual cycle on multidecadal timescale. The variation of surface wind stress is found as an important driver of phase shift of SST annual cycle. Furthermore, it is evident that the SST annual cycle in CMIP6 historical simulations experience notable bias compared with that in ERA5 SST for both phase and summer/winter SST. The low-frequency variability is often overshadowed by substantial high-frequency part or, in some cases, underestimated in models. The oversensitivity of modeled SST to anthropogenic forcing significantly contributes to these results. A well-simulated temperature annual cycle is required for more realistic feedback mechanisms and interactions between regional climates.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SWITCHED-CAPACITOR MODULAR MULTILEVEL CONVERTER TO ACHIEVE INDUCTOR-LESS, FILTER-LESS, AND TRANSFORMER-LESS MEDIUM-VOLTAGE POWER CONVERSION FOR HIGH POWER DENSITY APPLICATIONS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Capacitor Voltage Balancing, Modular Multilevel Converter, Multilevel Inverters, Pulse Width Modulation, Staircase Modulation, Switched - Capacitor Converter

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Power electronic applications that demand ratings exceeding 250kW require medium voltage (MV) converters to handle the high power (HP) levels. MV HP converters are widely used in motor drive applications such as in heavy-duty electric and hybrid-electric propulsion/traction drives, as well as in other industrial applications including refiners, fans, pumps, and rolling mills. In addition to drives applications, the increased grid integration of renewable energy resources to achieve a more sustainable and cleaner energy has led to the proliferation of MV HP converters in utility applications. MV converters have played a major role in modernizing traditional transmission and distribution networks and facilitating the smart-grid transition. They can provide active control of power quality, provide shunt and series compensation, and achieve self-healing, islanding operation, fault handling, and other functionalities. To achieve low common mode voltages (CMV), low dv/dt stresses, low electromagnetic interference (EMI), and better harmonic performance, MV HP converters are often implemented with multi-level topologies. Among the several multilevel converter topologies, the modular multilevel converter (MMC) has received increasing interest due to its modularity, efficiency, and voltage and power scalability features. However, some challenges still exist for utilizing MV converters in general, and MMCs in particular, whether in motor drives or grid applications. These challenges are mainly driven by the high power density requirements. Along with cost, reliability, and efficiency, power density has recently become among the fundamental figures of merit when characterizing a power electronic conversion system performance. Nevertheless, many barriers exist that hinder achieving high power densities in MV applications. These power density barriers include the magnetic components such as transformers, harmonic filters, and the arm inductors of MMC-based MV conversion systems. As a result, any advancement along the power density trajectory would not be possible without a substantial reduction in the volume and weight of the aforementioned magnetic components. This research proposes the switched-capacitor modular multilevel converter (SCMMC) as a high power density converter, which can achieve inductor-less, filter-less, and transformer-less MV conversion. The dissertation is divided into six parts. In the first part, the power density challenges of MV converters are highlighted in grid and drives applications. In the second part, the switching frequency and the modulation technique choice of the multilevel inverters are presented. The importance of using the lowest frequency modulation with high number of levels to achieve the lowest harmonic distortion is demonstrated as the approach to make a filter-less and transformer-less operation possible. In the third part, the SCMMC topology is introduced as a solution towards high power density MV power conversion through its arm inductor-less topology. In the fourth part, the control of the SCMMC is presented; a low output frequency modulation technique is proposed for the SCMMC, and a startup control strategy is proposed for the SCMMC with middle submodule. In the fifth part, a 2kW, 425Vrms single phase SCMMC prototype built in our lab is showcased, and its modulation techniques are verified. In the final part, the scope of future research is presented.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Teaching College Piano Literature Courses: Toward A New Approach

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Artificial intelligence, College, Pedagogy, Piano Literature, Teaching, Technology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Piano literature (or keyboard repertory studies) is commonly included in piano performance and some piano pedagogy degrees in the United States. This single or sequential course is required by the National Association of Schools of Music (NASM) at both undergraduate and graduate levels. While most universities include such courses in their degree requirements, it might be argued that not all instructors are well-equipped to teach piano literature courses. An oft-cited maxim in higher education is that "faculty teach the way they were taught" because they usually receive little formal training in teaching before entering the classroom. There are almost no pedagogical resources or materials that directly address issues regarding teaching piano literature courses to prepare young piano faculty and facilitate their teaching of such courses. While the fields of piano pedagogy, music theory, music history, and musicology have many up-to-date resources available for reference, there is minimal scholarly discussion of teaching piano literature courses in educational journals or at conferences.

This treatise aims to serve as a reference for both young and experienced college professors to think about how piano literature classes for 21st-century pianists can and should be taught. It compiles the wisdom and experience of established textbook authors and course instructors at prominent music institutions in the United States. Using a qualitative inquiry approach, this document will discuss essential and neglected topics surrounding teaching a piano literature course. Discussions include teaching methodologies and strategies for Generation Z and Generation Alpha in the Artificial Intelligence world, selecting course materials that include overlooked composers without compromising canonic composers, and navigating the practicality of assignments in a piano literature course. This investigation seeks to initiate discussion on these important topics and contribute to the pedagogy of piano literature in higher education.

DISS_description.DISS_title: LOW SELF-CONTROL, NEIGHBORHOOD COLLECTIVE EFFICACY, AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT AS EXPLANATIONS OF VICTIMIZATION

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: A wealth of research has documented the association between low self-control and child victimization. However, the conditions under which low self-control has the greatest impact on victimization have rarely been examined and, more importantly, no prior research has examined the complex ways in which neighborhood characteristics interact with self-control and other individual characteristics to impact victimization. Using data from the Project on Human Development in Chicago Neighborhoods, the current study tests whether the effect of low self-control is contingent upon age and poverty and whether the positive effect of low self-control on victimization is lessened in neighborhoods with high collective efficacy. Furthermore, this study goes beyond the prior literature by examining the multifaceted nature of conditional effects. By employing three-level multivariate Rasch models and cross-level three-way interactions, the research demonstrates that low self-control increases the risk of victimization, and that the effect of low self-control depends on the combined effects of neighborhood collective efficacy of children, age, and poverty. Thus, this study claims that child victimization is a product of the complicated interplay between neighborhood context—child-based collective efficacy—and children’s individual characteristics—low self-control, age, and poverty. This study advances our understanding of the specific conditions and situations where low self-control most significantly influences victimization, emphasizing the intricate nature of conditional effects. This research contributes importantly to building a developmental and life-course perspective on victimization. In addition, by forging new pathways in understanding the multifaceted influences on victimization, this research paves the way for innovative strategies in prevention and intervention, ultimately contributing to more effective and holistic approaches to addressing victimization across the lifespan.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Global Active Subspace Method

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this dissertation, we focus on the novel dimension reduction method and its application on sensitivity analysis. First, we introduce the Monte Carlo method, one type of surrogate model, polynomial chaos expansion, the active subspace method and global sensitivity analysis. Then, to overcome the issues when there are high-oscillated or noised components in the function, we propose a global generalization of the active subspace method. We form the algorithm, do the error analysis and establish a new type of sensitivity measure based on our method. We present numerical experiments in each section to explain the framework, and support the effectiveness of our new method

DISS_description.DISS_title: POST-DISASTER RECOVERY IN ADJUNTAS, PUERTO RICO: EXPLORING THE ROLES OF SOCIAL CAPITAL ACTIVATION, NGO PARTICIPATION AND INSTITUTIONAL TRANSFORMATION
DISS_description.DISS_supp_title: RECUPERACIÓN POST-DESASTRE EN ADJUNTAS, PUERTO RICO: EXPLORANDO LA FUNCIÓN DE LA ACTIVACIÓN DEL CAPITAL SOCIAL, LA PARTICIPACIÓN DE LAS ONG Y LA TRANSFORMACIÓN INSTITUCIONAL

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Community Grassroot Movements, Institutional Changes Post-Disaster, NGO, Post-disaster Recovery, Puerto Rico, Social Capital

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation examines the interaction of social capital, interorganizational dynamics, the role of the third sector, and institutional change in post-disaster recovery context. The dissertation is a qualitative case study in the rural town of Adjuntas, Puerto Rico post-2017 Hurricane Maria. Puerto Rico was impacted by category 4 Hurricane Maria on September 20, 2017, and left a death toll around 3,000 to 4,000 people across the island and communties without communications systems, water, gasoline, road access and electric power for months and even over a year in some isolated communities. Around 6% of residents emigrated to US in the months right after the hurricane. The rural town of Adjuntas was selected to study disaster recovery within Puerto Rico due to its rural low-income context and its history of community participation in mining opposition and sustainable projects, with the local NGO Casa Pueblo playing a significant role in its history of community grassroot movements since 1980.

This dissertation takes a three-paper approach. The first paper, in chapter two, is based on the social capital and post-disaster recovery literature. It uses the three dimensions of social capital, bonding, bridging, and linking to categorize and examine social capital dynamics. It concludes that disaster recovery is rooted in a game of relationships, with bonding social capital at the center of those relationships. In this paper, the central argument is that bonding social capital is used by communities as a gateway to other manifestations of social capital, such as bridging and linking.

The second paper, in chapter three, discusses the role of non-governmental organizations in disaster recovery. This chapter confirms the literature about the key role of NGOs in post-disaster recovery, which often become first responders. It further claims that countries and communities where governmental response capacity is weak, post-disaster response is highly dependent on the response capacity of NGOs. This chapter also uses the metaphor of “sancochos comunitarios” to illustrate the interorganizational dynamics of NGOs discovered in Adjuntas.

The third paper, in chapter four, suggests that a large-scale disaster presents an opportunity to shape institutional fields. They create the conditions to invite the integration of new players, including individuals, organizations, and networks that together have the potential to change institutional fields by creating new institutions, norms, collective consensuses and values that define the new society post-disaster recovery. This chapter integrates the concepts of sense of urgency, time compression, and institutional fields to develop an analytical framework as a tool to understand institutional change dynamics in post-disaster contexts.

DISS_supp_abstract.DISS_para: Esta disertación examina la interacción del capital social, la dinámica interorganizacional, el papel del tercer sector y el cambio institucional en el contexto de recuperación posterior a un desastre. La disertación es un estudio de caso cualitativo en el pueblo rural de Adjuntas, Puerto Rico, después del huracán María de 2017. Puerto Rico fue impactado por el huracán María categoría 4 el 20 de septiembre de 2017, y dejó un saldo de muertes entre 3,000 y 4,000 personas en toda la isla. Dejo comunidades sin sistemas de comunicaciones, agua, gasolina, acceso a carreteras y energía eléctrica durante meses e incluso más de un año en algunas comunidades aisladas. Alrededor del 6% de los residentes emigraron a Estados Unidos en los meses inmediatamente posteriores al huracán. El pueblo rural de Adjuntas fue seleccionado para estudiar la recuperación de desastres dentro de Puerto Rico debido a su contexto rural, de bajos ingresos y su historia de participación comunitaria en la oposición minera y proyectos sustentables, con la ONG local Casa Pueblo jugando un papel importante en su historia de movimientos de base comunitaria desde 1980.

Esta tesis adopta un enfoque de tres artículos. El primer artículo, en el capítulo dos, se basa en la literatura sobre capital social y recuperación post-desastre. Utiliza las tres dimensiones del capital social, “bonding, bridging and linking” para categorizar y examinar la dinámica del capital social. Concluye que la recuperación ante desastres tiene sus raíces en un juego de relaciones, con el capital social de “bonding” en el centro de esas relaciones. En este artículo, el argumento central es que las comunidades utilizan el capital social de “bonding” como puerta de entrada a otras manifestaciones del capital social, como lo son “bridging” y “linking”.

El segundo documento, en el capítulo tres, analiza el papel de las organizaciones no gubernamentales en la recuperación de desastres. Este capítulo confirma la literatura sobre el papel clave de las ONG en la recuperación post-desastre, que a menudo se convierten en primeros respondedores. Afirma además que en los países y comunidades donde la capacidad de respuesta gubernamental es débil, la respuesta post-desastre depende en gran medida de la capacidad de respuesta de las ONG. Este capítulo también utiliza la metáfora de los “sancochos comunitarios” para ilustrar la dinámica interorganizacional de las ONG descubiertas en Adjuntas.

El tercer artículo, en el capítulo cuatro, sugiere que un desastre a gran escala presenta una oportunidad para dar forma a los campos institucionales. Crean las condiciones para invitar a la integración de nuevos actores, incluidos individuos, organizaciones y redes que juntos tienen el potencial de cambiar los campos institucionales mediante la creación de nuevas instituciones, normas, consensos colectivos y valores que definen la nueva sociedad después de un desastre. Este capítulo integra los conceptos de sentido de urgencia, tiempo comprimido y campos institucionales para desarrollar un marco analítico como herramienta para comprender la dinámica del cambio institucional en contextos posteriores a un desastre.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Riemannian Broyden Family of Limite-memory Quasi-Newton Methods

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Quasi-Newton methods have gained popularity across various domains, providing efficient iterative algorithms for finding optimal solutions to unconstrained optimization problems. Their limited- memory variants offer advantages in terms of reduced storage and computational requirements. This dissertation generalizes full Broyden family of limited-memory quasi-Newton optimization methods on Riemannian manifold (LRBroyden). The work encompasses the comprehensive anal- ysis, implementation, application and evaluation of LRBroyden. An essential extension to this research involves the adaptation of these algorithms to stochastic methods tailored for large-scale optimization. This results in the generalization of the stochastic variant of the Riemannian full Broyden family of limited-memory quasi-Newton methods, incorporating with variance reduction (LR-SBroyden-VR). The dissertation provides empirical insights into parameter selection and offers a thorough evaluation of the performance of various methods.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Molecular Impact of rRNA Modifications On Ribosome Function And Biogenesis

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Cryo-EM, Ribosome, rRNA Modification, Translation

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Ribosomes are giant RNA-protein complexes responsible for translating the information encoded by the genome to create the proteome in all kingdoms of life. In budding yeast, the mature cytoplasmic 80S ribosome consists of 79 ribosomal proteins (r-proteins) and 4 ribosomal RNAs (rRNAs), which form the 40S small subunit (SSU) and the 60S large subunit (LSU). One of the most important chemical features of ribosomes is post-transcriptional modification of the rRNAs, most of which are comprised of pseudouridylation and 2’-hydroxyl methylation. Previous biochemical and genetic studies have shown that rRNA modifications: (1) facilitate ribosome biogenesis; (2) stabilize the structure of ribosomes; (3) ensure the efficiency and fidelity of the translation activity of ribosomes; (4) impact antibiotic sensitivity. Notably, the identification of partial modification sites on rRNA has added a new layer of ribosome heterogeneity, indicating its role in regulating gene expression. Despite the demonstrated importance of rRNA modifications, the molecular basis of how rRNA modification affects ribosome biogenesis and ribosome function remain elusive, owing to the lack of structural information. In this thesis, I investigate the structural impact of rRNA modification on ribosome biogenesis and function. I solved a series of atomic resolution cryo-EM structures of mature ribosome and precursor ribosome isolated from yeast mutant strains defective in rRNA modification activity. By comparing them with previously reported wild-type structures with fully modified rRNAs, I identified a surprising number of local and global structural changes. Removal of pseudouridine (Ψ) results in loss of Ψ-associated water molecules and Y-associated base pairing; altered structural arrangement of the decoding center; abnormal inter- and intra-subunit movement. Removal of 2’-hydroxyl methylation (Nm) results in gain of Nm-associated water molecules; altered sugar pucker preference; disrupted structural arrangement of the exit tunnel; impaired maturation of peptidyl transfer center; erroneous domain motions. These structural abnormality upon loss of Ψ or Nm, provide molecular explanation for the observed functional defect, paving the road towards understanding the role of rRNA modification played in maintaining the accuracy and efficiency of ribosome production and function.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Renewable Energy Interface Stability and Power Quality Management of Underground Cable Based Distribution Systems

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Renewable energy source has been integrated into our distribution system with a rapid pace. At the same time, the increasing amount of renewable energy source lead to instability and low power quality issues to the distribution systems, especially for underground cable based distribution systems. The major cause of these issues are the resonant phenomenon, which can lead to unwanted oscillations of voltage or current and then cause control or hardware failure of the distribution system. So, measures must be taken to suppress, transform, or eliminate these unwanted factors. This dissertation addresses the issues and analyzes the causes of the underground cable based distribution systems with renewable energy source. The state-of-the-art techniques to solve such issues are introduced. To perform the theoretical analysis, the mathematical and simulation models are built for inverter-based renewable resources, distribution grid interface, and underground cable based distribution lines. After that, the proposed strategy is comprehensively introduced. The research shows that the traditional interface inverter control method limits the possibility of utilizing the characteristics of inverters. In order to introduce the new method, a novel PLL-less and voltage sensorless inner loop control method of the interfacing inverter of the renewable energy source and the distribution network is presented. Then, the virtual resistance control method is carried out to showcase how the aforementioned issues can be solved. The first chapter will give an introduction of the background of the research, and lead out the emerging problems we are facing. The second chapter will give a description of the base methodology to be used in the research. The third chapter will introduce the control method which will be used for the solution. Chapter four will discuss the virtual resistor based method in detail. And finally, chapter five will conclude the dissertation and provide future works.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Statistical depth in point process and its applications

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation includes four research projects. The first two projects mainly focus on the depth method on temporal point process data. The third project is the depth method on spatial point process. This is an extension of the first two projects. The fourth one is about memory and future movement decoding on spike train of small rats, which is collaborated with Dr. Aaron Wilber's lab in Psychology Department. I will provide summaries of each project below. The details can be found in the main chapters.

Project 1: Statistical Depth for Point Process via the Isometric Log-Ratio Transformation. Statistical depth, a useful tool to measure the center-outward rank of multivariate and functional data, is still under-explored in temporal point processes. Recent studies on point process depth proposed a weighted product of two terms - one indicates the depth of the cardinality of the process, and the other characterizes the conditional depth of the temporal events given the cardinality. The second term is of great challenge because of the apparent nonlinear structure of event times, and so far only parametric representations such as Gaussian and Dirichlet densities have been adopted in the definitions. However, these parametric forms ignore the underlying distribution of the process events and are difficult to apply to complicated patterns. To deal with these problems, a novel distribution-based approach is proposed to the conditional depth via the well-known Isometric Log-Ratio (ILR) transformation on the inter-event times. Motivated by a uniform distribution on simplex, the new method, called the ILR depth, is formally defined for general point process via a Time Rescaling. The mathematical properties of the ILR depth are thoroughly examined and the new method is well illustrated by using Poisson and non-Poisson processes to demonstrate its superiority over previous methods. Finally, the ILR depth is applied in a real dataset and the result clearly shows its effectiveness in ranking.

Project 2: Depth-Based Statistical Inferences in the Spike Train Space. Metric-based summary statistics such as mean and covariance have been introduced in neural spike train space. They can properly describe template and variability in spike train data, but are often sensitive to outliers and expensive to compute. Recent studies also examine outlier detection and classification methods on point processes. These tools provide reasonable result, whereas the accuracy remains at a low level in certain cases. In this study, we propose to adopt a well-established notion of statistical depth to the spike train space. This framework can naturally define the median in a set of spike trains, which provides a robust description of the "template" of the observations. It also provides a principled method to identify "outliers" and classify data from different categories. We systematically compare the new median, outlier detection and classification tools with state-of-the-art competing methods. The result shows the median has superior description for template than the mean. Moreover, the proposed outlier detection and classification perform more accurately than previous methods.

Project 3: Statistical Depth in Spatial Point Process. Statistical depth is widely used as a powerful tool to measure the center-outward rank of multivariate and functional data. Recent studies have introduced the notion of depth to the temporal point process, which exhibits randomness in the cardinality as well as distribution in the observed events. The proposed methods can well capture the rank of a point process in a given time interval, where a critical step is to measure the rank by using inter-arrival events. We propose to extend the depth concept to multivariate spatial point process. In this case, the observed process is in a multi-dimensional location and there are no conventional inter-arrival events in the temporal process. We adopt the newly-developed depth in metric space by defining two different metrics, namely the penalized metric and smoothing metric, to fully explore the depth in spatial point process. The mathematical properties and large sample theory, as well as depth-based hypothesis testings, are thoroughly discussed. We then use several simulations to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed depth method. Finally, we apply the new method in a real world dataset and obtain desirable ranking performance.

Project 4: Memory and Future Movement Decoding on Spike Train Information. Movement through space and establishing memories based on such experiences is essential for survival of animals including humans. This ability is thought to require storage of memories often in an allocentric (map-like) framework and conversion to a body-centered reference frame comprised of specific locomotor actions (e.g., turn right). These frameworks must be coordinated in a fluid manner during navigation. The encoding observed in hippocampus (HPC) and parietal cortex (PC) has led to the notion that this circuit operates as a part of a coordinate transformation network; for example, transforming a remembered allocentric representation into the appropriate action. While HPC neurons are typically modulated by allocentric locations, PC neurons are modulated by multiple reference frames including actions (e.g., right turn). This hypothesis was tested using a complex spatial sequence task where rats learn to navigate to unmarked locations fixed in space in a specific sequence. Landmarks are distributed around the room for spatial orientation. We use a sequence (1-2-3-4-1-2-3-5-) that has a repeating path segment (1-2-3) followed by one of two distinct actions. Specifically, the rat learns in context 1-2-3-4, to go to 4 for reward, while in context 1-2-3-5 the rat must go to 5. Thus, navigation to zone 4 or 5 requires a map-to-action transformation. This emulates the spatial memory problem one encounters when driving through an intersection and remembering the appropriate action given the current route and goals (e.g., turn left to a bank versus right to home). Sets of "cued" runs in which a light at each goal leads the rat through the sequence are interleaved with unguided (memory) runs through the complete 1-2-3-4-1-2-3-5 sequence . During memory runs, following an error, a light cue directs the rat to the next zone in the sequence. Thus, during memory runs, the rat must coordinate between remembered allocentric context and egocentric action. We found that decoded PC ensembles (and some single cells; but not simultaneously recorded HPC ensembles) predict upcoming actions following the repeating path segment (3-4 & 3-5) during "memory" but not "cued" trials. Additionally, we hypothesize that accurate action selection by PC will require HPC encoding of memory for the allocentric context. Consistent with this hypothesis, we found that a failure in allocentric context decoding (forgetting if came from 5 vs 4 while navigating 1-2) by HPC ensembles (but not by PC ensembles) also predict behavioral errors. Thus, we provide evidence that the HPC-PC circuit is a coordinate transformation network for interfacing between map like and person centered reference frames.

DISS_description.DISS_title: KEVIN DAY’S CONCERTO FOR EUPHONIUM AND WIND ENSEMBLE: A COMPREHENSIVE PERFORMANCE GUIDE

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Concerto, Euphonium, guide, Kevin Day, performance

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: American composer Kevin Day (b.1996) experienced a quick rise to notoriety in the wind band community, largely fueled by the success of his Concerto for Euphonium and Wind Ensemble (2018). The work’s first movement, premiered by Demondrae Thurman, Associate Dean and Professor of Euphonium and Chamber Music at Indiana University and the Texas Christian University Wind Ensemble, saw an outpouring of interactions and views through the spread of a social media post by Thurman. This premiere quickly led to a series of concerto commissions by Kevin Day, elevating his reputation and expanding his body of work. At this moment in time, Concerto for Euphonium and Wind Ensemble is one of four works written for euphonium by Black composers. The work’s quality solidifies it as a piece that should be studied by high level euphoniumists. This performance guide incorporates analysis of form, motivic elements, and musical narrative concepts as delineated by Byron Almén. Furthermore, it draws from techniques informed through the author’s preparation and performance experience, as well as insights gleaned from interviews with Kevin Day, Demondrae Thurman, and SSG Hiram Diaz of The President’s Own United States Marine Band. In addition to the utilization of method books by Jean-Baptiste Arban, David Vining, and Johannes Rochut, Kevin Day’s 25 Advanced Studies for Euphonium are highlighted as modern works written for euphonium that will serve as an aid to preparing the concerto. Finally, the guide includes exercises composed by the author that isolate passages from the music and simplify them, facilitating a thorough understanding of the intervallic relationships and techniques required to execute the Concerto at a high level.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Contribution of Storm Waves to Bed Shear-Stress and Sediment Movement Near the Florida Panhandle Coast

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bed Shear-Stress, Florida, Northearstern Gulf of Mexico, Reef, Storm waves, Tropical cyclones

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Coastal areas are very dynamic places, and a lot of that is due to the movement of waves and currents, which are responsible for disturbances on the seabed by causing shear-stress. Bed shear-stress can cause sediment motion and transport, which is very important in coastal areas because of beach morphology changes, viability of coastal constructions, among others. However, sediment transport depends on very complex and interactive processes, some of which are still not very well understood or sometimes poorly calculated. Waves and currents are the main drivers of sediment movement in coastal areas. This study analyzed the wave contribution to the bed shear-stress near the coast of the Florida Panhandle. Florida is one of the most vulnerable states to hurricanes in the US, but the Peninsular Florida acts as a shield for the Gulf side from westerly hurricanes, and the wide West Florida Shelf protects this region from the Gulf waters. Dog Island Reef is located near the coast of the Florida Panhandle, on a low gradient and low energy continental margin. The region is composed mostly of sandy beaches, barrier islands, and low energy waves arrive at the shoreline. Four stations were chosen near Dog Island Reef to have sediments collected and analyzed for size distribution. The sediment sampling stations were strategically located in between two other sites where wave data were collected for four years (2008 – 2011). The wave data was acquired using moored ADCPs and narrowed down to the period of peak hurricane season (August 1st to October 31st). Relevant statistical wave parameters such as significant and maximum wave heights (HS and HMax), and wave directions (WDir) are presented for both sites during each storm period. The four sediment samples were classified into the textural group “slightly gravely sand”, presenting a low percentage (~ 5%) of fine gravel or bigger; station 2 showed a high (72%) percentage of small sizes (fine sand or smaller) when compared to the other 3 stations (25%). Six tropical cyclones that passed through the Northeastern Gulf of Mexico in that period were selected for the analysis. All storms caused similar wave heights at site A (HS ~ 1.1 m, HMax ~ 1.7 m) with highest waves coming from south-southwest quadrants, and the highest wave caused by Tropical Storm Fay. Site B had more variability in wave height (HS 1.5 ~ 2.8 m, HMax 2.7 ~ 4.5 m) and spread directions. Tropical Storm Lee created southerly winds with the longest fetch, generating the highest waves in the record. All recorded wind directions followed an organized and delineated clockwise (counterclockwise for Fay) change of directions during storms closest approach to mooring sites, while wave directions followed that same pattern with a -15° offset approximately. The critical shear stress for initiation of movement was calculated for both sites considering median grain size d50 = 292.9 µm, and was 0.2 Nm-2. The mean calculated wave-induced stress was approximately 0.04 Nm-2 at both sites, and maximum of 0.52 / 1.11 Nm-2 for sites A/B respectively. Tropical Storm Lee caused the highest stresses for the longest time at both sites. During the four-year period analyzed, stress was above critical threshold of movement for less than 10% of the year, and storms were usually responsible for about 50% of that contribution.
