The finite-difference based method is especially useful when there are high-order interactions or in the presence of noise. The methods are used for global sensitivity analysis and machine learning explainability, and numerical comparisons with activity scores, global activity scores, SHAP, and KernelSHAP are provided.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Defining the responsiveness of glucocorticoid myopathic skeletal muscle to mechanical overload

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Anabolic resistance, Glucocorticoid myopathy, Mechanical overload, mTORC1, Muscle atrophy, Protein synthesis

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Muscle atrophy decreases physical function and overall health. Increased glucocorticoid production and/or use of prescription glucocorticoids can result in a myopathy that presents with significant muscle atrophy and weakness. Glucocorticoids cause atrophy by activating the glucocorticoid receptor, thereby transcribing genes that shift protein balance in favor of net protein degradation. While mechanical overload can blunt glucocorticoid-induced atrophy in young muscle, it is unknown whether mechanical overload influences glucocorticoid receptor nuclear translocation, a critical step in the receptor activation process. Moreover, it is unknown whether muscle contractile force alters regulation of glucocorticoid receptor because those susceptible to glucocorticoid myopathy are generally at risk of having reduced muscle force generation capacity. Therefore, Specific Aim 1 sought to determine whether contractile force differentially regulates glucocorticoid receptor activation within the skeletal muscle. Male mice were subjected to a single bout of unilateral, electrically induced muscle contractions by stimulating the sciatic nerve at 100 Hz or 50 Hz frequencies to elicit high force or moderate force contractions of the tibialis anterior (TA), respectively. Dexamethasone (DEX) was administered via intraperitoneal (IP) injection at 1mg/kg to activate the glucocorticoid receptor acutely. Treatment with DEX increased glucocorticoid nuclear translocation and expression of putative target genes, but those outcomes were mitigated by high force, but not moderate force, contractions. The ability of high force contractions to mitigate glucocorticoid receptor translocation coincided with a sustained ability for muscle contractions to increase rates of muscle protein synthesis, which is an outcome that can ultimately reduce the negative shift in protein balance induced by glucocorticoids. Interestingly, moderate force contractions did not increase rates of muscle protein synthesis only in the DEX treated mice. Thus, these data show that force generation is important for the ability of resistance exercise to mitigate glucocorticoid receptor translocation and ultimately activate the processes that will reduce the loss of muscle mass in those with elevated glucocorticoids. While these data and the classic data demonstrate the potential for mechanical overload to mitigate glucocorticoid myopathy by reducing glucocorticoid receptor activation and increasing rates of muscle protein synthesis if the mechanical overload and glucocorticoid treatment are started at the same time, it is unknown whether mechanical overload can increase muscle protein synthesis when the glucocorticoid myopathy is already present. Determining whether mechanical overload can increase rates of muscle protein synthesis in glucocorticoid myopathic muscle is important because long-term glucocorticoid exposure can increase the expression of genes that may prevent activation of pathways like the mechanistic target of rapamycin in complex 1 (mTORC1) that contribute to the increase in rates of muscle protein synthesis. Therefore, Specific Aim 2 sought to determine the extent to which mechanical overload increases muscle protein synthesis during the initiation of glucocorticoid myopathy and after the myopathy has more fully developed. Early myopathy was induced in physically mature female mice via daily IP injections of saline as control or 1mg/kg DEX. After 1 week of treatment, the left TA muscle of all mice was subjected to a bout of muscle contractions as stated in Aim 1. In a subsequent experiment, physically mature female mice received regular drinking water as control or DEX in their drinking water for 2 weeks to fully induce myopathy. After 2 weeks of treatment, mice were subjected to unilateral muscle contractions. In both experiments, signaling through mTORC1 and rates of muscle protein synthesis were assessed. Despite initiation of myopathy following 1 week of DEX treatment, mechanical overload increased protein synthesis and mTORC1 signaling equally compared to control mice. After 2 weeks, mechanical overload activated mTORC1 signaling equally in both DEX and control mice, but protein synthesis was only increased by mechanical overload in control mice, suggesting that the stage of glucocorticoid myopathy alters the anabolic response to mechanical overload. Altogether, our data demonstrate that contractile force and duration of glucocorticoid treatment regulates the ability of mechanical overload to alter the signals that would be needed to minimize the atrophy induced by glucocorticoids.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SOLVING HIGH-DIMENSIONAL FULLY NONLINEAR CONVEX PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS USING DEEP LEARNING

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this dissertation, we develop two novel schemes for solving fully nonlinear PDEs that are based on the theoretical treatments of \textit{second order backward stochastic differential equations} (2BSDEs), established in \cite{STZ12}. The first scheme is a multi-step algorithm which iteratively approximates the optimal quadratic variation using an approximation of the value function and its first and second derivatives. The second scheme, which is based on the maximum principle for 2BSDEs, approximates the solution in an iterative process that combines all time steps into one iteration. Our theoretical results demonstrate the convergence of the schemes for a broad class of problems. Numerical results on an example of fully nonlinear PDEs, the well-known Merton investment-consumption control problem with stochastic volatility Scott's model, will be presented to demonstrate the accuracy and advantages of both of our proposed schemes. Unlike many of the deep schemes in the literature, where only point estimates are provided, the schemes developed in this thesis provides an accurate field estimate of the value function.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Quantifying Simulated Deep Convective Transport and Its Sensitivity to Lightning Data Assimilation in a Supercell and Mesoscale Convective System

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: cloud top height, data assimilation, deep convection, modeling, vertical transport, WRF-Chem

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Deep convective clouds exert an important impact on the chemical composition of the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere (UTLS) since they can rapidly transport aerosols and chemical species from the planetary boundary layer (PBL) to the UTLS. The impacts on air quality and atmospheric chemistry vary depending on the extent of the transport. This transport can change the composition of trace gases and thereby affect weather and climate. This thesis examines two observed cases of deep convection, an Oklahoma supercell on 29 May 2012, and a mesoscale convective system (MCS) on 11 June 2012, both during the Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry (DC3) campaign. The first objective is to document the rate of simulated trace gas transport from the PBL to the UTLS. We utilize the Weather Research and Forecasting model coupled with Chemistry (WRF-Chem) to simulate the deep convection. To reduce errors in the timing, location, and depth of the simulated deep convective clouds, a new type of lightning data assimilation (LDA) is employed (Heath et al., 2016). We also perform a WRF-Chem simulation without LDA. Thus, the second objective is to determine the utility of the LDA scheme. The WRF-Chem runs utilize a nested grid with horizontal grid spacings of 36 and 12 km, and 70 vertical levels extending to 50 hPa. STAGE-IV and IMERG Final Run precipitation observations are used to compare simulated rainfall with and without LDA in terms of their timing, location, and intensity. GOES-13 brightness temperature data are used to calculate observed cloud top heights that are compared with simulated cloud tops with and without LDA. Besides the traditional statistical (grid-to-grid) techniques, object-based verification is used to evaluate the simulated precipitation and clouds. Results show that the LDA technique improves the timing, development, and especially the location of the deep convective clouds. Results also reveal that the LDA method increases the correlation between amounts of simulated CO that are transported from the PBL to the UTLS via deep convection for both cases compared to aircraft observations. Computed mass fluxes reveal that flux densities of the supercell exhibit 13.37% greater CO flux densities and 42.94% greater water vapor flux densities in the surface layer, meaning that the supercell transports more CO and H2O from the surface to higher altitudes per unit area in the supercell region than the MCS case. The MCS case demonstrates a weaker transition from the troposphere to the stratosphere in terms of mass fluxes compared to the supercell case.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Development of Musical Style and Ludic Function in Early Video Game Music

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Formenlehre, ludic function, ludomusicology, schema theory

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this dissertation, I discuss the ways in which a musical cue in a video game expresses a given gameplay context, or ludic function, within a game’s overall design. My study focuses primarily on the soundtracks of games published circa 1980–1995, beginning at the point when music became a common feature of video games and ending with the rise of CD-ROM-based game machines, when the technological possibilities of streaming audio contributed to a fragmentation of musical style across the industry. I address the musical conventions of several common ludic functions in early video game music, describing the ways in which these conventions differ depending on a game’s genre and setting.

After a review of relevant literature in Chapter 1, I examine video game music derived from preexisting sources (e.g., films, television, and classic cartoons) in Chapter 2, describing the ways in which these compositions established many of the semiotic codes of early video game music. I begin by discussing arcade games from the latter half of the 1970s, which relied almost entirely on preexisting compositions to accompany the on-screen action. Then, I briefly address two game genres popular in early arcades—the maze game and the shoot ’em up—and the ways in which preexisting compositions from film and classic cartoons set stylistic precedents for particular ludic functions in original soundtracks later in the decade.

In Chapter 3, I discuss the musical properties of the most common ludic functions found in action games of the 1980s and early 1990s. My discussion is divided into three sections based on when each ludic function occurs relative to the overall structure of a game: before gameplay begins (title screen cues, menu music, and cues immediately preceding gameplay), during the main part of the game (level background music, power-up cues, and music for boss battles), and after a segment of gameplay (victory music, death and game over cues, and music for ending and credits sequences). I consider the ways in which form, harmony, melodic contour, and other features are commonly connected with particular ludic functions.

In Chapter 4, I focus on a single ludic function—level background music—and its varied musical realizations within a single game genre: the platformer. After an overview of the early history of the genre, I describe the musical conventions used to differentiate among several common location types in platformers: overworlds, underworlds, underwater and sky areas, islands, deserts, and icy/snowy areas. I then discuss common musical strategies for communicating a level’s position within the overall game structure: heroic signifiers for opening levels, static and repetitive music for mid-game areas, and several harmonic schemata used to convey gravitas in the game’s final stages.

In Chapter 5, I discuss ludic function in Japanese role-playing games (JRPGs), a subgenre of role-playing game which descended from Western-developed titles but quickly developed its own unique set of musical conventions. I begin by summarizing the early history of role-playing games, both in the West and in Japan, and the musical conventions established by Koichi Sugiyama in the foundational 1986 JRPG Dragon Quest. Then, I discuss the ways in which different cue types convey the relative safety or danger in several environments and contexts—towns, castles, fields, dungeons, and battles—as well as the features of JRPG victory and game over music, which differ from their counterparts in action games. I conclude by describing instances in which these musical expectations are subverted to convey narrative information to the player.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MY SONG IN THE NIGHT: A CONDUCTOR’S GUIDE TO SELECTED CHORAL ARRANGEMENTS OF PAUL J. CHRISTIANSEN

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Christiansen, Lutheran choral tradition, Paul J.

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this dissertation is to provide a conductor’s analysis of a specific set of repertoire by Paul J. Christiansen. The selected works were limited to Paul J.’s arrangements of pre-existing musical material. In-depth analysis was limited to works in print and available for purchase still today. The author seeks to facilitate informed performance of these works and provide a general resource for conductors who have an interest in performing the music of Paul J. Christiansen.The study includes a short biography of Paul J.’s life and career, providing a brief historical context for this man’s work. It also includes a short history of the development of the Concordia College choral department, namely the Concordia Choir and Concordia Christmas concert, for which Paul J. was synonymous for nearly five decades. An annotated catalog of Paul J.’s many choral arrangements is provided. Brief information about the key, meter, tempo, origin, performance length, date of publication, publisher, and voicing is provided. The study concludes with an analysis of two subsets of arrangements of Paul J. Christiansen: Christmas carols and folk tunes. These subsets of arrangements include the vast majority of Paul J.’s works that continue to be frequently performed and are available for purchase. For each piece, a general overview is provided, followed by a form and suggested performance notes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: COMPLEX MAGNETIC GROUND STATES IN THE LAYERED COMPOUNDS LnTAl4Ge2 WITH TRIANGULAR LANTHANIDE NETS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Frustrated magnetism, Magnetic order, Magnetic phase transition, Magnetoresistance, Rare-earth magnetic materials, Specific heat

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Strongly correlated spin systems continue to draw significant interest due to the complex interplay between structural, charge, and spin degrees of freedom. This intricate relationship gives rise to a range of novel phenomena, such as topologically protected spin textures (like skyrmions), unconventional electronic band physics (e.g., flat bands), and other emergent states. In this dissertation, we present our results from investigations into three distinct compounds within the category of geometrically frustrated materials, specifically those of the LnTAl4Ge2 variety. We elucidate the process of design and synthesis for these compounds, followed by a thorough characterization of their physical properties, including magnetic, thermal, and electronic attributes.

First, we outlined the design and synthesis of new materials, specifically LnTAl4Ge2 single crystals, utilizing the molten metal flux crystal growth method. By modulating the molar ratio of the reactive elements and the heating/cooling profile, we successfully produced phase-pure crystals. We then elucidated the crystalline structures of the synthesized LnTAl4Ge2 single crystals using Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) and Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS), highlighting that the fabrication of large, phase-pure specimens poses significant challenges. We observed the presence of impurity phases such as AuAl2, LnAl2Ge2, and Ln2Al3Ge4 alongside with LnTAl4Ge2 phases. Furthermore, we found that compounds where the Ln = Ce, Sm, Gd, and Tb can be more easily obtained as phase-pure LnAuAl4Ge2 crystals; similarly, when Ln = Sm, Gd, Tb, Y, and Lu, the production of phase-pure LnNiAl4Ge2 crystals can be more easily achievable.

Then, We focus on examples with novel magnetism and reported the comprehensive study of magnetic, thermal, and electrical properties in the antiferromagnetic phase of TbAuAl4Ge2. Following the discussion of TbAuAl4Ge2, GdAuAl4Ge2 compound is studied, together with the thermal results of YAuAl4Ge2. The temperature and magnetic field-dependent magnetization, heat capacity, and electrical resistivity measurements reveal that both Tb- and Gd-variant compounds exhibit several magnetically ordered states at low temperatures, with evidence for magnetic fluctuations extending into the paramagnetic temperature region. For magnetic fields applied in the ab-plane, there is particularly rich behavior, with several ordered state regions that are separated by metamagnetic phase transitions. Despite Gd being an isotropic S-state ion and Tb having an anisotropic J-state, there are similarities in the phase diagrams for the two compounds, suggesting that factors such as the symmetry of the crystalline lattice, which features well-separated triangular planes of lanthanide ions, or the Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yosida interaction control the magnetism. We also point out similarities to other centrosymmetric compounds that host skyrmion lattices, such as Gd2PdSi3, and propose that the LnAuAl4Ge2 family of compounds are of interest as reservoirs for complex magnetism and electronic behaviors.

Next, we reported and bulk physical properties of SmAuAl4Ge2 single crystals, together with experimental results for LuAuAl4Ge2. Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal van Vleck paramagnetism due to trivalent samarium ions, with complex antiferromagnetic ordering at TN1 = 13.2 K and TN2 = 7.4 K. Heat capacity measurements show that the transitions at TN1 and TN1 are first and second order, respectively, while also revealing that the Sommerfeld coefficient is not enhanced compared to the nonmagnetic analog YAuAl4Ge2. Together with electrical resistivity measurements, these results show that SmAuAl4Ge2 is a weakly correlated metal, where the combination of van Vleck paramagnetism with the triangular net arrangement of the samarium ions, leads to complex magnetic ordering at low temperatures, resembling what is seen in other LnAuAl4Ge2 (Ln = Gd and Tb) analogues. In addition, positive linear magnetoresistance appears within the ordered states over a wide field range, further establishing SmAuAl4Ge2 and the broader family as hosts for novel magnetism and anomalous magnetotransport behaviors.

Finally, we reported results for GdNiAl4Ge2, which crystallizes in a rhombohedral structure that features geometrically frustrated triangular nets of lanthanide ions. Magnetic, thermodynamic, and electrical transport measurements reveal metallic behavior with antiferromagnetic-like ordering in small magnetic fields, which strongly evolves to produce anomalous hysteresis for magnetic fields applied in the ab-plane. In particular, over a limited portion of the temperature-field phase space, the magnetic susceptibility of the field-cooled curves is smaller than that of the zero-field-cooled curves, and the ac magnetic response exhibits frequency and field-dependent peaks only in the zero- field-cooled curves. This suggests the formation of history-dependent spin structures or domains with complex spin relaxation dynamics, resembling what is seen on other materials with nontrivial spin textures. This establishes GdNiAl4Ge2 as a host for intriguing quantum spin states and further focuses attention on this family of materials.

Taken together, the great sensitivity of these properties to changes in temperature and magnetic fields, as well as chemical tune, make the LnTAl4Ge2 family of materials as a reservoir for an environment to search for strongly correlated magnetism and connect them to broader classes of anomalous magnetic metals, including those with geometric frustration [83, 84, 85, 5, 86], topological protection [87, 88, 89, 90], unconventional Hall effects [91, 92], skyrmion states [71, 93, 7, 27, 94, 36], and possibly a metallic quantum spin liquid behavior [95]. This makes our work a great value in developing the present understanding of magnetism. In addition, our work has attracted solid researchers to further study these materials [81, 152]and will be of great value to the theorists for guiding the improvements in understanding magnetism.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MUSIC THERAPISTS’ KNOWLEDGE OF AUTISM: A SURVEY OF MUSIC THERAPISTS WHO WORK WITH AUTISTIC CLIENTS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: ASKSP-R, Autism, Autism Knowledge, Music Therapy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to assess music therapists’ knowledge of autism via a validated measure to explore their perspectives regarding how they practiced music therapy with autistic clients. The participants for this study were 336 MT-BC’s practicing across the United States providing music therapy services to at least one autistic client. The dependent measure was a survey created by combining the ASKSP-R by McClain et al. (2020) with previous demographic, professional and clinical practice items selected from previous research by Kern, Rivera, Chandler, and Humpal (2013) and modified to today’s terminology and practice standards. Results showed that, overall, music therapists had adequate knowledge of autism as measured by the ASKSP-R however there were gaps in knowledge found. Music therapists reported feeling confident providing music therapy services to autistic people. Regarding how music therapists informed their practice, they reported using several different resources, organizations, and training programs such as Autism Speaks, Autistic Self Advocacy Network, Autistic Women & Nonbinary Network, Registered Behavioral Technician training, and applied behavior analysis and safety care training. The free text responses on the professional practice portion of the survey revealed strong feelings about the current controversy over appropriate services for autistic persons. Since the ASKSP-R and portions of the survey used person-first language and deficit based language, several music therapists expressed their concern and opinions through textual responses on the survey, through emails, and social media. While several music therapists showed support for a social model and the neurodiversity paradigm, others showed their support for the medical diagnosis model, therapies for autism such as ABA, and organizations such as Autism Speaks. This study concludes with my personal responses and recommendations as an autistic person to the study, diagnosis, and services provided to autistic persons.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Cumulative Influence of Teachers' Affective Demeanor on Students' Reading Engagement Across First Through Third Grade Classrooms

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: classroom emotional climate, elementary teachers, multilevel growth models, student engagement

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Teachers play a large role in determining whether or not the classroom climate experienced by students is positive, especially through their visible emotional behaviors (i.e., neutral, positive, and negative emotional expressions). Research suggests that teachers make specific contributions to the classroom emotional climate in actions such as building relationships with students, managing classroom behaviors, and displaying enthusiasm during instruction. The current study explored one specific contribution teachers make to the classroom emotional climate (i.e., teacher displayed affective demeanor) likely associated with maintaining student engagement. The purpose of this study was to capture the unique influences of teacher displayed affective demeanor as it relates to students’ engagement. Secondary analysis using video recordings of 84 first through third grade classrooms were used to explore teachers’ displayed affective demeanor (n = 79) and students’ off-task behavior (n = 539) during reading instruction. Limited research addresses the contribution of teacher displayed affective demeanor as students progress through elementary school and move to new classrooms. This study investigated these associations both concurrently and longer term (across three school years). Specifically, multilevel growth models were used to explore whether and how teachers’ affective demeanor and students’ off-task behavior were associated over time. Two main research aims were addressed: (1) How does teachers’ displayed affective demeanor relate to students’ off-task behavior cross-sectionally in first, second, and third grade? and (2) How does teachers’ displayed affective demeanor relate to growth in student off-task behavior from first through third grade? Teachers’ demeanor characteristics were associated with students’ off-task behavior and distinct associations between students’ off-task behavior and teachers’ demeanor were present in first, second, and third grade. Additionally, an increase in teachers’ positive demeanor was associated with less off-task behavior in the spring of third grade and a more rapidly declining rate of growth in off-task behavior over time. The results suggested that first grade teachers’ positive demeanor contributed to changes in students’ off-task behavior in the same school year as well as the following two school years that students experienced in different classrooms.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TARGETING THE AMYGDALA WITH TRANSCRANIAL MAGNETIC STIMULATION TO ALTER THE LATE POSITIVE POTENTIAL

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The affective salience network is composed of a variety of brain regions, including, but not limited to, the anterior insula, amygdala, and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex. Based primarily on fMRI studies, previous research suggests that activity in the affective salience network is related to suicidal behavior. The affective salience network’s specific role in suicidal behavior is not known, but one possibility is its core function in the orienting response to salient stimuli, including threat. This orienting response aids in survival and, if diminished to threatening stimuli, may underlie the affective salience network’s relationship to suicidal behavior by contributing to a key construct in leading theories of suicide: capability for suicide, specifically its subconstruct called fearlessness about death. Existing treatments for suicidal behavior are sub-optimal, and thus interventions targeting the affective salience network may prove beneficial in treating suicidal behavior by decreasing capability for suicide. In a first step towards investigating such an approach, Chapter 1 reviews the literature on capability for suicide, the affective salience network, neural measures of affective salience, transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and how it can be used to stimulate subcortical areas. Chapter 2 discusses an attempt to use intermittent theta-burst stimulation (iTBS), a type of repetitive TMS, to alter affective salience network activity in healthy young adults by indirectly targeting a key region of this network: the amygdala. In line with previous research using a similar approach, a portion of the rostral medial frontal wall (RMW) that demonstrated high functional connectivity with the amygdala was stimulated to alter the affective salience network’s orienting response to affective pictures. To examine this neural activity, an event-related potential called the late positive potential (LPP) was measured. Analyses did not reveal any significant difference in the LPP between stimulating the RMW and a control site (V1). However, if effect sizes were to hold in a larger sample, the data suggest that iTBS stimulation to V1 reduces the affective salience network’s response to threatening images. Chapter 3 discusses future directions based on the results presented in Chapter 2, and ends with remarks on the state of the suicide neuroscience field. Specifically, I discuss the assumptions in the present paradigm, and offer suggestions for how the field can improve. In summary, this work failed to find a significant effect of stimulation to the RMW to alter the LPP. Nevertheless, the data suggests the possibility that V1 stimulation reduces the salience network’s response to threatening images. With further investigation, the relationship between V1 stimulation and salience network activity may inform the scientific community’s understanding of the relationship between sensory information and salience.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Generational Status and Anxiety: The Role of Familism Among Latinx College Students

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: anxiety, familism, generational status, Latinx college students, mental health, minority context

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The Latinx college population is at risk for developing anxiety symptoms due to stressors related to minority contexts. This study examined the role of familism among Latinx college students and how it relates to generational status and anxiety. The sample included 154 Latinx college students attending Florida State University (Mage = 20.4, SD = 1.692; 71.4% female; 74.9% U.S. born). Participants completed surveys via Qualtrics. A path analysis was utilized to examine the mediation from generational status to familism to anxiety outcomes. Results indicated no associations with anxiety. In this study, familism did not mediate the association between generational status and anxiety. The findings of this study highlight familism subscales and their relation to income and gender which imply that family obligation may be impacted by income and gender.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Impacts of a Tongue Thrust Disorder on Clarinet Playing

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Clarinet, Disorder, Myofunctional, Orofacial, Tongue Thrust

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The topic of Orofacial Myofunctional Disorders (OMDs) and how they can challenge instrumental performance is an area of research that is not frequently discussed. My interest in this topic began during my pursuit to improve areas of playing such as tongue positioning and articulation. I felt that I was hitting roadblocks, many of which I struggled to overcome. I wondered what was different about me and why progress in these areas was so challenging. After some reflection, I began to consider whether the tongue thrust diagnosis I received in my teen years could still be manifesting in some way. This inspired my research on Orofacial Myofunctional Disorders, Tongue Thrust Disorder, and their relationship to clarinet performance.

The research in this treatise aims to accomplish three goals. The first is to provide readers with a better understanding of OMDs and Tongue Thrust Disorder and their side effects. The second is to discuss the existing literature researching the relationships between clarinet performance and Tongue Thrust Disorder. Finally, it will explore some pedagogical methods and their effectiveness in cases of tongue thrust.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Exploring the Influence of Climate Modes on Extremes Related to Atmospheric Fronts Along the Eastern United States

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Atmospheric Fronts, Climate, Energy demand, Meteorology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Atmospheric fronts are responsible for changes in temperature, precipitation, and wind direction, and are often associated with extremes related to the weather, such as cold snaps and flooding, that have significant socio-economic impacts. Winter cold fronts moving across the eastern United States are known to leave residents in states of extreme cold and dangerous weather. These temperatures can lead to an increase in electricity demand, which can result in increased carbon emissions. With several states working to reduce carbon emissions, a better understanding and predictability of fronts and their temperature change impacts would help power companies better budget for carbon emissions and guide capital investment in renewable technologies. In this research, we analyze how several leading modes of climate variability, such as the NAO, PNA and ENSO, influence temperature extremes related to the passing of atmospheric fronts. This manuscript investigates the average temperature anomalies associated with the passage cold and warm fronts for locations in North Carolina, New York, Florida, and off the coast of Florida. Several characteristic patterns defining the passage of fronts in each location have been discussed. With these anomalies characterized, they were compared to the average temperature anomalies associated with cold fronts during the positive and negative phases of the NAO, PNA, and ENSO. The modes were found to influence the characteristic anomalies surrounding cold fronts. Each mode impacted every location differently, but they could cause or suppress extreme temperatures as they related to the passage of cold fronts. A preliminary exploration of the relationship between electricity demand and the passage of cold fronts was also discussed. The influence of frontal strength on spikes in electricity demand was found to result in a higher probability for larger spikes in demand with stronger cold fronts and a lower probability for spikes with weaker fronts. The location in New York was selected to analyze how cold fronts during ENSO may change this relationship that was found between cold fronts and electricity demand spikes. This preliminary investigation proved that there is a relationship between electricity demand spikes and cold fronts and that the modes of variability can impact this relationship. This provides potential for more extensive work to be done in the future to fully quantify the scale relationship between fronts and electricity demand during specific phases of modes of variability.

DISS_description.DISS_title: VOICES FROM THE SPANISH DIASPORA: SELECT ART SONGS BY MARÍA RODRIGO AND EMILIANA DE ZUBELDÍA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: art song, female composer, Spain, Spanish, turn-of-the-century, voice

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Spanish composers María Rodrigo Bellido (1888-1967) and Emiliana Zubeldía e Inda (1888-1987) exhibit remarkable personal and professional parallels. Both were born the same year during the Bourbon Restoration in Spain, received world-class training abroad, and were accomplished concert pianists and published composers in an era when most Spanish women were illiterate. Still in their prime, they left Spain and lived the remainder of their lives in the Americas, having key roles in the establishment of collegiate music programs in Puerto Rico and Mexico, respectively. It is difficult to overestimate the quality of their work and significance of their achievements.Their music is endowed with rich individuality and reflects the synthesis of wider European musical trends, national and regional folk music, key mentors’ and collaborators’ influences, and their own unique compositional vision. Both were prolific vocal and instrumental composers, yet neither has received due recognition outside of Mexico and Spain. Very little of their work has been published, and the scores that do exist are often hard to locate and difficult to read. Additionally, the majority of the limited scholarly research published about their lives is written exclusively in Spanish, making it inaccessible to an English-speaking audience. This project represents an essential English-language biographical resource and a detailed analysis of twenty-five of Rodrigo and Zubeldía’s art songs, with the object of providing greater awareness of and access to this body of work for students, teachers, and professional performers in classical voice. With over 41 million Spanish speakers in the United States and a growing demand for racial, cultural, and gender inclusivity, this treatise is an important addition to existing literature.

DISS_description.DISS_title: UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECTS OF ANTHROPOMORPHISM ON CONSUMER ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIORS TOWARD NEW LUXURY BRANDS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: anthropomorphism, luxury brands, marketing, new luxury brands

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This study examined the effect of anthropomorphism in marketing for new luxury brands and its influence on consumer attitudes and behaviors, with a specific focus on brand recall, attitudes toward the ad, attitude toward the brand, and intentions to purchase. The data was collected using a convenient sample from the Florida State University (FSU) student population and through an online survey resulting in 195 recorded and analyzed responses out of a sample of 237. The results of the study revealed statistically significant findings regarding the effects of anthropomorphism on consumer attitudes and behaviors. Specifically, the findings supported the hypothesis that anthropomorphism in marketing for new luxury brands positively influences brand recall. These results contribute to a theoretical understanding of the use of anthropomorphism in marketing, provide recommendations for practitioners, and suggest avenues for further research in the field of anthropomorphism and new luxury brand marketing.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXPLORING AN INTEGRATED MODEL OF PERFECTIONISM AND DEPRESSIVE SYMPTOMS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The relationships between perfectionism and depression have been widely studied among college students (Smith et al., 2020). Research has explained their relationships by suggesting different mediating variables in cognitive, social, and behavioral contexts, specifically based on the Perfectionism Social Disconnection model (PSDM; Hewitt et al., 2006) and the Existential Model of Perfectionism and Depressive Symptoms (EMPDS; Graham et al., 2010). However, research has not examined the simultaneous effects of cognitive, social, and behavioral variables on the relationships between perfectionism and depressive symptoms with consideration of multidimensionality of perfectionism. The multidimensionality of perfectionism can be explained with perfectionistic strivings, narcissistic perfectionism, and perfectionistic concerns. The lack of an integrated model of perfectionism and depressive symptoms have engendered some limitations in comprehending multidimensional perfectionism and depressive symptoms. The limitations include: 1) the unique/conjoint effects of each perfectionism factor were not fully examined and 2) the relative strengths of mediators or their relationships were unclear in the perfectionism-depressive symptoms model. The purpose of this study is to investigate the integrated model of perfectionism and depressive symptoms through a cognitive, social, and behavioral lens by focusing on the three variables representing each domain: perceived life discrepancy, lack of social belongingness, and self-concealment. A total of 346 college students aged from 18 to 34 were recruited from a southeastern university and were used for the current study. The sample was composed of 73.9% female (N = 255), 23.4% male (N = 81), and 2.0% others (N = 7). The sample included 65.3% (non-Hispanic) White (N = 226), 12.1% Hispanic (N = 42), 4.3% (non-Hispanic) Black (N = 15), 2.9% Asian (N = 10), 0.9% Middle Eastern (N = 3), and 13.6% Bi/multiracial (N = 47). The sample consisted of 79.5% of students identified as heterosexual (N = 275), while 15.9% identified as LGBQ (N = 55). The sample also contained 2.3% international students (N = 8) and 20.2% students (N = 70) who identified themselves as a first generation in college. The sample spread from freshman to graduate students (8.4% freshman; 23.4% sophomore, 28.9% junior, 28.9% senior +, and 10.4% graduate). A cross-sectional design was used to test the integrated model of perfectionism and depressive symptoms and estimate path coefficients and mediation effects in the model. This research focused on three research questions: 1) Do three factors of multidimensional perfectionism - perfectionistic strivings, perfectionistic concerns, and narcissistic perfectionism - significantly predict depressive symptoms? 2) Do perceived life discrepancy, lack of social belongingness, and self-concealment mediate the relationship between the three perfectionism factors and depressive symptoms, controlling for other perfectionism factors and GPA (integrated parallel mediation model)? and 3) Does self-concealment additionally mediate the relationship between perceived life discrepancy and depressive symptoms and between lack of social belongingness and depressive symptoms in the parallel mediation model in research question 2 (integrated serial mediation model)? GPA was considered as a covariate to control its consistent relationships with perfectionism and depressive symptoms among college students (Huang, 2015; Madigan, 2019; Sörberg Wallin et al., 2019). Research found that perfectionistic strivings, perfectionistic concerns, and narcissistic perfectionism impacted depressive symptoms separately (research question 1). However, only perfectionistic concerns predicted depressive symptoms when the other perfectionism factors and GPA were controlled for. After the integrated model was established, the model presented several significant parallel and serial mediation effects. Research found that perfectionistic concerns impacted depressive symptoms simultaneously through perceived life discrepancy, lack of social belongingness, and self-concealment in the parallel mediation model, in addition to its direct influence on depressive symptoms. Although perfectionistic strivings and narcissistic perfectionism did not impact depressive symptoms directly, they impacted depressive symptoms through lack of social belongingness. Self-concealment did not mediate the relationship of the two perfectionism factors with depressive symptoms. Perceived life discrepancy did not mediate narcissistic perfectionism and depressive symptoms but showed a tendency to mediate perfectionistic strivings and depressive symptoms (research questions 2). However, with the inclusion of serial mediation effects of self-concealment between the other mediators and depressive symptoms (the serial mediation model), self-concealment did not directly mediate the relationship between perfectionistic concerns and depressive symptoms unlike the result in the parallel mediation model in research question 2. Instead, perfectionistic concerns impacted depressive symptoms through lack of social belongingness and self-concealment in sequence. Narcissistic perfectionism and perfectionistic strivings also showed a tendency to influence depressive symptoms through the path from perfectionism, lack of social belongingness, self-concealment, and depressive symptoms (research question 3). Surprisingly, unlike the other two perfectionism factors, perfectionistic strivings played a unique role in decreasing lack of social belongingness or perceived life discrepancy, which later impacted reducing depressive symptoms under the circumstance where GPA and the other two perfectionism factors were controlled for. Among the three mediators, lack of social belongingness functions as a stronger mediator than the other mediators consistently across perfectionism factors. The study implications and limitations of this study were discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A SPACE OF OUR OWN: INFORMAL SOCIAL SPACES IN MIDDLE SCHOOLS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Adolescence, Middle School, School Design

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Despite efforts, evidence suggests adolescent mental health continues to decline. The CDC’s Youth Risk Behavior Data Summary & Trends Report showed a rise in persistent feelings of sadness or hopelessness among adolescents from 2009-2019 (Center for Disease Control and Prevention, 2021). Similarly, the percentage of adolescents having suicidal ideations, plans, and attempts has also increased (Center for Disease Control and Prevention, 2021). Adolescents spend a significant amount of time inside a school building, making this environment integral to improving adolescent mental health. According to Jacquelynne Eccles and co-authors (1993), many school environments do not support the developmental needs of adolescents. They hypothesized that a mismatch between adolescent needs and the opportunities to meet said needs in school environments is a cause of negative psychological effects, such as poor mental resilience (Eccles et al., 1993). To address this need, this study explores how informal social spaces in middle schools, i.e., unstructured, non-instructional, and relatively unsupervised spaces, can be designed to better support adolescents’ developmental needs.

Adolescence, the developmental years between childhood and adulthood, is often a difficult time for many. Early adolescence (ages 10-15) is the liminal stage of these developmental years and is marked by the onset of momentous biological, psychological, and social changes (Arain et al., 2013). During this time, adolescents attempt to find their place in society, resulting in an increased need for belonging and autonomy (Wang & Hofkens, 2020). Many middle schools lack the infrastructure and programming to support adolescent needs for exploration and self-management. Further, the lack of interactions and opportunities for building relationships can prevent students from satisfying their increased need for a sense of belonging (Wang & Hofkens, 2020). Informal social spaces, such as libraries, cafeterias, and circulationspaces may be a solution for schools helping adolescents meet their developmental needs since these spaces offer students the opportunity to be themselves and interact with each other freely (Wang & Hofkens, 2020). When intentionally designed, informal social spaces have the potential to increase adolescents’ mental resilience and overall mental health by giving them the opportunity to receive genuine support from one another (Vieno et al., 2007).

DISS_description.DISS_title: USING ‘OMICS’ METHODOLOGIES TO IDENTIFY ACTIVE, NOVEL HYDROCARBON DEGRADING MICROORGANISMS IN THE NORTHERN GULF OF MEXICO AND IN THE GLOBAL OCEAN

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: hydrocarbon-degrading microbes, marine hydrocarbon cycle, metagenome-assembled genomes, metagenomics, metatranscriptomics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Hundreds of millions of liters of oil and natural gas are introduced to the ocean annually, yet the ecological consequences of hydrocarbon inputs into the marine environment are poorly understood. In particular, the role of microbes in oil and gas consumption in the marine environment is not well characterized. Much of what is known about hydrocarbon degrading microorganisms, particularly those in the marine environment, stems from cultivation-based studies. However, the majority of microbes elude cultivation, which leads to a significant knowledge gap regarding the degradation capabilities of uncultured, indigenous microbes in the ocean. Multi-omics approaches allow for circumventing the need to culture an organism in the lab to study its physiology and provides a definitive link between taxonomy, function and activity of uncultured hydrocarbon degrading microbes. In this thesis, resolving the identities, metabolic capabilities, and activity of uncultured hydrocarbon-degrading microorganisms was done through utilization of new computational methods for multi-omics datasets to analyze metagenomes and metatranscriptomes from the Gulf of Mexico (GOM) water column and global ocean by taking advantage of.

Chapters two and three were solely focused on microbial hydrocarbon degradation, while chapter four included analysis of both hydrocarbon production and consumption. In chapters two and three, genome assembly, gene annotation, and read mapping was used to elucidate microbial hydrocarbon degradation pathways in the GOM (our datasets) and global ocean (previously existing datasets, such as TARA Ocean). Metagenome assembled genomes (MAGs) combined with read mapping revealed that previously unrecognized, uncultured microbes are actively expressing genes and pathways for hydrocarbon degradation. For example, in chapter 2, Planctomycetota, Verrucomicrobiota, and Latescibacterota, clades lacking known methane-oxidizers in the marine environment, were identified as novel, non-canonical methanotrophs in the GOM and in the global ocean. These findings help resolve rate measurement and metatranscriptomic data that showed methane oxidation is an active process in northern GOM hypoxic zone, an ecosystem where canonical methane-oxidizing microbes are at negligible abundances. Similarly, chapter three multi-omics data analysis from the Deepwater Horizon (DWH) oil spill deep-sea plume, in which methane was the most abundant hydrocarbon, and from the global ocean revealed non-canonical methanotrophs in the Cycloclasticus. This represents a novel finding as this clade lacks members that are known carry out aerobic methane oxidation. Additional clade specific substrate degradation potentials that have not been reported previously included Bermanella genomes that encoded and expressed genes for medium and long chain n-alkanes and cycloalkane degradation, as did Colwellia, Cycloclasticus, and UBA11654. However, DWH Bermanella encoded an alkane hydroxylase, not an alkane monooxygenase, which is an important finding given that alkane hydroxylase has a narrow substrate range (C8-C16) compared to alkane monooxygenase (alkB) (C12-C26), and is entirely consistent with the profile of Macondo oil where C8-C16 were the most abundant non-gaseous n-alkanes. Lastly, SAR324 and UBA11654 contained members that encoded for aromatic hydrocarbon degradation. While chapters two and three evaluated microbial consumption of fossil fuels input to the marine environment, both naturally and through anthropogenic activities, in what is termed the long-term hydrocarbon cycle, chapter four evaluated the complete cycle of hydrocarbon production to consumption in the photic zone, termed the short-term hydrocarbon cycle. The short-term hydrocarbon cycle was evaluated using metatranscriptomic data from the photic zone of the GOM and previously assembled genomic data from over 8,000 MAGs from OceanDNA (Nishimura and Yoshizawa 2022) and close to 1,000 Prochlorococcus and Synechococcus genomes from the Prochlorococcus Portal. This analysis revealed active pathways for the production of pentadecane (C15) and heptadecane (C17) by Prochlorococcus and, to a lesser degree Synechococcus, co-occurring with active n-alkane degradation, including C15 and C17 alkanes, by microbes in the photic zone of the GOM. Additionally, this active n-alkane degradation pathway was similar to the dominant hydrocarbon degradation pathway in the DWH oil spill plume. Specifically, the complete pathway from alkane degradation via alkane-monooxygenase through fatty acid metabolism was reconstructed for 18 bacterial phyla and one archaeal phylum.

Overall, the findings in this dissertation indicate there is a large, diverse, and active group of microbes with the ability to degrade a spectrum of hydrocarbon substrates. Collectively, these analyses of uncultured planktonic microbes link taxonomy and function and provide an opportunity to predict the microbial response to oil and gas input to the marine environment, thus providing new insights into the fate of oil (and gas) when hydrocarbons are input to the ocean, leading to a greater understanding of the ecological consequences to the marine environment.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE COMBINATION OF CHILDHOOD TRAUMA AND COVID-19-RELATED TRAUMA: DO COPING AND RESILIENCY DECREASE THE HARMFUL EFFECTS?

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Childhood trauma, Coping, COVID-19, Resiliency

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Childhood trauma has a pronounced effect on both children who have experienced trauma as well as adults who were exposed to trauma as children (Felitti et al., 1998). This sobering reality is even more pronounced for more vulnerable communities (HHS, 2018), such as people of color, women, individuals who identify as LBGTQ+, and individuals of lower socioeconomic status. Exposure to childhood trauma can result in a whole host of psychological as well as physiological effects Felitti et al., 1998; Giano et al., 2020; Sonu et al., 2020). While there exists research on the stand-alone topics of childhood trauma (e.g., type, proximity, duration; SAMHSA, 2020; Zare, et al., 2018) and collective trauma (i.e., natural disasters, terrorist attacks; Blanchet-Cohen & Nelems, 2013; Chriman et al., 2014) minimal research exists on the subject of COVID-19-related trauma and the combination of pre-pandemic childhood trauma. The following study investigated the relationships between pre-pandemic childhood trauma and COVID-19-related trauma in adults during the pandemic while controlling for general mental health difficulties. Being that the pandemic is ongoing, the specific period examined in the current study was from the onset of the pandemic in early 2020, though when the data was collected in early 2022. The study also sought to explore if resiliency and coping had a moderating effect on the combination of these two types of trauma. A convenience sampling method using Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk; www.MTurk.com) was utilized to recruit 127 adults, all over the age of 18, who had previously been exposed to at least one form of childhood trauma before the onset of the pandemic. The study sought to explore the following research questions: (1) Is childhood trauma related to current COVID-19-related trauma in adults during the pandemic, controlling for general mental health difficulties?, (2) Is childhood trauma related to peak COVID-19-related trauma in adults during the pandemic, controlling for general mental health difficulties?, (3) Do coping and resiliency moderate the relationship between childhood trauma and COVID-19-related trauma, controlling for general mental health difficulties? Assessment measures employed by the study include: Trauma History Questionnaire (THQ; Hooper et al., 2011), COVID Stress Scale (CSS; Taylor et al., 2020), Depression Anxiety Stress Scale (DASS-21; Lovibond et al., 1995), Brief Coping Orientation to Problems Experienced (Brief COPE; Carver, 1997), and the Brief Resilience Scale (BRS; Smith et al., 2008). A path analysis was utilized to explore the relation between pre-pandemic childhood trauma, COVID-19 distress, coping, and resiliency. Results from the original research questions were not significant and will be discussed further in the results section. Furthermore, results from the final research question, focusing on whether resiliency and coping moderated the relationship pre-pandemic childhood trauma and COVID-19-related trauma, were inconclusive. Additional findings from the study found that both types of trauma were widespread amongst the research participants. Implications for psychological theory development, clinical practice, and possible directions for future research is discussed.

DISS_description.DISS_title: PROFILES OF SPORT COMMITMENT AND MENTAL HEALTH AMONG NON-STUDENT-ATHLETES AT US UNIVERSITIES

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: A commitment is the “pledging or binding of an individual to behavioral acts” (Kiesler & Sakumura, 1966, p.349). Commitment has been examined across many academic areas such as Psychology (Michael, 2021), Sociology (Kemper, 2012), and Business (Carballo-Penela et al., 2020). For example, in Psychology, commitment refers to a state that predicts one’s behavior and maintains relationships with other people (Michael, 2021). In Sociology, commitment is defined as a contribution to maintaining an ongoing connection with all the relevant social groups from one’s personal history (Kemper, 2012). Also, researchers in the business area explained the commitment to sustainability as an element that has a favorable impact on job seekers’ intentions to seek employment opportunities within the organization (Carballo-Penela et al., 2020). Notably, Commitment has been regarded as an essential element of motivating, persisting, and achieving objectives in sports (Hall, 1993), and has also been studied frequently in the Sport Psychology and Management field (Scanlan et al., 1993, p.1).

A commitment is known to have different types of outcomes. Specifically, many researchers conducted studies on how commitment can influence one’s mental health by applying Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT). ACT is “a type of behavior therapy that uses processes such as acceptance, mindfulness, and commitment behaviors to create some flexible psychological processes” (Karimi, & Aghaei, 2018, p.2). Applying the ACT in the educational and psychological contexts reduced the psychological problems (e.g., anxiety, depression, and stress) of students (Karimi, & Aghaei, 2018). Thus, exercisers who used the ACT during aerobics had higher levels of subjective well-being and lower psychological distress (Xu et al., 2021).

Commitment influenced an individual’s mental health, yet, there have been no studies on how different types and levels of Sport Commitment may be associated with one’s mental health among college students. Sport Commitment is one’s psychological state of participating in sports due to the desire or perception of obligation or both (Scanlan et al., 1993). The original Sport Commitment Model (SCM) is a representative framework of Sport Commitment for explaining the persistent involvement in sports and is designed for youth sports. (Scanlan et al., 1993). To apply this model to adult populations, Scanlan et al. (2016) updated the original SCM and described it as a theoretical framework to “examine commitment and explain why athletes involve in their sport continuously” (p. 234), however, several studies applied the model to non-athletes such as recreational players as well (Bum, 2018; Casper & Andrew, 2008; Gabriele et al., 2011; Kang et al., 2020; Ko & Kim, 2021; Wilson et al., 2004).

Even though many studies have focused on the determinant of Sport Commitment, only little research has concentrated on the outcomes of Sport Commitment including mental health outcomes and, further, no studies have investigated the potential association between different profiles of Sport Commitment and mental health outcomes among college students who are not student-athletes. Therefore, the purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between two different profiles of Sport Commitment (i.e., Enthusiastic Commitment, Constrained Commitment) and levels of various mental health outcomes (i.e., stress, anxiety, depression, happiness, and psychological well-being) among college students who are not student-athletes in the US.

To fulfill the objective of the present study, this research was designed as cross-sectional research. I recruited 300 participants via Prolific, and the 83 items survey was distributed using Qualtrics. As measurements, I adopted the SCQ-2 (Scanlan et al., 2016), DASS-21 (Lovibond & Lovibond, 1995), OHQ (Hills & Argyle, 2002), PERMA Profiler (Butler & Kern, 2016), BRCS (Sinclair & Wallston, 2004) to assess Enthusiastic Commitment, Constrained Commitment, stress, anxiety, depression, happiness, psychological well-being, and resilient coping. After collecting the data, I conducted the descriptive analysis and Canonical correlation analysis to explore the association between two profiles of Sport Commitment and one’s stress, anxiety, depression, happiness, and psychological well-being.

As a result, it showed that participants who were enthusiastically committed to sports had high levels of happiness and psychological well-being, and lower levels of stress, anxiety, and depression. In contrast, participants who had a higher level of Constrained Commitment tended to have higher degrees of stress, anxiety, and depression, and lower happiness and psychological well-being.

The present study holds significance both in terms of theoretical and practical implications. It contributes to the theoretical expansion of the SCM by examining the mental health outcomes of two profiles of Sport Commitment among college students who are not student-athletes. Additionally, the results highlight the crucial roles of the university in maximizing the level of Enthusiastic Commitment that lead to enhancing mental health among college students.

DISS_description.DISS_title: TEACHER MORALE AND DISTRICT AND SCHOOL LEADERSHIP IN A RURAL, HIGH POVERTY, AND ETHNICALLY DIVERSE DISTRICT

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The research questions addressed in this exploratory survey research were: 1) what is the degree of teachers' morale, and what perceptions do teachers have about their district and school leadership, 2) how does the degree of teachers' morale differ by their background characteristics, and 3) how are teacher perceptions of district and school leadership associated with their sense of morale, controlling for their background characteristics in the Friendship (pseudonym) County School District (FCSD)? While many studies have established the link between school leadership and teacher morale, few studies have explored teachers' sense of morale and relationship with district and school leadership using a districtwide teacher survey in an ethnically diverse and economically disadvantaged district such as the Friendship (pseudonym) County School District (FCSD). Based on a districtwide survey of 123 teachers, I found that the overall degree of teacher morale in the Friendship County School District (FCSD) is high. This study also found that the degree of morale was significantly and negatively associated with the level of stress and health impact, showing that teachers who experience more stress and negative job impacts on their mental and physical health are more likely to report a lower degree of morale. Another significant finding was that the five dimensions of school leadership and, likewise, five dimensions of district leadership are significantly and positively associated with the degree of morale; thus, teachers who perceive their leadership positively along these five dimensions are more likely to report higher morale. Implications and recommendations for district and school leadership for increasing teacher morale are offered.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ENGAGING LIBRARIANS IN THE SCIENCE OF READING: THE IMPLICATIONS OF DIRECT INSTRUCTION IN EVIDNECE BASED PRACTICE FOR LANGUAGE AND LITERACY DEVELOPMENT

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The purpose of this study was to first determine whether a librarian’s years of experience positively correlated with their literacy knowledge and efficacy, and to second determine whether structured exposure to specific and targeted education of evidence-based strategies for literacy could enable librarians to improve their knowledge of the tenants of literacy and early language development. 10 librarians from a North Florida Public Library System were surveyed prior to and upon completion of an 8-week professional training course targeting evidence-based strategies for language and literacy development. The pre-training survey, consisting of 7 demographic, 25 knowledge, and 15 efficacy questions, intended to serve as a baseline of the librarians’ knowledge of general language components, acquisition, and development, as well as their level of confidence in employing their knowledge to promote early language and literacy development (efficacy). The post-training survey consisted of the same knowledge and efficacy questions with the addition of 5 free-response questions. Data were collected on the pre- and post-knowledge and efficacy responses. All participants demonstrated an increase in the number of correct knowledge responses and increased efficacy ratings from pre-training to post-training. Additionally, years of experience was found to positively correlate with the librarians’ efficacy ratings pre-training. However, years of experience was observed to have a mild negative correlation with pre-training knowledge. Implications of this study suggest that although exposure to structured training for language and literacy may be helpful in improving knowledge and efficacy in youth service librarians, years of experience in the role does not guarantee that veteran librarians will possess more knowledge than those newer to the field. A wider scope of training and content is needed to ensure strong foundations of knowledge.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Characterizing Interaction Between Gene Delivery Polyplexes and Bio-Inspired Surface Coatings for Localized Gene Delivery

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: DNA-PEI polyplexes, localized release, polyethyleneimine, Surface-based transfection

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Nucleic acid delivery is crucial for several biomedical applications, including tissue engineering, medical implant coatings, cancer treatment and regenerative medicine. Localized delivery of nucleic acids through biomaterial substrates can overcome several difficulties associated with common systemic delivery and maintain high vector concentrations at the target site to enable increased transfection efficiency. In this project, we aim to develop substrate-based nucleic acid delivery coatings that can provide extended and localized release of non-viral gene delivery vectors for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications. In vitro studies are conducted to characterize the absorption and release interactions between surface coatings made of the bio-inspired and naturally derived polymers, including polydopamine (pDA), hyaluronic acid (HA), glycol chitosan (GC), and their combinations, and a model polymeric gene delivery vector composed of polyethyleneimine (PEI). PEI-DNA polyplexes N/P ratio was observed to have a statistically significant impact on the amount of DNA loaded onto each coating, while the surface coating type and concentration were surprisingly found to have no statistically significant effects. Surface-based transfection as well as bolus transfection from these coatings are studied over time for NIH3T3 and HEK293 cells. Surface-based transfection efficiencies were significantly impacted by the coating types and polyplex N/P ratios for transfection on HEK293 cells. However, for transfection on NIH3T3 cells only coating type had a significant impact on the transfection efficiencies. In conclusion, this study adds to our understanding of how different biocompatible materials interact with nucleic acid delivery polyplexes, which aids in the creation of surface coatings that facilitate effective localized nucleic acid delivery for tissue engineering and biomedical implant applications.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Unpacking the Association Between Callous-Unemotional Traits and Offending

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Until the past few decades, criminological research has almost exclusively focused on examining the link between various environmental risk factors and criminal behavior. Since then, an emerging body of research has developed exploring the association between different antisocial traits and offending. The culmination of this research has revealed personality constructs such as low self-control, impulsiveness, aggressiveness, sensation seeking, and Machiavellianism, among others to be positively associated with greater criminal behaviors. However, this area of research, also known as propensity-based studies of offending, remains incomplete. The criminological literature has largely overlooked the potential explanatory power of callous-unemotional traits when attempting to identify the diverse factors that predict assorted offending patterns, including chronic levels of offending. To be certain, research in developmental psychology has linked these traits to a host of negative life outcomes typically found within criminological studies, including offending. And yet, research in the developmental literature has yet to uncover why, and under what conditions, this link exists as well as how this association changes based on the variant of callous-unemotional traits being examined. Likewise, research examining the etiology of callous-unemotional traits has many gaps in the literature particularly concerning male-female differences as well as discerning what environmental risk factors explain such development. This dissertation will address these gaps in the literature by examining potential pathways to the development of both variants of callous-unemotional traits as well as associations between the variants and various offending measures (i.e., general, nonviolent, violent, life-course-persistent offending, and illicit drug use). The results revealed that the etiology of both variants of callous-unemotional traits is dependent upon the sex of the individual. Additionally, the environmental factors that predicted callous-unemotional traits were different based on the variant being investigated. The models examining the callous-unemotional traits-crime link likewise found that the association differed based on the variant as well as the sex of the individual. The results of these analyses also find support for the link being nonlinear and partially due to a shared genetic etiology. The implications of these findings are discussed in reference to policy, theory, and future research.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EXAMINATION OF RATING DISCREPANCIES IN MULTI-INFORMANT ASSESSMENTS OF CHILDHOOD BEHAVIORS ACROSS DOMAINS: A META-ANALYTIC STUDY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Throughout the literature, there is a well-documented discrepancy between rating of children’s behaviors across different informants, typically parents and teachers. Many different theories have been investigated to address the root of these discrepancies. Previous studies have examined if these discrepancies are the result of informant interacting with the child across different contexts, teacher expertise in typical childhood behaviors, parent mental health and stress, and the quality of the rating forms. The current study sought to investigate such discrepancies in a meta-analytic framework in which eleven different informant pairs were examined rating eight different behaviors categories. It was hypothesized that the informant pairs that interacted with the children in similar contexts, such as Parent-Parent and Teacher-Teacher informant pairs, would demonstrate more similar ratings. This hypothesis was supported. It was also hypothesized that there would be more agreement on more observable behaviors, such as externalizing behaviors. This hypothesis was not supported. It is important to be able to understand when such rating discrepancies occur, because the ability to anticipate such rating discrepancies can be used in both clinical and empirical research.

DISS_description.DISS_title: AN ANALYSIS AND EXPLANATION OF THE REPRESENTATION OF THE 3-D WARM CORE STRUCTURE IN TROPICAL CYCLONES ACROSS VARIOUS REANALYSIS DATASETS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Tropical Meteorology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The warm core structure of a tropical cyclone (TC) has been previously analyzed through aircraft observations, dropsondes, satellite-borne Advanced Microwave Sounding Unit (AMSU) data, and numerical simulations. It has been shown that aircraft that fly through a TC collect data that represent the warm core of a TC well; however, it has been theorized that microwave and satellite data struggle to resolve and represent the warm core structure throughout the entire center of the TC because of the coarseness of the satellite observations. Numerical simulations have been utilized to study the height of the warm core with a maximum around 4-8 km and have found that the height is nearly constant with varying intensities (Stern and Nolan 2012). This study aims to analyze the warm core structure of a TC through reanalysis datasets (ERA5, ERA-Interim, MERRA2), as these datasets are the only ones outside of aircraft and observations, that can provide long duration data of 3-D and 4-D structure. ERA5 has the finest resolution of the three datasets that are analyzed with MERRA2, and ERA-Interim increasingly coarse. The average temperature anomaly with respect to the whole basin from the zonal mean in all basins is about +4-9K in ERA5, +3-6K in ERA-Interim, and +4-8K in MERRA2 with the West Pacific basin having the highest magnitudes of average temperature anomalies. ERA5 typically sees the highest magnitude in terms of maximum average temperature anomaly while ERA-Interim sees the lowest values in all basins, in addition to most of the datasets showing tropical storms being statistically significantly cooler than all other intensities. The height of the warm core, described here as pressure, was subjectively analyzed through the geopotential height anomalies, and was found to be nearly constant with increasing intensity around 350-400 hPa, with the West Pacific having the highest warm core around 300 hPa. These results suggest that the strength of the warm core varies within each basin and within different reanalysis datasets. The resolution of the datasets carries a large role in how well the warm core is represented, however, the strength is comparable to prior works. The height of the warm core in this study showed to be more constant with differing intensities which is different than what was found in previous works where the height of the warm core increased with intensity.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Dominant Cultures: Examining Perceptions of an LGBTQ+ Campus Environment

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: campus culture, college environment, LGBTQ+ students, queer students, sense of belonging

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: LGBTQ+ students exist on college campuses in greater numbers than ever before. Campus culture directly impacts how LGBTQ+ students experience college and contributes to their overall sense of belonging. Campus culture in turn is shaped by students’ access to resources and the effectiveness of those resources. Students’ experiences, for better or for worse, are shaped by the programming they have access to and the environment the college fosters through these programs. This dissertation in practice examines the relationship between LGBTQ+ students on Emerson College’s campus and the resources they use. Utilizing an exploratory case study methodology including focus groups and campus observations, this research examines the following questions: What are the experiences of Emerson’s LGBTQ+ students? How do Emerson’s LGBTQ+ programs and policies meet the needs of LGBTQ+ students on campus? In what ways do Emerson’s efforts enhance LGBTQ+ students’ feelings of belonging? This study found that many organizations and campus spaces operate as queer by default due to the orientation of their members, shaping the way that students experience campus culture. As such, other motivators such as race, ethnicity, and background prior to coming to college influence the connections students seek on campus moreso than their LGBTQ+ identity. This study also found that LGBTQ+ students experienced belonging in both LGBTQ+ campus activities and non-LGBTQ+ campus activities, although students do feel a need for more specific LGBTQ+ programming reflective of community struggles. Lastly, findings indicated that students felt that administration and faculty have a major impact on the sense of belonging present on campus as well as the LGBTQ+ offerings of the college, and there is a need for both groups to better their efforts as students feel they are earnest but misguided. The findings of this study revealed multiple implications for practice. Most of all, sense of belonging on campus for LGBTQ+ students encompasses many components, all directly related to their base need for connection. This means their sense of community cannot be pinpointed on any one item being present, but rather on multiple factors that create genuine relationships with others. LGBTQ+ students on Emerson’s campus experience that definition in unique ways unique to Emerson’s campus environment – perhaps most significantly, their sense of belonging being influenced greatly by being in the majority and attending a campus where they are able to interact with other LGBTQ+ students in a variety of settings, not just in specific organizations that cater to that population.

DISS_description.DISS_title: IMPROVING CLINICAL RISK MODELS THROUGH INTEGRATION OF POLYGENIC RISK SCORES AND OMICS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have significantly contributed to the identification of genetic variants by leveraging thousands of loci associated with complex traits and diseases, leading to breakthroughs in human genetics research. However, interpretation of these results is often difficult as the GWAS-identified variants (single-nucleotide polymorphisms [SNPs]) often have small effect estimates on target traits, limiting their direct application to disease research. Methods such as polygenic risk score analysis have been presented to enhance disease risk prediction, however, the clinical utility of these methods are controversial. Similarly, the identification of genes associated with likely causal SNPs is unclear as identified SNPs explain only a small portion of heritability. Genetic regulations of GWAS findings are often characterized using statistical methods such as transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS), but these methods tend to ignore functional mechanisms that play critical roles in gene-regulatory pathways, resulting in loss of predictive power.In this essay we present three integrative methodologies for improving disease risk prediction as well as identifying likely causal genes through incorporation of omics level data and GWAS results for complex traits. First, we propose an integrated PRS method that leverages multiple PRS methods, as well as multiple GWAS datasets, to improve coronary artery disease (CAD) risk prediction over clinically used prediction models (PCE). Our results indicate that our proposed method improves model discrimination for incident CAD cases over the PCE model while also improving risk reclassification in European populations. Second, we propose a Cauchy integrative model that aggregates gene expression levels, DNA methylation, and splicing event information to increase identification of likely causal genes in 24 GWAS complex trait datasets. Additionally, we extend our method to identify causal genes for lung adenocarcinoma risk. Finally, we implement our Cauchy integrative model to identify likely causal omics biomarkers for CAD and propose a penalized regression framework integrative PRS model to improve risk prediction in an African population when limited to a European GWAS and reference panel.
