Finally, I will conduct a case study on the historical contracts of football head coaches at one prominent NCAA member university (i.e., Florida State University). This study will show the evolution of how student athlete mental health has been addressed in head coach contracts over time and as the NCAA has released more materials on the topic. The findings of this study have the potential to influence the NCAA, or its member organizations, to obligate coaches to report student athlete mental health concerns, which in turn, could prevent tragic outcomes. Further, these articles will be used to emphasize the potential role of coaches as reporters, not practitioners, due to the unique relationship they have with their student athletes. Coaches should never be responsible for treating student athletes mental health issues but should be able to identify the symptoms associated with this status and refer the effected athlete(s) to the proper channels. Finally, by conducting these three studies, I hope to show how beneficial student mental health regulations will be for all actors involved, including the athletes themselves, their coaches, athletic department, and university staff, and even the NCAA as a league. Enforcing policy related to student athlete mental health, specifically within coach employment contracts, could potentially reduce the member organizations’, and by proxy the NCAA’s, chances of being held vicariously liable. Further, when coaches uphold this stipulation within their contractual, their chances of being held negligent for student athlete mental health concerns may also be reduced. Finally, although the NCAA and its member organizations should just ‘care’ about student athletes, by including contractual stipulations and policy for coaches, the student athletes may have a better chance of receiving care and treatment for potential mental health concerns.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A NOVEL GENETIC PLATFORM TO STUDY INTESTINAL TUMORIGENESIS IN DROSOPHILA

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: cancer model, colon cancer, Drosophila, enteroendocrine cell, intestinal stem cell, tumorigenesis

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Epithelial tissues rely on the activity of stem cells to sustain their structure and proper functioning. These stem cells are responsible for generating various types of cells, that are essential for the tissue's normal homeostasis, through division and differentiation. In order to ensure precise control over stem cell behavior and the decisions they make regarding cell fate, constant communication through a network of signaling pathways between different cell types is necessary.This delicate network of cell-cell interactions however is frequently disrupted in the face of cancer and the development of tumorigenesis. However, the mechanisms by which these interactions are broken and often co-opted to support tumor growth in different genetic contexts are not yet well understood. To shed light on this phenomenon, we have developed several genetically complex colorectal models utilizing a novel genetic platform named PromoterSwitch. PromoterSwitch allows us to generate large, transformed clones from a small subset of individual adult Drosophila intestinal stem and progenitor cells. By utilizing this platform, we have discovered that genetic alterations commonly found in colon tumors can interfere with the normal process of cell fate determination within the transformed tissue and in neighboring wildtype cells. Furthermore, our research has revealed that transformed enteroendocrine cells, which are a specialized lineage of intestinal hormone-secreting cells, play a crucial role in supporting tumor growth via the regulation of the proliferation of intestinal stem cells through multiple mechanisms that depend on the specific genetic background of the clone. These findings suggest potential vulnerabilities that could be targeted for therapeutic purposes such as enteroendocrine cell differentiation and the hormone Tk, which results showed plays a pivotal role in driving intestinal tumorigenesis. The findings of our work emphasize the importance of developing and investigating disease models that faithfully recapitulate the intricate genetic landscapes observed in human cancer patients in the context of an otherwise healthy epithelial tissue to precisely mimic the initiation and progression of the disease in humans. Our research also showcases the remarkable capacity of Drosophila as a robust model organism for studying genetically complex diseases in a sophisticated manner. By leveraging the close homology and conservation of epithelial tissue and disease-relevant genes and pathways, Drosophila offers unique opportunities to make groundbreaking discoveries with direct implications for human diseases. Overall, our study demonstrates that disruptions in cell fate decisions and the exploitation of enteroendocrine cells are key factors in tumor growth providing a deeper understanding on the cellular heterogeneity and plasticity observed in the disease that could pave the way for the development of new therapeutic strategies aimed at exploiting these mechanisms for effective colorectal cancer treatment.

DISS_description.DISS_title: DESIGN OF HURRICANE RESISTANT RESIDENTIAL STRUCTURE IN FLORIDA: CONSTRUCTION STRATEGIES FOR ALLEVIATION AND COST ANALYSIS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Natural disasters in Florida threaten the millions of people who live there. Storm in the most frequent natural disaster that leaves behind unimaginable levels of devastation. Hurricanes are created over warm waters by tropical disturbances and when strong enough, they can travel at a speed of more than 155 mph. Many structures run at the risk of total failure of the structure due to the force of winds and storms. The building and engineering sectors are important participants in reducing risks and restoring the essential infrastructural goods many are accustomed to, even if numerous programs and methods exist to return normalcy to inhabitants after a disaster.The major objective of this thesis is to present techniques for construction alleviation against hurricane wind loading to increase the resilience of residential construction in Florida. This thesis is divided into two main goals in order to achieve the results aimed. The first step is to examine the problems caused by hurricane wind loading on residential structures, the construction advice that can be used to get older buildings ready for this natural disaster, and the associated expenses. The second objective of this thesis is to determine how, if the primary residential structure breaks during a storm, a cost-effective safe room can be built to safeguard the occupants. The initial objective of this investigation is to identify structural weaknesses by reviewing the research. Since the structures are composed of various components, it is crucial to identify which ones require attention. The design pressures and forces can then be investigated to find the best building suggestions by calculating the wind loading pressures of the various structures. An engineer's judgment on the likely cost can be generated after the construction recommendations for various types of structures have been established to educate the stakeholder of the recommendation's cost. In short, this study aims to ensure that the rooms are risk-free and cost-effective while also being resistant to hurricane wind loads.

DISS_description.DISS_title: LARGE EDDY SIMULATIONS TO INVESTIGATE THE FUNDAMENTAL FLOW PHYSICS OF SUPERCRITICAL CARBON DIOXIDE TURBULENT JETS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Large Eddy Simulation, Supercritical Fluids, Turbulence

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Supercritical Carbon Dioxide is of interest in a wide range of engineering problems, including carbon capture, utilization, and storage as well as advanced cycles for power generation. Non-ideal varia- tions in physical properties of supercritical Carbon Dioxide impact the physics of these systems. It is important to understand how drastic changes in thermodynamic properties influence these flow physics in order to aid in and optimize the design of future technologies related to carbon capture and sequestration. In this study, we simulate turbulent supercritical Carbon Dioxide jets to gain a better understanding of these physics. Of particular interest is the impact of pseudo-boiling on supercritical flow dynamics. We use a second order finite volume method with adaptive mesh re- finement as implemented in the reacting flow solver, PeleC, to perform a Large Eddy Simulation of three turbulent jets of supercritical Carbon Dioxide. Additionally, we use the Soave-Redlich-Kwong equation of state to close the system and more accurately incorporate the departure from ideal gas behavior into the turbulent flow physics. We look at a variety of quantities of interest, including but not limited to axial velocity decay and spread, resolved Reynolds stress profiles at different down- stream locations, and resolved turbulent kinetic energy along the axial direction of the flow. Across the three cases, the only parameters that vary are the temperature and density of the ambient fluid. One case is isothermal, where the jet and ambient fluid temperature are the same, while the other two cases are non-isothermal, with one involving injection crossing over the pseudo-boiling point and one with injection moving away from the pseudo-boiling point. Results are contrasted with established theory for ideal gas jets and similar numerical studies involving transcritical injection in order to capture the effects of widely varying thermal properties in the pseudo-critical region. We found that the isothermal supercritical jet exhibits many similar flow characteristics compared to ideal gas round turbulent jets, with minor differences seen in the decay and spreading rate of the jet and in a noticeable anisotropy between resolved turbulent kinetic energy components. The non-isothermal jet excluding the pseudo-boiling point exhibits only small difference compared to the isothermal case. The non-isothermal case involving the pseudo-boiling point displays markedly dif- ferent behavior, with evidence indicative of increased Kelvin-Helmholtz-like instabilities and much faster jet decay and disintegration. These factors impact the degree of mixing in the transition region of the jet, leading to finer-scale vortices and faster transition to ambient properties.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Towards Smart Wireless Sensing: Human Body Tracking and Object Detection

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There is a growing demand for technology that can sense people and objects without imposing excessive overhead. Traditional solutions usually require people to wear additional devices on their bodies and install cumbersome sensors on objects. The prevalence of wireless signals and wireless devices provides us with the opportunity to sense both the human and physical environment. This dissertation showcases how we can leverage wireless signals to sense people and objects without the need for physical contact with their bodies or the objects themselves. To this end, we propose three commodity WiFi-based sensing systems: GoPose, 3D-ID, and LiquidSense, towards smart wireless sensing.

Specifically, we first present GoPose, a 3D skeleton-based human pose estimation system that reuses WiFi devices in a home environment. It works for unseen activities even when the user is moving around, offering on-the-go pose tracking for previously unseen activities. Second, we propose a WiFi vision-based system, 3D-ID, for person re-identification in 3D space. Our system leverages the advances of WiFi and deep learning to help WiFi devices ``see", identify, and recognize people. Finally, we introduce LiquidSense, a new approach to sensing the liquid level that is low-cost, high accuracy, widely applicable to different daily liquid containers, and can be easily integrated with existing home networks without additional cost. These sensing systems demonstrate that wireless signals can be utilized to effectively sense both the human body and objects.

DISS_description.DISS_title: REIMAGINING ‘BODYWORK’ IN THE WAKE: A COLLECTION OF BLACK QUEER, TRANSGENDER, AND NONBINARY BODY AUTONOMY ORAL TESTIMONIES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bodywork, Cultural body, Liberatory, Oral Histories, Queer, Trans

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Black queer, transgender, and nonbinary (BQTN) people are among the most vulnerable populations in the United States due to structural racialized and gender discrimination (Clifton, 2021). In the United States, civil and human rights protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, asexual, and intersex (LGBTQAI+) people have historically been politically and culturally contested within sport and physical culture studies. As a bodyworker and insider to the queer and trans community, I am choosing to use oral history interviews to explore the liberatory bodywork spaces created by and for BQTN bodyworkers in the Southeastern United States. Liberatory bodywork is an expression of various modalities of physical and/or energetic techniques working with the human body for individual and collective transformation and freedom praxis. Liberatory bodywork recognizes the ongoing anti-Black violence and colonialism on our physical beings. Through liberatory bodywork, physical activity, and embodied movement is practiced and taught with an explicit recognition and reverence for the land, participants lived experiences, and personal and collective commitments to freedom. Moreover, liberatory bodywork invites scholars and community members into integrative approaches to understanding human and non-human relations as emancipatory sites and interventions into the ongoing harm of structural oppression.

Though gender identity is not documented in the U.S. Census, the estimated population size of transgender individuals has been collected through national population surveys and has significantly increased over the last decade (Meerwijk & Sevellius, 2017). In 2016, the Williams Institute estimated that 1.4 million adults identify as transgender, and more recently in 2021, more than 1.2 million LGBTQ adults identify as nonbinary. Yet, in June 2021, the United States introduced (over thirty states to date) record-breaking anti-transgender legislation, focused specifically on eliminating sport participation and gender-affirming healthcare for transgender and nonbinary people (Mosier, 2022). In response to the state’s discriminatory measures, individuals and groups at the local, state-wide, and national levels have organized in the fight for transgender rights, affirming healthcare, and sports participation.

Federal and state anti-transgender sport and healthcare legislative policies are predicated on the structural erasure of transgender people resulting from Western colonial constructs such as gender, race, and sexual orientation hierarchies (Carrington & McDonald 2009; Travers, 2008; White et al. 1995). These value systems permeate institutional practices that reproduce regulatory policies regarding sex, gender identity, and expression by categorizing their cultural acceptability exclusively on a binary basis (Travers, 2008). Further, such laws and regulations become an impetus for further material conditions and symbolic violence that decrease and severely restrict access to basic resources such as housing, healthcare, employment, education, sport, and recreation, to name some (Johnson et al., 2020). The deliberate practice of systemic oppression compounds historical and generational traumas endangering the livelihood and well-being of BQTN people. Such corporealized harm is somaticized and lives inside of physical material bodies, contributing to the shortening of BQTN people’s lives. The immense amount of stress caused by the struggle to simply survive is a great barrier to health and vitality.

Consequently, BQTN communities need resources that contribute to both understanding and addressing the oppressive conditions that restrain access to embodied healing resources, which can alleviate individual and collective harm. Accordingly, this dissertation explores the ways that BQTN bodyworkers in the Southeastern United States navigate sport and physical cultural spaces, in turn, by generating ontological spaces of liberatory bodywork and resisting normative (and oppressive) practices of bodywork. Throughout this process, I draw from the Sankofa tradition, politically engaged sport sociology, and physical cultural studies (PCS) literature. My research study is important because BQTN people have been strategically and systemically disembodied by governmental policies, public discourse, everyday practices, and incomprehensible violence. Further, the dominant hegemonic culture in institutionalized sporting spaces compounds this harm. Consequently, this dissertation confronts racialized and gendered discrimination that leads to the erasure of BQTN people. Despite the social reproduction of power relations that erase BQTN people, we still exist and in particular claim our existence within sport and physical culture. These liberatory and life-affirming bodywork communities do exist and play an important part in BQTN's struggles for body autonomy and self-determination.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Nucleosome distribution and sensitivity dynamics characterize the functional genome in infection and disease

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Chromatin, Cockayne syndrome B, Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus, Nucleosome, Occupancy, Sensitivity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The 6.8 billion base pairs of human DNA must be packaged into chromatin to fit into the nucleus. The nucleosome, approximately 150 bp of genomic DNA wrapped 1.65 times around the histone octamer, is the fundamental unit of chromatin. While this organization likely evolved for packaging, it has been co-opted for regulatory processes. All cells undergo DNA-templated processes such as transcription, recombination, replication, and DNA damage repair. Therefore, the nucleosome architecture must be remodeled to provide access to the underlying genome. Assessment of nucleosomal dynamics in response to certain stimuli reveals the genomic loci that play a role in response to that stimulus. Classically nucleosomal dynamics are assessed by MNase mapping of nucleosome occupancy. MNase digests the internucleosomal linker DNA leaving only nucleosomally protected DNA. Sequencing nucleosomally protected fragments and mapping their genomic location suggests nucleosome locations. One longstanding expectation has been that nucleosome occupancy should be fundamentally different in cell types with different physiologies. Surprisingly, our lab has discovered that disparate cell lines have fundamentally similar basal nucleosome occupancy. We showed that nucleosome occupancy changes only transiently in response to a stimulus returning to basal positions on a timeframe commensurate with the response. The transient nature of these occupancy changes shifted the perspective on studies of chromatin structure and suggested that future studies of nucleosome occupancy dynamics should include high-resolution temporal analysis. More recently, we demonstrated that nucleosomes in their basal positions differ in their sensitivity to MNase, with some locations readily digested with relatively low concentrations of MNase, and others requiring higher concentrations of MNase to be digested. The works presented here used these two analyses, occupancy, and sensitivity, to identify distinctly different features of the functional genome. The present research focused on two disease models using a model of the Kaposi sarcoma herpes virus (KSHV) reactivation and an immortalized cell line from a Cockayne syndrome patient. For each of these models, we have identified transient changes in nucleosome occupancy with temporally resolved MNase mapping. Additionally, we have identified longer-lasting nucleosomal changes with MNase sensitivity. KSHV is a gamma herpes virus that is responsible for the oncogenic transformation of infected cells. We used an inducible system to reactivate KSHV, which simulates the lytic cycle of the virus life cycle and is eventually responsible for oncogenic transformation. We measured nucleosome occupancy at 0, 12, 24, 36, and 48 hours after reactivation. We observed changes in nucleosome occupancy at the -1 nucleosome at loci important for viral reactivation and oncogenic transformation, such as the AKT2, PRCC, and CDC6 genes. These loci are enriched for MAZ, PATZ1, WT1, KLF15, EGR2, E2F, and PBX3 transcription factor binding sites (TFBS). These TFBS are consistent with responses regulating cell growth, proliferation, and oncogenesis. Our nucleosome sensitivity studies revealed persistent changes at loci important in nuclear transport, signal transduction, and oncogenesis, including TPR and TRAF6. We identified TFBS for factors that regulate oncogenesis, including WT1, MAZ, KLF12, PATZ2, and E2E4. We conclude that occupancy and sensitivity studies provide distinct and biologically important aspects of the functional genome. Cockayne syndrome B is a progressive autosomal recessive developmental disorder resulting from mutations in the CSB protein. CSB plays multifaceted cellular functions. CSB plays a role in chromatin remodeling, transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair (TC-NER), and oxidative DNA damage repair. We measured nucleosome occupancy in a CSBnull cell line and a CSBWT cell line. We observed changes in nucleosome occupancy at the -1 position in genes that contribute to the neuroactive ligand-receptor interaction and hippo signaling pathways. These loci are important in neurological development and organ size development, two important aspects of Cockayne syndrome B. We also observed that these loci are enriched for TFBS that have a role in DNA damage response, DNA repair, and development. Our nucleosome sensitivity studies revealed changes at loci, including NEIL2, which is important in base-excision pathways. Interestingly we identified different classes of TFBS in the sensitivity analysis. These TFBS included ZIC2, ZIC3, TBX1, and TBX15 and are involved in neurogenesis, bone, and cartilage formation. We conclude that occupancy and sensitivity studies provide distinct and biologically important aspects of the functional genome. In conclusion, we surmise that nucleosome occupancy and sensitivity can detect two levels of change in nucleosome architecture. Nucleosome occupancy changes are transient and happen in disease-specific genes and global genes, which are common to other genes. Nucleosomes with changes in sensitivity to MNase represent more persistent changes and occur in the genes which are more disease-specific.

DISS_description.DISS_title: THE IMPACT OF COVID-19 SOCIAL DISTANCING UPON THE SLEEP QUALITY OF COLLEGE STUDENTS

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Background: As the coronavirus disease continues to spread around the world, millions are being impacted by societal changes and social distancing. When the majority of educational institutions closed campuses, college students were left vulnerable to developing difficulties as they were forced to adjust to these changes. They are already particularly vulnerable to sleep difficulties, which will increase further for those with other mental health problems.Hypothesis: Following school closure, college students will display an increase in sleep difficulties across sleep onset latency, subjective sleep quality, sleep quantity, daytime dysfunction, and disturbing dreams. This relationship will be strengthened in those who experience greater levels of stress, ruminative thinking patterns, or depressive symptoms. Changes to amount of light exposure due to increased screen use will account for a proportion of these difficulties. Methods: Secondary data analysis was done using self-report questionnaires administered across four time points, and a fifth time point was collected to further expand the data. Multiple regression analyses evaluated the hypotheses across the 100 individuals (mean age=19.45, 85% female) who completed measures both pre- and post- school closure. Repeated measures regression analysis was utilized across the 1201 individuals (mean age=19.43, 76.7% female) who completed measures solely during a single time point. Results: There was a significant decrease in sleep quality when looking across all five time points (F(1,1199)=12.49, p<.001), although sleep quality initially did not change from pre-pandemic to the first time point. Worry about COVID-19 was the primary mediator of worsened sleep quality across studies (F(1,94)=4.66, p=.033 and F(1,370)=48.64, p<.001 respectively), although mental health difficulties were not consistent moderators. Screen use changes was only significant within study two (F(1,518)=357.58, p<.001). Conclusion: These findings help further explain the consequences of COVID-19 stay-at-home orders upon college students. Sleep quality worsened as the pandemic and social distancing measures continued. Those who viewed the pandemic as more of a threat and experienced more worry about it in particular were vulnerable to developing sleep problems, particularly if they were engaging in more social distancing measures. Additionally increased screen use, particularly in relation to having virtual classes, decreased sleep quality. Beyond the role of light exposure and mental health difficulties, beliefs about COVID-19 were a primary determinant of sleep quality changes in college students.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SURVEY OF SCHOOL SPEECH-LANGUAGE PATHOLOGISTS’ PERSPECTIVES ON CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE IEP PRACTICES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD), culturally and linguistically responsive (CLR) instruction, English learners (EL), Individualized education program (IEP), School-based speech-language pathologists (SLPs), speech or language impairment (S/LI)

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The rising number of students with disabilities who identify as culturally and linguistically diverse (CLD) necessitates the use of culturally and linguistically responsive (CLR) instruction and related supports. Fourteen percent of English learners (ELs) have a disability (with disability as defined by Individual with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). School-based speech-language pathologists (SLPs) often support the communication needs of these students, especially for those students who are eligible for special education and related services as students with a speech or language impairment (S/LI). Characteristics of CLR practices may be reflected in a student’s individualized education program (IEP). However, there is little prior research describing CLR considerations for this population in a school setting. A total of 40 individuals from 14 states, completed an online, 22-item survey to reflect their use of CLR practices in existing IEPs for ELs with speech or language impairments. Participants also rated how often they use various CLR features in therapy and assessments with students who are ELs. Respondents varied greatly in their use of CLR features within an IEP of EL child with a S/LI. Participants reported that they never provide materials/progress notes in the child’s first language and never refer to use of child’s first language within the IEP. In contrast, approximately half of respondents reported that they always engage in culturally relevant practices in therapy. Additionally, most SLPs reported that they always or sometimes collaborate with other professionals in the school setting. Participants indicated that they sometimes use CLR features in goals they write within an IEP for a child who is an EL. The present study provides unique insight on school-based SLPs’ use of CLR practices. This offers implications for future training (i.e., ASHA seminars or school courses) and development of IEPs concerning the incorporation of CLR features and practices for children who are EL.

DISS_description.DISS_title: NUMERICAL STUDIES OF MAGNETIC PROPERTIES IN LOW DIMENSIONAL STRONGLY CORRELATED SYSTEMS

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Frustration, Low dimension, Magnetism, Non-equilibrium dynamics, Strongly Correlated Systems

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This thesis is devoted to the study of magnetic properties of strongly correlated quantum matters in one and two dimensions. The study employs predominantly numerical techniques, such as Exact Diagonalization (ED), Finite Temperature Lanczos (FTLM), and Density Matrix Renormalization Group (DMRG), complemented by semi-analytical approaches. In the absence of exact solutions or controlled analytic approximations, numerical methods have profoundly impacted our understanding of complex many-body problems. Utilizing these numerical tools for investigating the ground state and finite temperature properties of quantum magnets, as well as understanding their non-equilibrium dynamics in cold-atom quench experiments, comprise the two major themes of this thesis.

The first part of this thesis, comprising Chapters~\ref{ch3}-\ref{ch5}, discusses the ground state properties, elementary excitations, and finite temperature behavior of various magnetic systems motivated by recent experimental observations.Elementary excitations often play a vital role in understanding the ground state and the finite temperature properties. Chapter~\ref{ch3} focuses on the significance of multimagnon (quasiparticle) interactions and their connection to finite temperature terahertz optical experiments on a ferromagnetic (FM) spin-$1$ quasi-1D compound.

Chapters~\ref{ch4} and \ref{ch5} jointly contribute to our understanding of magnetism in undoped and doped Mott insulators in magnetically frustrated systems. Chapter~\ref{ch4} discusses ``two coloring" and ``three coloring" exact ground state solutions of the 2D XXZ magnets at special points in bipartite (square) and tripartite (triangular) lattices. It further emphasizes the influence of these exactly solvable points on the other parameter space of this model away from the solvable points, which we explore using ED and large-scale DMRG simulations. In Chapter~\ref{ch5}, our focus shifts to investigating the mechanism of kinetic frustration in the moi\'re bilayer WSe$_2/$WS$_2$ compound, prompted by the intriguing observation of an increase in the Curie-Weiss temperatures as the density decreases below half-filling. While a definitive model for the bilayer system remains elusive, we employ both the Hubbard and $t-J$ models to shed light on their distinct magnetic properties across low, intermediate, and high temperatures. Underlying zero temperature phase transitions are analyzed using large-scale DMRG simulations, providing experimentally consistent results.

The second part of this thesis, comprising Chapter~\ref{ch6}, explores a new frontier in condensed matter systems, specifically the non-equilibrium dynamics of isolated quantum magnets, well-suited for cold-atom experiments in one dimension. We explain the thermalization process in a generic isolated quantum system without a heat reservoir, drawing upon the Eigen State Thermalization Hypothesis (ETH). Focusing on the Quantum Many-Body Scars (QMBS), the states weakly violating ETH, we study the real-time dynamics of two different quantum spin models. We first analyzed the thermalization of various initial multimagnon states in the FM Heisenberg spin-$1$ chain, leveraging prior insights on multimagnon bound state formation due to onsite anisotropy ($D$). Both thermal and athermal behaviors akin to those reported for QMBS are observed depending on initial conditions, which we explain with an analytic approximation that is accurate in the limit of dilute magnon density and small $D$. Secondly, the resilience of quantum scars in a bond-staggered Heisenberg spin-1/2 chain under a periodic local drive is investigated. Instances are found where the driven spin collectively thermalizes or fails to thermalize with the remaining spins, contingent upon the frequency and strength of the drive.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Habitat Use and Ecological Connectivity in Imperiled, Highly Migratory Species: Case Studies with Loggerhead Sea Turtles

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Characterizations of habitat use and ecological connectivity are essential components of a complete ecological understanding of any organism. Habitat use may be broadly defined as the behaviors that an animal exhibits in any scenopoetic context, while ecological connectivity comprises the multitude processes, whether spatial, geochemical, or genetic, that connect geographically discrete populations or assemblages. Such efforts are particularly important for imperiled, highly migratory species, which are typically comprised of reduced populations that exist in anthropogenically-reduced scenopoetic contexts. These species often face multiple threats with the potential to disrupt habitat use and ecological connectivity, and ensuring that these processes are preserved in these species is critical to their survival. However, these species are difficult to observe due to their vagile natures, and it is therefore difficult to holistically characterize baseline habitat use and ecological connectivity to inform conservation efforts. There is a need for research that seeks to fill in gaps in our understanding of habitat use and ecological connectivity in individual imperiled species, and that augments or develops tools to aid in these efforts, for pplications in both focal species and other imperiled species.Sea turtles (superfamily Chelonioidea) comprise seven highly-migratory imperiled species that face contemporary threats to their existence via the disruption of habitat use and ecological connectivity. Gaps in the current understanding of sea turtle habitat use and ecological connectivity include: 1) Limited knowledge of habitat use at relatively low-abundance nesting beaches; 2) Limitations of approaches used to characterize ecological connectivity between breeding and foraging areas, and to make inferences about habitat use at these areas; 3) Limited ecological knowledge of immature sea turtles; 4) Limited specific knowledge of resource use at high-use foraging areas; and 5) Lack of characterizations of genetic structuring and connectivity utilizing contemporary genetic markers. I undertook a multifaceted approach that utilized loggerhead sea turtles (Caretta caretta) as a case study to address these gaps, and to provide information to inform effective management efforts for this and other imperiled, highly-migratory species. My work took place in four parts. The first (Chapter 2) addressed gap 1 by providing an important update to knowledge of nesting abundance and hatchling productivity for an understudied population of loggerhead sea turtles in the Gulf of Mexico, and highlighting the importance of site-specific management plans for sea turtles. The second (Chapter 3) addressed x gaps 2 and 4 by investigating the relationships between epibiont assemblages and tissue stable isotopes from nesting loggerhead sea turtles, and showing that epibionts have the potential to be informative towards sea turtle foraging ecology. The third (Chapter 4) addressed gaps 3 and 4 by characterizing the isotopic niches of foraging adult and subadult loggerhead turtles and providing evidence that loggerheads exhibit intraspecific niche partitioning between adults and subadults. The fourth (Chapter 4) addressed gap 5 by analyzing genome-wide SNPs from loggerheads nesting at four genetically discrete populations in the Gulf of Mexico and providing a higher-resolution characterization of structuring and connectivity between these populations, in addition to identifying putatively informative markers for future population assignments. This work can serve as a foundation for impactful future studies into habitat use and ecological connectivity of, and the augmentation of management plans for, sea turtles and other imperiled, highly migratory species. Agencies responsible for management of nesting beaches or other reproductive units can make efforts to analyze high-resolution data on threats and productive output to inform management practices at a biologically relevant scale. Further investigations into epibionts in any host species could lead to the identification of indicator species used to determine where individuals have been prior to migration. Spatial, behavioral, and isotopic studies can help determine why and how lifestages partition their resources in loggerhead, and perhaps other species, of sea turtles. Agencies responsible for management of these assemblages can begin to account for that partitioning in management plans. Genome-wide SNPs have the potential to inform genetic structuring and connectivity and generate accurate assignments in species with metapopulation dynamics. Agencies responsible for management of imperiled marine species can take steps to ensure that existing genetic connectivity is maintained and that isolated populations receive adequate protections. Researchers can investigate dispersal, and agencies responsible for management can investigate the direct impacts of threats to specific populations, and ideally work to mitigate those threats, using genetic assignments. My work can provide impetus for these efforts to improve our knowledge of habitat use and ecological connectivity and to augment management efforts in sea turtles and other imperiled, highly-migratory species.

DISS_description.DISS_title: IMPACT OF EFFORT AND EXPECTANCY ON THE P300

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Effort, Expectation, Motivational Signficance, P300, salience, Surprise

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Motivationally significant stimuli activate motivational systems to support perception and action. Rewards are naturally occurring motivationally salient stimuli that activate approach behaviors, for example, effort for a reward. Two theories have been proposed regarding the impact of effort on subsequent reward salience. Effort discounting theories suggest that effort is costly and makes the outcome less salient. Comparatively, effort justification theories posit that the reward is more salient after exerting effort. Existing literature has supported both theories; however, the methods used (e.g., fMRI, behavior) were not temporally precise, so we extend this work by using electroencephalogram (EEG) to better understand the sequential effects of effort on reward processing. The P300 event-related potential has been used as a measure of motivational significance and is related to reward processing. The P300 is also associated with task relevance (experimentally manipulated significance) and stimulus expectations. Literature shows that P300 amplitude to reward feedback is increased following high compared to low amounts of effort, supporting effort justification theories or increased salience of the feedback after effort completion. Critically, however, these studies have failed to control for subjective stimulus expectations known to influence P300 amplitude. It may be that outcome feedback is more unexpected when more effort is required. When less effort is required, there may be no differences between expected and unexpected stimuli because participants can predict relatively well when the cue may be presented. To investigate the influence of both effort and expectancy on P300 amplitude to reward feedback we created a monetary reward task that varied effort and waiting, high and low amounts (duration) of effort (waiting), and expectancy. Expectancy was manipulated by having some trials countdown the number of presses left (countdown) as subjects exerted effort or waited, so participants know when the reward was coming. Alternatively, some trials stayed static (no countdown) and gave no information about upcoming reward presentation. From this task we also investigated mean differences in behavioral response rate, reaction time, and trial duration for effortful trials, and related the P300 amplitude to the behavioral measures. The initial study focused on these within subject differences, but it is known that effort for reward is disrupted in various psychological and neurological disorders, especially depression where anhedonia is a symptom that reflects problematic consummation and motivation for rewards. Indeed, P300 amplitude is consistently decreased in people with depression or anhedonia and may be a good biomarker of motivational salience deficits in people with anhedonia symptomology. Thus, we investigated relationships between P300 amplitude and self-reported anhedonia symptoms. We demonstrated that the amount of effort or waiting required influenced P300 amplitude—high effort amounts or waiting durations had larger P300 amplitudes than low effort or waiting, which varied by expectations. When subjects knew when to expect reward presentation (countdown), there was no difference between high and low amounts of either effort or waiting. Comparatively, when expectations were violated (no countdown), there was a significant difference between high and low amounts (durations) of effort (waiting). Additionally, effort for reward processing seems to be distinct from reward processing following waiting as P300 amplitudes were larger following effort conditions. The present study also demonstrated task effects on behavioral reaction times; when more effort was required, participants were quicker to start the trial, and participants that were faster at pressing across the task (shorter trial durations) had lower P300 amplitudes. Finally, individuals with lower experiences of pleasure or heightened anhedonia symptoms had blunted P300 amplitudes following effort compared to waiting conditions. These results provide evidence for effort justification theories and are interpreted within the motivational significance framework, which suggests salient stimuli in the form of surprising, unexpected, and task relevant reward stimuli may enhance attention and/or facilitate subsequent action by eliciting a larger P300 amplitude waveform. Moreover, the P300 was attenuated to reward feedback during effort conditions in individuals experiencing anhedonia symptomology suggesting disrupted processing of motivationally salient reward stimuli. Our results call for future investigation of expectations on reward processing in addition to task relevance.

DISS_description.DISS_title: VIRTUOUS KNOWERS: A VIRTUE-THEORETIC ANALYSIS OF THE INTERSECTION OF DOXASTIC AGENCY, DOXASTIC OBLIGATIONS, AND DOXASTIC JUSTIFICATION

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Doxastic Agency, Doxastic Involuntarism, Ethics of Belief, Justification, Virtue Epistemology

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this dissertation, I argue for a virtue-epistemological take on doxastic agency, doxastic reasons, doxastic obligations, and doxastic justification. After a brief introduction, in chapter 2 I argue in favor of doxastic involuntarism. I argue that, though the work of theoretical reason is to produce true beliefs, it does not do so in a way similar to how practical reason produces actions. I support this claim by focusing on the debate between doxastic voluntarists and involuntarists. I reframe this debate and then argue in favor of doxastic involuntarism, which has significant implications for theoretical reason. Many proponents of doxastic involuntarism characterize their view as one that denies that we can form beliefs at will. A sometimes-implicit assumption is that the formation of a belief is something that could, in principle, be an action. Their reason for why we cannot form beliefs at will is that there are various obstacles that impede us performing such an action. In contrast, I characterize the dispute between doxastic voluntarists and involuntarists as a dispute over whether the formation of a belief is an action, not over whether it is an action we can perform. I present an understanding of the nature of belief that implies that the formation of a belief is never an action. I use this characterization of the nature of belief in an argument in favor of doxastic involuntarism. In chapter 3, I argue for a new understanding of reasons for belief and doxastic obligations. I argue that, if doxastic involuntarism is true, then we should reconceive what are traditionally called reasons for belief. The truth of doxastic involuntarism would rule out a certain understanding of reasons for belief according to which they are necessary conditions for doxastic obligations. Thus, reconceiving reasons for belief would require reconceiving doxastic obligations. I argue that, in fact, a re-conception of reasons for belief warrants abandoning the notion of doxastic obligations, understood as obligations to form, alter, or relinquish doxastic states. Instead, the only sorts of obligations we would have that concern our doxastic states would be aretaic or practical. In chapters 4 and 5, I apply the arguments from chapters 2 and 3 to testimonial beliefs and doxastic justification, respectively. In chapter 4, I argue that a general feature of human psychology provides strong reason to modify or reject anti-reductionism about the epistemology of testimony. Because of the work of what I call ‘the background’ (which is a collection of all of an individual’s synthetizations, summarizations, memories of experiences, beliefs, etc.) we cannot help but form testimonial beliefs on the basis of a testifier’s say so along with additional evidence, concepts, beliefs, etc. Given that we arrive at testimonial beliefs through the work of the background, to be justified in holding a testimonial belief, we must not only have a rational speaker’s say so, but we must also form such beliefs in the right way. If this is right, then, contrary to typical anti-reductionism, justified testimonial beliefs require more than just a trustworthy testifier’s say so—another requirement is that they are formed in the right way. In chapter 5, I argue that what it takes for an agent to be justified in holding a belief is that the agent formed the belief in the right sort of way, which should be understood in terms of virtue epistemology. That is, in contrast to the predominant way of understanding doxastic justification—a deontological view according to which you are justified in holding a belief if and only if it is permissible for you to hold the belief—we should understand doxastic justification aretaically: you are justified in holding a belief if and only if your belief is the result of the operation of virtue. I argue that the aretaic account of justification is superior to the deontological one.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ROBERT MARCELLUS: CLARINET TEACHING FROM THE CLEVELAND INSTITUTE OF MUSIC AND NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Robert Marcellus was one of the most respected clarinetists and teachers in the twentieth century. He was a performer in the Cleveland Orchestra and taught at both the Cleveland Institute of Music and Northwestern University. His students occupied positions in major orchestras and universities. The purpose of this research was to collect and compare pedagogical information from the experiences of Robert Marcellus’s students from both the Cleveland Institute of Music and Northwestern University. Interviews were conducted with J. David Harris, Diane Barger, David Bell, Steve Cohen, Kathy Jones, Lee Morgan, Michele Gingras, and John Weigand. A similar set of questions were asked to each interviewee. Questions pertained to participants’ time frame in studying with Mr. Marcellus, their experiences in private lessons, Mr. Marcellus’s communication skills, his personality, the studio environment, pedagogy, and syllabus of study. After all the interviews were completed, the results were analyzed to provide insight into his teaching. The information was categorized into six groupings: inspiration, communication, personality, Mr. Marcellus’s studio, pedagogy, and syllabus of study. The groupings were examined based on criteria for the interviewees: location of study, specific years in school, and length of study. Along with the analysis of the interviews, a full transcript of each interview is included. The experiences of his students are valuable in describing the teachings of Robert Marcellus.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Cloud Feedbacks and Convective Self-Aggregation in the Radiative-Convective Equilibrium Model Intercomparison Project

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: climate sensitivity, cloud feedbacks, idealized modeling, organized convection, radiative-convective equilibrium, tropical convection

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Changes in cloud properties in response to surface warming have been consistently identified as the feedback contributing the largest uncertainty in the overall climate feedback parameter, which describes changes in top of atmosphere radiation balance in response to warming surface temperatures. The primary concern regarding clouds are twofold: (i) Clouds have competing influences on the climate. Their high albedo reflects solar insolation, cooling the climate system while simultaneously absorbing and re-emitting the radiation emitted by the Earth, a warming effect on the climate system. (ii) Clouds are inherently a subgrid-scale process for most climate change studies (such as those using global climate models), necessitating the use of a parameterization scheme. Here, an ensemble of models of many types in an idealized configuration of the tropical climate is leveraged to investigate how and why deep-convecting clouds change the way they do, what the resultant cloud feedbacks are from these changes, and how organized convection affects these changes and cloud feedbacks.

Deep-convecting anvils, independent of how cloud fraction is defined, increase in height, increase slightly in temperature, and (generally) decrease in cloud fraction with warming sea surface temperature while mid-level cloud fraction robustly decreases with warming. The response of tropical clouds to warming found in this work follows previously established physical reasoning, confirming this reasoning across a much larger ensemble of models that explicitly simulate convection than previously considered. The cloud feedbacks associated with these changes generally align with results using comprehensive global climate models and observations, especially for cloud feedbacks associated with tropical high clouds. However, when convection organizes, different cloud regimes become more important. There is an established understanding that organized convection alters the mean climate state. If convective organization is absent, the cloud feedbacks have a smaller magnitude. Amongst domains that have convective organization, if a domain is strongly organized, the cloud feedbacks are weaker and sometimes switch sign. This is primarily due to the impact of changes in cloud optical depth in the shortwave, specifically high clouds thickening (as opposed to thinning) with warming in strongly organized domains, as well as more strongly organized domains having more low clouds to begin with. The shortwave cloud optical depth feedback also plays an important role in causing the tropical anvil cloud area feedback to be positive which is directly opposed to the expected negative cloud feedback found in prior work. This calls into question the expectation for and assumptions regarding a negative tropical anvil cloud area feedback, particularly the role of changes in cloud optical depth with warming, especially given these simulations more accurately resolve convection.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Urban-Rural Disparities in Access to COVID-19 Testing Sites: The Impact of Funding Cuts in the Capital Region of Florida

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: COVID-19, Rural health, Social Vulnerability, Testing access

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: In this study I analyzed the relationship between access to COVID-19 testing sites and neighborhood characteristics before and after federal funding cuts to determine if socially vulnerable communities were more likely to be affected by testing site closures. This was studied across eight counties in Florida’s panhandle: Leon, Wakulla, Taylor, Madison, Jefferson, Gulf, Gadsden, and Franklin. For the purpose of this study, the study area will be referred to as the Capital Region (as it includes Leon County, which hosts the capital of Florida, and all of Leon County’s neighboring counties). This project has three objectives: (1) To create a Social Vulnerability Index (SoVI) that summarizes the social determinants of health in the region, (2) To investigate how levels of access to COVID-19 testing sites changed over time as a result of testing site closures, and (3) Lastly, to analyze access before and after federal funding cuts, and the change in access, in relation to social vulnerability factors. The geographic scale for these analyses is at the census tract level. To accomplish these objectives, I (1) generated SoVI to measure social vulnerability, (2) calculated the drive-times from the population-weighted centroids of each census tract to the closest, two closest, and five closest testing facilities to measure access; and calculated the difference in drive times before and after federal funding cuts, and (3) utilized Generalized Additive Models (GAMs) to analyze the relationship between drive times and social vulnerability. From the results, I detected which census tracts had the lowest access to COVID-19 testing sites and which were the most affected by testing site closures. I found that SoVI did not have a statistically significant relationship to access to testing facilities when accounting for spatial autocorrelation, which was counter to expectations. However, I found that there was a consistently significant relationship between rural census tracts and high drive times to COVID-19 testing facilities. Rural status was the only significant indicator of an increase in drive time as well. These findings highlight the need for more comprehensive strategies to address healthcare access disparities in rural areas. This study enriches the argument for the essentiality of public health federal funding and provides important insights on how federal funding cuts for COVID-19 mitigation efforts affect at-risk communities, specifically rural ones.

The purpose of this research is to analyze how geographic accessibility changed as a result of closures to state-funded testing sites and to identify which communities are the most affected. These findings have important implications for policy makers and local planners because they can inform decisions related to the allocation of resources for public health services. Additionally, evaluating how changes in funding affect geographic access to testing can help guide future decisions regarding public health funding and resource allocation.

The intellectual merit of this research lies in its assessment of urban-rural disparities in access to testing sites and social vulnerability at a finer geographic scale than the extant research. Whereas most COVID-19 studies analyze accessibility and vulnerability at the scale of county-level units (e.g., Tao, et. al, 2020; Kim, et. al, 2021; CDC, n.d.), I measured these variables at the scale of census tracts. The application of SoVI will provide local governments with an evidence-based understanding of relative vulnerability across census tracts in the Capital Region and their capacities to prepare for, respond to, and recover from COVID-19. Because there is no standard for the number of testing facilities to consider in the drive-time analysis, I compared the findings from the closest, two closest, and five closest testing facilities and analyzed how the results changed. Furthermore, there are very few studies that examine the relationship between access to testing sites and social vulnerability. One relevant study conducted by Mullachery and colleagues (2022) analyzed vulnerability and access in 30 US cities, but none were in Florida or in rural communities. My project contributes empirical findings on unstudied regions impacted by COVID-19.

The broader impacts of my project are to demonstrate how critical COVID-19 federal funding is for disadvantaged communities. The findings of this study may help policymakers and healthcare providers better understand the needs of rural communities and develop targeted interventions to improve access to testing. The lack of a statistically significant relationship between access to COVID testing sites and SoVI suggests that other factors, such as rurality, may be more important in determining access to healthcare services, particularly for North Florida.

DISS_description.DISS_title: EVALUATION OF A SCREENING BATTERY FOR DEVELOPMENTAL LANGUAGE DISORDER

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Developmental language disorder, Screening

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Students with developmental language disorder (DLD) have difficulty understanding and using oral language, and these difficulties negatively impact academic achievement. DLD has a prevalence of 7-8% of school-age students, yet research has shown that less than half of those students are receiving services. Implementation of a screening tool in early elementary school has the potential to improve identification challenges of DLD in schools. The purpose of this study was to evaluate a comprehensive language screening battery that included seven language measures. The study aimed to identify what language measures were most predictive of overall language ability and determine what language measures resulted in the highest diagnostic accuracy for DLD. One hundred and twenty-six students were administered a screening battery that included sentence repetition, nonword repetition, listening comprehension, expressive vocabulary, receptive vocabulary, synonyms, and paired associate learning. All students were then administered the Core Language subtests from the Clinical Evaluation of Language Fundamentals-5th Edition (CELF-5). The CELF-5 served as the reference standard to evaluate the screening battery. A dominance analysis was performed to determine the relative importance of all measures as well as determine what models explained the most variance in the outcome. A series of logistic regressions were then used to determine what measures predicted DLD. Predicted probabilities from the logistic regressions were entered into ROC curve analyses to analyze diagnostic accuracy of various models. Results of the dominance analysis revealed that sentence repetition was the most dominant predictor of language ability. Adding additional measures to sentence repetition slightly increased the amount of variance explained, but the changes in R2 were not significant. Results of the logistic regression revealed that sentence repetition was the only consistent predictor of DLD. Preliminary results indicate that including additional measures with a sentence repetition task increases diagnostic accuracy. However, results related to diagnostic accuracy should be interpreted cautiously due to the small sample size of students with DLD (n=17).

DISS_description.DISS_title: STOCHASTIC OPTIMAL CONTROL THROUGH GRADIENT PROJECTION METHOD AND BACKWARD ACTION LEARNING

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Convergence Analysis, Noise Learning, Sample-wise Backward Action Learning, Stochastic Maximum Principle, Stochastic Neural Network, Stochastic Optimal Control

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The aim of this work is to carry out convergence analysis and algorithm implementation of a novel sample-wise backpropagation method for training a class of stochastic neural networks (SNNs). The structure of the SNN is formulated as a discretization of a stochastic differential equation (SDE). A stochastic optimal control framework is introduced to model the training procedure, and a sample-wise approximation scheme for the adjoint backward SDE is applied to improve the eﬀiciency of the stochastic optimal control solver, which is equivalent to the back-propagation for training the SNN. The convergence analysis is derived by introducing a novel joint conditional expectation for the gradient process. Under the convexity assumption, our result indicates that the number of SNN training steps should be proportional to the square of the number of layers in the convex optimization case. In the implementation of the sample-based SNN algorithm with the benchmark MNIST data set, we adopt the convolution neural network (CNN) architecture and demonstrated that our SNN is more robust than the conventional CNN. To further demonstrate that our algorithm can be adopted to solve an array of problems (including high dimensional ones), we present the result of learning noisy functions of using SNN and demonstrate that SNN can capture complex noise level of the function very well. We also present results of solving the high dimensional HJB/Linear Quadratic Control Problems, by casting the problem in the control framework hence the SNN formulation.
