DISS_description.DISS_title: HIGH-TEMPERATURE THERMOMECHANICS OF BNNT NANOCOMPOSITES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Boron nitride nanotubs, composites, decomposition mechanism, high-temperature stability, hybrid composite, nanotube modeling

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: After the discovery of carbon nanotubes, boron nitride nanotubes were first theoretically predicted and successfully synthesized in 1995 by an arc-discharge method. Following that, other techniques for BNNT synthesis were discovered; however, growing highly purified BNNTs remains difficult. The research on the physical properties of BNNTs shows that they have a stable broad band gap, excellent mechanical strength, high thermal conductivity, and high oxidation resistance. These properties make them a perfect candidate for future nanocomposites for high-temperature applications. Interesting effects of BNNT addition with the resultant mechanical behavior and thermal conductivity in a matrix are observed when BNNTs are applied to form nanocomposites with polymer, metal, and ceramic matrices. Modeling and simulation methods of nanotube composites are highly advantageous in developing BNNT-based nanocomposites.This report presents a Ph.D. dissertation for assessing and developing multifunctional BNNT composites applicable in space or high-temperature composite structures. The report will cover the critical elements accomplished, focusing on the decomposition and high-temperature stability of BNNTs, high-precision polymer and ceramic SLA 3D-printed BNNT composites, hybrid composites, and nanotube composite modeling techniques.

DISS_description.DISS_title: A multidimensional study on articulation deficits in Parkinson’s disease

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: dysarthria, motor speech disorders, Parkinson's disease, speech acoustics, speech kinematics

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation encompasses a series of studies aimed at characterizing the articulatory speech characteristics of individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) and healthy control (HC) speakers using perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic measures. The first study investigated group differences in perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic measures, while the second study explored changes in these measures during conversational, less clear, and more clear speaking conditions. The third study examined the predictive power of acoustic and kinematic measures for perceptual outcomes of intelligibility and articulatory precision.

Forty speakers, including 22 with PD and 18 HC speakers, participated in the study. Acoustic and kinematic speech data were collected simultaneously using the Wave System, an electromagnetic articulography device. Participants read the phrases “Buy Bobby a puppy,” “Tess told Dan to stay fit,” and “Carl got a croaking frog,” using three speaking conditions, including conversational, less clear, and more clear speech. Acoustic and kinematic measures were derived from corner vowel tokens and the /aɪ/ diphthong. Perceptual ratings of intelligibility and articulatory precision were obtained from 368 listeners through crowdsourcing.

Linear mixed-effects models were employed to analyze group effects (Study 1), speaking condition effects (Study 2), and the predictive relationship between acoustic and kinematic measures and perceptual outcomes (Study 3). Study 1 revealed that speakers with PD exhibited lower intelligibility and articulatory precision ratings, as well as compressed acoustic vowel space areas (VSAs) compared to HC speakers. Study 2 demonstrated that perceptual measures aligned with expectations (i.e., less clear < conversational < more clear), while some acoustic and kinematic measures followed the predicted trend (i.e., acoustic and kinematic distance), and others did not (i.e., kinematic VSA, F2 slope). Study 3 identified acoustic VSA and kinematic distance as strong predictors of intelligibility and articulatory precision, with a stronger association with articulatory precision.

In summary, these findings provide valuable insights into the effects of speech clarity cues on perceptual, acoustic, and kinematic measures of articulation in speakers with PD. By utilizing a multidimensional framework, a more comprehensive understanding of dysarthria's effects on speech articulation in individuals with PD emerges. Methodological considerations, including speech stimuli, measurement techniques, and speaker dialect, are discussed in relation to the study outcomes.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Associations between objectively measured habitual physical and sedentary activity, the P300, and depression in older adults

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Depression, EEG, Older Adults, Physical activity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Deficits in cognitive processing, as measured by P300 activity, have been noted in older adults struggling with depressive symptoms, thus understanding factors that may influence cognitive processing are an important area of interest in the search to improve quality of life during older adulthood. Activity levels, such as physical activity (PA) and sedentary behavior, is one such factor. Although literature pertaining to the associations between PA levels, sedentary behavior and depression in older adults appear abundant, much of the recent work investigates the relationship between interventions, such as bouts of exercise throughout a week, workout types, and fitness levels. There is an evident gap in knowledge on the influence habitual activity levels (day-to-day activity) plays on the cognitive aspects of depression in older adults. The goal of our study was to utilize neurophysiological measures collected during a Go/No-Go task, in addition to accelerometers, which collect continuous data on habitual activity levels and self-report measures to investigate the relationship cross-sectional relationship between P300 amplitude and latency, depression symptoms and objectively measured habitual PA in a sample of older adults (n=75). Although no association was found between P300 activity and depression symptoms, heighten depressive symptoms were found to have a significant relationship with longer periods of prolonged sedentary behavior (sedentary bouts, SBs), but not overall sedentary activity. Furthermore, increased No-Go P300 amplitude was associated with higher levels of Daily Lifestyle Activity (e.g. slow walking, grocery shopping) as well as, higher daily incidences of prolonged periods of sedentary and moderate-vigorous activity (MVPA). Moreover, Go-Infrequent latency was shorter among participants who had longer periods of MVPA. Age was found to be associated with increased P300 latency as well as, habitual activity levels, such that older members of the sample engaged in lighter habitual activity and less MVPA. Exploratory analysis revealed subjective reports of time spent walking and in MVPA per day were associated with objectively measured Daily MVPA and prolonged periods of MVPA. In contrast, subjective reports of sitting per day were not associated with objectively measured sedentary activity, showing a potential limitation of subjective measures. Taken together, the current project demonstrates the negative influence prolonged periods of sedentary activity has both on depressive symptoms and cognitive processing as measured through P300 activity, while exploratory analysis illuminated the importance of objectively measured habitual activity over subjective reports as a potential tool to better understand the elements of day-to-day life that impact cognitive and psychological functioning of older adults.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Examining Multiple Methods for Nonparametric Multivariate Profile Monitoring

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Bayesian Hypothesis Testing, Change Point Detection, Kolmogorov-Smirnov, Nonparametric Multivariate Process Monitoring, Statistical Process Control, Universal Residuals

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Statistical Process Control (SPC) tools are popular for monitoring system performance. SPC tools usually monitor the changes of the behavior of a sequence of noisy observations, called profiles, to validate whether the process of interest is operating under desired conditions over time. The challenges of a good SPC tool include quick detection of out-of-control (OOC) process and minimizing the probability of false alarms when the process is in-control (IC). The task of a change-point detection (CPD) tool, often used in conjunction with an SPC, is to identify the time-point when the process becomes OOC for the first time. We propose multiple nonparametric methods, including regression trees and random forests, to model the functional relationship of the observed profile with possibly multiple predictors/explanatory variables. We use a Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) statistic of the residuals at current and past time-points as the monitoring statistic. In addition to the first KS based test, we present a method where we smooth this KS statistic with Bayesian Bootstrap. To obtain our third SPC tool, we apply Universal Residuals along with Bayesian hypothesis testing ideas. In the latter SPC tool, we are able to perform a post-hoc analysis and develop credible intervals of the change-point time. We perform extensive simulation studies to assess the performance of our proposed methodologies and compare them among themselves and with other existing methods. For these comparisons, we use two logical performance metrics: average run length (ARL) and false alarm rate (FAR). We also compare these competing methods in terms of their computational costs. We conclude with a summary of their potential applications, advantages, and limitations of our methods. Our plans for future research include improving the Bayesian Bootstrap method using an informative prior, improving the post-hoc analysis of our Universal Residuals method, and further residual based SPC tools using Kullback-Leibler divergence and the Beta Distribution.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Dissecting the Regulators of DNA Replication Timing

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: ASARs, Replication Timing, Transcription

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: During S-phase, the mammalian genome replicates in a defined temporal order called the DNA Replication Timing (RT) program. This program is developmentally regulated and is perturbed in diseased cell states, such as cancers and progeria. In recent years, the field has uncovered multiple layers of regulation of the RT program. These layers of regulation range from genome wide (Rif1), to chromosome wide (ASARs) and domain wide (ERCEs). Transcription is a process in the nucleus that tightly correlates with RT and has been suggested to be yet another way the cell regulates its RT program. Here I used a systematic approach to investigate how ectopic insertions of a series of transcription units in a late replicating domain influences the RT of that domain. Through this work, I show that transcription of a small gene is not sufficient to induce a RT advance. Since the only difference between the transcription units used in this study is the promoter itself, I posit that the local epigenetic environment built around the inserted promoter is critical for the ability of the promoter to induce a RT advance. Additionally, I present evidence that transcriptional activation using an inducible promoter can lead to a controlled RT advance. We also identified and characterized chromosome wide regulators of DNA RT, Asynchronous Replication and Autosomal RNAs (ASARs), across human autosomes. Utilizing the known features of ASARs, we identified 68 transcribed loci across human autosomes as candidate ARARs with allelic expression imbalance and asynchronous RT. Indeed, we discovered that five of these 68 transcribed loci share the characteristics and functionality of ASARs and classified them as novel ASARs. We further decoupled the RT of any particular ASAR allele from the RTs of the other allele, other ASARs on the same chromosome, and RT genome wide. Importantly, we showed that the RT of an ASAR allele was independent of the expression profile of the allele, which indicates that transcription is neither necessary nor sufficient to induce early DNA replication of the ASAR.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Penance and Penitential Intent Within Religious Themed Works of Chaucer

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Canterbury Tales, Chaucer, Criseyde, Penance, Troilus

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The evolution of the concept of penance during the Middle Ages in England reflects the influence of many geopolitical sources, as well as the expanding influence/maturation of the Roman Catholic Church and the development of sacramental rituals during this period. One of these sacraments was codified as a result of the Fourth Lateran Council, which evolved the concept of penitence from an evocation of one’s personal relationship with God into a sacrament presenting the Church as the ultimate authority on the Christian afterlife. Prior to the advent of the Council and its doctrine, penitential writings such as the Soul and Body poems and the dream poetry of the time established penance as largely a personal matter, and the writings were more intended to convince the faithful to take reckoning of their own connections with the divine rather than to enforce penitential doctrine vis-à-vis the Church specifically. As medieval England accepted the Lateran Council’s doctrine and the Christian community began to place more emphasis on concepts such as mandatory Church-based confession and Purgatory, the religious perspective on the afterlife became more nuanced. In adopting a broader perspective on the afterlife, the Church was able to attract more parishioners, which in turn helped to spread the Church’s influence. Given this perceived rise in the importance of penance following the Council, it naturally becomes a topic to be explored in the literature of the period. Perhaps because of his use of the vernacular as well as his placement of classical pagan characters into some texts, Chaucer’s writings are not considered as openly religious as those written by some of his contemporaries; nonetheless, there exists an undercurrent of piety throughout several of his works that merits analysis. The most prominent of these works include Troilus and Criseyde, the Prologue to the Legend of Good Women, and the Canterbury Tales told by the Friar, Pardoner, and Parson. All of these draw attention to the importance of penitence despite their emphasis on classical mythology and then-current social themes. This thread culminates in the Retraction to his Canterbury Tales, which he presents as an apology for the faults found in his complete body of works and as a personal plea for the grace of both God and his audience. Through his use of the Retraction and apologies, Chaucer brought religious and penitential themes to the attention of his largely secular court audience. In turn, because he wrote for the courtiers and not for the Church or a specifically religious patronage, he was provided a forum from which to point out the flaws he found apparent in aspects of the Church and its representatives while still incorporating Christian penitential messages in his writings.Coinciding with his discussions of penance, also notable within Chaucer’s works is the fact that he presents personal intent or “entente” as a theme within his writings. This concept appears within several of the Canterbury Tales, most notably those told by the Pardoner and Friar, but is also referenced in Troilus’s prayers to the God of Love and in Chaucer’s defense of his writings in the prologue to the Legend of Good Women. Given the myriad interpretations of his works, his use of these concepts invites the question of his regard for the import of penitential intent and contrition. This becomes especially important in that it reflects on the Retraction to his Canterbury Tales, wherein he rescinds nearly all of his most famous literary works ostensibly in the name of repentance for having created them. It is possible to interpret the Retraction in multiple different ways as well, from a genuine plea for forgiveness in the face of death to a way to promote himself or escape criticism by the Church. This is indicative of the larger issue surrounding the interplay between Chaucer’s notions of intent and his treatment of penance. When viewed in this light, the Retraction becomes a tool used to draw focus to Chaucer’s true intent in constructing his texts. The goal of this examination is to consider Chaucer’s use and discussion of penitential concepts to argue that he presents a thematic progression regarding representations of penance between Troilus and Criseyde, the Prologue to the Legend of Good Women, and the Canterbury Tales, moving from what may be described as a more personal, albeit playful, take on the concept in Troilus to more institutionalized interpretations in the Legend’s Prologue, the Canterbury Tales, and its accompanying Retraction. This exploration of penitential history resembles the evolution of penitential concepts across the whole of the medieval period.

DISS_description.DISS_title: REDUCING STRESS IN LEISURE TRAVELERS THROUGH THE USE OF BIOPHILIC DESIGN ELEMENTS TO ENHANCE THE SENSE OF ARRIVAL IN HOTEL LOBBY INTERIOR DESIGN

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Biophilia, Design, Hotel Lobby, Sense of Arrival, Travel, Well-being

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: The objective of this study was to gain knowledge as to the impact of the use of light, materiality, and access to nature in reducing stress in hotel lobbies. This topic rose to importance with the rise of the pandemic of 2020 as safety precautions began to change and people stopped traveling completely. In order for hotels to regain business, they would have to rethink their design to accommodate people’s stress levels, as they have become hyper aware of their interior surroundings having been stuck in their homes for long period of time. With little research president on this topic area, this study sought to gain knowledge from a review of literature and original research on which biophilic design elements are most effective in reducing stress levels of parents traveling with young children to child friendly, resort style hotels. The elements studied were materiality, light, and access to nature. This study examined three hotels of varying affordability in the Orlando, Florida area and the researcher chose to examine three high traffic zones of the lobby including the entry, seating, and check-in desks. After using a snowball sampling technique to reach a sample size of fifty participants, the researcher came to the conclusion that of the three biophilic design elements, access to nature was most effective in reducing feelings of anxiety in high traffic zones of resort style hotel lobbies. A virtual survey helped the researcher come to these conclusions as well as hotel lobby observations and cataloging images and behaviors.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Effect of Shared Book Reading and Video Viewing on Preschool Children's Vocabulary and Knowledge Acquisition in Informational Text

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: An experimental study was conducted to examine the effects of shared book reading and video viewing on preschoolers' vocabulary and knowledge acquisition in informational text. The study included 60 preschool children who were randomly assigned to three experimental groups —shared book reading group, video viewing group, and shared book reading plus video viewing group. The content in the book and the video clip was equivalent, since the book was an exact transcript of the video, meaning children received the same information content and similar visual images in both media. What was varied was that the images in the print version were static while in the video were animated with music, which represented the distinct differences between the two media. Baseline vocabulary and knowledge measures about the content of the book/video were administered to all children prior to the experiment. After the pretests, children in the shared book reading group were read aloud the book twice, children in the video viewing group watched the video clip twice, and children in the shared book reading plus video viewing group were read aloud the book once and then watched the video once. Thereafter, children's vocabulary and knowledge acquisition were assessed. The Simple Slopes Analysis revealed statistically significant differences between the groups on the dependent variables of vocabulary and knowledge, controlling for the pretest scores, TOPEL, age, gender, race, and socioeconomic status (SES). In terms of vocabulary acquisition, the results demonstrated that there were significant differences between the shared book reading and two-media groups, and between the shared book reading group and the video viewing group when children’s scores were one standard deviation below the mean, with better outcomes for children in the two-media and video viewing groups. Also, there was a significant difference between the shared book reading group and video viewing group when children’s pretest scores were at the mean, with better outcomes for children in the video viewing group. As for knowledge acquisition, there were significant differences between the shared book reading group and video viewing group, as well as between the two-media group and the video viewing group when children’s pretest scores were one standard deviation above the mean, with better outcomes for children in the video viewing group. Cross-classified generalized random-effects (CCGRE) models were used to explore the extent to which the repetition frequencies and difficulty levels of the words influenced vocabulary acquisition. After controlling the pretest scores, both word repetition frequency and difficulty level explained the variance on vocabulary acquisition, with difficulty level explaining more variance than repetition frequency. The discussion of the findings and null findings is followed by limitations and suggestions for future research.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ECOLOGICAL ASSEMBLAGES: CHRISTIAN ANIMISM, INDIGENOUS INGENUITY, AND MORAL BRICOLAGE

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation aims to present a more compelling and transformative religious-moral framework for environmental behavior. It specifically seeks to offer alternatives to prevalent Anglo-European, Christian approaches such as dominion, stewardship, and theocentric models, which view nonhuman nature primarily as resources to be controlled, conquered, or utilized for the benefit of humanity’s material or spiritual well-being. These frameworks fall short in fostering a truly transformative shift in our relationship with the environment. To achieve this, it a new religious-moral framework that recognizes the intrinsic value of nature and considers nonhumans as ends in themselves is required.One promising approach that comes close to such a model is known as “Christian animism.” Christian animism endeavors to establish a fundamental connection or compatibility between Christianity and Animism, aiming to guide Christians towards more environmentally conscious behavior and worldviews. However, existing scholarly work on Christian animism primarily focuses on constructing theological justifications for adopting this framework, often overlooking the longstanding incorporation of Christian and Animist worldviews among various indigenous groups in North America. To address this oversight, my manuscript examines how American Indian movements have merged their traditional Animist cosmologies with Christian worldviews as a means of adapting to changing socio-political contexts during the era of colonization. Emphasizing the ecological implications of this adaptive strategy, I align decolonization efforts with the creation of new frameworks for environmental conduct in a time of escalating climate crises. By recognizing the historically marginalized indigenous teachings, practices, and ecological wisdom as legitimate and potentially superior, this research challenges the colonizing “rational” Anglo-European understandings of nature that have arguably contributed to significant global environmental damage. Employing historical, ethnographic, and textual research methods, I demonstrate how the religious and ecological assemblages of American Indians can enrich and inform the development of Christian animism. In return, I argue that when appropriately contextualized and guided by decolonial methods and objectives, Christian animism can reciprocally contribute to the spiritual and political aspirations of contemporary American Indian environmentalism.

DISS_description.DISS_title: MENTAL HEALTH IN SCHOOLS: A QUALITATIVE IMPLMENTATION CASE-STUDY OF A MULTI-TIERED EVIDENCE-BASED MENTAL HEALTH PLAN IN A SMALL RURAL SCHOOL DISTRICT

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Mental illness is an epidemic sweeping the nation and, more specifically, the world of education (Salerno, 2016). According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] (2020b), approximately 4.4 million children 3-17 years old in the United States have been diagnosed with anxiety, and approximately 1.9 million diagnosed with depression. Roughly half of the children nationwide have experienced at least one traumatic event in their life (Sacks & Murphy, 2018). For these and other reasons, Schmidt et al. (2015) asserted that mental health and suicide prevention are paramount concerns for schools and districts. Small rural districts and schools struggle with employing and contracting qualified school- and community-based mental health providers. This qualitative implementation case study examined how small rural school and district staff members understand and prioritize the components of an evidence-based mental health program within a multi-tiered framework being implemented, and sought to better understand how school administrators, teachers, and mental health providers perceived strengths and weaknesses of the interventions associated with this program.Eleven participants made up of teachers, administrators, and district- and school-based mental health providers were selected from an elementary, middle, and high school. After analyzing the district mental health plan and semi-structured interviews, the findings displayed evidence that Suncoast County district staff somewhat to fully understood the components of the plan being implemented. Six themes were extrapolated from participant responses related to strengths and barriers of the implementation of an evidence-based, multi-tiered mental health program.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Isotopic niche overlap among foraging marine turtle species in the Gulf of Mexico

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: foraging ecology, marine turtles, niche overlap, stable isotope, sulfur isotope, sympatric species

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Sympatric species may overlap in their use of spatial and trophic resources, which can increase the risk of competition. Comparing the ecological niches and quantifying the degree of niche overlap among these species can provide insights into the extent of resource overlap. This information can be used to guide multispecies management approaches tailored to protect priority habitats that offer the most resources for species. Stable isotope analysis is a valuable tool used to investigate spatial and trophic niches, though few studies have employed this method for comparisons among sympatric marine turtle species. For this study, δ13C, δ15N, and δ34S values from epidermis tissue were used to quantify overlap and compare isotopic niches in loggerhead (Caretta caretta), green (Chelonia mydas), and Kemp’s ridley (Lepidochelys kempii) turtles sampled from a shared foraging area located offshore of Crystal River, Florida, USA. Overall, the results revealed high degrees of isotopic overlap (>68%) among species, particularly between loggerhead and Kemp’s ridley turtles (85 to 91%), which indicates there may be interspecific competition for resources. Samples from green turtles had the widest range of isotopic values, indicating they exhibit higher variability in diet and habitat type. Samples from loggerhead turtles had the most enriched mean δ34S, suggesting they may forage in slightly different micro-environments compared to the other species. Finally, samples from Kemp’s ridley turtles exhibited the smallest niche size, which is indicative of a more specialized diet. This is one of the first studies to investigate resource use in a multispecies foraging aggregation of marine turtles using three isotopic tracers. These findings provide a foundation for future research into the foraging ecology of sympatric marine turtle species and can be used to inform effective multispecies management efforts.

DISS_description.DISS_title: SOLVING CLUSTERING PROBLEMS USING RIEMANNIAN OPTIMIZATION

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation considers the optimization problems that are in the form of minX∈Fv f(x)+λ∥X∥1, where f is smooth, Fv = {X ∈ Rn×q : XTX = Iq,v ∈ span(X)}, and v is a given positive vector. Clustering analysis is a fundamental machine learning problem with broad-ranging applications. Its aim is to group unlabelled data objects into clusters according to a certain similarity measure such that objects within each cluster are more similar to each other than to objects of another cluster. Several clustering problems can be formulated as such optimization problems, such as community detection, k-means clustering, discriminative k-means clustering, and normalized cuts. In this dissertation, three Riemannian optimization approaches for the clustering problems in terms of assignment matrix are proposed, which are ARPPG, AManPG, and Inexact_AManPG. It is proven that the domain Fv forms a compact embedded submanifold of Rn×q and optimization-related tools are derived. Global convergence analysis for Inexact_AManPG is then established. Numerical experiments on clustering problems including community detection, k-means, discriminative k- means, and normalized cut for image segmentation are used to demonstrate the performance of the proposed optimization approaches. ARPPG, AManPG, and Inexact_AManPG algorithms as with many other projection and dimension reduction methods, can have difficulties with time and space complexity when the number of clusters is not reliably known or too large. To address this limitation, we also propose a recursive version of Inexact_AManPG algorithm.

DISS_description.DISS_title: The Making of Black Scientists

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Black Identity, Ethnography, Identity Development, In Vivo Coding, Positional Identity, Scientific Identity

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: There is a dominant Discourse that juxtaposes science and Black cultures. This Discourse limits who can be a scientist and creates a racist, seemingly-objective landscape in which Black individuals must persevere. This study examines a Black-centered informal learning space and its STEM tasks, termed FUBU Camp and FUBU STEM, to understand how Black learners perceive their developing racial, scientific, and positional identities with the research question, “How do the Black learners participating in FUBU informal settings approach and make sense of their racial, scientific, and positional identities through experiences as participants within the informal FUBU STEM setting?” I used the factor model of multiracial identity (Wijeyesinghe 2001; Wijeyesinghe & Jackson, 2012), STEM identity development frameworks (Carlone & Johnson, 2007; Hughes et al., 2020), and a positionality framework (Mensah, 2016) to analyze research participants’ voice stories about their experiences in FUBU STEM. In vivo and emotion coding was used to analyze research participants' accounts to create overarching stories of how they approached and made sense of their identities. Results indicate that research participants had various ways of leveraging positional and racial identities in FUBU STEM engagements in ways that helped them see themselves as Black scientists. Findings suggest that current science education conceptualizations of rigorous scientific tasks limit opportunities for Black learners to see themselves in science. Through identity-building tasks, research participants in this study saw expanded terms that incorporated other identities.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Intergenerational Perfectionism: Mechanisms and Treatment

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Anxiety, Depression, Parenting, Perfectionism

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Internalizing disorders are a broad category of psychopathology in children characterized by children’s reactions to stress that occur within the self, such as emotional distress related to feelings of anxiety and depression. Perfectionism, which is defined as high standards of performance which are accompanied by tendencies for overly critical evaluation of one’s own behavior, is a well-defined risk factor for internalizing psychopathology in children and across the lifespan. Despite this risk, there is currently a lack of efficacious treatment options targeting perfectionism in children. Therefore, more research is needed to both a) understand maintaining mechanisms of perfectionism in children, and b) continue the development and investigation of treatments targeting those factors. Chapter 2 describes the development and evaluation of a measure of a novel construct hypothesized to be relevant to the development of perfectionism in children, parent sensitivity to children’s errors, described as the extent to which parents are distressed by their children’s mistakes. Exploratory factor analysis revealed a stable 3-factor structure consisting of Checking Behaviors, Evaluative Worry, and Emotional Investment. Total and individual factor scores demonstrated good internal reliability and associations with relevant constructs. Mediation models demonstrated that parent sensitivity to child errors predicted overprotective parenting behaviors, which in turn predicted child anxiety symptoms. These data demonstrate that parent sensitivity to child errors may be one important factor that can contribute to parenting behaviors that increase risk for perfectionism and associated psychopathology in children. In Chapter 3, I developed and evaluated the efficacy of a novel intervention targeting perfectionism in children. This intervention consisted of a single, virtual study visit in which both parents and children were encouraged to decrease certain behaviors related to perfectionism in children. There were no group differences on primary outcomes of perfectionism or related internalizing symptoms. However, post-hoc analyses suggested that parents and children in the control group decreased perfectionism-related behaviors, and that these behavior reductions predicted decreases in perfectionism and internalizing symptoms regardless of group assignment. Overall, these data suggest that parents and children are able to decrease perfectionism-related behaviors following a single study visit, and that reductions in these behaviors can be an effective approach for treating perfectionism and related internalizing symptoms.

DISS_description.DISS_title: ETHNIC IDENTITY, SELF-EFFICACY, ACADEMIC ADJUSTMENT, AND ANXIETY SYMPTOMS IN LATINX UNDERGRADUATES

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Academic Adjustment, Anxiety, Ethnic Identity, Mediation, Self-Efficacy

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Objectives: The Latinx population is one of the fastest growing minority groups in the United States, with a current population of around 60 million people, they make up roughly 18% of the US population. The current study examined the relationship between ethnic identity, self-efficacy, academic adjustment, and anxiety symptoms in Latinx undergraduates.

Methods: Sample consisted of 155 participants (Mage = 20.4, SD = 1.67; 72.7% female). Ethical approval was granted by Florida State University Institutional Review Board (IRB) (Study ID: STUDY00003509). Participants completed an online Qualtrics questionnaire available to eligible students using FSU’s secure network (Qualtrics Software, 2021). Completion of the survey questionnaire took approximately 35-40 minutes.

Results: No domains of ethnic identity (exploration, resolution, affirmation) were correlated with symptoms of general anxiety (r = .010, p > .05; r = .036, p > .05; r = -.135, p > .05) respectively. Results found college self-efficacy significantly mediates the effect of ethnic identity-exploration on academic adjustment with an estimated standardized indirect effect ab = 0.11, 95th percentile bootstrap CI [.05, .11]; p<.01, and standardized direct effect c = .125 , 95th percentile bootstrap CI [-.04; .281]; p>.05).

Conclusion: As the Latinx college population continues to increase, researchers in this area of development must pay close attention to all aspects of the college environment that may influence Latinx outcomes. Ethnic identity, college self-efficacy, and academic adjustment were all shown to positively correlate with one another, emphasizing the need to continue research on how higher levels of ethnic identity may promote successful academic adjustment

DISS_description.DISS_title: NOVEL METHODS IN TRANSCRIPTOME-WIDE ASSOCIATION STUDY

DISS_categorization.DISS_keyword: Statistical Genetics, Transcriptome-wide association studies

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: Genes with moderate to low expression heritability may explain a large proportion of complex trait etiology, but such genes cannot be sufficiently captured in conventional transcriptome-wide association studies (TWASs), partly due to the relatively small available reference datasets for developing expression genetic prediction models to capture the moderate to low genetically regulated components of gene expression. In the first chapter, we introduce a method, the Summary-level Unified Method for Modeling Integrated Transcriptome (SUMMIT), to improve the expression prediction model accuracy and the power of TWAS by using a large expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) summary-level dataset. We apply SUMMIT to the eQTL summary-level data provided by the eQTLGen consortium. Through simulation studies and analyses of genome-wide association study summary statistics for 24 complex traits, we show that SUMMIT improves the accuracy of expression prediction in blood, successfully builds expression prediction models for genes with low expression heritability, and achieves higher statistical power than several benchmark methods. Finally, we conduct a case study of COVID-19 severity with SUMMIT and identify 11 likely causal genes associated with COVID-19 severity.

In the second chapter, we introduce a method, Comprehensive omics-phenotype association estimation using \textit{Cis-} and \textit{Trans-}regulated elements (ComPACT), to integrate genetic information from \textit{trans-}loci into classic association studies, by iteratively detect potential outlying locus. Like SUMMIT, ComPACT is also capable of utilizing summary-level data to construct imputation models. However, as an extension of SUMMIT, ComPACT do not require individual-level genotype data to do model tuning. We apply ComPACT to the deCODE summary-level data and construct 233\% more imputation models than the existing method. In addition, we verify that the selected models were statistically robust by validation using an external dataset, INTERVAL, and show that our pipeline had achieved similar prediction accuracy to using individual-level data. Finally, we conduct a case study of Alzheimer's disease and identify 207 likely causal proteins, whereas competing method identify 19 likely causal proteins.

DISS_description.DISS_title: Mathematical Study on the Expressive Power of Machine Learning and Applications in Optimal Filtering Problems

DISS_abstract.DISS_para: This dissertation investigates the practical expressive power of machine learning models as general function approximators and their practical applications in optimal filtering problems. The practical expressive power of these models depends on the choice of \textit{model structure} (deep or shallow), which sets the upper limit of expressive power, and the \textit{trainability} of the model, which enables the realization of the expressive power in practical applications, such as regression and classification. Our primary objective is to enhance the practical expressive power and overall performance of neural networks (NNs) by improving their trainability. In addition to traditional machine learning tasks, we specifically focus on the optimal filtering problem, which holds significant importance in science and engineering. When addressing the representation of filtering density in optimal filtering problems, we adopt a similar rationale for practical expressive power by considering the \textit{model structure}, which determines the theoretical capacity for storing probability distributions, and the \textit{trainability}, which determines the optimization cost for utilizing the expressive power of the model to approximate the filtering density. By carefully balancing these two factors, our aim is to enhance the overall performance of optimal filtering problems.

The first part of the dissertation focuses on enhancing the practical expressive power of neural networks by improving their trainability. To achieve this, we first introduce the concept of the general activation transform (GAT) as a generalization of the traditional elementwise activation function in the function space. The GAT can be derived from the general deep neural networks (GDNNs) framework, in which the affine transformations in traditional deep neural networks (DNNs) are replaced with integral transforms, with a finite-rank parameterization of the weight integral kernels. The GAT maps the input vector into the function space by treating the input vector as coefficients of the input basis function, performing activation on the state function, and generating the output through integration with the output basis function. We specifically focus on GAT-ReLU, a variant of GAT with ReLU activation, which exhibits enriched activation patterns and smoother solutions compared to traditional ReLU activation. By selecting proper basis functions (continuous and high-variation), GAT-ReLU enhances the practical expressive power of the model, which is demonstrated by many numerical experiments. Apart from GAT, we introduce transferable neural networks (TransNet) for solving partial differential equations (PDEs) by reducing the optimization difficulty through the idea of transfer learning. The construction of transferable neural feature spaces involves re-parameterization of hidden neurons and auxiliary functions. Theoretical analysis validates the high quality of the resulting feature space, characterized by uniformly distributed neurons. Extensive numerical experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and improved transferability of our proposed method across different PDEs.

The second part of this dissertation concentrates on addressing the optimal filtering problem by different choices of representations for filtering density. This involves considering the model's theoretical capacity for representing probability distributions and the associated optimization cost for approximating the distributions. By carefully balancing these factors, we aim to develop effective approaches for solving the optimal filtering problem. We first introduce an adaptive kernel method that utilizes a Gaussian mixture model (GMM) to represent the probability density function (PDF) within the Bayesian framework. The state dynamics are formulated using the Fokker-Planck equation, and the PDE operator is decomposed into linear and nonlinear parts. The linear part is analytically incorporated into the GMM model, while the nonlinear part is approximated using an adaptive kernel algorithm. Bayesian inference is applied to each Gaussian component in the GMM to incorporate observational data. We also provide many numerical examples to validate the performance of the GMM representation in solving nonlinear filtering problem. In addition, We also explore the use of score-based models for solving optimal filtering problems, where the score function (gradient of the logarithm of the PDF) plays a central role in representing the filtering density. We train score-based generative models to approximate samples from the prior distribution, and by combining the learned score functions of the prior and likelihood, we can directly generate samples from the posterior distribution. Score-based models leverage the high capacity of deep neural networks (DNNs) to effectively capture non-Gaussian and high-dimensional distributions. Our numerical experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach, showcasing its ability to handle high-dimensional (up to 100 dimensions) and highly nonlinear filtering problems effectively.
